From geoffw@nexsys.net Sat Apr  2 11:31:18 1994
Return-Path: <geoffw@nexsys.net>
Date: Sat, 2 Apr 1994 11:26:12 -0800
From: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White)
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Raving and sexualove (oh my!)
Content-Length: 2177
X-Lines: 54
Status: RO



	It seems that this subject has never really been explored
	here on sfraves but I think if there ever was a place to talk
	about raving and sex/love this would be it.  First a few qualifiers,
	I'm using the term sexualove to try to be a little more accurate
	and to also side step some flames.  Sexualove is that special energy
	that you feel for (an)other(s) that would or could reach expression
	in a physical (sexual) way.  It doesn't mean that you have to actually
	"have sex" (but it could) but it is a "deeper" feeling then just the
	"platonic" emotions that have readily been shared.

	My questions are:

	1) How has your sex/love life, capacity, expression, etc. changed
	since you have been raving?

	2) For people who are single, do you find it easier or harder to get
	into a sexualove relationship now that you are a raver?

	3) For people in committed relationships, how has raving changed your
	sexualove cycles/behavior?

	4) Is making love to another raver "different" than making love to
	a "non-raver"?

	5) Does the Eros that is generated at some parties (like a Wicked)
	excite you or is it a turn off?

	6) Since you have become a raver, do you think that you are more or less
	open to exploring other sexualove lifestyles then the one you are
	currently practicing?

	7) Do you think ravers are more tolerant of other people's sexualove
	preferences?

	8) If you are at a party and the music is _really_ goin-off and
	a friend comes up to you (that you've wanted for sometime, I
	might add) and wants you to go with them to the chill-out room
	(obviously to make- out); do you go with them or do you stay on the
	dance-floor?

	9) For those of you who trance, how has this affected your sexualove
	life?  Do you enter trance states more easily while making love?  Does
	it get in the way of meeting perspective partners at a party (as in
	you look pretty funny with your eyes crossed :)

	10) How many of you now (or have) made love to music (house or
	otherwise) and how has this experience affected you?


I know some of these questions are pretty intimate, you can use some 
anonymous mailers to reply, if you don't want anyone to know who you are.

There was a great piece in Doonsbury recently about the hyper-sensitive frat 
boy (or the "Greco-American Cultural Association Member") who was so offended 
that he didn't get an A that he sued the school. He used all this colorful
left wing politically correct jargon to describe the trauma he was being put
through by the evil teacher who gave him a B because he blew off the final exam.
So all you mean people who are going to say something nasty about those poor
Frat Boys, go read Doonsbury and raise your social consciousness first, and
don't flame people just because they're stereotyped as stupid beer guzzling 
misogynistic homophobic jerks, since they were probably born that way, 
inheriting it from their parents. Try to have some compassion for their
situation: when you rebel against parents like that, they stop paying your
credit card bill, and that really hurts where it counts. 

        -Don

I just wanted to tell you all that of course all campuses are different, 
and there are a couple of fraternities that I would like to highlight (in 
a round-a-bout way). There are fraternities that aren't beer chugging 
festivals year round, but actually forbid drinking. 

Alpha Gamma Omega is a Christian fraternity (I understand that 
this is a touchy subject here on SFR, but keep flames to your 
fireplace.) There also is Epsilon Sigma Rho that will hold 
members accountable to not drinking/doing drugs if you first 
say right off that it's against your religion (or whatever). I like this 
very much; I mean if it's going to be around and if you don't want to do it 
(whatever that is) then it's good to have someone "on your side."

Of course, the common thing to say is, who cares? Well, I do. And that is 
my soapbox for the day.

Mike	<masolis@hamlet.ucdavis.edu>
	<hula@deeptht.armory.com>

From sfraves-owner  Sun May  1 19:33:13 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA03730; Sun, 1 May 94 19:33:13 PDT
Received: from crl.crl.com (crl.com) by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA03723; Sun, 1 May 94 19:33:06 PDT
Received: by crl.crl.com id AA19715
  (5.65c/IDA-1.5 for sfraves@techno.stanford.edu); Sun, 1 May 1994 19:31:54 -0700
From: Bryce Ryan <brycer@crl.com>
Message-Id: <199405020231.AA19715@crl.crl.com>
Subject: Rave, Community, and Money [LONG]
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Sun, 1 May 1994 19:31:54 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 6867      
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Greetings, ravers!  This is a long, and somewhat philosophical post.
You may wish to save this, and read it at your leisure.

I've been involved with organizing raves since last September (actually,
earlier if you count all the planning for that first Fluid Groove--which
started in July (!) ), and helping out with quite a lot of events in
one capacity or another since that time, too.  One of the questions
that has recently been asked of me (in the context of Liquid Air) is:
why not charge money or have a donation basket at your parties.  This
question led me into a long explanation of my philosophy and beliefs.
That thread led me to post this message, share these beliefs with you,
and, hopefully, engender some discussion about these issues.

My subject line is "Rave, Community, and Money" because I want
to open a discussion with you all about the role of money in our real
and virtual community of SFRaves.  

I strongly believe that community (intentional, virtual, and physical) is
based on the desire of its participants to be with each other, to share
themselves, to work toward common goals in ways that could *not* be
accomplished by individuals.  It is also my utopian idea that people
engage in activities together because they want to, and not for immediate
material gain.  Any gain that is achieved is shared _by the community_,
not by one or more individuals.  This is not to say that each person
participating in the community may not gain from a shared project...far
from it.  However, I cannot support the idea of one individual benefitting
substantially more than other individuals from the efforts of the community.
From their own efforts, yes.  From community projects, no.

I believe that raves *are* a community project.  I have never regarded any
liquid air as "my" party.  Sometimes, as a figure of speech, and for the
sake of easy communications, i or others use that phrase.  But, I don't
believe it for one second.  I've always approached these things as a
community effort, and my role was to act as the organizer, to help people
coordinate their activities and schedules so that we could be together
in one place, at one time, with the essential tools of our community
at hand: a space, a sound system, DJs, and smiles.  the "rave" is what
*we* make of it, what we add to it, what we give and receive.  consequently,
i believe that each person who participates in a community project, like
a rave, adds something to it.  the dancers add something. the lurkers
add something. the security people (if present) add something. the 
money takers (if present) add something. i further believe that each
participant's contribution is valuable.

i am as egalitarian as i can possibly be.  i believe in equality and a
fundamental recognition of the worth of each individual.  *this* is what
engendered my rather rabid posts last year about "DJ Worship".  DJs are,
for the most part, nice folks, with a great skill.  however, i do not
value this more than the skill of a dancer, or other rave participants.

so, valuing egalitarianism as i do, i fail to see how i can support some
people paying money to others for something they do together, each with
an equal skill in their field. and other people taking what's left (the
profit) for their own use. i fail to see why some people get in free to
parties, while others pay, and still others get paid.  the party wouldn't
happen without everyone, so why shouldn't everyone share the risks and
rewards?

i should take a moment and say that this post occurs only in the context
of raves. i am *not* addressing the larger socio-politico-economic world.
just the issues of this community. it is also the case that i've paid my
money at any number of raves and rave-like events, gotten in free at others,
and even been paid once or twice.

having seen my share of events from both sides of the decks, from both
sides of the cash drawer, i *know* that things cost money.  and that
commitments are made.  and that some spaces cost astronomical amounts
of money to rent.  my question is:  why assume that burden if the
community will is not there?  it seems to me that when a payer/payee
relationship is established, the event is no longer a community project;
rather, entertainment or a consumable. 

if i enter into a consumer relationship, then, as a wise consumer, and
only consume the highest quality i can get for my money...i'm constantly
looking for the most "bang for the buck".  if i am present to be entertained,
then i am also looking for the highest level of quality.  and, i am 
establishing a me/you relationship....*you* entertain *me*.  this is
philosophically no different than buying a newspaper or food. it also
means that i, as a consumer, can take it or leave it.

a community project, on the other hand, is a "we" relationship. *we* do
something for each other and for the larger communities we live in. *we*
do it because we can, and because we want to. *we* assume no greater
burden than we (as individuals) can bear.  and yet, though each individual
contributes as they can, the resulting synergy of a well-coordinated,
consensus driven project, is just amazing.  i have seen and participated
in gatherings of 5,000 people or more that had no fee at the door (because
there wasn't a door), where everyone was fed and housed and cared for.
all you had to do to participate was to get yourself there...which could
be done in as much or as little luxury as you pleased.  one could be taken
care of, or take care of others. one could speak, or not. one could dance,
or not.  these gatherings (of varying sizes) were real turning points in
my concept of community, and form the basis of the beliefs i have
expounded above.  these are not silly concepts...these are real beliefs
that really work in the real world.

personally, i want to do community projects. i believe it is possible to
do community-oriented raves on a grand scale, but only if everyone in the
community *wants* to participate.  i believe that community events require
the informed consent of everyone, with willing participation in the often
tumultuous process of organizing and executing the event. and, i believe
that a community-oriented rave can be done without charging money at the
door, without establishing any consumer relationship.  what *is* required
to do such things is commitment and ingenuity...which i believe this group
has in abundance.

so, the short answer to the questions i've been asked about money and
Liquid Airs is:  i don't believe in it.  the money and time i spend in
organizing these things is willingly and freely donated to the community,
just as your participation, time, and money spent in attending is willingly
and freely donated to the community.
-- 
Bryce Ryan ------- AMBIANCE ----------- brycer@crl.com-----
======================================= NEW ADDRESS =======

Just for fun...

   ______________________________________________________________
   Attached is some correspondence which actually occurred between a
   London hotel's staff and one of its guests.  The London hotel
   involved submitted this to the Sunday Times.  No name was mentioned.
  
 
      WHAT TO DO WITH ALL THOSE "FREE" SOAPS WHEN TRAVELLING
      ******************************************************
  
   Dear Maid,
   Please do not leave any more of those little bars of soap in my
   bathroom since I have brought my own bath-sized Dial.  Please remove
   the six unopened little bars from the shelf under the medicine chest
   and another three in the shower soap dish.  They are in my way.
   Thank you,
                                            S. Berman
  
   ----------------------------------------------------------------------
  
   Dear Room 635,
   I am not your regular maid.  She will be back tomorrow, Thursday, from
   her day off.  I took the 3 hotel soaps out of the shower soap dish as
   you requested.  The 6 bars on your shelf I took out of your way and
   put on top of your Kleenex dispenser in case you should change your
   mind.  This leaves only the 3 bars I left today which my instructions
   from the management is to leave 3 soaps daily.
   I hope this is satisfactory.
					    Kathy
 					    Relief Maid

   ----------------------------------------------------------------------
  
   Dear Maid -- I hope you are my regular maid.
   Apparently Kathy did not tell you about my note to her concerning the
   little bars of soap.  When I got back to my room this evening I found
   you had added 3 little Camays to the shelf under my medicine cabinet.
   I am going to be here in the hotel for two weeks and have brought my
   own bath-size Dial so I won't need those 6 little Camays which are on
   the shelf.  They are in my way when shaving, brushing teeth, etc.
   Please remove them.
                                            S. Berman
  
   ----------------------------------------------------------------------
  
   Dear Mr. Berman,
   My day off was last Wed. so the relief maid left 3 hotel soaps which
   we are instructed by the management.  I took the 6 soaps which were in
   your way on the shelf and put them in the soap dish where your Dial
   was.  I put the Dial in the medicine cabinet for your convenience.
   I didn't remove the 3 complimentary soaps which are always placed
   inside the medicine cabinet for all new check-ins and which you did
   not object to when you checked in last Monday.  Please let me
   know if I can of further assistance.
                                            Your regular maid,
                                            Dotty
  
   ----------------------------------------------------------------------
  
   Dear Mr. Berman,
   The assistant manager, Mr. Kensedder, informed me this A.M. that you
   called him last evening and said you were unhappy with your maid
   service.  I have assigned a new girl to your room.  I hope you will
   accept my apologies for any past inconvenience.  If you have any
   future complaints please contact me so I can give it my personal
   attention. Call extension 1108 between 8AM and 5PM.  Thank you.
                                            Elaine Carmen
                                            Housekeeper
  
   ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 
   Dear Miss Carmen,
   It is impossible to contact you by phone since I leave the hotel for
   business at 745 AM and don't get back before 530 or 6PM.  That's the
   reason I called Mr. Kensedder last night.  You were already off duty.
   I only asked Mr. Kensedder if he could do anything about those little
   bars of soap.  The new maid you assigned me must have thought I was a
   new check-in today, since she left another 3 bars of hotel soap in my
   medicine cabinet along with her regular delivery of 3 bars on the
   bath-room shelf.  In just 5 days here I have accumulated 24 little
   bars of soap.  Why are you doing this to me?
                                            S. Berman
  
  ----------------------------------------------------------------------
  
   Dear Mr. Berman,
   Your maid, Kathy, has been instructed to stop delivering soap to your
   room and remove the extra soaps.  If I can be of further assistance,
   please call extension 1108 between 8AM and 5PM.  Thank you,
                                            Elaine Carmen,
                                            Housekeeper
  
   ----------------------------------------------------------------------
   
   Dear Mr. Kensedder,
   My bath-size Dial is missing.  Every bar of soap was taken from my
   room including my own bath-size Dial.  I came in late last night and
   had to call the bellhop to bring me 4 little Cashmere Bouquets.
                                            S. Berman
  
   ----------------------------------------------------------------------
  
   Dear Mr. Berman,
   I have informed our housekeeper, Elaine Carmen, of your soap problem.
   I cannot understand why there was no soap in your room since our maids
   are instructed to leave 3 bars of soap each time they service a room.
   The situation will be rectified immediately.  Please accept my
   apologies for the inconvenience.
                                            Martin L. Kensedder
                                            Assistant Manager
  
   ----------------------------------------------------------------------
  
   Dear Mrs. Carmen,
   Who the hell left 54 little bars of Camay in my room?  I came in last
   night and found 54 little bars of soap.  I don't want 54 little bars
   of Camay.  I want my one damn bar of bath-size Dial.  Do you realize I
   have 54 bars of soap in here.  All I want is my bath size Dial.
   Please give me back my bath-size Dial.
                                            S. Berman
  
   ----------------------------------------------------------------------
  
   Dear Mr. Berman,
   You complained of too much soap in your room so I had them removed.
   Then you complained to Mr. Kensedder that all your soap was missing so
   I personally returned them.  The 24 Camays which had been taken and
   the 3 Camays you are supposed to receive daily (sic).  I don't know
   anything about the 4 Cashmere Bouquets.  Obviously your maid, Kathy,
   did not know I had returned your soaps so she also brought 24 Camays
   plus the 3 daily Camays.  I don't know where you got the idea this
   hotel issues bath-size Dial.  I was able to locate some bath-size
   Ivory which I left in your room.
                                            Elaine Carmen
                                            Housekeeper
  
   ----------------------------------------------------------------------
  
   Dear Mrs. Carmen,
   Just a short note to bring you up-to-date on my latest soap inventory.
   As of today I possess:
  
   - On shelf under medicine cabinet - 18 Camay in 4 stacks of
     4 and 1 stack of 2.
   - On Kleenex dispenser - 11 Camay in 2 stacks of 4 and 1
     stack of 3.
   - On bedroom dresser - 1 stack of 3 Cashmere Bouquet, 1
     stack of 4 hotel-size Ivory, and 8 Camay in 2 stacks of 4.
   - Inside medicine cabinet - 14 Camay in 3 stacks of 4 and 1
     stack of 2.
   - In shower soap dish - 6 Camay, very moist.
   - On northeast corner of tub - 1 Cashmere Bouquet, slightly used.
   - On northwest corner of tub - 6 Camays in 2 stacks of 3.
  
   Please ask Kathy when she services my room to make sure the stacks are
   neatly piled and dusted.  Also, please advise her that stacks of more
   than 4 have a tendency to tip.  May I suggest that my bedroom window
   sill is not in use and will make an excellent spot for future soap
   deliveries. One more item, I have purchased another bar of bath-sized
   Dial which I am keeping in the hotel vault in order to avoid further
   misunderstandings.
                                              S. Berman
 
 
Take care,

From sfraves-owner  Mon May  2 11:23:04 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA15224; Mon, 2 May 94 11:23:04 PDT
Received: from ns.PacBell.COM by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA15015; Mon, 2 May 94 11:05:05 PDT
Received: from srv.PacBell.COM (mother.srv.PacBell.COM) by ns.PacBell.COM (4.1/PacBell-04/19/94)
	id AA23871; Mon, 2 May 94 11:05:09 PDT
Received: from pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM by srv.PacBell.COM (4.1/SMI-4.0)
	id AA02214; Mon, 2 May 94 11:05:08 PDT
Received: from lizard.srv.PacBell.COM by pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA27880; Mon, 2 May 94 11:05:05 PDT
Date: Mon, 2 May 94 11:05:05 PDT
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9405021805.AA27880@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: brycer@crl.com
Subject: Re: Rave, Community, and Money [LONG]
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU, sfraves-planners@techno.Stanford.EDU
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

> my question is:  why assume that burden if the
> community will is not there?  it seems to me that when a payer/payee
> relationship is established, the event is no longer a community project;
> rather, entertainment or a consumable. 

Bryce, I am in agreement with you about the difference between community
projects vs consumer products.  But I think there can also be a middle 
ground here, i.e. community-focused capatalism, where the profiteer can 
also be in tune to the needs and spirit of hir community.  This can lead 
to some very delicate situations, for obvious reasons.  But I don't think 
it is impossible to achieve a balance between the good of the community 
and the desire to make a profit, realizing that this does compromise the 
community ideal to some extent, and is very tricky to accomplish without 
an aura of phoniness, exploitation and hypocrisy.
 
> a community project, on the other hand, is a "we" relationship. *we* do
> something for each other and for the larger communities we live in. *we*
> do it because we can, and because we want to. *we* assume no greater
> burden than we (as individuals) can bear.

There will always be a question of whether anything can be organized in 
a completely communal way.  Choices have to be made about many things, 
like the name of a party for instance - was the name Liquid Air, or 
In The Light, chosen by the entire community?  How about the site, flyer 
design, DJ selection?  Even when there is no money involved, 
organizers/leaders will be questioned as to their motivations - Perhaps 
Bryce, (and I know that this isn't true) Liquid Air is a power trip of 
some sort, where you are promoting a vision of yours under the cloak of 
"community", where your "profit" is an ever-inflatable self-righteous ego.  
Somebody who didn't know you could accuse you of that.  I know that I 
have had to do some soul searching in this area with In The Light.  The 
important thing isn't whether organizers are making money as much as 
whether the organizers' hearts are in the right place.  
 
> personally, i want to do community projects. i believe it is possible to
> do community-oriented raves on a grand scale, but only if everyone in the
> community *wants* to participate. 

Some people want to participate more than others.  The question here is:
Can a community be sustained and nurtured by a minority of highly-
motivated participants, or must a "true" community always consist of 
equally motivated participants?   

> i believe that community events require
> the informed consent of everyone, with willing participation in the often
> tumultuous process of organizing and executing the event.

This is the ideal.  And sometimes it *can* happen this way, and when it
does, nothing can compare to the shared vibe that emerges.

I also think that think communities need leadership sometimes, and ideally, 
community-focused leaders act on their ability to empathize with a shared
vision of their community.  Not an easy task.  On the other hand, would 
you want to have to take some kind of vote before making each decision 
associated with organizing an event?

> and, i believe
> that a community-oriented rave can be done without charging money at the
> door, without establishing any consumer relationship.  what *is* required
> to do such things is commitment and ingenuity...which i believe this group
> has in abundance.

Ultimately, it is the non-profit, non-ego motivated projects which define
the heart of *any* community.  My feeling is that parties like Liquid Air,
In The Light, Blue Cube, Connections, MESS, Home, YSH, Launch Pad... will 
always be the heart and soul of the rave scene here; breeding grounds for 
the spirit of our community.  I also like to believe that this spirit can 
bubble up into the other more product-focused activities that go on around
us; that we can bring the spirit forged in these "family" parties to the 
less communally-focused aspects of the scene.  Ideally, there can be a 
kind of synergy between the underground and aboveground.  But yes, without 
the grassroots support from community-minded participants, the scene will 
surely die.

I remain optimistic, that many people *want* a sense of community in 
the rave scene, and will support and participate in events that at least
*try* to be community based.  I agree that removing the profiteer/consumer 
element from such events is crucial.  If enough people just donate what 
they are comfortable with, whether it be making a financial contribution,
or just showing up and sharing some positive energy, then our community 
will flourish.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com
____________________________________________________________________________

	id AA15770; Mon, 2 May 94 11:50:33 PDT
Received: by crl.crl.com id AA08420
  (5.65c/IDA-1.5 for sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU); Mon, 2 May 1994 11:49:15 -0700
From: Bryce Ryan <brycer@crl.com>
Message-Id: <199405021849.AA08420@crl.crl.com>
Subject: Re: Rave, Community, and Money [LONG]
To: lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com (Lee Fogel)
Date: Mon, 2 May 1994 11:49:15 -0700 (PDT)
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU, sfraves-planners@techno.Stanford.EDU
In-Reply-To: <9405021805.AA27880@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM> from "Lee Fogel" at May 2, 94 11:05:05 am
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 3637      
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

My mailer says that Lee Fogel said:
> 
> There will always be a question of whether anything can be organized in 
> a completely communal way.  Choices have to be made about many things, 
> like the name of a party for instance - was the name Liquid Air, or 
> In The Light, chosen by the entire community?  How about the site, flyer 
> design, DJ selection?  
>
it's true that not all aspects of Liquid Air nor In The Light are put to
a vote.  Then again, I've discussed many aspects of the events i've helped
organize with quite a few people.  In the case of the events i've helped
organize, i'm always open to suggestions and amendments (and perhaps i 
haven't made that clear to everyone).  I would hope, for instance, that
if i decided to name an event some outrageous thing (e.g. Kill John Doe),
that cooler heads would prevail, someone would have words with me, and 
that i'd fix it.  As for other important aspects, i *have* opened it up
for community discussion, and made quite a few adjustments.  I understand
your main point, and it's a valid one that must be taken into consideration.
At the same time, certain things *can* be left to a few people, *iff* those
people have the trust of the greater community, and also have their ears
to the ground.

> organizers/leaders will be questioned as to their motivations - Perhaps 
> Bryce, (and I know that this isn't true) Liquid Air is a power trip of 
> some sort, where you are promoting a vision of yours under the cloak of 
> "community", where your "profit" is an ever-inflatable self-righteous ego.  
>
yes, leaders/organizers *will* and *should* be questioned constantly. and
if i am on an ego trip, and don't realize it, i should be pulled down of
my pedestal (as should anyone).

> 
> Some people want to participate more than others.  The question here is:
> Can a community be sustained and nurtured by a minority of highly-
> motivated participants, or must a "true" community always consist of 
> equally motivated participants?   
> 
i believe that the real center of the matter is the definition of "equally
motivated".  one of the problems with the model of community energized by
a few is that even if the few have the best interests of all as their
motivation, they will eventually burn out.  this is why i believe that
the model of a substantially larger group given the opportunity to participate
in some smaller way will lead to events that are "funner" for everyone. it
also helps guard against the ego/elitism problems of small groups.  further,
it ensures momentum once a project is undertaken, since no single person is
"indispensable".

one of the issues that is related to this is the frequency of events.  if
the broader based model i am proposing is used, it seems to me that the
frequency of events will decrease, since it usually takes more time to
make decisions than if fewer people are engaged in the process.  this is
OK with me.  i am certainly happy to trade more involvement of more people
for fewer events.  

> On the other hand, would 
> you want to have to take some kind of vote before making each decision 
> associated with organizing an event?
> 
if that's what it takes, and people want to participate at that level,
i'll do it.  even with events that other people are organizing, i still
reserve the right to try and get them to change certain things that i may
disagree with (e.g. event name, DJ selection, door policy, sound stuff,
vibe stuff, even fog stuff).  i hope that others take the same approach.
-- 
Bryce Ryan ------- AMBIANCE ----------- brycer@crl.com-----
======================================= NEW ADDRESS =======

	id AA15948; Mon, 2 May 94 11:55:31 PDT
Received: from mail02.prod.aol.net by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA15935; Mon, 2 May 94 11:55:22 PDT

	(1.38.193.5/16.2) id AA12518; Mon, 2 May 1994 14:55:30 -0400
From: robertj308@aol.com

Message-Id: <9405021455.tn57251@aol.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Mon, 02 May 94 14:55:29 EDT
Subject: "Anthem" or I left my legs"-(long review)
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

"Anthem or I left my legs.......

in San Francisco. I went of "Anthem"  on Saturday and it turned out to be a
great party for me. First, the 19th street warehouse was a fresh space,
roomy, and not your usual sweat-box. I could always find room to dance, with
few annoying "drive-by" walkers, or  newly budding tree-stumps planting
themselves in front of you.

Rick Preston invited me, and put me on the DJ list, so it was my first "go to
the head of the class experience." I really loved this 18 and over party. I
admit I normally am more within my age comfort zone at the over 21 parties,
but this party brought that arbitrary self-inflicted obstacle down a bit
more.

Wiliam Blake said that "energy delights in energy," and like so many things
Blake said, I didn't understand it when I read it. However, after seeing so
many crazy-legged ravers hopping around like repossessed demons, I think I do
now. I am just astonished by the seeming boundless energy and abandonment 
the younger ravers dance with. And, they can dance with that same 
high-octane intensity they did earlier in the evening. I staggered out of the
party at six, my legs now weighing about 100 lbs a piece. 

I had another of my bathroom experiences. I walk into the bathroom, a 6'4"
grey-haired guy, obviously from adultland. Some guys get that scared-rabbit,
or am I gonna get busted by a narc look, for I have temporarily interupted
some low-level contraband exchanges. I just said "Peace, little ravers," and
walked over to the urinal.

The sound system was sufficent to blast my head off. Carlos, Thomas, and Jeno
in the main room. (By the by, exactly which planet is Jeno visiting us from
anyway?)  Markie (another space alien in my opinion) Spun, and Rick Preston
played the smaller room.

Rick played the 4 to 6 slot, so I was scheduled for a "they shot horses don't
they?"  all night dance rav-a-thon. Lucky Me!!!!!By the time 5 rolled around,
all the artifical enthusiasms or enchancements couldn't coagulate the rubber
in my legs. 

I made a night of it, rented a room on 7th street,  and slept from 7-1. I got
up, and oozed on over to 1015 at 2:00. I wanted to see if I could meet Lee
Fogel and some other SFravers. Aaron and Crunch said, he was around but  by
this time I was having difficulty getting my Irish coffee to my lips, and I
still had the two hour drive south to Monterey. So, I stuck in an ambient
tape, told my little pony which way to go, (but it knows the way by now) and
drove home. Thanks again SF. See ya "in the Light," or down the road.
Robertj----MRP


From sfraves-owner  Mon May  2 11:56:09 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA15981; Mon, 2 May 94 11:56:09 PDT

	id AA15973; Mon, 2 May 94 11:56:02 PDT

          Mon, 02 May 94 11:55:48 PST

From: JACOB%SLACVM.BITNET@Forsythe.Stanford.EDU
To: resonate@netcom.com, sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU

instructions on how to get directions elsewhere.  The orignal location did 
get busted, so the party moved to some other place which was cool (in

From sfraves-owner  Mon May  2 13:23:38 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA17917; Mon, 2 May 94 13:23:38 PDT
Received: from soda.berkeley.edu by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA17909; Mon, 2 May 94 13:23:28 PDT
Received: (laura@localhost) by soda.berkeley.edu (8.6.9/PHILMAIL-1.10) id NAA03997 for sfraves@techno.stanford.edu; Mon, 2 May 1994 13:23:37 -0700
Date: Mon, 2 May 1994 13:23:37 -0700
From: Laura La Gassa <laura@soda.berkeley.edu>
Message-Id: <199405022023.NAA03997@soda.berkeley.edu>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Liquid Air
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

All the best laid plans of mice and men etc etc . . . .

I don't know what fly-by-night voice mail service ( :-) ) Bryce
subscribes to, but wouldn't you know it the ONE day out of the
month that he REALLY needs it to work it goes down and no one
in the customer service office can do anything about it becuase
it's a weekend.

We did the best we could spreading the word carefully through
electronic channels, unfortunately not everyone logs on during
the weekend so they missed my message saying that if you needed
directions finger my account at soda.  Of course, for some
reason a machine at cal-poly decided to have some mail problems
Saturday, too, so that meant anyone on sfraves with an .edu
address didn't get the message until way too late due to the 
delay cal-poly injected into the message delivery process.

Oy vey, the net.

Anyway, Brian and I made our way to the site around 11:30, and
arrived to find Ethan, Lee An, and Bryce putting the last touches
on the sound setup.  Lee got started soon after, and people started
arriving.  We danced our butts off until about 1:30, when a patrolling
Golden Gate park ranger found us and told us we weren't supposed to be 
there and that we should leave.  So we did, going to the never fail
"Launch Pad" site.

Usually, when a party gets busted and moved, it loses people.  Well,
luck smiled upon us and the party gained over a dozen people during
the move.  All told there were about 45 people in the course of 
the night, dancing up a storm.  

Lee An played a great set (would we expect anything less of him?) and
I danced so hard I had to sit out most of the rest of the party.
Next came Ethan, giving us an acid groove ranging from smooth and
floaty (i.e. the recent Hexagone release on DJAX) to rather dark and
hard ("Laura" music, if you will :-) ).  Joe Rice ended the night on
a funky note, and at 4:30 (amid a picnic provided by Adam, Batya,
and other people with food) we loaded the ENTIRE sound system into
Bryce's little tiny Geo Metro and called it quits.

It was a great night.  Some kids who encountered us in the Park though
we might be Satan Worshippers due to the candles that had been set
out delineating the dance area.

Anyway, if you missed us don't worry, we'll be at it again.  Bryce
didn't just buy a highly mobile sound system to have it sit in his
garage all summer!

Laura

To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU

X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23b2/POP]

Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

i agree with most of the original post. i'd like to share some 
experiences i had with an event i/we threw here in raleigh (NC) last friday.

we used a site that we found that was outdoors. the site was on private 
property, but was just a fairly large tract of land that was being 
cleared but was not being used. 

we charged $5 a head for admission, but many people came in for less if 
they had no money or were just uncooperative. i felt more inclined to let 
them be dicks about it than try and make them leave. (the people that 
were broke weren't dicks, just the uncooperative ones :)

we had one incident where some of the local skaters just decided to come 
in and harrass people, ie some people were dancing with glo-sticks and they 
just sat there and hassled them. they hadn't paid either. i went to talk 
to them to try and work out an agreement and our conversation went 
somewhat like this:

'if you guys are gonna stay, we'd appreciate it if you put in $5 to help 
cover the cost of equipment and dj's gas money' 

'well, we're here, and we're not gonna pay. this isn't your land. we 
would have come out here anyway [bullshit, no one knew about that site]'

'it's very hard to do things that way. i fronted the money for the all 
the equipment so that people could have a good time, i can't afford to 
pay for it all myself though.'

'well, you paid for it. why should we? i don't care if you lose money'

'thanks a lot'

'fuck you'

'thanks. enjoy the party.' and i leave. as i'm walking away they yell, 

'why don't you turn it up?'


so you see, not everyone in a community is going to help out. if you ask 
me, not everyone deserves to be in the community.

other than that, the party went well. we broke even. had exactly enough 
money to pay for the equipment and buy breakfast for everyone who helped 
out, and had a great time. money did change hands, but no profit was 
made. 

the only problem is, i'm a student. i have bills to pay, and organizing 
that party to a lot of time. i can't afford to throw 'free' parties and 
support myself. parties like that can only reasonably be organised by 
people with free time and no financial worries. i'm not sure wether i 
could keep a bunch of money if i made it from a rave, but i'm sure i 
could convince myself to. 

shit, i don't even know what my point was. well, that's my story :)

/////////////////////////////////////////////////////
//////////  john     humphrey@unity.ncsu.edu ///////
/////////  rainbow   john_humphrey@ncsu.edu ///////
////////  humphrey   pgp key upon request  ///////
/////////////////////////////////////////////////

random things that pop into my head, like usual

DJs and Dancers...

while at any given moment in time DURING a party,
i think that people in attendance are providing
just as much as the DJ

in a more historical context,
the DJ has put out a lot of money to get the music,
and has (hopefully) spent time finding the best music to play

while a Dancer is just doing that,
MAYBE they put money and time into a more interesting outfit
MAYBE they brought food or water that they are handing out

but i doubt that even if they do both, they could have put in as much
time and money as the DJ

things that make this invalid:
DJ's who get all their records for free
DJ's who do all their practicing while performing
DJ's who play the same 5 year old records over and over

but i doubt these make up the majority of DJs

AND

i dont think raves are a community project

there are definitely parties and promoters who want to offer something
for the community, BUT there are also lots of people
who want to just go out and have fun

i personally dont mind putting in some effort into a party that i am not
paying for and someone else is
OR i can put in some money so they arent paying as much

BUT the method i like the most is where i throw a party and you get in for free
and then you throw a party and i get in for free
(free = not havign any commitment of doing something)
that way, i can enjoy myself and you can enjoy yourself
and we dont both have to be worrying about everything all the time

 ,
dana

"Wow."

I, like Bob, wanted this thread to die, but I had to point out something
funny in his last letter:

> >My experience with frat boys indicates that frat guys make great
> >friends but terrible boyfriends.  Hangin out with them is cool, dating
> >them is not.  I keep the boundary quite clear.
> 
> substitute "gays" or "blacks" for "frat boys" and you'll see what i
> mean.  come on, people!

OK, imagine she had said:

> My experience with gays indicates that gays make great friends but
> terrible boyfriends. Hanging out with them is cool, dating them is
> not. I keep the boundary quite clear.

I don't know about you, but my response wouldn't be "That bigot!" It'd
be more like, "Well, duh!" (although hopefully a bit more witty).

I think it's perfectly OK for girls to discriminate against homosexuals
by not dating them, and I think all (male) homosexuals would agree.

I personally draw a similar line--I will be friends with frat boys, but
I will not date them. But maybe that's just because I'm straight....

>in a more historical context,
>the DJ has put out a lot of money to get the music,
>and has (hopefully) spent time finding the best music to play

>while a Dancer is just doing that,
>MAYBE they put money and time into a more interesting outfit
>MAYBE they brought food or water that they are handing out
>
>but i doubt that even if they do both, they could have put in as much
>time and money as the DJ

My experience last summer was Qmart.  A few friends and I decided that
people needed more access to cheaper 'supplies' at raves after being
charged four dollars for a bottle of water at Mister Rogers (in SF).  So at
the next Full Moon we brought candy and water (bottled) and proceeded to
sell the water for a dolar a bottle and give away free candy.  It was my
first Full Moon so I hadn't quite 'got it' yet.  I realized what it was
really supposed to be about and at the July 4th FMR we did a bigger and
better Qmart where we changed our approach a little bit.  We gave
everything for free and just asked for donations to help defray our costs.
I think we got almost a hundred dollars in donations (someone gave us three
dollars for a blow pop cause he was so impressed), without any signs up
around us , or even trying that hard.  In the mornig I handed out oranges,
donuts, and cinnamon rolls and just loved seeing the smiles on peoples
faces.  I just recently met a girl at my school (U of Oregon) who I gave a
cinnamon roll too at Bonny Doon one morning (Fresh Start 6/93) and to know
that I made one person happy was my goal.  I guess what I'm trying to get
around to is the fact that I was hoping to spur a lot more sharing.  I came
to school and don't know if I had any real positive effectsbut what do you
guys see in San Francisco.  I've made myself think about how we can make
people realize they can be an active part of the community.  I feel active
because I'm giving (matierally but in  a way of myself/time) and I assume
they feel active because they are receiving but how to show people the joys
of both.  Hope this paragraph made some sense.

>things that make this invalid:
>DJ's who get all their records for free
>DJ's who do all their practicing while performing
>DJ's who play the same 5 year old records over and over

There are DJ's that get free records!  How?!

>but i doubt these make up the majority of DJs
>
>AND
>
>i dont think raves are a community project
>
>there are definitely parties and promoters who want to offer something
>for the community, BUT there are also lots of people
>who want to just go out and have fun
>
>i personally dont mind putting in some effort into a party that i am not
>paying for and someone else is
>OR i can put in some money so they arent paying as much

One of my things is that I always try to give five bucks at free parties if
I have it so that the people have something to help them throw the next
party.

>BUT the method i like the most is where i throw a party and you get in for free
>and then you throw a party and i get in for free
>(free = not havign any commitment of doing something)
What does 'doing something' mean?  Doing Something might be dancing or
being nice or bringing  some water to share...

>that way, i can enjoy myself and you can enjoy yourself
>and we dont both have to be worrying about everything all the time


> ,
>dana
>
>"Wow."

The Cloud Factory
Our People Make the Difference

In-Reply-To: <199405022056.AA14756@mothra.nts.uci.edu>
References: <199405021849.AA08420@crl.crl.com>
	<199405022056.AA14756@mothra.nts.uci.edu>
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I think we should remember that while the DJ spends money and time on
records, when the event is over the DJ gets to keep the records and
take them home and play them at leisure. Yes, the DJ pays extra, but
the DJ gets extra, too. 

I don't think they should be paid any more than anyone else at the
party. Cleaning up after a party is NOT fun. Lugging a ton of PA
equipment up stairs is NOT fun. Working door while the party inside
goes off is NOT fun. Sometimes I see too much emphasis placed on the
DJs, and not enough on everything else that makes it work. The party
is fun not because DJ so-n-so played these records in this sequence,
it is fun because everyone made it fun.

Sean

> I think we should remember that while the DJ spends money and time on
> records, when the event is over the DJ gets to keep the records and
> take them home and play them at leisure. Yes, the DJ pays extra, but
> the DJ gets extra, too. 

True. but they get hella worn quick.  If you're into fidelity you
don't want to listen to stuff played 13 times on a 1200 with the
stylus pressure cranked up to 5g and you don't have time to clean them
before or after playing.  Click, pop, no high frequencies!

> I don't think they should be paid any more than anyone else at the
> party. Cleaning up after a party is NOT fun. Lugging a ton of PA
> equipment up stairs is NOT fun. Working door while the party inside
> goes off is NOT fun. Sometimes I see too much emphasis placed on the
> DJs, and not enough on everything else that makes it work. The party
> is fun not because DJ so-n-so played these records in this sequence,
> it is fun because everyone made it fun.

	Yeah, but anyone without a major back injury can clean up, lug
PA equipment, or work door.  Not everyone has the skills or the wax to
DJ, and not everyone can front the green crimp-cut for the space
and/or PA.  Pay people what you think they're worth, and see who shows.
It's a self-selecting process.

	Still, though, "who's there" is very important -- thus the
emphasis on who's throwing the party.  If SoundVision or MESS are
hosting, I can expect a certain group and 'vibe'.  If Wicked are
hosting, I can expect a different group and vibe.  And so it goes, and
so I go.  Do what you like; maybe it'll go off, and maybe not.

// g

          YLEM - Artists Using Science and Technology

          is hosting a Forum:  Solart Global Network
          Wednesday, May 4, 7:30 pm
          at the Exploratorium McBean Theatre
          3601 Lyon St., San Francisco

          Presentation and Interaction by members of the
          Solart Global Network and you!  Join in the
          creation of of outdoor solar artworks to bring
          the Solar Age to fruition!

          It's free, all are invited!  Come and meet some
          like-minded Artomata!  It's also a free night at
          the Exploratorium ...

          Presentations:


            ALEX NICOLOFF - solar sculptor, will present some
                            current works including his
                "Spectral Wave" which will be installed at the
                Lawrence Hall of Science during the season of
                the Solart Global Network exhibitions and
                presentations in Summer 1995.

            ROGER MALINA - editor of the journal Leonardo, will
                           present an overview of solar artworks
                and will share his experiences with other associates
                involved in the Solart Global Network.

            DAVID ANDERSON - will present his Solar Saucer.

            KEITH RUTLEDGE - of the Renewable Energy Development
                           Institute will present the Solar Energy
                Expo and Rally '94.

            Come prepared to share your ideas, seek resource people
            and become a citizen of the Solar Age!  The sponsors are
            a coalition of 4 non-profit organizations:

            Ylem: Arists Using Science and Technology, an International
                        organization of artists based in the Bay area
                        with 250 members and formed in 1981.

            Leonardo/The International Society for the Arts, Sciences
                        and Technology.  Founded in Paris in 1968 and
                        based in the SF Bay area since 1981.  It's
                        scholarly journal Leonardo is published by
                        MIT press.

            The Renewable Energy Development Institute (REDI).  A
                        relatively young non-profit based in Willits,
                        CA.  Through its REDI Invitational Conferences,
                        Solar Energy Expo and Rally (SEER) and other
                        projects is becoming a vital resource in the
                        development of the Solar Age.

            The Exploratorium, our host, has taken a very strong stance
                        in support of Solar and all are members of
                        the Solart Global Network.

Mark Guthrie <winston@lurnix.com> wrote:
>Did you all here!  MaryJane's a free girl in Germany.  The German Supreme
>Court ruled that it was unconstitutional to put people in jail for under
>5 grams of marijuana or hash when alcohol and cigarettes are legal.  It's
>not just decriminialized like in Holland but legal.  Possesion of < 5g or

is it really legal?  Everyone thinks it's decriminalized in Holland but
it's NOT!  It's tolerated and that's a bit different.  Sure all the
coffeehouses sell but they can still get in trouble with the police if they
decided to make an issue of it.  One coffeehouse in particular had to
remove its menu when I was there in '91 because it was publicly displayed.
I mean, you can walk up to a cop and ask her or him to light your
spliff/joint whatever but that doesn't mean it's legal.  That is, unless
things have changed recently in Holland that I don't know about.  If
Germany has gone ahead and done this, I wonder how it's going to affect the
European Community when it decides to unite even further.  Will the rest of
Europe adopt this policy?

An Overview of Trance Theory

Introduction

Trance is a controversial subject.  Over the past several decades
researchers in hypnosis have failed to agree on the nature of trance.
Only recently has there been the recognition that trance is probably a
common and natural phenomenon.  "Trance" is also a popular music
style.

Trance Theory is a theoretical model for trance which embraces most
prior definitions of trance such as hypnosis and yogic meditative
trance but also includes phenomena which previously were not
consistently recognized as being part of the trance phenomena, such as
addiction but including, even, trance music.
  
Trance Theory is a systems analysis of states of consciousness, which,
for reasons of rigor and unambiguity, is expressed mathematically.
However, the theory itself has been developed by a deep self-analysis
of states of meditation and addiction but expressed as a system.  No
prior work has been found which attempted to explain trance in this
unique way.  Trance theory has nothing to do with other theories of
consciousness or approaches such as found in the studies of social
psychologists, neo-dissociative studies or cognitive behavioralists.
Although the present theory is based on an approach which did not begin
with the idea to explain what a trance is, an explanation for trance is
both a side-benefit and the name of the theory.


While the approach is specifically oriented towards computers and
systems the inspiration for the approach came from the experience of
nearly thirty years of meditation practice as well as professional
involvement in computer systems analysis.  The inspiration of
meditation was applied to systems analysis and the precision of systems
analysis was applied to the meditation experience.  Although the models
of NLP and Eriksonian hypnosis are well-known, Trance Theory explains
NLP and Eriksonian hypnosis in a new way.  It was actually during an
attempt to model technological addiction (Technophiliacs) that the idea
to attempt a specific approach to modelling trance occurred.  Addiction
seemed to be a type of pathological trance.  Certain social and
psychological problems can be seen as manifestations of pathological
forms of trance.  It appears that many current social and institutional
problems we see in the world have elements of pathological trances.  By
understanding how trance works, it may be possible to attack these
problems at their cause.

Further research is needed to delineate in a more precise manner the
social and psychological implications of the model.  However, the model
seems robust enough to form a reasonable basis for further
experimentation and research in social and psychological areas.

The Importance of Trance

Trance states are present in many forms.  There are also pathological
trance states.  Some pathological trances give rise to addictions of
all sorts, including drug, alcohol, TV, work and sex/love addictions.
Trances have characteristics which are manifested in all addictions.
Wier's theories on trance have implications for solving the "drug
problem," as well as "work addiction" problems in businesses and
institutions.  However, further work needs to be done before there is
anything like a trance therapy.  There are ways to transform
pathological trance states to something more like an "awake" state of
mind.  Trance terminating is something we can do.  We can learn it and
we can teach it.  But first people must know how to recognize
pathological trance states.


Some trance states have given rise to hierarchical organizations in
business, government and military organization.  These trances may be
at the root of environmental damage and have other social effects not
usually recognized as being based on "a trance."  Wier's studies show
this relationship.  Recognizing and terminating trance will result in
new forms of social organization.  Some of these new forms are already
present in networks, but most people do not understand the nature of
these networks and how they are related to trance.  For example, while
women's movements are manifesting opposition to certain pathological
trances the methods being used to terminate the trances are not the
effective ones.  Trance Theory can explain what the effective methods
could be, as an example.  The following is a simplified overview of
Trance Theory.  Further details are available from the Institute.

What is Trance Theory?

Trance Theory is a new theory which precisely defines human trance and
includes practical ways to measure, analyze and design hypnotic, dream
states, altered states of consciousness, meditation, as well as the
pathological forms of trance such as addictive and psychotic states.
Trance Theory does not fit exactly into neodissociative,
social-psychological or cognitive behavioral theories, but spans and
impacts them all.  Because Trance Theory is a new approach or new point
of view, it is not yet found an academic forum.

Ordinary Thoughts and The Cognitive Plane

Ordinary thoughts are impulses in the brain which reflect in some sense
the processes and sensations that occur in the body.  No restrictions
are placed on what a thought is nor what a sense is.  The Cognitive
Plane is the theoretical plane of awareness which is derived from
ordinary thought impulses.

Generating Cognitive Loops

In certain cases thoughts repeat in loop patterns.  These looping
patterns are important for learning and abstraction.  The looping
patterns of awareness generate secondary awareness planes which for the
most part lie coincident to and within the cognitive plane.  Generating
cognitive loops do not need to be verbal thoughts.  Some loops are
mantras, drumming, pacing and leading for an hypnotic induction, the
stimulus and response of television viewing and addictive behavior.
The content of the loop is not a factor in generating secondary
awareness planes.  The critical aspect is the repeating pattern which
is the necessary and sufficient condition.  Generating cognitive loops
are not particularly easy to discover in specific cases, but
discovering them are critically important to understand the nature of a
specific trance.

The Dissociated Plane

With increasing number of times a loop is repeated, as well as other
conditions, these secondary awareness planes may split off or
dissociate from the cognitive plane.  This is quite normal and happens
when something is 'learned'.  It is the normal 'multi-processing'
aspect of thinking.  In this process, for energy conservation reasons,
some cognitive functions are disabled.  The resulting awareness when
these cognitive functions are disabled has been characterized as trance
awareness, and this is defined as the 'dissociated plane.'

Trance

When the number and strengths of the dissociated planes exceeds that of
the primary cognitive awareness plane, the sense of self, the "I",
switches to the dissociated plane, which is commonly called a trance
state.  Some cognitive functions when disabled exhibit 'trance logic'.
  
Trance Logic

Trance logic occurs only because it is more efficient, energy-wise, to
disable some cognitive functions to perform tasks that are in the
dissociated plane.

Characteristics of trance logic include the following:  disabling of
judgment, time distortion, disabling or limiting of volition, decrease
of body awareness, motor inhibition, perceptual distortions, memory
distortions, increase in hallucinations, more intense ideodynamic
processes, absorbtion, inability to perform some cognitive functions
and increased ability to perform other cognitive functions.  For
example, some people may be incapable of performing mathematical
calculations while in trance, but others perform mathematical
calculations unusually well.
  

Sensation and Mentation

Sensations and mentations which occur in trance may occur either from
external stimulation (voice, images which are seen, sensations which
are felt by the body) or from internal stimulation (memories, voices,
visions, feelings and emotions).  These sensations may occur in either
the cognitive plane or in the dissociated plane, and combinations give
rise to four types of trance.

The Four Types of Trance

The first type of trance is described by a generating loop in the
cognitive plane with external stimulation which is perceived from the
dissociated plane.  Television viewing, movies, driving a car, playing
a drum are activities which are examples of this type of trance.

The second type of trance is described by a generating loop in the
cognitive plane with internal stimulation which is perceived from the
dissociated plane.  Meditation, mantra and inner visualizations are
examples of this type of trance.

The third type of trance is described by a generating loop in the
dissociated plane with an external stimulation which perceived from the
dissociated plane.  Addictions are characteristic of this type of
trance.

The fourth type of trance can be described as a generating loop in the
dissociated plane with an internal stimulation which is perceived from
the dissociated plane.  Psychosis are characteristic of this type of
trance.
 
Terminating a Trance

Because trances may be created without knowledge or intent, it is
critical to understand the detailed mechanics of trance and to discover
specifically what trances are enabled in an individual.  Trances may be
terminated or replaced with other trances either with or without the
permission or knowledge of the subject.  Social responsibility concerns
raise the hope that pathological trances would always be replaced with
more benign trances.  Most therapies intend to replace pathological
trances with more benign trances.  The ostensible goal of spiritual
consciousness raising activities is to terminate trances, but often
only trance replacement occurs.  In the worst cases benign trances can
become pathological but with the label 'spiritual.'

Trance Analysis: A New Method of Analysis

Trance analysis is no different, fundamentally, from any other kind of
analysis.  The goal is to take presenting symptoms or conditions and to
try to discover and expose the patterns.  Of course, in order to
discover a pattern, you need a model.  Without a model, there will be
nothing to distinguish the patterns from the chaos.

Trance is a condition for which no good model really existed up until
now.  Of course there were to behaviorists and psychologists who could
define trance in a very loose way in terms of social psychology or
'belief' systems or 'compliance' or a 'narrowing of attention' or
dissociation and other terms, but these terms were very vaguely
described and often not defined in a way which could be used in a
precise analytical way.
 
The only reason why we call this Trance analysis is that we use a model
for trance called Trance Theory.
  
Because there is a model for trance, it is possible to examine any
situation and see if there are the elements of trance present.  If so,
then a trance is present.  If a trance exist, then the theory says that
certain mental conditions will be present with certain
characteristics.  As Trance Theory evolves there will be measures on
these characteristics and such measures will give absolute diagnostic
indications which may have therapeutic value.

For example, although NLP is controversial with its modalities and
submodalities, such clues as where the eyes are as indicating access to
visual past or constructive visual, are similar to possible future
measures in Trance Theory.

Addictions, meditation, nationalism, spirituality all are different
enough but all share one thing:  they are all indicative of a trance.
So we can analyze them.  We can look for Generating Cognitive Loops,
Dissociated Latent Planes, and we can count loop content and we can try
to enumerate and describe the DLPs that these loops create.  We also
know that DLPs cause disabling of certain cognitive functions.  Which
ones?  We know that when DLPs are present, cognition can function in
strange ways.  For example, not everyone will hallucinate simply
because a DLP is present.  Sometimes a lessening of body awareness is
more important.  Sometimes a disabling of memory function is more
important.  Whatever is the particular result of the DLP, it is
important to associate the GCL with the DLP and the disabled cognitive
functions.

A trance analyst will attempt to discover the GCLs and DLPs and the
disabled cognitive functions.

You may notice that a trance analyst does 'similar' things as a
psychotherapist or psychoanalyst except that the model is different.  A
Freudian may look for polymorphous perversities, dysfunctional libidos
or Oedipus Complexes, and a Jungian might look for archetypes as models
for pathological behaviors.  But a trance analyst looks for
characteristic mental processing which creates trance.  Why is trance
important?  Trance causes a selective disabling of cognitive functions
in such a way that a robust variety of behavior can be seen and
explained from the very normal to the very abnormal and even the super
normal.

For this reason, the reinterpreting of human behavior from the point of
Trance analysis promises to give a rich dividend in terms of explaining
what is sick and what is healthy behavior.

For now, we don't know what addictions are sick and what addictions are
healthy.  A drug addict is sick, but what if that drug is coffee?  Or
vitamins?  Is performance addiction always sick?  What if the addiction
is to become a perfect Olympic downhill skier?  Or a perfect banker?
Or a perfect assassin?  Or a perfect sharpshooter?  Is a Florence
Nightingale sick or a national heroine?  Are national heroes
characteristic of pathological trances?  Do we need nationalistic
trances or not?  If what we do is governed by our social trances
instilled in us when we were very young, which of those social trances
are sick and which are not?

How can we really judge between social trances from different
cultures?  Trance analysis gives the possibility to expose the actual
mechanism of specific trances.  In doing so, it may be possible in the
future to answer these questions without resorting to moral or ethical
judgements.  What we do come face to face with, however, is the
philosophical problem of chaos.  It is trance which keeps us from this
fear.  If we destroy all of our trances, we will again be faced with
this chaos.  It is no wonder that religions and nationalistic movements
and drug addictions exist in the world.
 
Trance analysts can show us if specific trances are actually the ones
we want.  Or not.  The problem with being in a trance is that we cannot
make clear judgements as to if and when we want to get out of our
trances.  It is only when we know what our trances are and how these
trances affect our behavior and our sense of the world that we can
decide if these trances really serve our best interests.

In this final sense, a trance analyst is no different than any other
analyst, just more precise, and probably a bit more 21st century.


Designing Trances

Once trances are fully understood, it becomes possible to design a
trance by intent.  This implies that it is possible to methodically
design dreams, Altered States of Consciousness and addictions in such a
way that they cannot be resisted.  Successful religious and political
movements have stumbled on ways to design addictive trances without the
benefits of a study such as Trance Theory.  Trance Theory implies a
potential for more addictive religious or political trances while at
the same time showing how to avoid such trances and how to break them.
  
Continuing Research

Trance Theory has important implications in the following new areas:
Applying trance creatively.  
New-age trance, electronic states.  
Rediscovering shamanistic and yogic trance states.  
Implications for environment, society  and technology.  
Further studies on the nature of information.

The Trance Institute Activities

Publications

There is currently no known specific academic forum for this research.
Unless an already existing forum is discovered, the Institute will
publish its own findings.

The Institute currently publishes various pamphlets on the subject of
trance.
 
A Systems Paradigm For Trance

A Systems Paradigm For Trance describes Trance Theory.  It is now
available for $20.00 from the Institute.

Count Your Trances  

An article to introduce the concepts of pathological trance and to make
the connection with addictions.  This article was published in the
Winter, 1993, issue of The Quest magazine and does not represent the
current state of Trance Theory.  Reprint: $5.-

The International Trance Journal

The Institute will soon publish (July, 1994) a research periodical
called The International Trance Journal.  The readership of the Journal
will be professional trance analysts and trance designers or those who
are in mental health fields interested in technical research questions
involving trance in both technical and clinical situations.
Subscription: $50.- per annum (4 issues).  Papers may be submitted for
publication.  Write/email for guidelines.

Trance Courses

The Institute offers courses on trance to hypnotists, therapists, sales
personnel, managers, advertisers, musicians, fantasy makers, meditation
teachers, shamans, yogis, witches and spiritual seekers, all of whom
are interested in trance.  Courses teach the theoretical and practical
aspects of trance.  The various types of trance are demonstrated and
the attendee can experience them all.

It is important to realize that there are four types of trance only one
of which is hypnotic trance.  The Trance Institute studies them all.
Trance creation, design, analysis as well as trance termination are all
very important to the complete understanding of trance.

Trance termination courses are offered to therapists and addiction
counselors.  Special trance instructor courses are available for
professionals interested in becoming deeper involved in the activities
of the Institute.

Music and Dance Trance

Music and Dance are traditional ways light trance has been
experienced.  These ways do not require television, drugs or other
aids.  In this course we explore techniques for causing trance,
techniques for deepening trance.  Some traditional ways of trance such
as Sufi Dervish dancing will be demonstrated analyzed.

Trance Deepening Techniques

Light trances are common.  Ways to deepen trance are not so well
known.  This course examines deep trances and analyzes the causes of
deep trance.  Techniques for deepening trance are explored.  There will
be instructor-led deep trances.

Professional Development Workshop

Hypnotherapists and other professionals can learn precise ways to
deepen trance in their patients.  A variety of techniques will be
examined in detail.  The purpose is to give the professional an
in-depth appreciation of trance and to improve their skills in both
inducing trance as well as terminating trance!    This special course
will teach the theoretical and practical aspects of trance.  Various
types of trance will be demonstrated and the attendee can experience
them all.  In this course we explore techniques for causing trance,
techniques for deepening trance.  Light trances are common.  Ways to
deepen trance are not so well known.  This course examines deep trances
and analyzes the causes of deep trance.  Techniques for deepening
trance are explored.  There will be instructor-led deep trances.  This
special course is for professionals in the mental health field who work
with addictions of all sorts:  drug, alcohol. sex and love, are
covered.

Introductory Trance Theory

This introductory course in trance theory is for those with no need to
have a precision model of trance, but who wish to understand how trance
affects everyday life, how trances are introduced without our
permission, how a trance can be recognized and how it can be
terminated.

Advanced Trance Theory

For those handful of people who wish to have a precision understanding
of trance theory, this course is designed to give you everything you
need to understand and use trance theory.

Teacher Training Courses

Special trance instructor courses are available for professionals
interested in becoming deeper involved in the activities of the
Institute.

Addiction  

What is addiction?  The pathological trance.  Pacing without
co-dependency.  Drug switching.  Expanding options.

Trance  

Types of trances:  hypnotic, meditative, pathological, unconscious.
How unconscious trances are induced.  Characteristics of the trance
state.  Breaking a trance.

New Social Organizations  

Why communication patterns are more important than what they say.  How
pathological information moves.  How healthy information moves.
Training ourselves to recognize pathological information patterns.
Transforming the structure of communication in our lives.  How social
organizations can be healthier.  Implications for government, military,
business and family.

Personal Trance Analysis

The Institute will offer professional in-depth personal trance analysis
to individuals who wish to explore the foundations of their trances.
Trance analysis is not a substitute for psychotherapy or other
psychoanalytic treatments, but provides the individual a rich and
detailed set of practical information which can deepen an individual's
personal understandings.  For persons practicing meditation,
shamanistic trance, wicca, etc., a deeper understanding of trance
theory and techniques can make the trance experience more effective.
 
Barriers impeding trance or changing trance in undesirable ways can
also be removed through in-depth trance analysis.

Trance Design Consultants

The Institute will offer consultants in trance on an hourly or retainer
basis.  Trance consultants will be trained by the Institute in the
theoretical and practical aspects of trance analysis and design.  They
will be fully capable to help analyze specific situations and to design
and implement trances for specific purposes.  The trances produced can
be useful in various social and psychological settings.  Trance
consultants are particularly useful for evaluating and testing
commercial products such as music, video, etc. for various
entertainment, training or behavioral purposes.

Publications:
Trance Theory, avail for $20. from the Institute
Int'l. Journal of Trance, $50. per year (4 issues)
Count Your Trances (reprint of article in Quest magazine), $5.

For More Information, Write:
The Trance Institute

CH-8036 Zuerich
Switzerland

> Date: Sun, 1 May 1994 16:38:31 -0600 (CDT)
