> Sent from: cmbecker@ctdnet.acns.nwu.edu ("Canton Becker")
> 
> ****************** *GREETINGS, FRIENDS!* May 1, 1994
> ****************** This message is to announce the completion of the
> Communal Groove Machine (CGM), a program six months in the making that
> runs in "moocode" on CTDMOO, reched via telnet to ctdnet.acns.nwu.edu
> 8888.  (Further instructions on how to get there later in this
> posting.)
> 
> The CGM is an algorithmic composing agent that maintains a vast
> database of rhythm elements, music structures, and bass & chord
> patterns that it uses to compose techno songs whose essential
> qualities are determined by participants who interact with the machine
> in a text-based virtual reality.
> 
> The songs generated by participants using the CGM will be engineered
> and recorded for use in a ten-hour long production taking place in a
> popular nightclub in downtown Chicago in late June.  (The production
> is the creation of Northwestern University composer Amnon Wolman, who
> based the idea around the diaries of Andy Warhol; hence the overdone
> 10-hour length.)
> 
> Musicians, ravers, techno aficionados, composers, and anyone else
> interested are invited to explore the Communal Groove Machine,
> generate grooves, and contribute to the ever-growing groove elements
> library.  The compositional paradigm that forms the foundation of the
> CGM is that of the future; where the listener, the audience, the
> *subject* will orchestrate what she experiences.
> 
> TO PARTICIPATE: ---------------- Beginning noon, May 2nd, anyone with
> telnet access may telnet to ctdnet.acns.nwu.edu 8888 and connect as a
> guest.  (Email canton@nwu.edu for information about dial-up access for
> those who have modems but no internet access.)
> 
> When you connect as a guest, you will appear in the basement of
> CTDMOO, the Center for Talent Development MOO.  (Please be kind to any
> residents you bump into on CTDMOO; most are thirteen years old and are
> quite sensitive.)  Type 's' and hit return to go south.  Then type
> 'press silver button' to be transported to the Communal Groove
> Machine.  From there, things are pretty self explanatory.  However, if
> you are totally unfamiliar with MOO commands, you may want to read a
> few help pages, such as 'help basics'.  (especially 'help basics'.)
> Enjoy the groove.
> 
> TO CONTRIBUTE DATABASE ELEMENTS: ----------------------------------
> Email stuff to canton@nwu.edu.  Perhaps you ask, "What sort of stuff"?
> Keep reading.
> 
> If you are not interested in contributing to the database itself, but
> would rather just fiddle with the CGM and design yourself some techno,
> then you probably don't have to read the rest of this article.
> 
> THANKS FOR YOUR ATTENTION!
>                 If you have any questions,
>                           I am yours,
>                        Canton Becker
>                      canton@nwu.edu Artificial Intelligence & Music
> Technology Programs, Northwestern University
> 
> MORE SPECIFIC INFORMATION: --------------------------
> ------------------------------------------------ The Communal Groove
> Machine: Solicitation for chord and bass sequences.
> ------------------------------------------------
> 
> The Communal Groove Machine (CGM) algorithmically generates techno
> music based upon an immense library of drum patterns, chord
> progressions, dance cliches, etc.  Well, an *almost* immense library.
> We need some help from you.
> 
> If you feel inspired, creative, bored, or as if you need some groove
> in your karma, please email a chord progression or bass progression to
> canton@nwu.edu or Canton (#230) here, on CTDMOO.  Be sure to include a
> little note that mentions how you feel the progression sounds...  A
> weird notation system MUST be followed, which is described below.
> Please email only progressions in this syntax:
> 
> *NOTE* Both bass and chord progressions must be "16 beats long", that
> is, about two measures long in 4/4 time (a "beat" here is an eigth
> note) and in the key of C.
>  Yoj MUST specify at the top of your suggesion what tonality your
> submission fits under.  Options are: C major, C minor, or C ambiguous.
> (Something that was only centered around the 1st and the 5th would be
> ambiguous, for example.)
> 
> FORMAT FOR BASS LINE SUBMISSIONS: submit tonality, plus 1-16 lines
> whose total beat lengths are EQUAL to 16, and look like this:
> <note><n,f,s> <#beats> where <note> is any of C D E F G A B, <n,f,s>
> stands for natural, flat, or sharp, and <#beats> indicates how long
> the bass should hold this note.  PLEASE NOTE that the techno machine
> will not boringly play the notes you select and hold them for 8
> counts, etcetera... If you specify #beats as 4, the Techno Machine
> will *apply a rhythm* to the bass instrument over those four beats.
> 
> EXAMPLE:
>          Tonality: C minor
>          Cn 4
>          Bf 4
>          Ef 4
>          Cn 4
> 
> FORMAT FOR CHORD PROGRESSION SUBMISSIONS: submit tonality (as in
> bassline submissions), plus 1-16 lines whose total beat lengths are
> EQUAL to 16, and look like this:
> <note><n,s,f><m,M,A,d><0,7,9><0,M,m,d><0,M,m,d> <#beats> where <note>
> is any of C D E F G A B, <n,s,f> stands for natural, sharp, or flah,
> <m,M,A,d> determines whether the chord should be minor, Major,
> Augmented, or diminshed, <0,7,9> shows whether the chord should be a
> simple triad (0), 7th chord, or 7th+9th chord.  The first <0,M,m,d> is
> used to indicate the type of 7th, if any (0=no seventh, M=major 7th,
> m=minor 7th, d=diminished 7th) and the second <0,M,m,d> is used in the
> same way to describe the 9th.
> 
> EXAMPLE TRANSLATIONS:
>   'C minor chord' => 'Cnm000'
>   'E flat diminshed chord' => 'Efd000'
>   'F sharp major 7th diminished 9th' => 'FsM9Md'
> 
> EXAMPLE:
>          Tonality: C minor
>          Cnm000 4
>          Efm000 4
>          BfM000 4
>          Cnm000 4
> 
> 
> THANKS FOR ANY HELP!  Please realize that by emailing me any chord
> progressions or base lines, you are giving up all rights to your
> creation- the techno machine may use your creations in part or in
> whole without acknowledging you.  HOWEVER, WE WOULD LIKE IT IF:
>   You could ALSO provide with any material you send in: Your name,
> email address, phone number, ANYTHING: Quotes, .gifs, .au sound files,
> anything.  The production in which the music generated by the techno
> machine will be used is a multi-media sensory conglomerate...  Your
> creations, your ideas, your everything may be incorperated into music,
> video, lyrics, or anything else.  If you leave your email address, you
> will be added to a list which will keep you informed of dates for the
> production itself, any pending CD release of techno machine music,
> etc.
> 
> THANKS!  -Canton Becker and Amnon Wolman, Northwestern University
> Music Technology Program.
>

> -----------------------------------

>      will serve audio files of songs resulting from your MIDI code.

> after

is it really legal?  Everyone thinks it's decriminalized in Holland but
it's NOT!  It's tolerated and that's a bit different.  Sure all the
coffeehouses sell but they can still get in trouble with the police if they
decided to make an issue of it.  One coffeehouse in particular had to
remove its menu when I was there in '91 because it was publicly displayed.
I mean, you can walk up to a cop and ask her or him to light your
spliff/joint whatever but that doesn't mean it's legal.  That is, unless
things have changed recently in Holland that I don't know about.  If
Germany has gone ahead and done this, I wonder how it's going to affect the
European Community when it decides to unite even further.  Will the rest of
Europe adopt this policy?
------------------------------------------------------------------------

No, actualy it is decriminalized in Holland and everyone thinks it's legal
but it's not.  The word decriminalized doesn't mean legal.  That's why
they use that word in refference to Holland because it's not legal, the
police just don't actively pursue arrest - decriminalized.

-Winston

From: child@netcom.com (Spaced-Out Funky Earthchild)
Message-Id: <199405032136.OAA15938@netcom.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: trance states
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


Trance is a controversial topic.  Therefore I disagree with a lot of stuff 
written in that article about trance.

>anything like a trance therapy.  There are ways to transform
>pathological trance states to something more like an "awake" state of
>mind.  Trance terminating is something we can do.  We can learn it and
>we can teach it.  But first people must know how to recognize
>pathological trance states.

sure, but why terminate a trance state?  I think we are trancing all the time
but our consciousness is too demanding to allow many of us to trance on 
command.  I feel like the word, "trance" used in the paragraph above should
be renamed something like "awareness blinders".  Sure if a soldier is 
psycholocially broken down and then rebuilt by the military frame of thinking
and then s/he becomes a robot following ANY orders from "superiors", he
may be in a "trance" state.  I would call it awareness-narrowing.  If that
same soldier actually tranced then that human might no longer wish to be a 
human robot.

In my opinion, more people should get in touch with their trance states AS
WELL AS opening up their awareness boundaries.  Trancing is nothing to be
feared.  Whoever wrote that article on trancing has systemized, academized,
and tried to categorize it.......why not just enjoy it?

>trances with more benign trances.  The ostensible goal of spiritual
>consciousness raising activities is to terminate trances, but often
>only trance replacement occurs.  In the worst cases benign trances can
>become pathological but with the label 'spiritual.'

I completely disagree with this.  In my opinion, spiritual consciousness
raising should increase one's awareness of all-that-is.  Trancing is a doorway
to accessing the state of all-that-is.  I think that the author of the article
is personally bent against trancing and how dare he talk for everybody else
by saying that the "ostensible goal of spiritual consciousness raising
activities is to terminate trances"  He must be using a definition for trancing
that is very different from the one used on sfraves lately or else in my
humble opinion, he's overflowing with b.s.

Space

this was posted to seraves and neraves. i'm just forwarding it:

> ok, first a recap:
> 
> as many of you already know, this summer i am attempting to compile a tape of
> net-musicians, called NETherworld (clever, eh?) well, time is running out for
> all of you musical geniouses to send in your contributions.
> 
> ALL CONTRUBUTIONS MUST BE POSTMARKED BY JUNE 1, 1994 TO BE CONSIDERED!
> note that i moved the original date (may 15) back a couple weeks, so hopefully
> this will give you some extra time. also note that at this point i'm not
> asking for cd-quality fully produced copies....all i need is a cassette demo
> of your stuff so i can start selecting what will appear on the final tape.
> 
> any musical style, as long as it fits into the "techno" mold is acceptible:
> whether it be house, breaks, gabber, trance, ambient, whatever....all i ask
> is that the song is no longer than 6.5 minutes or so (if longer, the only
> way ill consider it is if its incredibly good....we only have so much space)
> 
> i only have the addresses for ne, se, and dcraves....if someone could forward
> this to some of the other lists i'd be grateful
> 
> so....looking forward to hearing your stuff....remember, JUNE 1 is the cutoff
> date....get those tapes to me!
> 
>
> send all tapes to:
> NETherworld c/o Jason Leder
> 112 Woodlane Ct.
> Glassboro, NJ 08028
>
> remember, tapes must be postmarked no later than june 1
>
> -jason/method one >>>scene but not herd<<< lederjaso@urvax.urich.edu

Subject: neiman marcus cookies redux
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Tue, 3 May 1994 18:03:27 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 3882      
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Soon after the dumb cookie recipie thang resurfaced on the net a
month or so ago it predictably made its way to premenos' internal
e-mail.  It bounced around and died out 'till today when I got this in
the mail from someone (who got it from someone at cisco) and I thought
I'd pass it on.  Hit -n- if you're not in a particularly humorous
mood...



> 
> A few years ago I was touring the Jet Propulsion Lab and they showed
> me a prototype of the Hubble Space Telescope.  "Pretty cool machine,
> guys," I said, "but is there anyway us amateur astronomers can get in
> on this kind of action?" They said yes, plans for the HST were
> available through the gift shop.  "How much?" I asked.  They said
> "Fifty." I said "Great!"
> 
> I picked up the plans and went home, happy as a clam, until I got my
> American Express bill.  The total amount due was $50,119.00!  I
> figured the $119 must have been from one of these Northwest student
> ticket vouchers, but where was that $50,000 from?  Only then did I
> realize that JPL had charged me, not fifty dollars, but fifty THOUSAND
> dollars.  Boy was I mad.  But it was too late to return the plans and
> get my fifty thousand dollars back, so I just chalked it up to
> experience.  But now I'm getting my revenge...by giving them to
> you for free!
> Please post them to every board you can think of and mail them to all
> your friends.  Remember, if you break the chain you'll get seven years
> of bad sunspot interference.
> 
> You will need:
> 
>  1 launch vehicle.
>  126 "Master Constructor" Erector Sets(tm).
>  1 Radio Shack(tm) Pro-2001 scanner.
>  1 2-meter block of glass.
>  1 box of aluminum foil.
>  4 sheets of #20 (coarse) sandpaper.
>  4 sheets of #150 (fine) sandpaper.
>  2 children's magnifying glasses.
> 
>  (optional) filters and instrumentation as needed.
> 
> Instructions:
> 
>  1. Using the erector sets, construct a superstructure capable of
>     supporting a 2-meter mirror and whatever instrumentation you will
>     be using.  Make sure that the superstructure can survive the
>     G-forces during launch.  Don't be tempted to skimp on the nuts and
>     bolts here.
> 
>  2. Using the #20 sandpaper, grind the block of glass until it takes
>     on the shape of a convex mirror.  Be very careful in this step
>     because if you get the shape wrong you'll have to start over
>     again.  Use the #150 sandpaper to smooth out any irregularities
>     and fix any minor problems with the focus.  Then melt the aluminum
>     foil and vacuum deposit 1-2 atomic layers of aluminum on the
>     surface of the mirror.  Mount the mirror in its place in the
>     superstructure.
> 
>  3. Mount the children's magnifying glasses at the focal point of the
>     mirror.  These will serve as an eyepiece for your instruments.
> 
>  4. Open the back of the Pro-2001 scanner.  There will be a 16-pin
>     chip on the upper left of the circuit board labelled 1Y1169AV.
>     Carefully clip out the fourth pin on the left and remove it from
>     the chip.  This will convert your Pro-2001 scanner into the usually
>     much more expensive Pro-2010 scanner with orbital transceiver
>     capabilities.  Close the back of the scanner, check that the
>     batteries are in place, mount it in the superstructure, and
>     connect it to your instruments.
> 
>  5. Make one last check of everything and you're ready to launch!
> 
> This is a true story, every bit of it, I swear on my father's sister's
> grave.  Even if it isn't, I hope that you get as much use and
> enjoyment out of your home-built Hubble Space Telescope as I have from
> mine!
> 



--

Howard Berkey                                             howard@netcom.com   
			      Eat at C-Ko's

> oranges or the like to be unable to bring then in.  

In my experience, it seems like the promoters don't seem to have that 
say.  I could be wrong on this, but the owners if they feel water and 
oranges will take away sales from the bar, will not allow them in.  I've 
never been to an event where I've been denied my water but it has 
happened I'm sure.

I hope they let you in with the oranges.

I actually had a response to this and wasn't going to post it, but now 
that the subject has been ressurected, I feel it important to note that 
a)black people have no choice to be black, they were born that way b) gay 
people have no choice to be gay, they were born that way c) frat people 
have a choice, they were not born frat people.  They chose to be frat 
people and by choosing have selected for themselves a certain lifestyle.  
Should they decide that lifestyle is not suitable, then they can always 
quit the fraternity.
Let me qualify real quickly that a) and b) in an of themselves are not 
negative qualities.  I was making no judgement in my statement about 
whether these qualities are positive or negative.  Just trying to keep 
flamers off my butt! (-;

From sfraves-owner  Wed May  4 07:35:00 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA23418; Wed, 4 May 94 07:35:00 PDT
Received: from ginsberg.CS.Berkeley.EDU by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA23411; Wed, 4 May 94 07:34:53 PDT
Received: by ginsberg.CS.Berkeley.EDU; id HAA05460; Wed, 4 May 1994 07:43:05 -0700
From: Adam Sah <asah@ginsberg.CS.Berkeley.EDU>
Message-Id: <199405041443.HAA05460@ginsberg.CS.Berkeley.EDU>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Reply-To: asah@cs.Berkeley.EDU
Subject: richly woven...
Date: Wed, 04 May 94 07:43:05 -0700
X-Mts: smtp
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

As some of you know, I've been trying hard to understand some fundamentals
  about people and life etc., and in particular, sorting out the situation
  I found myself in just before coming to grad school- namely, being a paid
  an enormous sum as a fancy programmer in Manhattan, and pretty much
  living "the life".  I had all of the usual conflicts and questions, only
  with a twist: I wanted to understand what was fundamentally wrong with
  doing well like this, having fun, and working relatively hard on
  something I've trained all my life to do, etc.- all relative to maturing
  and growing etc.

So, after a lot of thought, I have hit upon something which really helps
  clarify things, but as these things work, it raises more questions than
  it answers.

In the past, I've met a number of people who I consider to lead (sorry for
  the poor term, but I don't have a better one) "richly woven" lives, where
  the rest of us plebes don't.  Some characteristics:
  - fundamentally being relaxed about who they are, why they're doing what
    they're doing, understanding the people around them (ie. being able to
    talk/be comfortable with anyone), etc. - I'd say a spiritual contentment,
    but I really dislike to use New Age, religious, or other semantically
    overloaded terms...

  - being pc, not out of training, but just because it comes naturally (ie.
    would never get caught using a stereotype, probably because s/he
    knows a lot people in the stereotype, and knows there's more to it than
    that).

  - taking care of his/her body, again, not intentionally, because a doctor
    said so, or because of vanity- but just because they know that it's
    part of leading a balanced life.

  - an implicit notion of humility - but not humility like
    self-deprecation, which arises from lack of self confidence: humility
    like the village witch doctor has: you as an outsider would never think
    to _ask_ how large this person's ego is.

  - REALLY knows what s/he doesn't know.  There's a prof here who I'm sure
    everyone around here would claim is this richly-woven dude, but having
    worked for him, I realized that as nice a guy as he is etc. he lacks an
    understanding of what the other people do in the department and why
    their work is at all important.  This knows-what-doesn't-know thing
    clearly involves being very broadly educated and at the same time very
    deeply educated.  Ever notice how phd's tend to think they know than
    they do about areas outside their field?


Anyway, it occurred to me that the sfrave community has a disproportionate
  density of these kind of folk, so I figured I might ask...

Some questions:
 - Do you see what I'm seeing?  Can you add to this "definition"?

 - Do you know people who you feel are like this?  (please explain/tell the
   story if it adds to the understanding/definition...)

 - How smart do you have to be to be richly woven?  (an interesting
   question, I know: I'd like to believe that you don't have to be very
   smart, but realistically the only people I've met who come close have
   all had staggering amounts of brain matter...)

 - Where do psychoactives fit in?  (I have my own theories based on my own
   experiences, but I'd rather here other people's)

 - It seems clear that part of the path (aigh!) is just experience -
   meeting lots of people, doing lots of things, trying different
   lifestyles, etc.  It seems clear that travel is part of this, and yet I'm
   basically grounded for the next 4-5 years on my PhD here (a different
   kind of enlightenment, but an essential one).  Any suggestions on what I
   can do? (basically, I don't have more than a week off at a shot, and
   those weeks are painful losses if I can't log in... sigh...)

 - Presumably this enlightenment is process, not product.  Thus, a person
   will be richly woven if s/he is "on a path", and if s/he slips off it,
   so goes this enlightenment.  I am reminded of another mentor who seemed
   to really know the world, etc. etc. and who had family troubles which
   essentially ruined him mentally.  Thus, I think it's a temporal thing, no?
   What does this mean for this concept?

peace not piece
adam

Good to hear from you!  Attached are two files, a letter from Andrew Weil,
and the intinerary and costs.  Hope this answers your questions.





                        ANDREW T. WEIL, MD
                      l975 West Hunter Road
                    Tucson, Arizona 85737, USA


26 April l994

Dear Fellow Eclipse Chasers:

I'd like to invite you to join Sabina and me on a too-
good-to-be-true expedition to Peru and Bolivia to catch
a great total eclipse of the sun as well as to visit a
number of sacred sites.

I'm an avid fan of solar eclipses.  The last one I saw,
from a boat off Baja California in July of 1991 was
awesome and left me wanting more.  I'd been planning to
go to South America to see the November 3rd eclipse but
hadn't decided where to go, when India Supera of
Feathered Pipe Ranch asked me if I would lead a Rim
Institute tour.  When I saw the proposed itinerary, I
said, Yes!

Peru and Bolivia are two of my favorite countries.  I've
spent a lot of time in them studying medicinal plants
and, especially, coca leaves, but we'll be going to some
places I've never visited, including Nazca to see the
famous lines in the desert.

I'll be sharing my knowledge of Andean foods, medicines,
and customs, as well as taking coca breaks with you.  We
will talk about altered states of consciousness and the
symbolism of the "Marriage of the Sun and Moon."  I'll
answer your questions about natural medicine and lead
you to the unusual and delicious foods I know from the
Andes and the Altiplano.

Enough said.  Please try to join me in the cone of the
shadow on November 3rd in Peru!


Sincerely,


 Signed   Andrew Weil




NOVEMBER, 1994 JOURNEY TO THE SOLAR ECLIPSE, PERU AND
   BOLIVIA WITH ANDREW WEIL, RUBEN ORELLANA NEIRO,
   INDIA SUPERA, RICHARD EDELMAN and more....

ITINERARY

     DAY 1, Tues, Nov 1:  We fly directly from Miami to
Lima.  Overnight at the Ariosto Hotel.
                          LV MIAMI    5:35 P   AMERICAN
                          AR LIMA    10:35 P
     DAY 2, Wed, Nov 2:  Fly to Tacna on Americana in
the morning.  Prepare for the Eclipse.  This evening we
make camp.
     DAY 3, Thurs, Nov 3:  SOLAR ECLIPSE approximately
7:10 AM.  Fly to Nazca and stay overnight at Nazca Lines
Inn.
     DAY 4, Fri, Nov 4:  Nazca Lines:  flight to see
the Nazca Lines, huge figures laid out by carving into
the earth.
     DAY 5, SAT, NOV 5:  8:30 AM flight over the Andes
to Cuzco (11,000 feet high).  We stay at the Al Hambra
Hotel in Cuzco for three nights.  In the afternoon we go
to Ollantaytambo where massive blocks of granite form
perfectly joined walls. At the base of the terraces a
rushing stream feeds into a carved altar.
     DAY 6, Sun, Nov 6:  Morning in the Pisac market
to experience the colorful artistry of the Indians from
the surrounding mountains.  In the afternoon we visit
the Pisac ruins high on a mountain overlooking the
river.  At this finely preserved ancient ruin three
distinct styles of stonework exude mystery and majesty.
New parts of ruin have only recently been excavated.
     DAY 7, Mon, Nov 7:  Sacred Valley.  At Mori a
meteor crater which has been terraced by farmers forms
a natural amphitheater for ceremonies.  The Salt Mines
have always been holy to the Incas. Before enslavement
by the Spaniards they voluntarily worked one week a year there.
     DAY 8, Tues, Nov 8:  Train ride to Macchu Picchu.
Walk the stairstep Inca Trail to the top of Huayna
Picchu,  Young Man Mountain , which rises like a needle
over the sacred city of Macchu Picchu, the  Home of the
Gods .  We're at the Touristic Hotel tonight.
     DAY 9, Wed, Nov 9:  Hike a mile and a half along
the river to the Agua Caliente mineral springs in a
verdant canyon for a muscle soothing soak.  Depart on
the afternoon train for Cuzco, arriving at 7:30 PM.  The
Hotel Picoaga in Cuzco for four nights.
     DAY 10, Thurs, Nov l0:  In the morning we visit
the fortress of Sacsayhuaman - huge stones lining the
hilltop.  At the top, the Eye of the Puma, a complex
stone prayer circle, overlooks the valley.  Kenko, an
intricately carved boulder, offers magnificent vistas
above and a deeply feminine energy chamber in a cave
below.  The stone aqueducts and graceful waterfalls of
Tambomachay offer a peaceful site for a picnic lunch
with local friends.
     DAY 11, Fri, Nov 11: Raft trip (weather permitting
or free day in Cuzco if not).  Each bend of the river
opens breathtaking vistas on the Urubamba River, the
head waters of the Amazon.
     DAY 12, Sat, Nov l2:  Cuzco.  Visit cultural and
historical buildings of Cuzco by bus or wander through
the picturesque streets to the bazaar.
     DAY 13, Sun, Nov l3:  Fly to Puno on Lake
Titicaca.  Puno, known as the folkloric capital of Peru,
is home to the ancient tribe of Uros Indians.  Great
shopping in the colorful Puno bazaar.  Stay at the Puno
Touristic for two nights.
     DAY 24, Mon, Nov l4:  Day at Lake Titicaca.  The
sun shines brilliantly on the mystical lake.
     DAY 15, Tues, Nov l5:  Boat across Lake Titicaca,
stopping in Copacobana and Island of the Sun, home of
the Incan creation myth.  Landfall in Bolivia and take
the bus to La Paz to the Maria Meranda where we stay for
two nights.
     DAY 16, Wed, Nov l6:  Two hours by bus across the
rolling Altiplano (13,000 feet high) and we arrive at
Tiahuanaco the Temple of Veracocha, the Creator God,
where new souls come to incarnate on Earth.  Carved
stone heads representing human beings as well as beings
unknown to us line this vast and elegant temple complex.
     DAY 17, Thurs, Nov l7:  Fly from La Paz to Miami.
       Arrival time to be confirmed.

LAND PRICE: $2495
    ROUND TRIP AIR-FARE FROM MIAMI, $795
        ESTIMATED INLAND AIRFARE, $600
              $500 DEPOSIT

Upon receipt of your deposit, we will be send confirm-
ation and all travel particulars.

Little Rave Riding Hood-2(Humour)


I received more off-line mail about my Rave Riding Hood post than just about
any other  post. Will said he had seen version of Lattle Rat dating back to
the 40"s. I was given it in a Linguistics course which  I took in college and
  Raved it up a bit. for you. I understand there is a book which contains a
collection fo these, and if anyone knows of it, let me know. I use Rotten
Hut, as a teaser before I begin my Chaucer- Canterbury Tales lectures. For
those of you that enjoyed it, I suspect you that you read it out loud, which
I recommend.

(Part Deux)

 "Hoe Cake murder!!!  resplendent Ladle Rat Rotten Hut, end tickle ladle
basking an stuttered oft. Honor wrote tudor cordage offer groin murder, Ladle
Rave Rotten Hut mitten anomalous woof. 

 "Wail, Wail, Wail," set disk Wicket woof, "evanescent Ladle Rave Rotten Hut!
Wares or putty ladle rave gull goring wizard ladle basking?"
"armour goring tumor groin murders,"  reprisal ladle rave gull. "Grammers
seeking bet. Armour ticking arson burder barter end shirker pot cocklers."

 "O Hoe! Heifer blessing woke," setter wicket woof, Butter taught tomb shelf.
 "Oil tickle short court tudor cordage offer groin murder. Oil ketchup wetter
letter,  End-den,  O bowie!!  (end part deux)

robertj............Monterey

	id AA00458; Wed, 4 May 94 10:20:25 PDT

	id AA05039; Wed, 4 May 94 10:20:24 PDT
Received: from lizard.srv.PacBell.COM by pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA23421; Wed, 4 May 94 10:20:24 PDT
Date: Wed, 4 May 94 10:20:23 PDT
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9405041720.AA23421@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: asah@cs.berkeley.edu
Subject: Re: richly woven...
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Adam muses:
> In the past, I've met a number of people who I consider to lead 
> "richly woven" lives [...]  Some characteristics:
>   - fundamentally being relaxed about who they are, why they're doing what
>     they're doing, understanding the people around them (ie. being able to
>     talk/be comfortable with anyone), etc. - I'd say a spiritual contentment,

"Richness" is a relative thing.  If someone is *relaxed* with who they are,
and is spiritually *content*, it could be said that they have stalled out 
on the road to self-discovery/spirituality.  Even if someone feels that 
they are growing in a relaxed/contented way, it could be questioned 
whether much growth can really be taking place in the absence of 
challenge/struggle/doubt/frustration.  Does stagnation at one particular 
level of richness constitute a  "richly woven" life?  

>  - Presumably this enlightenment is process, not product.  Thus, a person
>    will be richly woven if s/he is "on a path", and if s/he slips off it,
>    so goes this enlightenment. 

I agree with this.  A person's "path" may simply be to find a "path", or
to explore a variety of paths.  Either way, some kind of change/discovery
is taking place.

>  Thus, I think it's a temporal thing, no?

I'm not sure that there's an absolute definition for a "richly woven" life.
Many apparently "rich" things in life may be devoid of meaning when viewed
from a different perspective.  I guess the richest life of all is one that
simultaneously experiences every aspect of the entire Universe - and such  
a life my not be possible in this world. 

>    What does this mean for this concept?

That each of us has to come up with our own definition of a "richly woven"
life, one that is probably based more on intuition and feeling than any
rational formula; a definition that may never be completely clear.

ObRave: Raving in and of itself doesn't seem as enriching as it used to be,
but it continues to provide me with leads toward the discovery of some
other new and enriching things.  
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com
____________________________________________________________________________

Subject: richly woven...
Reply-To: boccibob%groovy@us.oracle.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


i personally find that i really *like* lots and lots of change.  i
like to move to new places, i like making new friends, i like picking
up new hobbies.

i'd never claim to have a 'richly woven' life, but on the other hand,
the current working definition seems to preclude my ever even being
eligible :-)

i guess i'm sort of seconding Lee's comments.  the characteristics
seem sort of contemplative / static as opposed to experimental /
dynamic.  the words 'relaxed' and 'content' don't really seem to mesh
well with what Adam says later about the process being important.

hmmm.  interesting stuff, tho.
Bob


From sfraves-owner  Wed May  4 13:19:50 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA29696; Wed, 4 May 94 13:19:50 PDT
Received: from cc02du.unity.ncsu.edu by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA29687; Wed, 4 May 94 13:19:40 PDT

	id AA20278; Wed, 4 May 94 16:19:47 EDT
From: humphrey@unity.ncsu.edu
Message-Id: <9405042019.AA20278@cc02du.unity.ncsu.edu>
Subject: Re: richly woven
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU (sfraves)
Date: Wed, 4 May 1994 16:19:47 -0400 (EDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23b2/POP]
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 1285      
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

i often wonder if my life is following the right path. lately things seem 
to be going really well for me. i feel a lot more content with myself, 
sort of what could be described as an 'inner peace'. it's just that i 
feel so lost in the cosmic scope of things, i don't know wether i'm 
fooling myself into thinking i'm happy while i'm really suffering, or am 
i really doing something right and maybe life can be good, rich, and 
fulfilling. i've always thought of myself as being rich, though i never 
have any money, and am usually in debt. i don't know if having a lot of 
money is really that important at all as far as being rich goes. 
i love travelling, and seeing how poor some people can be such as those 
who live on the streets in jaipur, india, selling scraps of paper-trash 
that they have folded into origami type little toys and having a yearly 
cash flow of about a dollar, yet still be content and serene. are they 
poor? rich? it's all a matter of perspective. damn...lost track of my 
thoughts again....

From: Sun Kim <sunkim@mercury.sfsu.edu>
Subject: Re: richly woven...
To: SFRaves <sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU>
In-Reply-To: <9405041720.AA23421@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9405041345.A20160-0100000@mercury>
Mime-Version: 1.0

Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

On Wed, 4 May 1994, Lee Fogel wrote:

> ObRave: Raving in and of itself doesn't seem as enriching as it used to be,
> but it continues to provide me with leads toward the discovery of some
> other new and enriching things.  

I've only been raving for three months and I feel I've gotten a lot out 
of it.  When I went to my first rave in Februrary (Gathering) one of the 
first things that pleasantly surprised me was the openness that people 
seemed to have.  On a more specific level, I saw people smoking pot very 
openly in the chill-out room.  For months before then I was thinking, 
when will be somewhere were people are smoking pot and not making it seem 
dirty?  When in the dorm-rooms, my friends end up putting towels under 
the door.  Its all so secretive.  I felt so good knowing that there were 
places that I went where I didn't feel out of time and place.  What 
people were doing seemed so natural and carefree.  It wasn't so much the 
pot smoking itself but what it represented for me.  

One had the freedom to do what they wanted to do.  There was no judgement
on me or anyone.  (I'm sure there must be people who still judge but
that's the not overall feeling that I get.) By having this freedom to be,
I'm more at ease with who I am and less self-conscious about myself. 
Being in a supportive environment where people are non-judgemental, this
has helped me to be more honest and expressive with other people.  I was
very intimidated before to hug or kiss male friends but I feel its much
easier to do now. 

Listening to the music and being around ravers has given me a different 
perspective about my desires in life.  It definately has given me a 
bigger area to examine than before.  New areas to explore...



From sfraves-owner  Wed May  4 14:19:26 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA01117; Wed, 4 May 94 14:19:26 PDT
Received: from bethe.ucdavis.edu by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA01106; Wed, 4 May 94 14:19:18 PDT
Received: by bethe.ucdavis.edu (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA28752; Wed, 4 May 94 14:19:33 PDT
Date: Wed, 4 May 94 14:19:33 PDT
From: alves@bethe.ucdavis.edu (David Alves)
Message-Id: <9405042119.AA28752@bethe.ucdavis.edu>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: richly woven...
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


I don't see anything wrong with taking a good job.  You had a choice
about school or work.  IMO, grad school better be for personal
enrichment not for a better job.  

I don't think either choice should affect your "path of happiness"

Most of your richness laundry list sounds like self-confidence and maturity. 
I have met *many* immature grad students and PhD's. 
It isn't easy (or pleasant) to deal with someone who has loads of
self-confidence but lacks the maturity to temper it.

How does *anyone* learn to love themselves and not be an asshole to others?

>    Ever notice how phd's tend to think they know more than
>    they do about areas outside their field?

Hell yes.
This often bugs my wife.  I try and be more understanding of their
social shortcomings.  It has a lot to do with the way you are required
to present yourself in academia.  You speak with certainty and 
expect to be called on it.  This pattern doesn't always translate well into
other parts of life.  It is a pattern of communication found in lots of
places (not just school) but it is particularly pervasive there.

> - Do you know people who you feel are like this?  (richly woven)

I think so. 
I don't see anything wrong with viewing others as role
models - but there is a limit to the usefulness of this.  You need
look at yourself.  You make yourself every moment of the day.

> - How smart do you have to be to be richly woven?  

Not very smart - at least in a book/school sense.
Are there "richly woven" high school dropouts?
I would say yes.

> - Where do psychoactives fit in?  

Maybe there isn't fear of them.  Occasional entertainment?

> - It seems clear that part of the path is just experience 
> - Presumably this enlightenment is process, not product.  

Life is not just external stimulation.  
Any enlightenment I think I have I try and appreciate *now*.  
These insights have changed almost constantly in my life.

I don't think pursuit of an enlightened state should be all consuming
nor do I think it should be totally neglected.  It seems to come in
waves for me.  There have been periods of my life where I spent more
or less time on my personal philosophy-of-happiness.

The fact that you are in school means you will be busy, poor, and
trapped in one geographical area.  This in no way limits the stuff
you can "experience".   

I think the posts about being static have a valid point.  Are you 
implying that there is some plateau you want to reach?
I didn't interpret what you said in this way.

All I can suggest is that feeling comfortable with the idea of
being on an everchanging path may come with time.  And may just as
easily be ripped to shreds at a later time.  This idea of comfort
or being richly woven is transient but valid.  Am I making sense?

You are talking about the fundamentals of religion, spirituality, and
philosophy.  This is above all else a very individual and personal
struggle.

>peace not piece
>adam

peace to you,
Dave

From X Wed May  4 08:57:50 MST 1994
Article: 40779 of sci.space
From: baalke@kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov (Ron Baalke)
Newsgroups: sci.space,sci.astro,sci.space.shuttle,alt.sci.planetary
Subject: Space Calendar - 04/30/94
Date: 30 Apr 1994 16:47 UT
Organization: Jet Propulsion Laboratory
Lines: 159

NNTP-Posting-Host: kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov

Content-Length: 7262

     The Space Calendar is compiled by Ron Baalke and covers space-related
activities and anniversaries for the coming year.  The latest copy of the
calendar is available at explorer.arc.nasa.gov as pub/SPACE/FAQ/space.calendar.
Please send any updates or corrections to Ron Baalke
(baalke@kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov).  Note that anniversary dates are listed in
5 year increments only, and launch dates are subject to change.

     The following person have contributed to this month's calendar:

     o Art McClinton - NOAA-J Launch is now 9/28/94.

                          =========================
                               SPACE CALENDAR
                               April 30, 1994
                          =========================

* indicates changes from last month's calendar

May 1994
  May ?? - Soyuz TM-19 Launch (Russian)
  May ?? - TOMS Pegasus Launch
  May 01 - 45th Anniversary (1949), Kuiper's Discovery of Nereid (Neptune Moon)
  May 03 - DSPSE (Clementine) Lunar Orbit Departure
  May 03-4 - Eta Aquarids Meteor Shower
  May 04 - 5th Anniversary (1989), Magellan Launch (Venus Orbiter)
  May 06 - DSPSE (Clementine), 3rd Earth Flyby
* May 06 - MSTI-2 Scout Launch
  May 10 - Annular Eclipse, Visible from Mexico, USA, Canada
  May 18 - 25th Anniversary (1969), Apollo 10 Launch
* May 20 - Resurs Launch (Russian)
  May 24-25 - Partial Lunar Eclipse
  May 25 - DSPSE (Clementine), 4th Earth Flyby
  May 27 - DSPSE (Clementine), Lunar Flyby
* May 29 - 20th Anniversary (1970), Luna 22 Launch (Russian Moon Orbiter)

At 10:20 AM 5/4/94 PDT, Lee Fogel wrote:
>"Richness" is a relative thing.  If someone is *relaxed* with who they are,
>and is spiritually *content*, it could be said that they have stalled out 
>on the road to self-discovery/spirituality.  Even if someone feels that 
>they are growing in a relaxed/contented way, it could be questioned 
>whether much growth can really be taking place in the absence of 
>challenge/struggle/doubt/frustration.  Does stagnation at one particular 
>level of richness constitute a  "richly woven" life?  

I'm content to be challenged, as long as there is some possiblity of meeting
the challenge.

Frustration happens to me when I'm not making any progress.  I don't think
there is any virtue in becoming frustrated, spinning ones wheels may register
on the speedometer but it doesn't get you anywhere, in fact it digs you in
where you are.
                         &andy
                         KC1IP/6
                         the tie-dyed side of the force

Hi Everyone...

Sorry for the crosspost.  For safety's sake, be sure you are replying to me
and not to the world if you reply to this.

I've started a Summer Meet-While list.  It's an informal list of ravers.  
It purpose is to find and connect with people in territories of the 
nation you may find yourself in over this summer.

This will be the ONLY post about this.  Save this email!!!

For example, if someone was traveling through the large Delta hub at the 
Cincy airport, they could take the Meet While list, find my name, contact
me, and ask me about stuff, maybe an event, or anything.  

So how do you participate on this list?  It's quite easy.  Send me an
email message with a subject line of one of the following:

    #help    -  gets a simple help file
    #form    -  gets the form to follow for inclusion on the list
    #add     -  puts the form you got in a special mailbox for me to add to
                the list at a later date
    #summer  -  retrieves a current copy of the list


So, in a nutshell::

  1)  #form   (get the form and fill it out)
  2)  #add    (send it back to me)
  3)  #summer (get a copy of the list AT ANY TIME!)
  

Naturally, with a working list like this, if you get the list now vs. one 
week from now, it will be different.  I suggest getting a copy of the 
list as late as possible.

I'd also suggest keeping this message.

Please bounce this message around to your amigos who may not be on any 
rave lists due to email volume, but who may want to meet people over the 
summer.

Good luck on finals for those taking them.  Peace...



Andrew
-- 

(c) 1994, Andrew Bennett                     abennett@phoenix.aps.muohio.edu

Subject: Re: richly woven...
To: David Alves <alves@bethe.ucdavis.edu>
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
In-Reply-To: <9405042119.AA28752@bethe.ucdavis.edu>

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

For me, a richly woven life contains all facets of health, including 
mental, physical, spiritual, psychological, social, etc.  One should be 
moving forward in all areas of health in order to be a richly woven person.
     Moving forward is not the absence of strife, nor the presence of 
peace.  It is a state of being in which one assesses ones goals and 
measures current situations and opportunities against these goals.  This 
awareness enables one to make decisions that will promote ones goal, but 
will not violate one's personal code of ethics.  
    Moving forward allows for personal setbacks, errors in judgement and 
forgiveness of self and others for violations against the self.
    It is complete open-mindedness, honesty and willingness.
    
     On a daily basis I ask myself, "What have I done for my health 
today?"  I exercise, read, attend spiritual meetings, go to my therapist 
(ok, who doesn't have one by now?), go out dancing to raves, etc.   If I 
have made an effort in these areas to reach my goal then I have had a 
successful day.  It is irrelevant whether I had a good work day, whether 
I made a lot of money, whether I impressed people, etc.  I measure myself 
against myself.

     That's my view of richly woven life, and according to my own 
subjective view of it, I live it every day.
     By no means am I perfect, but I don't want to be.  If I reach my 
goals, then I need to evaluate where I am heading.  Something is awry.
 
     Life is a journey.  Enjoy each moment.
Tanya

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Wed, 04 May 1994 13:51:10 -0700 (MST)
From:IEAJS@asuvm.inre.asu.edu
To: perform-l@ACFcluster.NYU.EDU
Subject: Re: Music Yes

Let me add a few things to the discussion of music.
       1) Music/Sound is integrated into social practice.  There are no
societies without music, the body makes sounds (I'm including the voice).
       2) A discussion of music, perhaps moreso than of theater or dance,
should begin with reception, since, as Cage pointed out, the ears are always
open. The maker of music/sound is also the first receiver. Schechner suggests
that music is about rhythm/time. Abstractly, yes, but it is more about space/
body/position, since hearing situates one in relation to sound that is not, as
by the eyes, obligated to the gaze.
        3) recording and amplification are forms of representation that have
encoded performance away (far away) from the body and music/sound as energetic
systems.
        4) about this last point: music/noise/sound have a physical properties
that bodies in motion don't have.  Instruments are technologies.  The dialogics
of musical performance involve sound waves moving among persons.  This creates
another modality of performance, where the air is the mise en scene (pieces by
Alvin Lucier exemplify this beautifully).
        5) Back to # 1 - the social value and uses of music predominate over
the aesthetic.  Why else are those Striesand tickets so high; or, does anyone
really think another Rolling Stones tour will adds to the art of rock?
     Just mus-ing.
                  Sabatini

Subject: ComeUnity - LOVE & the struggle for collective transformation
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Cc: willis@husc.harvard.edu, jeremias@mit.edu, mpesce@netcom.com

I just got a job a Silent Records and wanted to go dance and celebrate
At Come/Unity but the cops busted it right after i got there. I was 
bummed, I really needed to dance. Oh well guess I have to go to 
SPAZ/YSH/Food Not Bombs.

Despite my disappointment I felt somewhat consoled by the friends and 
familiar faces. The rave community really has something special to it but 
we must continually be aware that we need to engage a broad range of issues
so that we can allow ourselves and others to unfold into new and more 
compassionate modes of being and becoming.

We must search for understanding and insight. We can do this by knowing 
how we know and using this knowledge of knowledge to guide our actions.

"What biology shows us is that the uniqueness of being human lies 
exclusively in a social strutural coupling that occurs through languaging...
Biology also shows us that we can expand our coginitive domain. This 
arises through a novel experience brought forth by reasoning, through the 
encounter with a stranger, or, more directly, through the expression of a 
biological interpersonal congruence that lets us see the other person and 
open up for hir room for existence beside us. This act is called LOVE, or 
,if we prefer a milder expression, the acceptance of the other person 
beside us in our daily living. This is the biological foundation of 
social phenomena: without love, without acceptance of others living beside 
us, there is no social process nd , therefore, no humanness. Anything 
that undermines the acceptance of others, from competency to the 
possesion of truth and on to ideologic certainty, undermines the social 
process that generates it. Let us not deceive ourselves: we are not 
moralizing, we re not preaching love. We are only revealing the fact that 
,biologically , without love, without acceptance of others, there is no 
social phenomenom. If we still live together that way, we are living 
indifference and negation under a pretense of love.
     The knowledge of knowledge compels. It compels us to adopt an 
attitude of permanent vigilance against the temptation of certainty. It 
compels us to realize that the world everyone sees is not *the* world 
but *a* world which we bring forth with others. I t compels us to see that the 
world will be different only if WE LIVE DIFFERENTLY. It compels us 
because, when we know that we know, we cannot deny (to ourselves or to 
oothers) that we know. 
     We have only the world that we bring forth with others, and only 
love helps us bring it forth"

--Humberto Maturana and Francisco Varela, _The Tree Of Knowledge:The 
Biological Roots of Human Understanding_

..........................................................................

From "This month at Barnes & Noble"...

	In "Cyberia: Life in the Trenches" of Hyperspace, author Douglas 
	Rushkoff explores and explains the world of technology, from 
	virtual reality, computer hackers, and technoshamen, to raves,
	smart drugs, and more. An "Electric Kool-Aid Acid Test" for the
	90's, "Cyberia" explores this fluorishing social network, the 
	cutting edge of culture most likely to be found where one least
	expects it -- Silicon Valley. Visit the trenches (in our own
	backyard) with the author of "Cyberia".

And from the book... 

The beginning...
	
	"Are we in the bowl yet?" the boy asks, feeling the first effect
	of the drug.
	  "I think so," answers his friend, also a sophomore at U.C Berke-
	ley, who punches a few keys on his computer, releasing a brilliant
	paisley landscape onto the monitor. "We're over the event horizon.
	Now it's just a matter of timer."
	  The questioner panics. "So we're in it, then ? We're in the at-
	tractor?"
	  "Are you talking about the acid, the computer, or the universe?"
	  A pause. The swirling computer-generated pictures are reflected
	in the boys' eyes. "All of 'em, I guess."
	  "I grok," agrees the operator.
	  Two college students at three in the morning, tripping on the
	drug Ecstasy as they create fractal images on a computer in their
	dorm room. Their topic of conversation? The end of our dimension,
	of course.

And the end...

	But maybe this is the real Cyberia. It's not tackling complex com-
	puter problems, absorbing new psychedelic substances, or living
	through designer shamanic journeys. It's not learning the terminol-
	ogy of media viruses, chaos math, or house music. It's figuring out
	how two people can sell smart drugs in the same town without
	driving each other crazy. It's learning how to match the intentions
	of Silicon Valley's most prosperous corporations with the values of
	the psychedelics users who've made them that way. It's turning a
	nightclub into the modern equivalent of a Mayan temple without
	getting busted by the police. It's checking your bank statement to
	see if your ATM has been cracked, and figuring out how to punish
	the kid who did it without turning him into an hardened criminal. It's
	not getting too annoyed by the agendas of people who say they
	have none, or by the inane, empty platitudes of those who say they
	do. It's learning to package the truth about our culture into media-
	friendly, bite-size pieces, and then finding an editor willing to put
	them in print because they strike him as amusing.
	  Coping in Cyberia means using our currently limited human lan-
	guage, bodies, emotions, and social realities to usher in something
	that's supposed to be free of those limitations. Things like virtual
	reality, smart bars, hypertext, the WELL, role-playing games, DMT,
	Ecstasy, house, fractals, sampling, anti-Muzak, technoshamanism,
	ecoterrorism, morphogenesis, video cyborgs, Toon Town, and
	Mondo 2000 are what slowly pull our society--even our world--
	past the event horizon of the great attractor at the end of the time.
	But just like these, the next earth-shattering mem to hit the news-
	stands or computer net my be the result of a failed relationship, a
	drug bust, an abortion on acid, or even a piss over the side of the
	porch.
	  Cyberia is frightening to everyone. Not just to technophobes, rich
	businessman, midwestern farmers, and suburban housewives, but,
	most of all, to the boys and girl hoping to ride the crest of the in-
	formational wave.
	  Surf's up.

	ComeUnity was going off as planned Garth had finished his set when I
	got there and Simon was getting into it.  It was nice to see a lot
	of "old skool" and everyone was having a great time, that's why
	It was such a bummer when the SFPD literally pulled the plug on
	1015 at 4:30 a.m. One Half hour into Jeno's set.  The police literally
	came in, unscrewed, and TOOK the master house mixer from the back
	room.  This folks is a very dangerous precident, it basically means
	that the police are going to play hardball when it come to the Scene
	they don't care about what is right, the Law, or federal judges, they
	have guns and we don't and furthermore who can we call to protect us
	from them? IF SFPD thinks that this will stop the Scene, they are saddly
	mistaken, all it will accomplish is driving the parties further 
	underground, IT WILL NOT STOP ANYTHING!  I hope they don't have to 
	learn the lesson the NYPD learned when they used the same tactics,
	eventually a lot of people died in an unsafe underground site.

	Let not let this happen here.

stuff happening lately.  Special events this weekend are the

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------- UPCOMING RAVES IN THE SF/BAY AREA ---------------------
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Thursday, May 5th - Your Sisters' House & SPAZ: Food Not Bombs Benefit
        Live performances by Ken Machines & the Machine Elves from Hyperspace
        Planet Six.  Music for Peace by the Liquid Concrete Air Band

In-Reply-To: <199405052017.NAA05996@netcom.com>; from "Raffaele Sena" at May 5, 94 1:17 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL0]
Message-Id:  <9405051352.aa04904@cruzio.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Doug Rushkoff's Cyberia does touch on raves, particularly
that halcyon time of ToonTown, Mark, Diana, Earth Girl and
then Chris. I've met Doug, used his previous book, How to
Get High Without Drugs, successfully with students, and had
good chats with him at Island Group meetings when he visited
Santa Cruz.

I like the way Cyberia interweaves its themes and its stories
of cyberculture in Northern California.  To my knowledge, this
is the first book of its sort.  One might even say its richly
woven...the devil made me say that! Fie!  Fie!

Enjoy...I did,
Will

-- 
Will Penna               408.423 8907

On Apr 29,  9:40am, you proclaimed:
} Just curious, was the letter ever sent?  If it was sent, was there a 
} response?

Nope... after talking with a few SC locals, we were convinced of the
inefficacy of sending a letter like we had wanted.  They are more
interested in seeing action instead of words, so as sometime in the
next few weeks I'd like to go down and do a beach cleanup - maybe
even make it a regular thing, with or without music.  

	Brian

> Subject: Micropower Broadcasting Workshop in SF

FRB?  anyone know what kind of broadcasting power these kits have?

questions would help me make up my mind.  i've been thinking about
picking up an FM-10 kit for a while, if the FRB kit is better and/or i
can learn something about improving broadcast range of the FM-10, the
class will be well worth the time.

Bob

Hi.  This is really long and it was already posted to alt.rave.

However, I enjoyed it.  I know I sometimes get cynical about raves and
ravers, and I know other people sometimes fall into that too, so I
thought I'd post this as a gentle reminder.  The author has been one
of my dearest friends for many years.

(Some of you may recall that for the last year or so, every time I'm
about to fly to Illinois I always looked around desperately for a
certain substance because I had this friend who I thought would
appreciate it.  This is said friend, and as you'll see, he got along
just fine without me.)

If you have any response to this, you may want to send it to the
address below but also cc: a copy to me because David may have to
leave the net soon.  I'll make sure he gets a copy.

stevie

Forwarded message:
> From moo5@midway.uchicago.edu Thu May  5 16:16:28 PDT 1994
> Article: 25175 of alt.rave
> Path: agate!howland.reston.ans.net!vixen.cso.uiuc.edu!David.Fruchter
> From: moo5@midway.uchicago.edu (David Fruchter)
> Newsgroups: alt.rave
> Subject: FURTHER report
> Date: 5 May 1994 21:07:57 GMT
> Organization: University of Illinois at Urbana
> Lines: 211
> Message-ID: <2qbn7d$7j9@vixen.cso.uiuc.edu>
> NNTP-Posting-Host: ug-mac13.cso.uiuc.edu
> X-Posted-From: InterNews 1.0@vixen.cso.uiuc.edu.
> Xdisclaimer: No attempt was made to authenticate the sender's name.
> 
> I'm writing this to everyone at alt.rave.  The chance to talk 
> to _thousands_of_people_at_once_ who UNDERSTAND, who've BEEN 
> THERE.  Oh my.  Fantastic.  Delicious.  I'm currently propped 
> up against a speaker at Further, in the _fast_ tent.  I'm on 
> *X*, and it's my first time.  I'd tripped at a rave once 
> before, and it was definitely incredible (it was in downtown 
> Chicago last summer, at Hubbard Street over this weird 
> restaurant), and I had one of the best times I'd ever had.  I 
> was telling people the legend of the Chockabarton (Cakkavali) 
> King, which I'll relate below.  On retrospect, I am thinking 
> of acid as something I might do every once in a while at a 
> rave.  For variety.  If I couldn't get any X.  [Or with it--
> WOW!]  I have to thank the kind brother who hooked me up, and 
> the one who sold me the lil' pill.  I was the Smartie Man 
> (some of you will know what that means.)  I was a bit nervous 
> about asking, but I never will be again.  People who _know_ 
> will be more than happy to hook up a kind brother.  I know I 
> would.  It's not like a Dead show or a Phish show that way at 
> all, at least since the first 10 or so I've seen of each (I'm 
> 23 -- just turned it -- my brithday's April 23, and 23 has 
> been a magic number for me for YEARS -- reference Robert Anton 
> Wilson, the Illuminatus Trilogy, Cosmic Trigger and all the 
> other fantastic gifts he's laid on the populace.  If someone 
> forwards or reads you this message, thanks, Bob!)  When I was 
> 14, freshman in a high school that only had 41 students, 11 in 
> my class, which was actually very very cool, lots of 
> community, really helped build my social skills after a 
> miserable alone bitter intellectual junior high including 
> three 8th grades and not even one 8th grade graduation, tho I 
> had skipped to go on a road trip with my mom and my brother 
> (who are two of my very best friends--in fact, I've just 
> realized I must X with each of them) up through Canada, hit 
> the Falls, and down through Boston and Mystic Connecticut, 
> very hip town, the whole trip was infinitely superior to some 
> stupid empty ritual like 8th grade graduation, I like my 
> rituals FULL), anyway that teensy high school in Westfield IL 
> (town of some 841) was great, even I, who am the furthest 
> thing from a jock that you'd ever want to meet (tho I do like 
> a bit of B'ball with the boys, we play Texas style, no fouls 
> called, the body contact with your best buds is the best, you 
> sadly, terribly, horribly don't get near enough of that in 
> "normal" friend-type situations, shit, any situation, everyone 
> in the _WORLD_ should take X, anyway, I like racquetball too 
> (it's _fast_) (and of course, there's DANCING) but I'm not any 
> kind of jock (non sequiter interruption: Steve Collins, my 
> brother, we WILL rave together someday), what a great high 
> school that was (my thoughts are _way_ outracing this pen 
> _damn_ I wish I had a computer, it's obvious I'm going to have 
> to buy a laptop just to take to raves, oh man, a color Mac 
> with trip graphics or video games (Maelstrom! Smile! screen 
> savers) as you're leaning up against a speaker, can you 
> imagine), but I keep losing Westfield High, where I (tho no 
> jock, as I may have mentioned) was on the baseball team, 
> manager of the basketball team, and water boy for the girls 
> volleyball team, and wasn't _that_ an exercise in pubescent 
> titillation, and everyone in the school was involved in the 
> Spring Musical (literally).  But back to R.A.Wilson, when I 
> was 14 and a freshman, I got to cruise around with the seniors 
> (that's how small it was), and my mom had a reporter/DJ pal 
> who was late-20's and took an interest in me, I think he 
> must've figured out that I was an intellectual explorer from 
> early on, I mean, I didn't do Acid until I was 19, but I 
> remember being totally enthusiastic and curious and eager 
> about psychedelics probably since I first heard about 'em when 
> I was 10 or so, right away I thought it was a great idea) 
> anyway this guy gives 14-year-old small-town freshman me a 
> copy of Wilson's Illuminatus trilogy, along with Bukowski's 
> Playing the Piano Drunk Like A Percussion Instrument Until The 
> Fingers Begin to Bleed a Bit.  That kicked my then-SF Fanboy 
> ass into high gear and another plane, I tell you.  I think 
> those gifts have shaped a lot of what I am today.  I'm done 
> with the RAW part of this, but I feel like mentioning one more 
> thing about  W'Field High, which is that I wish I had made 
> close friends with some people at the time I was there, cuz 
> they were really decent to me.
> 
> I feel like I need to pass on this word of advice to you 
> people who probably know it better than anybody:  never pass 
> up an opportunity to make a friend.  I feel like I've made a 
> lot of friends tonight.  I may not know their names when I run 
> into them at the next party, but I'll know 'em -- and they'll 
> be my friends.  It's amazingly easy for me to make friends at 
> raves, Shows, and other places of openness (isolation tanks); 
> you just be really open, very open, _wide_ open, and people 
> can tell so often right away that you're genuine, that you'd 
> never wish them any harm for any reason.  To Steve Collins 
> again:  you were so right when we discussed this last time you 
> were in C-U.  I'm definitely helping clean this place up when 
> it's all over and done.  That's the LEAST I can do, the $20 
> NOTwithstanding.  BTW, if any of the FURTHER organizers happen 
> to read this account in whatever fashion, including 
> telepathically, I love you guys.  It's all about love -- 
> enough said.  I have a dream of someday getting to know the 
> folx that put on these events, at least the Chicagoland 
> contingent.              Which gives us a quick twirl 
> back towards friendship.  Even though I was progressively 
> learning social behaviors through my friendship year at 
> Westfield, I hadn't learned enoough to be able to really 
> _cement_ a friendship, and I really regret that, not in small 
> part because having a friend or two through the 3 or 4 years 
> which followed like I have friends now would have made them a 
> lot easier, less depressing, and damn sure more fun, but I was 
> too busy being cynical -- what the fuck was that about, I 
> didn't even know anything about the shitty parts of life, I 
> had never paid a bill and I was always fed regularly, 
> _without_having_to_work_, a sweet deal any way you look at it 
> except the way I did.  [Two non-sequiters here:  Aaron 
> Stigberg, I saw your name in a minimag so I know you're still in 
> the scene, I hope we can party together sometime, I'd like to
> hear your/CHA tunefulnesses, I'm Dave from PS and Hyde Park.
> Secondly: everybody who can, visit the 
> isolation tanks in Chicago sometime.  Call SpaceTime Tanks at 
> (312) 472-2700.  I'm in no way affiliated, etc., etc.]  Back 
> to making friends: very few people, especially those who go to 
> RAVES or shows or state parks but most places outside big 
> cities too (on the other hand, if there had been no urban 
> Sprawl probably there would have been no techno and the drugs 
> wouldn't be _nearly_ as good), very few would even _know_how_ 
> to reject someone who truly, genuinely, openly offered them 
> friendship or a gesture thereof, even if they wanted to, 
> because it's such a rarity.  When I make my overtures (which 
> can include giving away little things like Smarties, telling 
> stories, dropping phrases in people's ears as I pass, touching 
> if it seems ok, just trying to give back the scene the 
> slightest pico-femto-fraction of what it's given me, 
> spiritually, hedonistically, philosophically--I'm going to a 
> _lot_ of raves from now on) with strangers at all the various 
> Scenes I mentioned above (raves, shows, etc.) I rarely get 
> anything but smiles and better.  Outside the Scene it's the 
> same, though, it really is.  TRY it -- the worst that could 
> happen is you'll end up confusing somebody, and if that is 
> their reaction they probably need a dose of just that kind of 
> confusion.  Even if you're working in some slave wager job, 
> even if you're whoring your mind white-collar for the Man 
> because you've got to be able to pay for THIS, you can still 
> touch the people you work with, the people _around_you_, 
> because we've all got the Life-Force in us, and the people who 
> need a glimpse of yours the most are just the ones who've 
> armored it the heaviest, who've trapped themselves inside the 
> most layers of propriety, society, and neurotica, I'm not 
> saying necessarily to _freek_ these folx (tho its worked 
> wonders for some) but kindness and honesty breed more of the 
> same, love will out, and sure that's cliche and sure everybody 
> (at least all of _us_ who rave, right?) knows it but raves 
> always remind me that it's true, especially this one, and this 
> implies that between times I'm getting way too caught up in 
> _relatively_ -- in the best sense of the word -- unimportant 
> SHIT, and I'm forgetting, and I think the same thing might 
> happen to some of y'all upon occasion, well this is your 
> reminder for the day from FURTHER, David Moses Fruchter 
> reporting.
> 
> PS:  I couldn't but help think, as I'm sure some of you have, 
> how perfect the words "rave" and "ecstasy" are to describe the 
> matrix of experiences they tag.  Say "ecstasy", feel the 
> phonemes glide off your tongue, 
> sultrysexysensuousslickeryslide, with that hint of a velar "k" 
> sound to represent the one moment of anticipation right before 
> you know you're going to _get_there_, and then you find the 
> anticipation itself tingling up and down your spine and face 
> and hands and then it becomes IT, you're there, and you know 
> that much much later when you foolishly but inevitably try to 
> compartmentalize the whole experience and make sense of it and 
> relate it to others of its kind and not, even to such a 
> shallow level as "which rave/show/road trip was better", you 
> know you'll have to drop it in the slot where you keep the 
> Others, the few but growing number of experiences which are 
> far too good to rate, which defy words (tho some of us give it 
> a shot, a knowingly doomed venture that still feels really 
> good), which are the ones where you "decide" to look up your 
> old books on Gnosticism and mushroom cults afterwards, direct 
> experience of the divine through altered consciousness (you 
> don't need drugs, dance does it too and does it UP, but drugs 
> don't hurt any, anyway,) and you KNOW you're loving life.  To 
> give you a glimpse of how far I'd fallen since my last rave I 
> was actually considering not coming here this weekend because 
> of the WEATHER, what was UP with that shit, luckily I have my 
> lovely friend/tour brother/fellow raver Richard Dunham (who as 
> a Recoverer doesn't use but still _gets_There_, no question 
> about it) to NOT let me pull any shit that would have been 
> THAT mindblowingly stupid.  Long PS, I know, but the stuff was 
> in me, and it had to come out.  Love.
> 
> The Legend of the Chockabarton King
> 
> In the season of the seventh moon, when the Gem Wheel has 
> risen from the Eastern Ocean, then will the Chockabarton King 
> mount his magic elephant and lead his people from the sixth 
> heaven, where you have merely to wish for the object of your 
> heart's desire and it will appear before you, to the seventh 
> heaven, where you don't even have to wish.
> 
> One more thing I'd like to share with y'all, for those who 
> have made it this far, like a special reward for perseverence.  
> It's the Hand of Delight, and it was created by the Universe 
> through Mark "T" Armantrout and I on a blazing hot and well-
> dosed summer day at the beautiful sculpture garden/nature 
> preserve Allerton Park in Monticello, IL.  Here you go:
> 
> Thumb:	WATER
> 
> Index Finger:	Light and Color
> 
> Middle Finger:		Language
> 
> Ring Finger:	Sound and Music
> 
> Pinky:	MAGIC
> 
> I wish you all every bit of the delight that I'm feeling right 
> now, and I could hardly imagine more.  --David
> 
>

Parties in all shapes and sizes again; there seems to be a lot of
stuff happening lately.  Special events this weekend are the 
Food Not Bombs benefit tonight and the Bulletproof boat party.
In other news, SPAZ moves to Fridays, and get ready for the next
Blue Cube party 8)...

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------- UPCOMING RAVES IN THE SF/BAY AREA ---------------------
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Thursday, May 5th - Your Sisters' House & SPAZ: Food Not Bombs Benefit
        Live performances by Ken Machines & the Machine Elves from Hyperspace
        Planet Six.  Music for Peace by the Liquid Concrete Air Band
        DJs DRC, Pollywog, Synthesis, Spliffmeister J.
        Cesar's Latin Palace, Mission @ Army, SF
        $5-$10, 9pm-? 415.SOLS.666

Friday, May 6th - Sound Factory
        live performance by the Fog.  
        DJs Super DJ Dmitry, Pete Avila, Aaron O.
        Djs Scott de Castro & Safar in the red room
        9:30pm-7am, 21+, 525 Harrison @ 1st.  415.543.1300.  

Friday, May 6th - Earth House Hold
        $5, 10pm.  415-267-6193

Friday, May 6th - ZenDada
        DJ's Taj & Markie Mark
        basement of 1015 Folsom 
        Midnite-7am  $10

Saturday, May 7th - Beltane Wicked
        Jeno  Garth  Markie  Thomas
        415.512.5713

Saturday, May 7th - Rush
        Ghost  Simon  Carlos  Bones  Jaz  Christophe
        415.487.7471

Saturday, May 7th - M&M
        DJ's Demi God, Ben, Plez, Greg G
        (415) 435-7559  (916) 854-1042

Saturday, May 7th - outdoor underground in Santa Cruz
        DJ's will probably be wool, drew, james(me:) + others.  
        Come join us.  All are welcome.  415.292.3289

Sunday, May 8th - Bulletproof Boat Party
        up top: Kirk, Alex, Josh
        below decks: Gerry V, Thomas, Ron
        Advance tickets from Bulletproof, 829 Haight.  Info 255.7168
        6-10pm.  After-party and buffet included.

Thursday, May 12th - Flour
        Dani & Mark Farina
        Deco, 510 Larkin @ Turk.  21+. 441.4007.
        (will be every other Thursday)

Saturday, May 14 - SFR Blue Cube Party
        DJs: Meme, Laura, Lee, Will, Ethan
        for info/directions email resonate@netcom.com w/subject line: INFO

Saturday, May 14th - Fundamental
        Spun  Josh  DJ Dan  Ernie Munson  Rick Preston
        Visuals by Donovan, Pure, Ken Stone
        $10, 18+ w/id.  415.487.4339  415.486.9400

        Markie Mark  Garth  Josh  Tony  Doran & guests
        415.267.4800

Thursday, May 19th - Soul Purpose/Acid Jazz
        Brass Recording Artist Lalomie Washburn
        Music by Mark Farina, Marques Wyatt, Kevin of Stone Groove & Stu P.
        at the Sound Factory, 525 Harrison.

Friday, May 20th - Test 2
        live acid trance, ambient room and
        hard trance w/Ethan, Mac, Shobhan and Alex
        415.395.8380

Saturday, May 21st - Launch Pad II

Saturday, May 28th - SFRaves presents In The Light
         ->Get Infected by Meme -> 
         ->Trance out with Laura ->
         ->Take an Acid House Bath with Markie->
         Audio by SoundVision - Three Turntables
        noon to 6pm at the bandshell, Golden Gate Park.

        415.266.8215    415.241.8815

        415.512.5713

Here are some weeklies, in the house/techno/acid jazz/etc vein.  Some
of them may have ended - let me know when that happens...

---------------------------- T h u r s d a y --------------------------------

Your Sisters' House - 9pm discussion - 10pm-4am funkygrooves - 415-435-7575
Universal Groove - $5. 415.281.5913  510.869.2727
Ajax Lounge - Acid Jazz w/Julius Papp (San Jose)
Lift - Digit, EFX, & guests - $5, 21+, 55 Natoma, SF - 415.267.5984
Inspirations - 364 S Market St, San Jose (back of Dimensions).  
        9pm-2am, 18+, $5.  408.236.2102  415.267.6974
        [5/5 - Anton, Robbie & Scott Hardkiss. Ambience by Gavin Hardkiss
                and Shawn Cooper]
        [5/12 - Ryan Tapia, Simon, Markie.  Ambience by Adam Douglass
                and Thad Jones] 
        [5/19 - Liquid, Jeff Taylor, Jon Drukman.  Ambience by T2K 
                and Chris Trance]
Pure Space - 10pm-4am, 21+, $5. DNA Lounge, 375 11th @ Harrison. 415.267.0640
        [05.05 (Cinco de Mayo) - Carlos Locos, Jalapeno Jeno, El Spun]
Shake Yo Buddha - acid jazz, rare groove, hip-hop, soul, funk, reggae.  
        369 S 1st St, San Jose.  9:30pm-2am. 21+, $5.  408.236.3787
        [5/5 - Tai, Michael Persons, Peanut Butter Wolfe]
        [5/12 - Ryan Tapia, Dave Galvez, Harry Who]
        [5/19 - Ryan Tapia, Julius, Mark Farina]
Flour - Dani & Mark Farina - Deco, 510 Larkin @ Turk.  21+. 441.4007.
        (every other Thursday, next one 5/12)

        DJs Charlotte (the Baroness) & guests

--------------------------- W e d n e s d a y -------------------------------

Motion - 400 S 1st St, SJ (side entrance of F/X). 21+.  408-236-3732
Fixx - Jan Cooley, Phillip, Aaron, Neon Leon.  Cocktails, 9th & Howard.
Stone Groove - acid jazz n' cosmic funk.  presented by Bulletproof.
        $3, 21+, 9pm-2am.  Miss Pearl's, 601 Eddy @ Larkin.  415.255.7168.
        [April DJs - Mark Farina, Gavan, Dani, Alex, Kevin, Gerry V, Kirk,
                     Andrew (Groove Merchant), Harry Who]
Recycle - every other Weds w/Carlos, Dutch, Christophe & guests. 415.599.3750
Pacific - 683 Clementina @ 8th (between Folsom & Howard) - 
        Starts at 10pm, $5.  415.985.5264
Gemini - josh, spun, donald glaude, la paix, rick preston, dj dan,
        carlos & dutch.  415.979.4915

------------------------------- Info Lines ----------------------------------

Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087.  Usually has 5-10 listings, updated daily.
Elmo - 415-884-ABCD
Freak Out - 415.485.6597

------------------------------ Radio Shows ----------------------------------
Sunday mornings 1-3:30am - Minor Minor KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
Sunday evening 6:30-9pm - Mescalina, KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
Sunday evening 9-11pm - Universal radio at 89.1 FM.  Trance dance
        and power house.  Guest DJs weekly (SF & East Bay)
Sunday night 10pm-2am - Ambience w/Michael Hayes & David X  KWOD 106.5 (Sac)
Mondays 10pm - Belladonna, KFJC 89.7, Foothill College (Los Altos Hills)
Tuesdays noon-3pm - "London Jamaica" w/Unknown KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
weeknights ~9pm - the Modern Mix w/Steve Masters KITS 105.3 (SF)
