Parties in all shapes and sizes again; there seems to be a lot of
stuff happening lately.  Special events this weekend are the 
Food Not Bombs benefit tonight and the Bulletproof boat party.
In other news, SPAZ moves to Fridays, and get ready for the next
Blue Cube party 8)...

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------- UPCOMING RAVES IN THE SF/BAY AREA ---------------------
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Thursday, May 5th - Your Sisters' House & SPAZ: Food Not Bombs Benefit
        Live performances by Ken Machines & the Machine Elves from Hyperspace
        Planet Six.  Music for Peace by the Liquid Concrete Air Band
        DJs DRC, Pollywog, Synthesis, Spliffmeister J.
        Cesar's Latin Palace, Mission @ Army, SF
        $5-$10, 9pm-? 415.SOLS.666

Friday, May 6th - Sound Factory
        live performance by the Fog.  
        DJs Super DJ Dmitry, Pete Avila, Aaron O.
        Djs Scott de Castro & Safar in the red room
        9:30pm-7am, 21+, 525 Harrison @ 1st.  415.543.1300.  

Friday, May 6th - Earth House Hold
        $5, 10pm.  415-267-6193

Friday, May 6th - ZenDada
        DJ's Taj & Markie Mark
        basement of 1015 Folsom 
        Midnite-7am  $10

Saturday, May 7th - Beltane Wicked
        Jeno  Garth  Markie  Thomas
        415.512.5713

Saturday, May 7th - Rush
        Ghost  Simon  Carlos  Bones  Jaz  Christophe
        415.487.7471

Saturday, May 7th - M&M
        DJ's Demi God, Ben, Plez, Greg G
        (415) 435-7559  (916) 854-1042

Saturday, May 7th - outdoor underground in Santa Cruz
        DJ's will probably be wool, drew, james(me:) + others.  
        Come join us.  All are welcome.  415.292.3289

Sunday, May 8th - Bulletproof Boat Party
        up top: Kirk, Alex, Josh
        below decks: Gerry V, Thomas, Ron
        Advance tickets from Bulletproof, 829 Haight.  Info 255.7168
        6-10pm.  After-party and buffet included.

Thursday, May 12th - Flour
        Dani & Mark Farina
        Deco, 510 Larkin @ Turk.  21+. 441.4007.
        (will be every other Thursday)

Saturday, May 14 - SFR Blue Cube Party
        DJs: Meme, Laura, Lee, Will, Ethan
        for info/directions email resonate@netcom.com w/subject line: INFO

Saturday, May 14th - Fundamental
        Spun  Josh  DJ Dan  Ernie Munson  Rick Preston
        Visuals by Donovan, Pure, Ken Stone
        $10, 18+ w/id.  415.487.4339  415.486.9400

Saturday, May 14th - Vision
        Markie Mark  Garth  Josh  Tony  Doran & guests
        415.267.4800

Thursday, May 19th - Soul Purpose/Acid Jazz
        Brass Recording Artist Lalomie Washburn
        Music by Mark Farina, Marques Wyatt, Kevin of Stone Groove & Stu P.
        at the Sound Factory, 525 Harrison.

Friday, May 20th - Test 2
        live acid trance, ambient room and
        hard trance w/Ethan, Mac, Shobhan and Alex
        415.395.8380

Saturday, May 21st - Launch Pad II

Saturday, May 28th - SFRaves presents In The Light
         ->Get Infected by Meme -> 
         ->Trance out with Laura ->
         ->Take an Acid House Bath with Markie->
         Audio by SoundVision - Three Turntables
        noon to 6pm at the bandshell, Golden Gate Park.

Saturday, May 28th - Funky Tekno Tribe/Come-Unity
        415.266.8215    415.241.8815

Saturday, June 4th - Wicked
        415.512.5713

Saturday, June 11th - Basics 2-year anniversary
        415.905.9629

Here are some weeklies, in the house/techno/acid jazz/etc vein.  Some
of them may have ended - let me know when that happens...

---------------------------- T h u r s d a y --------------------------------

Your Sisters' House - 9pm discussion - 10pm-4am funkygrooves - 415-435-7575
Universal Groove - $5. 415.281.5913  510.869.2727
Ajax Lounge - Acid Jazz w/Julius Papp (San Jose)
Lift - Digit, EFX, & guests - $5, 21+, 55 Natoma, SF - 415.267.5984
Inspirations - 364 S Market St, San Jose (back of Dimensions).  
        9pm-2am, 18+, $5.  408.236.2102  415.267.6974
        [5/5 - Anton, Robbie & Scott Hardkiss. Ambience by Gavin Hardkiss
                and Shawn Cooper]
        [5/12 - Ryan Tapia, Simon, Markie.  Ambience by Adam Douglass
                and Thad Jones] 
        [5/19 - Liquid, Jeff Taylor, Jon Drukman.  Ambience by T2K 
                and Chris Trance]
Pure Space - 10pm-4am, 21+, $5. DNA Lounge, 375 11th @ Harrison. 415.267.0640
        [05.05 (Cinco de Mayo) - Carlos Locos, Jalapeno Jeno, El Spun]
Shake Yo Buddha - acid jazz, rare groove, hip-hop, soul, funk, reggae.  
        369 S 1st St, San Jose.  9:30pm-2am. 21+, $5.  408.236.3787
        [5/5 - Tai, Michael Persons, Peanut Butter Wolfe]
        [5/12 - Ryan Tapia, Dave Galvez, Harry Who]
        [5/19 - Ryan Tapia, Julius, Mark Farina]
Flour - Dani & Mark Farina - Deco, 510 Larkin @ Turk.  21+. 441.4007.
        (every other Thursday, next one 5/12)

------------------------------ F r i d a y ----------------------------------

Corduroy City  - $5 - call for DJs and location - 415.974.9715
Life/Twirl - Sound Factory - 525 Harrison @ 1st, SF    415.543.1300   21+
	DJs include Doc Martin, Aaron O, Pete Avila
Deep - Nikki Rivera, Jason Hayes, Lewis. 6th & Harrison (the End-Up)
Raw - Neon Leon, Jan Cooley, David Harness & guests - 540 Howard - 415.243.8181
Ooga Booga - 2600 Watt Ave (upstairs @ country club lanes) - 916.484.4006
Apocalypse - 16th & Harrison, $7, all ages - 415.979.8411
SPAZ (Semi-Permanent Autonomous Zone), 2 sound systems, new DJs and live
        performances each week.  $3, 21+, 60 Sixth Street.  info 415.sols666 

---------------------------- S a t u r d a y --------------------------------

	6am-2pm at the EndUp, 401 6th @ Harrison.  $2.  415.979.4515

        Head on House DJs: Simon, Henrik, Ernie, Jay-J, Mic, Eric Lacy, Josh.
        House of Funk & Killa Grooves: Bam Bam, Miquel, Melvin J, John Howard
        21+, $8 before midnite.  415.764.2922

        [next one April 30th]
Contact! - various guest DJs. $5, 18+, 2721 Broadway, Sacramento.  916.484.5661

        free before 2, $2 after.  the EndUp (6th & Harrison).  415.543.7700

        Tickets at Bulletproof 629 Haight (255.7168)
Ameba Ambient Tofu BBQ + films - BBQ lit at 5pm; bring BBQables, blankets,
        records.  1732 Haight.

I-Beam Tea Dance - Neon Leon & others - 5pm-1am. 1748 Haight.

------------------------------ M o n d a y ----------------------------------

Mushroom Jazz (Jazid Up)- acid jazz w/Mark Farina, Thomas, Ammon, Is,
	Alex, Kevin, Bob Taylor and/or Julius Papp.
	$4, 10pm-4am.  1190 Folsom St, 21+. 415-905-8811

Pepper - various djs - 510 larkin @ turk  (Deco), 21+, $3, 10pm-2am

----------------------------- T u e s d a y ---------------------------------

        the I-Beam, 1748 Haight @ Cole.  21+, $2.  415.668.6006

        DJs Charlotte (the Baroness) & guests
        [5/10 - Josh, 5/17 - Dani, 5/23 - Mark Farina, 5/30 - Josh]

--------------------------- W e d n e s d a y -------------------------------

Motion - 400 S 1st St, SJ (side entrance of F/X). 21+.  408-236-3732
Fixx - Jan Cooley, Phillip, Aaron, Neon Leon.  Cocktails, 9th & Howard.

        $3, 21+, 9pm-2am.  Miss Pearl's, 601 Eddy @ Larkin.  415.255.7168.
        [April DJs - Mark Farina, Gavan, Dani, Alex, Kevin, Gerry V, Kirk,
                     Andrew (Groove Merchant), Harry Who]
Recycle - every other Weds w/Carlos, Dutch, Christophe & guests. 415.599.3750

        Starts at 10pm, $5.  415.985.5264
Gemini - josh, spun, donald glaude, la paix, rick preston, dj dan,
        carlos & dutch.  415.979.4915

        and power house.  Guest DJs weekly (SF & East Bay)
Sunday night 10pm-2am - Ambience w/Michael Hayes & David X  KWOD 106.5 (Sac)
Mondays 10pm - Belladonna, KFJC 89.7, Foothill College (Los Altos Hills)

Greetings everyone.

As it being that I'm new to the list, I thought I would formally
introduce myself (instead of just lurking) to all the net people out here.

My name is Ed (Ed E) and I'm a graduating grad student out of the School
of Library Science and Information (yes, there is such a major and no I
don't have my hair in a bun...).  Considering that I don't have a job
lined up or anything, I plan to spend some time out in San Fran at a
friend's house to unwind and perhaps even become employed. 8)

I'm currently residing here in Bloomington, Indiana in the Midwest and
have been a long subscriber to mw-raves.  However, considering that I'm
going to be out there in a week, I thought I would subscribe to this list
before I headed to San Fran.

Needless to say, it sounds like there is a great scene.  Granted, the
Midwest has it's moments (the highlight being chemical inconvienced with
Plastikman...), but I'm really looking forever to checking things out
here and meeting people.  In fact, I would really appreciate if I could
meet up with any of you (considering I don't know any ravers out here)
so that I could kind of get a sense for what's going on.  If any of you
could be so kind as to e-mail their phone numbers an such (I'm not sure I'll
have net access for a while) I'd be ever so grateful.

Peace,

Ed E

=) "The Salivdor Dali of Information Science" =)

On Thu, 5 May 1994, Mark Guthrie wrote:

> I purchased Psycick Warriors of Gaia - Of Biospheres and Sacred Grooves
> last night and was a little disapointed.  It's O.K., but just not as
> good as I expected and I felt like I coulda done better by going with
> some other things on my "to get" list that I know are great or that I
> shoulda takin a chance with something else.  Oh well, I guess that's
> what chances are all about.  How does Psycick Rythms compare with this
> one?
> 
> -Winston
> 
Psycick Rhythms, from what i understand, is like a sampling CD 
demonstrating various soundscapes that PWOG created. (this is what the 
guy at the record store told me anyway.  if he's wrong then flame him)  i 
enjoy the PWOG spinoff group eXquisite CORpsE.  their latest cd is called 
"inner light" on Kk records.  it is absolutely brilliant.  a nice 
tribal/trance combo.  very highly recommended.

see you in the phuture,
  _-_->psiborg<-_-_

got a beautiful throb to it, but it's so minimal -- just evolutions and 
permutations of a wicked beat, and not really complete until mixed.

in the car!

From: anthrax@uclink.berkeley.edu (Ann Elizabeth Loraine)
Message-Id: <199405061543.IAA08236@uclink.berkeley.edu>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: basics
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


Upon learning that the map point for Basics last Sat. was just a mile or two
away from my house, I decided to go to that instead of Lauchpad- sorry I
missed the sfravers who showed up to that one; hope to see you at the Blue
Cube!  Tickets were $10 and you had to have one to get in- the party was
in a warehouse behind Albany Hill.  A note on Albany police:  my friend
Dave says they are uncool and told me an anecdote or two to illustrate, but
apparently they didn't hassle the Basics party much, although they did
show up to say "turn it down" because some nearby apartment-dwellers were
complaining.  Oh well.

First to spin was Joshua, followed by Kenneth and then James.  Kenneth
tried out some new styles- sort of trance-oriented and not very easy to
dance to, but then he got into a more danceable groove that I liked much
better.  James came on after and kept it going til maybe 7 or so.  Rumor
had it that Markie might show later on, but it was not to be.

This was a good party...it was mostly the crowd that did it.  I like East
Bay parties mostly because of the kids (!) that show up.. You can really
tell they want to have a good time and maybe don't get the chance to get
out to the city that much.  I got a big kick out of a big group of really
young women who all showed up wearing exactly the same outfit - the baggy
jean and black bra look was in effect.  You go girlz!  The Vibe award goes
of course to Kenneth who brought these glasses that flash red lights in
your field of vision.....dancing with those on was so incredible.  He plus
maybe twenty others stayed on til it was over...although the turnout wasn't
high, Martin seemed pretty satisfied.  We asked him about his voicemail
message and he said he thinks that the scene is getting more solid and that
since fewer people are going out EVERY weekend, maybe their expectations
are changing.  I know mine are...I liked Basics because it felt like that
chez Groove party (was it Ethan & Bryce that threw that?) where people were
really cool and the crowd was kinda small.  You guys remember that one?
I still have all these neat Hello Kitty stickers that someone gave me!

Well, the New Moon party is coming up Tuesday!  Maybe I'll see some of 
you there?!  The location is East Bay and NOT Point Reyes this time, by
the way.  

seeya!

annthrax

	id AA21690; Fri, 6 May 94 10:15:27 PDT
Date: Fri, 6 May 94 10:15:27 PDT
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9405061715.AA21690@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: ComeUnity/1015 Folsom harassment
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I got to CU at around 1, the party in full swing with Garth spinning some 
really nice throbbing acid funk.  The 1st 1/2 of Simon's set didn't really
grab me as much so I spent some time in the Chill space - plenty of 
comfortable seating, with Jason spinning a nice assortment of ambient house.

The 2nd half of Simon's set really took off.  He seems to go more for
the mid & high frequencies, i.e. his grooves aren't deep and not as
trance-inducing, but once his sets reach a high energy seamlessness, I 
have no trouble going along for the ride.  As usual, the visuals at 1015 
Folsom were very stimulating.  Synergy was projecting their usual magic 
onto 2 giant weather balloons and this worked even better the usual double 
screens.  

When Jeno took over, the party was starting to peak; I don't know what it 
is about Jeno.  The stuff he started out with wasn't anything amazing, 
but there was something about the tones that seened to draw me into a 
trance state.  I'm beginning to wonder if it's psychological - I see Jeno 
and somehow this expectation is created - or I sense his focus, as though 
I can pick up on some kind of deep intensity vibe coming from the guy.  
Anyway, 20 minutes into his set, just as we were about to leave the 
stratosphere, the music stops.

It was 4:30am, we milled around while the SFPD look over the equipment
and had the main mixer de-wired and removed.  Someone started singing 
"we are family" and the rest of us clapped along.  There was very little 
anger displayed - it was really hard to believe that it was over.  It felt 
really weird going to City Hall later that same morning to chum it up with 
the SFPD for the _In The Light_ sound permit.

So does anyone know what the justification was for this bust?  The volume 
was not as loud as in the past, almost bordering on not being loud enough.  
You could barely hear it outside.  The sun roof was completely covered 
with insulation.  It's obvious that the management are trying to be 
sensitive to noise complaints.  I may not be current on all the legal 
details, but I thought 1015 had gotten an injunction against the police
action that had been levied against them.  This is starting to look like
police harassment.  

I know that 1015 is just a club-for-profit, but it has been a good home
to the House scene, one that will be surely missed.  I don't know if it
makes sense to have a petition of some sort to circulate and we would 
certainly need more info before doing such a thing.  I wonder what this
means for Beltane Wicked which is rumored to be at 1015 this weekend.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com
____________________________________________________________________________


From sfraves-owner  Fri May  6 10:22:47 1994

From: Bryce Ryan <brycer@crl.com>

Subject: Food Not Bombs Benefit
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Fri, 6 May 1994 10:21:17 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 1465      
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Hey, Ravers! I stopped by the Food Not Bombs benefit last night, held
at Caesar's, and co-sponsored by YSH and SPAZ (if i recall correctly).
This was a hella fun party folks!  I heard a rumor about another one
next month...if they do it, Bryce Bob Briggs says go :)

I walked in to find a cornucopia of food and some very friendly folks
staffing the donation station.  There was a flat of strawberries, a box
of oranges, and another box of bagels...cool stuff.  in the main room,
there was _breakbeat_!  i haven't heard breakbeat for a year and a 
half.  i was surprised, and kind of pleased in a twisted way.  i usually
can't listen to breakbeat for very long, but this was perfectly OK and
lotsa fun.  and people were dancing, which was also really nice.

the mezzanine had been turned into a vending area, with lots of cool
clothes and hats and other ravey things. the vendors were quite nice
and way laid back.  The FNB people did a really cool puppet show,
with lots of multi-media and video thrown in for fun.  there were
video cameras everywhere, it seemed, and a fabulous drumming circle.
we were also treated to some live techno by Ken Velocette (i think)
and the Machine Elves (?), which was mindbendingly good dance music.
the party really took off after that, and then we were treated to
more DJ music.

All in all, a fine time.
-- 
Bryce Ryan ------- AMBIANCE ----------- brycer@crl.com-----

Received: from DialupEudora by netcom.com (8.6.8.1/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id RAA13661; Fri, 6 May 1994 17:21:10 -0700
Message-Id: <199405070021.RAA13661@netcom.com>
X-Sender: donpierr@localhost
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Fri, 6 May 1994 17:20:00 -0800
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
From: donpierr@netcom.com (Don Gray)
Subject: Innovative Self Defense Classes
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

A lot of raves are held in potentially dangerous, poorly lit areas, late at
night.  Sometimes there are not a lot of people around outside, especially
when it is necessary to park a long way away from the venue.  We strive for
everyone to experience the global community that we live in.  However,
safety is still a concern to many people, both men and women.

A friend of mine took a self defense class from an organization a couple
of years ago that has hit hard economic times in the recent slow economy, and
they are in danger of going bankrupt.  They are asking their graduates to
help them fill their next few classes.  It is *NOT* JUST ANOTHER
SELF-DEFENSE CLASS.  They have a unique approach of empowering the
individual that other self-defense courses do not do.  I believe the work
they do is important and particularly innovative, and think it would be
tragic if their business closed, so I am spreading the word among people I
know.  If you or anyone you know might be interested in taking a self
defense class, please read this message.

Bay Area Model Mugging (BAMM) primarily teaches self defense to women,
but also offers classes to men, and children over the age of 7.  The
classes feature instructors in heavily-padded suits who attack the
students so that the students get to train their minds and bodies in
actually fighting off an assailant.  This is how it differs from other
self-defense classes.  The student actually gets physical, and
For someone who has ever felt helpless in this situation, it is
amazingly empowering to experience what it is like to take control.
Students report that they stopped feeling fearful and took control of
their lives as a result of the classes.

The women's classes are intensive 5-session courses in which students
learn to de-escalate conflicts, stand their ground in intimidating
situations, protect themselves physically from various kinds of blows,
and if necessary, deliver a knock-out blow to a single unarmed
assailant.  They actually deliver the knock-out blow at full force to
the heavily-padded instructor.  Advanced classes teach students to
cope with multiple and armed assailants.  Children learn to say no
effectively to adults, including those who may be authority figures,
and to fight a larger, more powerful assailant well enough to escape.
I believe the men's class is analogous to the women's class.

These classes are taught responsibly -- students are not trained to be
aggressors.  They are taught the skills they need to fight back if
they choose to, and the skills to de-escalate situations so that they
are less likely to need to make that choice.  Students are also given
training in making the choice of whether to fight back.  The aim of
the course is not to make someone feel compelled to fight, but to give
them that realistic option.  This is a supportive environment where
even women who don't believe that they can fight off someone bigger
and stronger learn that they can if they know how.

Although the classes are not cheap (approx. $500), no one is getting
rich off of them -- they are expensive to produce.  BAMM is committed
to all women who want this training being able to receive it
regardless of economic standing, and operates a scholarship fund to
support this.

If you or someone you know might be interested in taking a class from
BAMM, you are welcome to call BAMM directly at (415) 592-7300.

I have no affiliation with BAMM, and receive no benefit from this post
other than the satisfaction that it may help someone overcome a fear of
being attacked and empower that person to stay safe.

Please repost this anywhere you feel that it may be helpful, but please
take my name off of the header (I don't want to receive a bunch of
questions about it).

Thanks for your attention.

same person then it all depends on what you are in to.  I
know people who love him and I know peole who can't stand
his taste in music.

I've heard some of the remixes that Sasha-from-the-UK has done
and left them in the bins where I found them.  But that's just
my personal taste.

then you might want to check the Sasha disc out.  He's not
really "like" Jeno/Garth/et alia but I think there's enough of 
a common thread there to make a recommendation.

so ago.

Hi Folx--

I can verify what Don says.  This past winter I took
one of these classes--and it was worth it!  It was
expensive, gruelling, and got me past shitless to
fearless in the right situations.  I learned in the
basic course all the things he mentions and plan to go
on to some advanced courses next fall or winter.  I
*never* thought I could do what I did in that course!
My powers of breathing, surveillance, control and
relaxation are additional gains that I never imagined
I would have!

Thanks, Don, for mentioning these classes!  I *do*
feel much safer on my way to and from raves/parties
in the wee hours in the out of the way places because
I now know what to look for and what I can--and cannot--
do!

World's second oldest raver (yer never too old to learn),
Will

Will Penna               408.423 8907
If you believed that you deserved everything that you want,
you'd have it.   ILLUMINATIONS   Paul & Collins   HarperSanFrancisco

Date: Sun, 8 May 1994 02:39:27 -0700
In-Reply-To: raffs@netcom.com (Raffaele Sena)
       "Cyberia, the book" (May  5,  1:17pm)
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: raffs@netcom.com (Raffaele Sena), sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: Cyberia, the book
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Sorry this is a little late for the subject...

Here's a review of the book a longtime friend and ancient SFRaver wrote
recently:

-----------------------------------------------------------------------

I just read the whole fuckin' thing.
My capsule review: Yuck.

I think that overall, _Cyberia_ sucks hard. It portrays an entire culture
in terms only of drugs, pseudoreligious experience, and hacking. Now I saw
enough of this whole scene as it was happening to know that it was much
more than that, and that his analysis leaves out almost all of what I
consider "the good stuff."

As far as I am concerned, it is a sensationalist piece of trash, written by
someone who really didn't "get it" it the broadest possible sense. He got
sucked in by the auras of the famous personalities (McKenna, Leary, R. U.
Sirius) and by the potential shock value of exposing the
cyber-druggie-wierdos to the masses. He completely lost any critical
ability to figure out what parts of what he was being fed were true and
what was utter bunk (if indeed he ever had such a capability)

The entire ability of electronic communication technologies to bring
people together, McLuhan's whole spiel about electronic
retribalization, the entire concept of community (& Virtual
Communities a la Rheingold) completely eluded Rushkoff. It presents a
dark and hopeless world where drug-induced schizophrenia and
cybercrime dominate the day to day activities, if not the long-term
goals, of our entire culture.

------------------------------------------------------------------------

I haven't read it yet but am planning on doing so soon.  

	Brian

My parents know that I've gone to a few raves, but I know when I get back 
home from school that they are going (to try) to stop me from going to 
them.  My dad, working for ABC, Alcoholic Beverage Control, hears about 
a lot about the high profile ones.  He told me that a lot of "those types 
of places" have been spiking the smart drinks with opium and they are 
dangerous and my mom thinks its just part of the "fast lane".  I really 
want them to understand where I go is not about all those rumors your 
hear and Basic Instinct is not the norm!  Can anyone please give me some 
good things I can tell them so they don't freak out every time I go or I 
don't have to sneak out when I want to go?  Any and all comments would be 
appreciated, I know others would benefit by this info too.
rave on-Brian

From: deaks@netcom.com (Ernie Deakyne)
Message-Id: <199405090418.VAA08556@netcom.com>
Subject: Santa Cruz party experience (The Cliffs)
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Sun, 8 May 1994 21:18:01 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 1590      
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

   For all those who gave up looking for this party, you missed out!  My 
friends and I left from Monterey around 11:30, we hit Davenport and 
called the hotline and the directions seemed pretty simple... sure :)

   Anyways, we drive and drive and drive until we suddenly notice we are 
closer to San Francisco then Santa Cruz, so we start heading back towards 
Santa Cruz.  We stop in Pascedaro around 1:00 and call the # again.  We 
decide to keep looking and finally see some cars parked along the road 
and figure it was the place.  We get out and can hear the music, although 
it sounded more like it was coming from a car, or like it was coming out 
of a small stereo placed in a bush. We finally find our way to the crowd, 
and oh what a crowd!

   The vibe was fantastic, I met some SFraves people for the first time 
and met a ton of real cool people from Santa Cruz.  The sound was 
fantastic and the two black lights were just perfect. The music was some 
of the nicest trancey/dancey stuff I've heard in a while.  The weather wasnt 
too cold either.  My friends and I danced all night and into the morning 
(when just about 10 people were left) until we finally decided to hit the 
road.

   Anyways, just want to say hello to all the people I met there (I was 
the guy with the big huge flashlight with the flashing yellow thing and 
the flourescent light too :) )

Dj James: Some friends of mine are doing a wherehouse party in 
Watsonville this Friday and they're looking for some more DJ's... Drop me 
some mail if you're interested.

  Peace out - rave on... ..  .
S

Another word of endorsement for Men's Model Mugging. This is Robertj, and I
completed the first Men's Model Mugging course held in Monterey. The course
completely altered, and empowered my sense of safety and my ability to
diffuse potentially dangerous situations. It gives you options in crisis
situations, rather than just being frozen in fear. If you're afraid walking
on the streets, to and from the raves, you should take it.  robertj.......MRP

From sfraves-owner  Mon May  9 08:41:25 1994

	id AA18389; Mon, 9 May 94 08:28:36 PDT

	id AA27904; Mon, 9 May 94 08:28:35 PDT
Received: from lizard.srv.PacBell.COM by pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA26780; Mon, 9 May 94 08:28:35 PDT
Date: Mon, 9 May 94 08:28:35 PDT
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9405091528.AA26780@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: The Mathew Fox Meeting
Cc: sfraves-planners@techno.Stanford.EDU
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

7 or 8 of us, mostly SFRavers, gathered in the living room of Bob Jesse's 
house.  Matthew Fox arrived with Cliff, the guy who posted here has acted 
as Matthew Fox's liason to us.  Both of them were very warm and pleasant, 
and the atmosphere was very amiable and relatively relaxed.  

Things got off to an excruciating slow start with a each of us giving the
a personal introduction about the spiritual and raving aspects of our lives.  
Although I guess it was important that Matthew get a feel for who 
we were, most of us were extremely self-indulgant with the opportunity to 
confess our life stories to our celebrity guest.  About half the meeting 
was taken up with these "introductions".  Somewhere along the way, the 
point was made that we were *not* truly representative of the rave 
community at large.  In fact we never even attempted (nor were we asked)
about what SF Bay Areas ravers are generally about.

When Matthew started talking, it was clear that he was very well-practiced
at this sort of thing.  His presentation was smooth and polished.  He comes
across as a very likeable and charming guy, and it was clear that as the
meeting progressed we were generally happy to be seduced by him.  And why
not?  Isn't reaching out and communicating partly what we claim to be all 
about?  Matthew Fox seems to be a bridge builder; it is well known that he 
has met with *many* non-Christian groups.  I did find it ironic that the 
one bridge he has failed to build was within his own religion.  Defrocked 
by the Vatican, he has been hired on by the Episcopalian Church, where 
Matthew still expects trouble.  Even the Bishop who has promised to 
"protect him" from the "right wing" of the church has already told him that
he will *not* read any of Matthew Fox's books.  Hmm.  What does it mean
when your protector doesn't even want to know what you stand for..?  That
was one of the many questions that went unanswered.

As for what Matthew Fox stands for; he says that he wants to bring grass 
roots spirituality back to the Church.  His brand of Christianity, that he 
called "Creation Spirituality" places Christ as a mystical symbol, 
apparently on par with pagan godesses, modern cosmology, eastern 
philosophy...whatever it is that people use to connect themselves with 
essence of existence.  The important thing is that we are all a part of 
Creation and that we get in touch, through ritual, to the mystical and 
spiritual essence of all creation.  This more holistic approach to 
spirituality conjures up environmental issues and seems to run counter to 
the dulaistic nature of conventional Christainity that has separated 
worshippers from their God and has resulted in the spiritual alienation 
many of the masses seem to be suffering from these days.  OK, I can go 
along with that.  I can't, of course, speak for his fellow Episcopalians.

Matthew Fox is very enthusiastic about raving.  More than once he called us 
"revolutionaries" and even explained which Chakras raving addresses.  I
was rather impressed with the depth of his convictions here, especially
since the only rave he's ever attended one of the Sheffield Chistain-based
ones in the UK.  He deferred some of our questions about the planned
rave-masses to the Sheffield folks who would actually be putting them on.  
The one thing he did know was that the rave-masses would have a definate
Christain slant to them. 

We told him about our concern with using raving as a tool to deliver dogma,
and about our general dislike of the Christ theme, with all of its
associated baggage through its links to modern Christianity.  Although we
had to admit that *some* thematic content gets preached at our raves, we
tried to explain that the rather generic and abstract nature of such
content (i.e. unity, acceptance, etc.) allows the spiritual experience (if
any) to remain a deeply personal and individual one.  I think he heard us,
but he never answered our question of *why* the Christ thing is still so
important to him, or why it is so important to deliver a Christ-specific
message at a rave.  

The point was also made that there has not been a lot of success in
duplicating the Sheffield rave-masses in other parts of the UK.  San
Francisco was chosen because of the existing sense of community they
felt existed here.  At the same time, it is understood that Sheffield, 
being very economically depressed and blue collar, is a much different 
kind of community.  

Although none of us had expressed such a concern, Matthew made the point 
that they were not trying to "compete" with the existing rave scene here. 
Throughout the discussion, Matthew referenced various aspects of our 
previously expressed backgrounds, making sure to exhibit his deference 
for the African American Churches, Jewish influences and modern science.  
But he referenced a lot of other cultures as well, so my thinly veiled 
accusation here of pandering *might* be a little unfair.

We spent a bit of time on the use of psychedelics.  He basically attributed
his anti-drug quote in the newspapers to the Sheffield people's work with  
recovering addicts.  Matthew himself didn't seem to have much of a problem 
with the use of psychedelics, and accepted our testimonials about their 
benefits and agreed that they could be useful when used in the proper 
context.  He did object to the use of psychedelics as "fast-food" 
spirituality, however, and argued for the importance of ritual for building
a community.

When Cliff declared the meeting to be over, it was clear that many issues
were left unanswered.  He did not address the concern I had expressed about
the possibility that he was just being used by his church as bait for
bringing in fresh recruits.  Even if Matthew's intentions are sincere, this 
really isn't just *his* game, is it?  It isn't at all clear as to what the 
relationship between the Sheffield promoters and the rest of the rave
community will be, if any.  Are they going to allow flyers for _Wicked_ to
be placed in the basement of Grace Cathedral?   We expressed the desire to
talk some more, and I invited Matthew to come to _In The Light_, but he'll 
be touring Europe on a book tour for the next couple of months.

In the end, my mixed emotions about the unaddressed issues and about 
Matthew Fox himself left me feeling uneasily neutral.  Historically,
Christianity has adopted or embellished the rituals of other cultures for
the explicit purpose of winning over new members.  It is also not uncommon
for large institutions to allow for the odd renegade to operate within
their midsts as a symbol of liberalism and openmindedness while the
ongoing perpetuation of oppression and mass manipulation continues unabated.

Ultimately, the SF Bay Area rave scene will continue to do it's thing, 
Fox will do his, the Sheffield folks theirs, and the Church theirs.  It 
remains to be seen whether any of the agendas of these groups will coincide 
with each other in a meaningful or positive way.  
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com
____________________________________________________________________________

I checked out Pepper last week, and it was sort of low-key, not a
whole lot of people dancing most of the night.  The space (Deco) is
cool, so it's a great place to go if you just want to hang out
somewhere with a big sound system :).  I think someone said that the
first Test happened there. It's around the corner from Miss Pearl's
Jam House, and as far as parts of the Tenderloin go, it seems
relatively serene.

From sfraves-owner  Mon May  9 11:25:29 1994

From: Arthur Chandler <arthurc@sfsuvax1.sfsu.edu>
Subject: That Old Time Religion
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Cc: sfraves-planners@techno.Stanford.EDU
In-Reply-To: <9405091528.AA26780@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9405091109.C15845-0100000@sfsuvax1.sfsu.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


   I found Lee's thoughtful evaluation of the meeting with Mathew Fox very 
enlightening. The whole affair reminded me of one of the turns that the 
psychedelic movement took during the 60s and 70s. Lots of folks were 
dissatisfied with the religion and politics of their parents' generation. 
But after immersion in the music, drugs, and total ambience of the 
counterculture, many came away just as starved for permanent values as 
they had been when they first got involved in the scene. 
  "Chopping wood before enlightenment.... chopping wood after 
enlightenment," as the Zen koan goes.
  What do you do when the party is over, the musicians have packed up 
their instruments, and the gray dawn dissipates the last ecstasy of the 
night's vision of Truth, Beauty, and Justice?
   Many -- Bob Dylan being the most visible -- returned to the faith of 
their parents. It might have been a faith newly interwoven with New Age 
trappings of the Wisdom of Coyote or Neopaganism, but it was a return to 
the faith nevertheless. No big surprises here for the historian. If 
Christianity could survive (though not unscathed) defeat at the hands of 
the Moslems, schism into protestantisms, Darwinism, and the unrelenting 
onslaught of media distractions -- should we be surprised to find some of 
Christianity's younger, hipper proponents enthusing about raves and 
finding a perfect usefulness in the movement?

From sfraves-owner  Mon May  9 11:50:00 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA06841; Mon, 9 May 94 11:50:00 PDT
Received: from soda.berkeley.edu by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA06829; Mon, 9 May 94 11:49:51 PDT
Received: (laura@localhost) by soda.berkeley.edu (8.6.9/PHILMAIL-1.10) id LAA09742 for sfraves@techno.stanford.edu; Mon, 9 May 1994 11:50:04 -0700
Message-Id: <199405091850.LAA09742@soda.berkeley.edu>
From: laura@soda.berkeley.edu (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Mon, 9 May 1994 11:50:02 -0700
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: butterflies:  a true life story
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Hi all, this is sort of a party report on life outside of San Francisco.
I'll keep it short.

Anyway, I spent Saturday night in El Paso, Texas, at a party called Unity.  
It was held in a dusty grimey warehouse (I love old dirty warehouse parties) 
and had a large outdoor area, too.

Between 500 and 600 people came to El Paso, from the surrounding area, from 
Albequerque (4 1/2 hour drive away), Denver (11 hour drive), Durango (12 hour 
bus ride away), and even Oklahoma (those people left on Thursday to get there). 
When people make THAT much effort to go to a party, crazy things happen (and 
some of you all think Freemont is too far :-) ).

I had been feeling rather ill that afternoon so I spent most of the party 
sleeping in a back office in the warehouse, but during the times I was mostly 
awake I could *tell* something good was going on.  DJs Intensity (from 
Albequerque) and Wisc (from Houston) were going really strong.  Intensity 
put down a mixture of breakbeat, trance, and even a tiny bit of acid, and Wisc 
with a variety of breakbeat styles.  Every so often some of the local kids 
would wander back to the office I was in, and we'd sit around talking.  Like 
the rest of the US except for San Francisco, these people ranged from their
late teens to early twenties.  I met a few older sibling/younger sibling pairs, 
where a 19 or 21 year old had brought along a 15 or 16 year old sibling.  It 
was kind of neat because the younger kids were wide-eyed and energetic but 
didn't seem all lost and clueless.

The really young ones and the small club-and-fashion crowd cleared out around 
2am (the party had started at 9).  I had thought -- being in Texas -- that 
there would be a lot of beer around, but judging from the TINY number of 
empties I saw in with all the usual trash on the floor, there wasn't much 
alcohol at all.

Around midnight I woke myself up and hung out around the dance floor.  The 
warehouse was packed and people were really dancing hard, using their squirt 
guns to cool off (and for water fights in the outside area).  I, however, had 
never spun in front of that many people, and immediately came down with the 
absolute worst case of stage fright ever.  I looked in the bathroom mirror:  I 
was pale as a ghost.  I had heart palpitations and felt like looking for an 
airsick bag.  I was scared.  My turn on the decks came and I got down to work.  
After setting up my first two records I looked up and couldn't see the dance 
floor because about 25 people (evenly distributed between men and women) were
watching me intently.  Fortunately, about 2 tracks later, they were all dancing,
so I got over my shock and things went on quite normally from there.  

The party continued on till a bit after 7am.  By that time there were about 50 
people left, and some of them were skateboarding or roller blading around the 
warehouse while others were sharing donuts and juice for breakfast while still 
others danced to some happy silly disco spun by Shawn (also of Albequerque).  
The smile factor was high . . . overall people were very friendly and so very 
warm and nice to me.  The whole night gave me a much-needed boost in terms of 
my attitude toward the rave scene in general.  Here was a well-done party with 
a deadicated happy sharing energetic crowd that was lots of fun.  So anyway, 
there *IS* rave life out there in what could almost be thought of as unexpected
parts of the US, and it's doing quite well.  

Laura

can be correlated in any way with homosexuality.  I do not want to 
make a sweeping statement, but it does seem to me that a lot of male

actually, bob dylan kinda 'roamed' the spiritual/religious landscape.
he's jewish - his birthanme is zimmerman - and he did the xtian thing for
a while, then he was going to some jewish orthodox schul.
more importantly, i disagree  with you that xtianity is a foundation to which
people want to return. i think it is more the case that people never
achieve 'escape velocity' to break free of xtianity, and are pulled back,
to be crushed back on impact. the 'return' to xtianity of the flower
people did not consitute a triumph a further exploration of spirituality,
but an admission of defeat, a retreat into 'olde' values, which came with
the reaction of the late 70's. for xtianity to be able to incorporate
the spiritual elements whichi would allow us to grow , it would have to
change so drastically as to (almost) cease to BE xtianity! certainly,
mainstream xtianity can't do that. perhaps some other variations, like
gnosticism or some such variation could do it. at any rate, it would
ba a sex-positive, body-positive version of it. also tolerant of
the variety of human existence, feminist in some form, gay -affirmative.
anuyway, i have a hard time seeing all of this in present day xtianity.
but i might be wrong.
take care/shalom/acid + bass
ovid

i can't believe i'm quoting an Ann Landers article, but here goes; it
  looked just rite for the raves list...


here's what Ghandi said were the 7 basic roots of violence (as relayed
   by his grandson, Arun Gandhi:

     Wealth without Work.
     Pleasure without Conscience.
     Knowledge without Character.
     Commerce without Morality.
     Science without Humanity.
     Worship without Sacrifice.
     Politics without Principles.

once again, i can't believe i found anything this deep wading thru this
   particular segment of the paper; who'd a thunk?

seeya!

Dave Scruton
de la Fractallonomy

i may be wrong but i don't think arguing about the cost of opium is gonna 
help you win any fight with your parents. 

tell them that you like raving because of the music...because ravers are 
generally not drinkers and alchohol makes people violent while most 
ravers are friendly...that a night of dancing is more fun and much 
healthier than watching tv or going to a movie.

tell them that you see drugs in plenty of places beside raves, and if 
they are anti-drug, tell them that you are smart enough to 'just say no' 
and that they don't need to worry about you, you're a respobsable 
individual and if they don't trust you, you'll never be able to grow up 
on your own. that the crap about opium, tell them it was just 
sensalionalist garbage and that it doesn't really happen. if they don't 
believe you, tell them you don't like smart drinks anyway and that you 
only drink from the water fountain.

try to reason with them, but i wouldn't suggest fighting with them, it 
rarely works for me.

To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU,
        Warren M Hughes <MEC93WMH@ccs.edge-hill-college.ac.uk>
Subject: Re: GAY RAVERS
Reply-To: rnj%lila@us.oracle.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Warren M Hughes <MEC93WMH@ccs.edge-hill-college.ac.uk> asks:

>For personal research I would like to know if raving (ie liking to rave) 

>can be correlated in any way with homosexuality.  I do not want to 

>make a sweeping statement, but it does seem to me that a lot of male 

>ravers are gay.  Any feedback?

in the "early days" (1991) of raving in San Francisco, at most events i could  
see individuals, couples, and small groups of males that triggered my gaydar,  
sometimes subtly and sometimes blatantly.  not many - still a minority - but  
visible, and happly accepted by all, so it seemed.  i have a biased feeling  
that the gay males there set a high example for energetic, frolicking,  
creative, uninhibited dancing.

[the earliest well-integrated event i recall in SF had its brief life during  
my first year of living in the city, 1990, before i had ever heard the word  
rave in this context.  it was a thursday night gig called "Recess", produced  
by doc martin, who then lived in SF.]

one of the things that most appealed to me (a gay male) in that scene was that  
i could go to events in the company of *any* of my friends, not just the gay  
ones or the straight ones who would feel a bit out-of-place in a gay dance  
club.

so it seemed to me, the scene grew straighter after Toon Town hit it big (new  
year's eve 1991-92).  when Care*Free (a saturday weekly) began at 177  
townsend, it drew (by design) a mostly hip-gay crowd, with a sizeable,  
comfortable minority of straight ravers.  even the gay component was  
well-integrated w/ lesbians and gay males both, a combination unusual in SF  
clubs.  [fond memories of hot, sweating, smiling, energy...]  when the "other"  
big, more ordinary-club-like, less rave-like saturday night gay weekly  
("Colossus") closed, Care*Free was flooded with the Colossus crowd and became  
less rave-like.

since Care*Free closed and continuing to the present, it has seemed to me that  
the SF rave scene is mostly straight, or if there's a sizeable gay component,  
it's no longer visible to me as such.  i still find people in the scene to be  
uniformly gay-positive, and completely accepting of M-M and F-F affection.

From sfraves-owner  Mon May  9 19:07:16 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA15459; Mon, 9 May 94 19:07:16 PDT

From: "Fred Heutte" <phred@well.sf.ca.us>
Message-Id: <9405091850.ZM5087@well.sf.ca.us>
Date: Mon, 9 May 1994 18:50:43 -0700
In-Reply-To: lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com (Lee Fogel)
        "The Mathew Fox Meeting" (May  9,  8:28am)
References: <9405091528.AA26780@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.0.0 15dec93)
To: lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com (Lee Fogel), sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: The Mathew Fox Meeting
Cc: sfraves-planners@techno.Stanford.EDU
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Mime-Version: 1.0
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Thanks for the excellent report and comments, lee.  I found your
concerns to be very clearly expressed and well-founded.  

The separation between the sacred and secular is not always so great
as in our society.  In many other cultures, rituals (defined broadly
as social activities with a definite order or sense of performance,
and with broad participation) have elements of both . . . or at least
the same participants.  Remember that early scene in 'The Harder They
Come' with the choir and band rockin' and the churchgoers going into
various trance-like states?  The same people may have been out late
the previous same night drinking and dancing with the same musicians
playing somewhat different music . . . and so on.

I wonder along with you about the gulf between the organized, bureaucratic
church (which Fox is definitely a part of culturally and professionally,
even if he is not ideologically aligned with them) and the purely secular
(if spiritually-inclined) traditions involved in the r*** scene.  

In the early 1960s, this was an issue too.  With Vatican II came a
cultural revolution in the Catholic Church.  With a great deal of struggle
over turf and doctrine, a lot of local parishes began experimenting with
'folk masses' where acoustic guitars and newer rewrites of old hymns
supplanted the traditional organ and choir.  

Now, it so happens my dad was a choir director at our local parish. 
While he was in favor of opening up the liturgy (this is in the earliest
days right after the mandatory Latin mass was being gradually turned over
to English and other modern languages, remember), he was pretty appalled
at the cheesy folk-liturgical music being churned out by earnest sincere
seminarians.  There was some good stuff, too, but it was certainly not
easy finding things that were liturgically and musically compatible.
In other words, as in all things quality was scarce.  

Through a variety of events, he was dropped as director of our parish
choir (although he was hired back several years later), but a very
fortunate thing happened.  Although we were in DC, he linked up with a
progressive parish in Baltimore who had a brilliant cantor, Matt Frehling,
but needed a choir director.  So that's how we found ourselves trundling
up the Balt-Wash Parkway every Sunday morning to this black parish in
Baltimore (St. Gregory), where they had this amazing choir and this 
amazing music combining traditional Catholic hymns, things borrowed from
the black Protestant churches, some of the new folk-based stuff and some
of my dad's own compositions.  In the upheavals of 1963, amidst both
Vatican II and the zenith of the civil rights movement, this was pretty
amazing stuff, and I'm sure though it wasn't apparent to me as a kid
that it was also risky to people's livelihoods and community stature as
church participants and employees.  We still have some great 15 ips
tapes of some of the singing and music from that time.  Amazing stuff.

And to complete the story, my sister ended up being in our local parish
folk group, singing Catholic hymns and 'Precious Lord' and who knows
what else every Sunday.  And somehow it actually worked out OK, because
that too was grounded in the time and the community and expressed the
very apparent need to develop new liturgical forms that reflected the
experience and background of the participants.

But it certainly didn't come down as an edict from the Archdiocese:
you WILL have folk masses and you WILL enjoy it -- which is how most
of their edicts came down then and now.  Quite the opposite, it was
a contrarian stance and one that got a lot of resistance from the
less freewheeling suburban churches that dominated the internal
hierarchy.  

I say all this because the call on the question of whether to get
involved with or approve of Fox's proposed 'rave masses' is not a
simple one.  What it really gets down to is whether there is an
*authentic* experience that can be developed, even out of seemingly
widely variant cultural practices such as organized religion and
organized raving.  Of course, we have already seen that the underlying
incipient links between trance/dance/spirituality/music are definitely
there.  But it is so easy for hype to overcome and crush the fragile
syncretic bonds that must be built in order to find the common ground.

I haven't been an active participant in the Catholic Church since high
school, but I have to say those Sunday morning masses at St. Gregory's
in Baltimore expressed and developed the feeling of community and
commitment like nothing else I've seen since  . . . except for those
moments at 5 am when you're looking around you all over the floor
with the music going like THAT and people going off like THIS and
you can *see* the Awareness Quotient just zooming up.

So, though I was unable to meet Mathew Fox and really am likely to be
at best on onlooker on this developing story, it's of great interest
to see where it might lead.  I am quite skeptical, I must say, but I've
also learned it's important never to say "never" to a new idea, a new
way of linking people together and reaching to to reinvigorate the deep
connections we need to help overcome the deteriorating relationships
among people and between us and our environment that threaten us all.

And that's my Jeremiad for the week, the Philippic has been cancelled :-)

By the way, I was standing around recently when a Hemp Initiative
volunteer approached Tom Hayden (I'm a volunteer on his campaign) and
talked to him briefly about his meeting with Matthew Fox. According to
Hayden, Matthew Fox said although he supported the legalization of
marijuana, he wouldn't sign the petition. Hayden didn't know Fox's
reasons (Hayden, by the way, did sign the petition a while back, in
case you're wondering).

I realize that this information is third-hand at best, but together
with everything else I've heard about Fox, I think that his opinions
on drug use in general are not very well formed, and he's somewhat
ambivalent at best about the spiritual and recreational uses of 
psychedelics. I wonder if anyone's offered him a good "controlled"
(whatever that means) psychedelic experience so he can form his own
judgements?

Subject: Re: GAY RAVERS
To: trance@netcom.com (Tamara Palmer)
Date: Mon, 9 May 1994 23:55:30 -0700 (PDT)
Cc: rnj%lila@us.oracle.com, sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
In-Reply-To: <199405100155.SAA13148@netcom.com> from "Tamara Palmer" at May 9, 94 06:55:28 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 2484      
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

My mailer says that Tamara Palmer said:
> 
> That being said, why do you think there isn't more integration between the two
> scenes? Do you think that there is asome apprehension in the gay community,
> or do you think it might be a function of us over- analyzing it?
> 
I think there are several reasons (and more, i'm sure) why things are less
integrated than some of us would like.  Speaking as an authority on the 
subject :) , there is one obvious thing at issue: promotion.  at gay and
lesbian oriented events, i rarely see "rave" flyers, ditto the reverse
direction.  there are notable exceptions, but those exceptions tend to be
the mega-events.  

it is also the case that promoters of gay events rarely promote at non-gay
places because of a sense of proprietorship.  there have been many folks
and regular events that have changed dramatically because of a wider appeal.
many gays and lesbians recall with some sorrow some favored club that "went
straight".  there is a whole rash of emotions attending that experience
which i won't get into, because many of them are heterosexist. a case in
point is Uranus, which went from being a very underground thing to being
extermely aboveground, and a home for suburban gawkers who went around
making rude remarks about the folks who went there from the beginning;
such experiences do tend to drive out the group that makes a party "fun".

it is also the case that few heterosexual promoters promote at gay
and lesbian places, often because of simple ignorance.

as a gay male, i can also say that i am often wary of groups of more than
two young straight unknown men, especially adolescents.  it's a safety
thing...getting harassed or bashed because i'm wearing or acting something 
"out of the ordinary" is the last thing i want if i'm enhanced and in strange
surroundings. folks can be the nicest people on earth, but i don't necessarily
know that, and i'm generally not willing to risk my well-being for a momentary
thrill.  harassment or bashing is much less likely at gay or lesbian focussed
events---numbers and security see to that.

finally, we mustn't forget simple statistics. even though i'm from san 
francisco (the supposed gay and lesbian mecca), the overall statistics
suggest there are fewer gays and lesbians to go around....by a factor 
of almost 10. so many parties, so little time! :)
-- 
Bryce Ryan ------- AMBIANCE ----------- brycer@crl.com-----

bryce:
> I think there are several reasons (and more, i'm sure) why things are less
> integrated than some of us would like.  Speaking as an authority on the 
> subject :) , there is one obvious thing at issue: promotion.  at gay and
> lesbian oriented events, i rarely see "rave" flyers, ditto the reverse
> direction.  there are notable exceptions, but those exceptions tend to be
> the mega-events.  
> [...]
> it is also the case that few heterosexual promoters promote at gay
> and lesbian places, often because of simple ignorance.

Many of us who lean toward the hetero end of the spectrum really miss
the days when house music parties were more mixed in their sexual
orientations.  I was at the End-Up recently, and the vibe there was
*great*.   Some _In The Light_ teasers have already been distributed 
there (thanx Cap'n), and we plan to do some serious flyering there.  

I had a pretty good time at Carefree a couple of years ago, and the sexual 
focus of that party wasn't nearly as much of a put-off for me as the 
uptight heterosexual meat-market atmosphere i've experienced at many strayt 
clubs.  I think there's a very special joy that comes out whenever people 
who have been oppressed/repressed get to be in an atmosphere where they 
can be accepted for who they really are.

--------------------------------------
Date: 5/9/94 7:16 PM
To: Dianna Jacobs
From: rnj%lila@us.oracle.com
Warren M Hughes <MEC93WMH@ccs.edge-hill-college.ac.uk> asks:

>For personal research I would like to know if raving (ie liking to rave) 

>can be correlated in any way with homosexuality.  I do not want to 

>make a sweeping statement, but it does seem to me that a lot of male 

>ravers are gay.  Any feedback?

in the "early days" (1991) of raving in San Francisco, at most events i could  
see individuals, couples, and small groups of males that triggered my gaydar,  
sometimes subtly and sometimes blatantly.  not many - still a minority - but  
visible, and happly accepted by all, so it seemed.  i have a biased feeling  
that the gay males there set a high example for energetic, frolicking,  
creative, uninhibited dancing.

[the earliest well-integrated event i recall in SF had its brief life during  
my first year of living in the city, 1990, before i had ever heard the word  
rave in this context.  it was a thursday night gig called "Recess", produced  
by doc martin, who then lived in SF.]

one of the things that most appealed to me (a gay male) in that scene was that 

i could go to events in the company of *any* of my friends, not just the gay  
ones or the straight ones who would feel a bit out-of-place in a gay dance  
club.

so it seemed to me, the scene grew straighter after Toon Town hit it big (new  
year's eve 1991-92).  when Care*Free (a saturday weekly) began at 177  
townsend, it drew (by design) a mostly hip-gay crowd, with a sizeable,  
comfortable minority of straight ravers.  even the gay component was  
well-integrated w/ lesbians and gay males both, a combination unusual in SF  
clubs.  [fond memories of hot, sweating, smiling, energy...]  when the "other" 

big, more ordinary-club-like, less rave-like saturday night gay weekly  
("Colossus") closed, Care*Free was flooded with the Colossus crowd and became  
less rave-like.

since Care*Free closed and continuing to the present, it has seemed to me that 

the SF rave scene is mostly straight, or if there's a sizeable gay component,  
it's no longer visible to me as such.  i still find people in the scene to be  
uniformly gay-positive, and completely accepting of M-M and F-F affection.




From sfraves-owner  Tue May 10 10:23:43 1994

Hmmm. Many interesting points of view here... I don't know if I have a
definitive POV because I'm still trying to figure it all out. I guess
currently I'm suspicious of most "religions" but consider my life to be
intensely "spiritual".   That said, an argument could be made that what
I call "spirituality" is just my form of "religion", if so, then I
definitely feel like I'm "rolling my own" :).

As far as Christ/X -ianity is concerned, like many African-Americans, I
was "christened" in an Xian church (Many neo-pagan types use Xian
instead of Christian to seperate what they feel is some form of hateful
shame that is passing itself off as "Christianity" but has _nothing_ to
do with the spirit of what Christ/Jesus actually taught which IMHO is
pure trancendental Love, Christ would never have burned witches) and
was "confirmed" around the age of 12 at First A.M.E. Zion church in
Brooklyn N.Y.  Even as a child I marvaled at the whole of Creation and
how intricate it all was.  I remember having a couple of peak religious
experiences, but never in the church, being the precocious lad that I
was, I began to wonder why this was so.  By the time I was 14, I was
Out of the Church, I knew that there was a divine (I could see it in
action all around me) but it seemed that the people "in the church" had
lost contact (or never had it in the first place), I also noticed a lot
of judgement and condemnation in the church and I couldn't reconcile
this with the words of Jesus that I read in the Bible, (I used to read
the New Testiment a lot, especially Revelations, which scared and
fascinated me at the same time) Around this same time I had my first
psychedelic experience which only made me realize how little I knew
about reality (and also how much there was to know)  I guess I started
"On the Path" as some would say.

	There was always a lot of what some would call "lower psychism" in my
family.  My relatives, young and old were always "seeing things" and having
dreams of dead "ancestors" and relatives whould would give them messages
(mostly daily numbers :), this was so common that I took it all for granted and
assumed this was the norm, it wasn't until many years later that I found out
this was not the case.  Any way, I began to study vast and wide areas of what
some people would call "The Occult", mostly very basic things like numerology,
astrology, gemitria, palmistry, etc.  But quickly delved into deeper studies 
such as Tarot, Symbology and the finer, more technical and psychological aspects
of Astrology.  All the while I still considered myself a Christian (I didn't 
believe in any foolish concept of forbidden knowledge, and quickly realized
that this was a scam perpetuated by the priests/rabbis to keep the populace
under their control) even though I didn't go to church much.  I flirted with
ceremonial magic but I didn't want anything bad enough to work magic to get it
and I though it was wrong (bad karma) to bend someone to your will just for
your own selfish ends so I sort of fell out of it.  After I moved to Baltimore
I became involved with a "spiritual community" called Savitria where I learned
how to meditate, became exposed to Theosophy, Rudolph Steiner and more advanced
Aspects of Astrology, Tarot and Kaballah.  It was around my 16 th birthday that
I had an extremely intense spiritual experience.  I had stayed home from school
to Trip (something I used to do often) and listen to music, (I was always a 
raver, I used to just do it alone :).  I had just finished listening to 
"Close to the Edge" by Yes and was sitting in lotus position on the floor in
front of my speakers in a very relaxed trippy state, it was a beautiful
sunny summer day and as I gazed ahead of me, I became aware of a tiny-tiny
green bug sitting on the table right in front of my head, as I watch it I became
aware of the life that was this little animal, and the consciousness that 
animated that life, and then I realized that the same force that animated that 
bug, animated and emanated through me... It is hard to explain what happened
next but lets just say that I was everywhere and nowhere at the same time,
actually time had nothing to do with it because I was at the beginning and
at the end and everyplace in between.  For a few seconds or minutes (I don't
know which) I was one with Eternity.  When I came back to earth I was totally
blown away, all of creation was humming and buzzing around me and everything 
shown with an intense light.  I layed down on the carpet in a complete state
of Bliss.  As I was lying there, I became aware of a distinct "sound" sort
of like a tuning fork but much clearer, it seemed to come from everywhere
and inside of me at the same time, in fact it emanated from a place whose 
co-ordinates were at right angles to every co-ordinate in 3-space (I know
this doesn't make sense) as I closed my eyes to listen more intently I became
aware of this "point of light" that seemed to be in the middle of my head,
right between my eyes (where the "third eye" is supposed to be I guess) as
I merged with the sound, the light got brighter and became a small sun.
By this time I was completely wigged out but I had been tripping for several
years and knew the difference between acid hallucinations and this wasn't
one of them, (the dosage that I had taken was relatively low any ways)
well this experience changed my life, I knew it was real because it persisted
for about three days after the trip had worn off.  Occasionally over the years
it has returned but I've had other experiences that were different but
no less compelling since then.  If you begin to study a wide range of world
religions you soon realize that "There is no religion greater than Truth"
to coin the Theosophist motto but more importantly no religion has the complete
story, each one is just a vehicle or viewport to view the Divine from, some
viewports are more suited to different observers at different times in their 
lives but they are viewports never the less, this applies to things like
Big Science (which is very much a religion complete with demi-gods and dogma)
as well as Xian fumdementalism. As far as the Christ and all of that, most folks
(including the atheist) have believed the hype put out by the Church.  Some
would say that my experience was a blast of Christ consciousness, in this
context, what Matthew Fox and his co-horts are getting at makes sense, forget 
about the cross and all that other stuff, most of which the average person 
doesn't understand any more then they understand what happens on the dancefloor at 4 a.m. When you LIVE the Christ Energy THAT is the shit! IMHO Chirst/Jesus
was just dude cruising around with his Chakras fully open and beaming.  If you
have studied any of the various stories/myths legends and FACTS of the indian
subcontinent, then you would realize that the stuff that Jesus did was no big
deal on the level of moving psychic energy.  When your channels are open
and the kundalini/shakti is Boomin' many thing are possible, that is why he said
"And greater things than I have done, ye shall do also".  So I would say
to paraphrase one of my teachers, the choice is really an individual one,
are you gonna spend your time Hating the Church? or are you gonna spend your 
time Loving all of Creation?  Would you all feel better if instead of Matthew
talking about the Cosmic Christ he replaced it with the Cosmic Gel-Cap?
It's all one and the same, the baggage that is present is want you take with
you.  If you look back into the history of humanity, _every group_ has done
so much fucked up shit that they should not have a right to live, and if you
dwell on it, then you might as well give up now.  But part of the message
is that of forgiveness, THIS IS NOT OBEDIENCE, some fucked-up church official
dupted you into thinking that they are one and the same, THEY ARE NOT.
Perfect Love does not mean that you have to tolerate abuse and violence, what it
does mean is that you don't take retribution, when it is your turn to be on top.
(This is where many Xians and other members of large denominatoions go wrong)
They actually start to believe that shit that they are "God's" choosen people
(not that they aren't but they forget that their enemies are as well :) and
start to act out their image of God. So much evil in the world is done in the
name of good, think about your own interactions with children and animals and
see if this rings true,  how often do we become absolute tyrants over beings
that we have ultimate control over?  Is this any better or worse than 
what the Church/Temple  has done to Us?

Well after this rant you might think that I'm comming out in support of
Christianity which I'm not, in fact I think that Judaeo-Christianity in it's
present form is at the root of a lot of the world's problems, but not all.
I dare say that it would be a lot better if Buddist dominated the world but
I could be wrong.  I think fundementally the big difference in the world is
between the people that experience the direct divine essence of LOVE and people
who have not or cannot have that experience.  I myself am pretty much a Goddess
or Divine Mother worshiper (I see Her in all of her forms from Shakti to Kali,
from Hecate to Venus, from Gaia to Nut), mostly it's just a metaphor that I can
access reality from, sorta like a programming language is used to access
the power of a computer, I guess you can always program in assembly language
but that is not always the best choice, (Is C++ beter than LISP?, maybe for 
some things and for some people, times and places but not all) this IMHO is the
same with religious cosmologies.  Pick one and start coding :)

Just a quick reminder to let everyone know about
tomorrow 's South Bay Lunch ...

When: Wednesday  
Time: 12.15 to 1:?? PM  
Where: Greer Park, Palo Alto

Directions:

* From 101 (South or North) take the Oregon Expressway Exit
  Northbound: Past San Antonio Road 
  Southbound: Past University Avenue 

* Left at the first signal - W. Bayshore
  (it's a frontage road that takes you south again)

* Follow this road approx. 1/4 mile (pass apartment complexes on right)
  
* You will see the park on your right hand side. Turn into the first 
  driveway on your right.

* We'll meet on the grassy knoll , behind the round baseball fence.
  Next to the restrooms and ball courts.

Bring lunch, toys, yourselves!

> Um, just being pedantic, but Christ is a title, not a name.  It means
> "the Annointed One".

> Now, instead of arguing about whether Tanya went back to the Church of her

To me, spirituality is beyond the realm of cognitive explanation or 
understanding.  I have found that if I am in tune to the-god-within, then 
I will follow the best path laid out for me.  Consequently, I cannot 
explain why I think I feel happier, only that I do.  I feel this is my 
path because the-god-within is pleased.  I see myself making progress in 
all areas of my life.
It works for me.


  Also, what exactly
> do you mean by having faith?  Is there some kind of removal of
> earthly responsibility involved?  

No.  Faith to me is at the end of intellectual masterbation, so to 
speak.  Its a spectrum.  Essentially after all the mental arguements with 
myself and with others,  it comes down to this: intellectual 
understanding is irrelevant.  I must believe that what I perceive is for 
real and that what I think and experience is valid.  I must trust in my 
experiences and in what I perceive as truth.  I only stipulate that this 
faith in my view of myself and my relation to the universe and God 
pertain to me, and is not something I need to force on others.
And I don't.

> 
> I'm sorry if the above sounds sarcastic, it's not meant that way.  
> 
I didn't take it sarcastically.  Actually, you just sounded interested. 
Cheers!

>Wealth without Work.

I believe there are problems associated with this but I wouldn't say it's
a "root of violence".

>Pleasure without Conscience.

Nothing wrong with this in my little hedonistic brain.  Why should you have
a conscience about this unless your fun is adversly affecting someone, in
which case you shouldn't be doin' it.

>Knowledge without Character.

Now were getting somewhere.  At first I didn't beleive this could happen
but then I realized I was confusing knowledge with wisdom.

>Commerce without Morality.

Yep.  And this comes from greed, one of the TRUE "roots of violence", which
comes from self-centerdness, THE "root of violence" and every other major
social problem, well almost every other social problem.

>Science without Humanity.

Solve the greed problem and you solve this one.

>Worship without Sacrifice.

Maybe, maybe not.  My agnostic brain says "no comment" on this one.

>Politics without Principles.

All politicians have principles, it's just a matter of what they are and
unfortuneatly most of them are linked back to the greed thing again.  
Funny how that one keeps comming up.

-Winston (setting Gandhi straight on a couple o' things) ;-)

Date: Tue, 10 May 94 11:07:46 PDT
From: winston@lurnix.COM (Mark Guthrie)
Message-Id: <9405101808.AA06388@cassy.lurnix.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Aphex Twin
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Steven Hill (of Windham-Hill record label) dedicated a whole hour of
his weekly syndicated space/ambient/new age radio show "Music from
the Hearts of Space" to Aphex Twin (Richard James) last week.  It's
pretty uncommon that the show is dedicated to one artist, usualy it's
a compilation show based on a theme such as "Celtic Twilight" and then
they'll play celtic influenced stuff from various artists or something.
As you could guess, he played stuff from Selected Ambient Works volumes
I and II.  At the end of the show when the play list is read and commentary
is given by Steven Hill he attributed James' success to his "not being
afraid to keep it simple".  Over and out.

-Winston

From sfraves-owner  Tue May 10 14:33:29 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA04454; Tue, 10 May 94 14:33:29 PDT

	id AA04904; Tue, 10 May 94 14:33:41 PDT

From: alves@bethe.ucdavis.edu (David Alves)

To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: faith
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


>>  Also, what exactly do you mean by faith?

>No.  Faith to me is at the end of intellectual masterbation, so to 
>speak.  Its a spectrum.  Essentially after all the mental arguements with 
>myself and with others,  it comes down to this: intellectual 
>understanding is irrelevant.  

Exactly.  
This is the "leap of faith" beyond any personal, logical, moral, belief
system we operate under.  Faith has to be defined as beyond all
intellectual understanding or rationale.  By this measure, faith is
usually beyond words.  A personal experience.  No logical system can prove
any kind of god idea (old man in sky or oneness with universe) - it
fundamentally requires faith.

I think eastern religion (buddhism) addresses this in a more straight
forward manner than western religion.  Christian thinking along these
lines is much newer (this century) but has been explored.  The buddhist
riddles (Koans?) are designed to overload the conscious moment, to 
destroy the mask, to break your logical systems down and give you pure
insight into the universe - existing as part of it or all of it at once.

This suggests a more ancient understanding of faith as beyond intellect.
And in turn, creates a historically wider separation between religion 
and politics (a very good thing).

Nevertheless, I believe that where you place your faith is still arbitrary.  
East vs West (god) is a non-question.

Any person will be influenced by the political history and
ceremonial trappings of a religion.  These differences between
major religions of the world are very real.

Ooooommmmm,
Dave
