>From ez026264@manet.ucdavis.edu  Wed May  4 14:25:21 1994
From: ez026264@manet.ucdavis.edu
Date: Wed, 4 May 1994 13:46:53 -0700
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Censorship


This is a copy of a letter I sent to a few friends. Anyone have
any opinions, ideas, input, etc? I'm not on SFR anymore, so
please email privately.

>From ez026264@manet.ucdavis.edu Wed May  4 13:42:39 1994
From: ez026264@manet.ucdavis.edu
Date: Wed, 4 May 1994 13:39:51 -0700
Message-Id: <199405042039.NAA08112@manet.ucdavis.edu>
To: csc@pilot.njin.net, itchris@manet.ucdavis.edu
Subject: Censorship
Cc: ez026264@hamlet.ucdavis.edu
Status: R


I ran into someone today in the MU: Mike Sheehan, my supervisor for
SESAP, the Student Educators in Substance Abuse Prevention. I am
currently in training to be such a counselor.

SOme time ago, about four weeks, I would guess, Mike Sheehan found out
from me that I have a drug-information database on my account at
UC Davis on the Storer Sun file system (dale.ucdavis.edu, etc.) He
promptly called me to his office to discuss the "appropriateness"
of a potential SESAP intern having such information readily available
_and_ making it available to the public on request. The latest file
listing and caveats relating to my archive can be found by fingering
ez026264@othello.ucdavis.edu

Mr. Sheehan and I met today by chance in the Memorial Union complex
on campus and he mentioned that the day before (yesterday, May 3,
1994, Tuesday) he had talked to Jeanne Wilson of UCD's Student Judicial
Affairs Office regarding my file archive. According to Mr. Sheehan, his
supervisor found my archive somehow distasteful and/or threatening and
contacted Jeanne Wilson. There is now a letter en route from Student
Judicial Affairs to my residence calling me for an appointment, though
I made an appointment with Ms. Wilson promptly upon hearing this
information from Mr. Sheehan. The appointment is scheduled for
Friday, May 13, 1994 at 11:00 am. A possibility that was discussed
between Mr. Sheehan and myself was a change to Information Technologies
policy to disallow the keeping of such an archive on my account.

I would like to know what my rights and responsibilities are regarding
this situation, as well as Information Technologies' opinion on this
matter. It seems to me that censoring my archive by disallowing the
keeping of certain files that one organization finds distasteful,
while the archive obviously does not present a threat to the security
of Information Technologies' hardware or software, is simply not
right.

Please contact me as soon as possible on this matter.

Thank you,


--------------------------------------------------------
  ()  ,    hazrat           _ _ _
  /`-'|  Gregor Mosheh     ' ) ) )          /      /
 /   / __  _  _,  __,_      / / / _____    /_  _  /_
/__-<_/ (_</_(_)_(_) (_    / ' (_(_) \_)__/ /_</_/ /_
              /|      Finger gmosheh@nyx.cs.du.edu
             |/               DO IT NOW !
                       Trust me, you'll like it.

   I understand nobody likes shameless self-promoting, but that's not 
what I am trying to do :)...  I've been spinning house/tribal and some

shows, but I try and do as many local (Monterey) events as I can.

get to know some more people, so if you're interested in hearing one of 
my tapes, just drop me some mail and I'll get one off to you as soon as I 
can.  I'd appreciate perhaps another tape in return or just some comments :)

>From owen_mcinerney@qm.claris.com  Tue May 10 14:06:25 1994
Date: 10 May 1994 14:04:53 U
From: "Owen McInerney" <owen_mcinerney@qm.claris.com>
Subject: Re: Gay Ravers
To: "sfraves" <sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU>

While we're on the subject...

I have being going to Wicked among other raves for almost two years now and
on the way into Wicked at Townsend last Saturday one of the organizers
(Courtney) said aloud  -  "Are you guys sure you're not looking for
ThunderDome the Gay Club that's on around the back - King St." 

I find this really insulting, especially when I have being going to Wicked
for so long now that I practically know half the crowd and I generally hang
out with 15-20 other men/women who happen to be gay/lesbian/bi/don't care 
that have also frequented Wicked for just as long.  

I kinda felt like Wicked was unique where people didn't care; it was above
all that crap/attitude that you get at regular straight/gay clubs. Ah well.


So I felt like saying to the organizer  "F**k you asshole, this is San
Francisco not Kansas" but I resisted and recalled that last time Wicked was
at Townsend (about 2 months ago) there was also jerks on the door(with metal
detectors) but not quite as insulting/segregationist.

P.S.  I did had a great time, was introduced to Markie (God) and successfully
blanked the door insults.

xoxo

there is a definite 'gay men only, thank you' type attitude
where women get dirty looks for existing in that space

this is not THE problem, but A problem...

another is the comment 'well thats pretty much a GAY club, you know...'
as if it were a bad thing

and i've heard that said about a lot of clubs in the LA area
there was one club where the owner was quite prowd that the
crowd was a third gay (with a tinge of lesbian) on a nite
not really advertised as such
that was a good nite, with lots of energy beign provided by the gay men
that wasnt there without them

point being...??

i dunno.. how many gay/lesbians that you know who dont go raving do you invite?
and if they dont want to, is it that they dont like raving or
something else?

 I was wondering if anybody out there could tell me if I would be allowed
to bring my claves with me to MOTION tomorrow night? ( Claves are simple
percussion instruments - two sticks of dense , hard material that go "CLACK"
when struck together) . I have seen percussionists there , but I didn't know
if you had to be a "friend of the promoter" to be permitted to drum. 

 I realize that no drumming should be done within earshot of the DJ , as it
would throw off his monitoring. If I brought mine , I would stand off to the 
side with the other percussionists when I feel like playing.

 I'm especially interested in bringing them tomorrow , as I won't be
doind too much leg dancing -  one of my right leg calf muscles is achy.

 In any case , if I show up withor without claves , I'll be wearing my
Goofy (tm) t-shirt - so if you see me , say hello!

From: resonate@netcom.com (analog resonate)

To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: volunteers needed!
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

	For the Blue Cube party on saturday:

	if any of you community minded partiers would like to help
	out on saturday I would greatly appreciate it.


	we need:

	6 people to take 1 hour shifts walking out side once every
	20 minutes to make sure that no one is hanging out on the street
	or in the driveway. most often there isnt' anyone but the few times
	people start to gather its worth it to ask them to either go inside
	or hit the road.
	so thats about 10 minutes of work out of one hour to help insure
	a bustproof party....


	1 person to be a tape operator for the duel DATs.
	we are DATing each DJ- they are all playing predetermined set lenghts
	to fit on a DAT perfectly. you'll need to start recording on one
	DAT 5 min before the end of one DJs set and start recording 5 min
	before the next dj. this only requires minor audio skills which
	i will be happy to teach. watching the levels would be helpful also
	and i'd be happy to teach that. so you get free professional digital
	audio experience!

	thats it! all volunteers are welcome!

	see you all on saturday- its gonna be a blast!

	-rsn8

intellectual understanding or rationale.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------

I don't necessarily believe this but I might so to play devil's advocate
it could be said that faith is a big cop-out and tottaly irrational attempt
to keep beleiveing something that you want to beleive even when there is
no evidence to support your belief or even evident contrarty to your
belief.  I think I might side with Spok on this one, it seems pretty
illogical.  I believe if there is a god/creator and we are supposed to
seek it (seems like a pretty common internal drive for us) that we are
supposed to use our minds to do it and that quite possibly blind faith
makes the creator embarrased for us.  That's how I'd feel if I gave 
my creations brains and started the hide and seek game and they came up
with all these off-the-wall interpretations about my existence, killed
over different beliefs about me, and used their brains to build weapons
of war and oppresion instead of to better life for everyone and to find
a way to get off this hunk-o-rock to come find me.

But then again, maybe the opposite is true and we will never become
enlightened beings until everyone gives up rational thought and has only
faith.  I tend to believe the former though, as we've seen how much progress
we have achieved through it, even though most of it is for the wrong reasons.
At least it's proven and we know it works, we should just try to alter the
course.  What's the track record for blind faith?

-Winston

From: alves@bethe.ucdavis.edu (David Alves)
Message-Id: <9405112132.AA06294@bethe.ucdavis.edu>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: faith (and raves)
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


(response to Mark Guthrie's comments on faith and an attempt to
 relate this to raving)

You asked what faith was.  I think faith is belief that falls outside
of logic.  You can't prove anyone's god with logic.  Conversely, it is
pointless to use god in a logical argument (i.e. the moronic debates
about abortion where evryone is "right" cuz god says so).

This is the flaw in anyone using god to justify war or any other poltical
action.  I think we agree here.  I respect anyone's "blind faith" but I
do not recognize any moral high ground or the use of god to justify any
political action.  

Finally, I am also not suggesting that you can walk around all the time in 
some blissed out trance state, immersed in your "blind faith" without serious
consequences.  For instance, while you are marveling at the cosmic
oneness of the universe you may very well get run over by a truck.
We need to use our minds and our logic to live and survive.

This seems rave related to me.  It is important to create such a positive
"vibe" atmosphere because we are physically and psychologically vulnerable 
when tranced out or trying to achieve this state.  Regardless of the exact 
personal nature of the spiritual moment. 

Well, at least I tried to close the loop on this one ...
Dave

Subject: new moon review
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


New Moon Review

The New Moon party was in a huge house on Albany Hill, home of 
Gregg, Jeff, Dave and Carmen.  This house is great for parties because 
even when the sound is up, you can't really hear much of anything 
outside on the street, except when the windows are open.  Also, there 
is plenty of room for dance floor (the living room) and chill space.

First, the decor:  Kenneth Paul outdid himself with the chill space.  He 
spread out these beautifully silky parachutes over a couch and 
cushions and hung more from the ceiling.  He decorated the walls 
with posters and hung a huge, beautiful cloth painting of a reclining 
woman illuminated with black lights.  The effect was cosy and warm 
and perfect for nestling and talking.  The altar -a staple of the New 
Moon party, was set up below the dj and consisted of lots of 
momentos of friendship, love, harmony and peace presided over by a 
smiling Buddha surrounded by candles.  Sean brought black lights 
and lots n' lots of toys...yay! plus some gak, which, ahem, can be 
removed from carpet only after some serious scrubbing with soap 
and warm water.  (But it's worth the trouble...)

The evening began with an absolutely fabulous ambient set by M 
Normal.  She really set the tone for the party, which by then was 
going strong with maybe forty or so people who were feeling very 
mellow and companionable.  Mona, the light behind the New Moon 
parties, is resting up back home in Mississippi, but she faxed us a 
virus questionaire which we passed out to people at the party who 
filled it out and decorated it with paints and pen.  Thanks to all those 
who responded- she is going to love these momentos of the party 
which she unfortunately could not attend.

Charles Alexander followed with another ambient set.  By the time it 
was over, we were itchin and twitchin and wanting to dance, and 
Galen satisfied our urges.  Dante spun after Galen.  His set was 
awesome, mindblowing, and had us all screaming and shouting for 
more.  By the way:  he also spins at Together on Tuesday nights at 
1015 Folsom.   Check him out!  Then Kenneth went on:  he gave us 
some funky techno that had us all sweating and shrieking some 
more.  Shortly after daybreak, Charles came on again with more 
ambient followed by Thomas, whose also ambient set mellowed us 
out and set the mood for breakfast- pancakes and eggs for the 
dedicated ones who stayed all night.  Someone else spun after that, 
but I missed it (rats) because I had to go to work.  

Thanks to everyone who came and who helped set up.  It was truly 
an organic effort with lots of people unexpectedly contributing vibe 
and creativity and who truly made this party something to 
remember.  Thanks also to Gregg & housemates who provided this 
fabulous and intimate space.   Oh yes, this party was also to celebrate 
the engagement of Heather and Glen, who will be celebrating their 
wedding at the next one June 9.  The next party will be outdoors- at 
the beach.   If you want to help out, call and leave a message at the 
Great Day Times voicemail:  415-267-3076.

Work at WIRED
and experience life at a successful start-up
where people actually like their jobs!

***Online Publishing Nerd***

If you're a net surfer, Mac literate, and want to help us migrate
WIRED from paper to electrons, this three-month internship is for you.
WIRED is offering a unique opportunity to become one with the machine
language of online publishing.  We need someone to pull text out of
Quark Xpress and format it for database, gopher, WWW (html) and
America Online. Other duties include weeding and feeding our area on
America Online, replying to email, and adding your psychic power to
the creation of a truly out-of-magazine experience.

We'll pay you a measly $100/wk for 30-40 hours of your time, and if
you can come in to the office at least three days a week, you can
telecommute the rest of the time.

Required:
=-=-=-=-=
 o Familiarity with Mac OS
 o Internet experience including telnet, gopher, WWW
 o Available to start work in San Francisco between June 1 and June 15


Desired:
=-=-=-=-
 o Mac graphics experience (Photoshop)
 o Mac spreadsheet experience (Microsoft Excel)
 o Mac database experience (FileMaker Pro, 4th Dimension, SQL-compatible DBMS)
 o Quark XPress experience
 o Microsoft Windows experience (especially Internet apps)
 o UNIX experience - BSDI, SGI IRIX preferred
 o Experience writing HTML  / designing WWW documents / running gopher server
 o Text formatting experience
 o File format conversions on DOS / Mac / UNIX / Windows
 o Familiarity with MUDs / MOOs / Conferencing systems (such as the WELL
   MindVox, FirstClass BBSs, USENET, America Online

Still with us? Then send a resume and references to jobs@wired.com
with the subject line: Online Intern. (No snail-mail, fax, PostScript,
*.pdf files or carrier pigeon submissions, please).

	id AA07382; Thu, 12 May 94 08:55:07 PDT
Date: Thu, 12 May 94 08:55:07 PDT
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9405121555.AA07382@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Something Special is Happening
Cc: sfraves-planners@techno.Stanford.EDU
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

First, kudos to Gregg Helt & his housemates for opening up their home for 
the New Moon party (sorry I couldn't make it).  And thanx to Anthrax
for that great review.  Is it my imagination, or has the tone and content
on SFRaves been very positive and interesting lately?  Especially when 
compared to the travesty Alt.rave has become.

I find it interesting that while the mainstream SF Bay Area House Scene 
has been going through some convulsions recently, there seems to be an
upsurge in special parties like Liquid Air, New Moon, Launch Pad and 
Blue^3.  Add these to In The Light, MESS, Spiral Jive, Atomic Dog, Freak 
Out and some others, and it becomes pretty clear that we've got a thriving 
underground scene here.  All of these free parties, put on and supported 
by people who care what raving stands for tells me that there is a very 
big heart in the House Community that is Beating harder than ever.

The other interesting thing is just how many SFRavers are involved with
these parties.  I am convinced that the communication that is fostered 
on SFRaves helps a lot of us stay clued in to the ideals of our scene.

Personally, I don't buy into the underground vs mainstream split all that
much.  The main promoters in the Bay Area seem to be pretty concientious
for the most part, and the crosspollination between the different types of
parties seems to be healthy for everyone.  SFRavers go to all types of 
parties, and in a way, some of us are like missionaries bringing the 
concepts of communication, hope, and openmindedness to others.  Most of us
don't do this in any overt or orchestrated way.  It's basically a vibe 
thing: just feeling good about ourselves, and communicating positive 
feelings to others.  How I wish there was a scene like this when *I* was 
growing up - maybe I wouldn't have spent as many years of my life hating 
the world around me so much.

Anyway, I just got the flyers for _In The Light_, and they look 
GREAT (thanx Ethan!).  _In The Light_ is going to be a chance to spread
some of our Heart to the mainstream - and we need help flyering for it.
I'll be at the Blue^3 with flyers for anyone who wants to help, especially
people who are planning to go to some big parties over the next couple of 
weeks.  Hopefully, Ethan will have some _Launch Pad_ flyers too.  This is
a fun way to get involved - to be able to invite people to free outdoor
parties being put on by people that you know.  I have to catch a plane 
early the next morning, so I'll only be there until 12 or so.  Hope to see 
you. :-)
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com
____________________________________________________________________________

Yes!! Lots of great shit goin on all around us and it's only gettin better.

Here's a few updates:


Launch Pad: Escape Velocity:
++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
 
is happening -- come hell or highwater -- on sataurday the 21st. As always
it will be FREE and in a most cherished spot. DJs will be: Buck, Meme, Lee,
Ethan, Tamara & some surprise guests. The full soundvision system will be
in effect. We've got nice fliers for it and will have loads of them at the
Blue Cube; please get come from us and help get the word out. Actually I
think this party could get really big. There were *loads* of people
planning on coming to the last one, I'm sure they'll all turn out for this
one. Way it stands now, there's not much else happening that night either.
Call 415.985.5244 for more info.



Test Two
++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

The night before Launch Pad -- Friday May 20.
This party is gonna be great! *Big Warehouse* in SF. Hard dance music by
Alex, Ethan, Takesh & Mac; Live ambience, deep dub, acid and other tweeky,
chilly vibes from Jonah (SpaceTime Continuum), Sir Sensual, Jen from 
Planet 6 and other guests. Audio by soundvision, visuals by Hyperdelic. 
*ALL AGES* $5. Call 415.395.8380 for more info.

From: Zachary Eitzen <zachary@tsunami.ATMOS.ColoState.Edu>

"zippie" stuff - i'm including this, but i have no idea how legit it
is...                                            


 Z I P P Y   P R O N O I A*  T O U R   --  UPDATE / PRESS RELEASE

 (* the feeling that others are conspiring to help you)
 ____________________________________
 THE PLANET AWAITS A SIGN

 Any relatively conscious planeter has at least begun to suspect that the
 competition-based system within which human culture is currently operating
 is incapable of adapting, and needs to be re-coded.  A self-enclosed system
 cannot observe itself (i.e. it has no sense of humour)!

 The Sign for which we all yearn (so deep in our hearts that it feels like
 world angst or personal depression) must announce in a Grand and Magickal
 manner-- as far removed from he old style Business Plan as possible-- that
 WE, the relatively conscious, are a hell of a lot more numerous than even WE
 supposed.  This Sign must also demonstrate these numbers-- that, indeed, it
 is precisely because we have been increasing daily underground that the
 point has now been reached where the manifesting of such a Sign has become
 possible... and inevitable.

 For consider: this Sign, because it will alert the next fractal ring of
 increasingly conscious planeters, will precipitate unimaginable global
 social change.  Therefore, the most important questions become: from where
 in the culture could this Sign appear?  Are there already hints of it?  And,
 are YOU ready to help it happen?

 In very real, here and now terms, where is there a new cooperative cultural
 meme of sufficient and accelerating numbers into which we might usefully
 insert and apply our own skills and energies? This meme must also make its
 adherents eager to swarm together in large celebrations of new lifestyle.

                The news is good.  Very, very good.

 I see only one sociological phenomenon within Western Culture which has any
 chance of bringing about the required maximum change in the maximum number
 of people in the minimum period of time.  UK Rave Culture has been evolving
 for five years now, and at its most accelerated, the tribal rave scene has
 united the raw young idealism and enthusiasm of Rave with the eco-wisdom of
 Festival Culture to produce a mix of meltdown proportions.

 T H E   Z I P P Y, harmonised in both hemispheres of the brain,
 technoperson and hippie.

 Nobody has to give up anything-- merely start activating your ignored
 hemisphere.  Literally ALL are welcome, for all will benefit.  And its
 because everyone will be happier when the evolution has occurred that it
 will succeed.  You are invited (and very definitely needed) to make it
 happen.
                        -Fraser Clark
                         London
                         May, 1994

 And the latest dates...

 NOTE:  Where Rave is used, Ambient Rave is intended
 **************************************************************
 May 15                 Rainbow Gathering in Central Park, New York
                        Michael John introduces the Zippy Idea to Family

 June 9-11              Zippy Netweave Legend Launch (Press Conference)
                        3 p.m., The Meadow, Central Park, New York
                        (Possible fund-raiser private party or clubs)

 June 18                        NYC Rave
                        (other E. Coast events June 7-24 are being
 finalised)

 June 24/25             Boulder, CO Raves

 July 1-8               Rainbow GatherRave
			Rainbow Gathering, Wyoming

[ NOTE:  I SINCERELY DOUBT this will be a rave in the "loud dance-amplified 
music" sense.  From what I've read they're just going to hang out at the
Gathering, and then continue on their journey. If they had any plan of
throwing a "traditional" rave at the Rainbow Gathering, I am sure it will 
be squelched when they meet up with the Rainbow Family ;-) It has been
stated several times that ravers/zippies are welcome at Rainbow 
Gatherings, but that the amplified music is NOT.  -- Laura ]

 July 8- Aug 21         Zippy Pronoia dates TBA

                        Each night at World Unity Music Festival
                        Flagstaff, Red Butte, AZ
                        South Rim, Grand Canyon  (Free outdoor on 26th??)

                        250,000 Zippy ravers at/around Biosphere 2, Arizona

From sfraves-owner  Thu May 12 12:52:11 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA16439; Thu, 12 May 94 12:52:11 PDT
Received: from netcom.com (netcom4.netcom.com) by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA16177; Thu, 12 May 94 12:33:21 PDT
Received: from DialupEudora by netcom.com (8.6.8.1/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id MAA19684; Thu, 12 May 1994 12:33:37 -0700
Message-Id: <199405121933.MAA19684@netcom.com>
X-Sender: nrg@localhost
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Thu, 12 May 1994 12:36:04 -0800
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
From: nrg@netcom.com (ethan miller)
Subject: Friends & Family
Cc: sfraves-planners@techno.Stanford.EDU, komotion@netcom.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I remember being amazed, when I first dicovered sfraves, at the degree to
which parties were analyzed. The door price, cost--or lack there of--of
water, ventilation, sound quality, door person/security courtesy level,
general vibe etc., were all thoroughly evaluated. Essential information to
any 'promoter' that actually *cared* about the people he/she expected to
come to, to pay for their party.

The value of this was not lost on me; for I realised that here was the
essential yet missing ingredient in much of our culture, indeed modern
society: a caring relationship between producer and consumer. There is
nothing inherently wrong with the producer/consumer relationship: if we are
eskimos and you build for me a kayak knowing full well that my life and my
family's well being depends on its integrity, if its constuction reflects
your love and respect for our family, then I am overjoyed to pay you, to
put the same love and respect into what I do for you, this being one of the
bases for what we might call community. In this way producer/consumer
becomes: give service, get service. Removing temporal immediacy from the
relation adds yet that much more freedom to it, as it now reflects a
deposit of trust and faith in the community, your belief that it will meet
your needs now and in the future.

Communication, feedback, trust, faith, belief.

So when it occurred to me to 'throw parties' it was with the full benefit
of the knowledge that, to do so, I would be engaging in a trusting and
caring relationship with you, the people I cared about and hoped would come
to my party, to our party, to this profound celebration of life we have
found we can create together.

Along the way I learned something really funny: the less a party cost you,
the less it cost me. "Home" cost you $15 and me $1000. "Chez Groove" cost
you $10 and me $300. At least I was making progress ;-) The obvious outcome
of this trend is that free parties cost the least: $100 gets you fliers, a
generator, a trailer to haul the sound system in, duraflame logs, blow
pops.
Split two ways it still costs less than organic ;-)  ;-) (double wink). 

But more importantly the energy is different. We all come prepared to give,
prepared to share. This is something to celebrate. 

One of my favorite parties that fell out of this approach was the first
Blue Cube party: Friends & Family. It was really an awesome demonstration
of what we (yes--sfr!) can do together. 

Ever since, I've been kinda working up to trying to do the next one. I
think we maxed out the Blue Cube on that one so I've been looking for a
space that could accomodate more of us and be in posession of the following
essential characteristics: two rooms (to support our awesome array of sfr
talent) all ages, all night, in sf, good people, good energy behind it, and
of course: low cost. Well I've found it and I'm psyched. The space is
called Komotion (many of you know it, and yes, there will be big fans
present ;-). 

Here's their blurb:

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
Komotion is an artist's collective, an alternative, an experiment. We are a
diverse group of musicians, writers, artists and engineers seeking to
create an environment that inspires and informs. Our multi-purpose arts
center is home to some 40 musicians who perform, rehearse and record here.
Our evening events, run by all-volunteer labor, are adventurous and bring
forward special talent. We have presented music of all kinds, art, poetry,
film, theatre, video and dance, as well as hosted numerous benefits. Our
engineers produce many recordings by emerging Bay Area artists in our
16-track studio. A core of writers works on our magazine, which provides a
forum for debate around cultural and political issues.

Komotion doesn't pay the performers at its events except to cover their
expenses. The door charge, drink prices, etc. are so low that in general,
we can only cover the rent and the basic expenses out of the events. Even
without money, however, many new acts and established artists have chosen
to perform here. Being artists ourselves, we put great care into the sound
and other aspects of the facility, to create the best possible experience
for performer and audience alike. The actual scheduling of events, editing
of the magazine, etc., is sone by committtee in a kind of anarchistic
fashion. We find things to be livelier with as few rules as possible.

Komotion has a current membership of about 300 locally and another 100 or
so internationally. At this point, our events are not "membership only" but
becoming a member is an expression of support for a center of this kind. On
our tenuous budget, *we need your support* to continue. Becoming a member
means contributing money or something neede for the Klub's operation. $5,
$10, $20, and $50 memberships are available, though donations of any amount
are welcome.

For more information: call: 415.648.4923; or email: komotion@netcom.com
++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

As much as I'd like to do this one absolutely free, Komotion relies on
their weekly parties to pay the rent, and IMO, they're a fantastic group of
people, and a killer space well worth our support. So the upshot is: we can
do a no-cash-up-front, very-low-cost-party ($3 at the door) that will cover
our hard expenses and have the added benefit of supporting Komotion which
has been a long standing home to tons of killer underground sf talent.

The date is set for Saturday June 18th. So far we have:

Dance:
Alex (sfr)
Ethan (sfr)
Lee (sfr)
Spun (maybe)
Tony (maybe)
And I'm gonna see if Markie is interested...

Ambient:
Meme (sfr)
Ronan (sfr)
Joe Rice (sfr)

Visuals:
Donovan

We still need visuals, beanbags, lights, furnishings etc. for the ambient
room and the dance room. If Spun, Tony, & Markie can't make it (there's a
huge Cool World offering djs megabucks at the Cow Palace that night; funny
coincidence, the last huge Cool World was the same night as the last F&F,
which, actually, wasn't a coincidence in that case) then there will be
additional DJ slots available as well. As you can see there is stil room dj
wise in the ambient room though I'm hoping M and Charles will spin as well,
though I haven't asked them yet. Fliers will be done as soon as the lineup
settles down, so please get some from me and help spread the word.

Needless to say *your* involvement is not only welcome but requested. 

take it easy
ethan

 ethan miller                     nrg                            pgp me

I haven't heard of anything for Friday, so maybe you can get some sleep
and get ready for the next night, with another Blue Cube party, w/SFR
DJs and partiers galore, and also the return of Vision...

--------------------- UPCOMING RAVES IN THE SF/BAY AREA ---------------------

Thursday, May 12th - Flour
        Dani & Mark Farina
        Deco, 510 Larkin @ Turk.  21+. 441.4007.
        (will be every other Thursday)

        DJs: Meme, Laura, Lee, Will, Ethan
        for info/directions email resonate@netcom.com w/subject line: INFO

        Spun  Josh  DJ Dan  Ernie Munson  Rick Preston

        $10, 18+ w/id.  415.487.4339  415.486.9400

        Markie Mark  Garth  Josh  Tony  Doran  Mark Farina
        415.267.4800    408.236.2022

        Brass Recording Artist Lalomie Washburn
        Music by Mark Farina, Marques Wyatt, Kevin of Stone Groove & Stu P.
        at the Sound Factory, 525 Harrison.

Friday, May 20th - Test 2
        live acid trance, ambient room (Jonah, Sir Sensual and Jen) and
        hard trance w/Alex, Ethan, Takesh & Mac
        All ages, $5.
        415.395.8380

Friday, May 20th - Mother Earth Sound System #7
        DJs Brad, Scottie, Stonie, and guests
        all nite long  (510) 549-6240  (415) 487-7681

Friday, May 20th - Trip Zone - 510-380-3131

Saturday, May 21 - 25th Anniversary of Berkeley Free Clinic
        Come celebrate 25 years of community service with:
        the Mother Earth Sound System DJs & 
        KALX DJs Minor Minor, Nami, and Benny B
        FREE - 2110 5th St. (@ Addison, beside Steamworks), Berkeley
        For info, call the BFC @ (510) 548-1666 or contact MESS

Saturday, May 21st - Launch Pad II
        DJs will be: Buck, Meme, Lee, Ethan, Tamara & some surprise guests. 
        The full soundvision system will be in effect. :)

Saturday, May 28th - SFRaves presents In The Light
         ->Get Infected by Meme -> 
         ->Trance out with Laura ->
         ->Take an Acid House Bath with Markie->
         Audio by SoundVision - Three Turntables
        noon to 6pm at the bandshell, Golden Gate Park.

        415.266.8215    415.241.8815

        Chill-Core-Collective and Lotus

of them may have ended - let me know when that happens...

to get all the info every week.

majordomo@sfraves.stanford.edu with either the line

s*bscribe sfraves-calendar   or
uns*bscribe sfraves-calendar   

(type 'u' in place of the '*' - i've taken out the 'u' so this message
 passes thru majordomo's filter)

I'm also pleased with the current 'state of the vibe', and am hoping to
be around the SF scene more in the next few weeks.  I can't make it
down for Blue Cube II, unfortunately, but hope to be at both F&F and
In the Light.  June is On the Road with the Grateful Dead for me, which
starts June 8-9-10 at Cal Expo in Sacramento, and proceeds to Seattle,
Eugene, Las Vegas and Shoreline the weekend before July 4th, plus whatever
raving/housing/trancing I can get in, in between.  And any DJing I can
possibly do as well, of course!  *Plus* my long-hoped-for promo tape which
is | | this close to being "in the can."  I'm not sure when I'll have the
entire package including J-cards ready but I should have at least some
cassette dubs by the end of May for your listening enjoyment.  I'm feeling
a lot better about my mixing in part because of the discipline of doing
the takes on the promo (eight so far and two or three more to go) and in
part because of a big step forward that suddenly sort of happened during
my practice session night before last.  I don't know how to describe it
except to say it was a lot like what we called "going over the hump"
back in my ham radio days of learning Morse Code.  It seemed like there
were a couple of spots where everyone struggled to get through, one was
around 5 words per minute (I was doing WPMs long before BPMs :) and
another around 12, and another around 18.  And once you got past 18
you could 'hear' words instead of just letters on Morse Code (or CW as
us hams usually call it), a sort of 'opening up' or wider field-of-
perception.  It was kind of like that the other night; I've been listening
to other mix tapes to pick up on beat-matching and mixing techniques, and
had been listening (again, for the nth time) to some of the Connection II
tapes and in particular to the Jon Williams/Phil Smart "Kitchen Synch"
tape, and something sort of *happened* and I felt like a whole couple of
months of struggling with vinyl mixing techniques finally paid off.  Whew!

So anyway, I'm getting jazzed to be on the road again after a couple of
months sticking pretty close to home here in Portland and (unexpectedly)
moving from my long-time house share to an apartment.

So . . . be prepared . . . be positive . . . and see you in the future!

phred

I know this sounds a little crazy, but what the heck, these opportunities
only come around once in a great while.

If anyone cares to join me, I'm planning to go to In the Light during the
day on the 28th (I'll already be in SF because DB Expo is at the Moscone
Center that week, the one computer trade show a year I do now that
Interop has moved to Las Vegas), and then fly directly to Seattle for
the XLR8R/Choclit Factory/Astralwerks Earthspace Xtravaganza that night!
I'll check on airfares and availability tomorrow and put the info here
in case anyone else has the same crazy urge.  It may not be possible
to do this because of flights being booked up for the holiday weekend,
but I tend to think that Saturday evening flights are easier to get
than others during that time period.  

see you in the future!

driving. Inspirations lost their 18 and up license aabout two weeks ago, 
and have decided to move the thing to the Oasis, but they couldn't get 
the booking until next week, i believe, so they have ahd their last two 
parties a bit incognito. Anyway, my room mate, Talizman, who often posts 
to you guys through my account, spun first and did a pretty good job, got 
the crowd going ( all 25 of them), but just as he was getting into it, 
the S.J. police showed up and said turn it off. Apparently you need a 
license for amplified music after dark. The police were cool, though no 
shouting or force, just said that was the way it was and we had to turn 
it off. the promoters ( forgive me for not knowing their names)  were 
going to move the party elsewhere, but  my group took off, so I don't 
know what happened after that. 
that's my little report on inspirations. If anyone has anything to add or 
correct, please do.
peace.
btw personally i thought talizman was great, but i figure people might 
consider me biased, so i thought i would just add it at the end.
kathy


From sfraves-owner  Fri May 13 13:42:40 1994

	id AA06554; Fri, 13 May 94 13:42:45 PDT
Message-Id: <9405132042.AA06554@groovy.us.oracle.com>
Date: Fri, 13 May 94 13:42:45 PDT
From: Bob Ramstad <rramstad@us.oracle.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Motion + "red lights" + sale
Reply-To: boccibob%groovy@us.oracle.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


Motion was a good time.  Saw some SFR people enjoying themselves.
(RobertJ, Mr. Grigsby, Larry Ching, Pete Reiter...)  Excellent
visuals, good crowd.  Loren spun first and did a really nice job, but
with no crowd to enjoy it really.  Spun came on and managed to get
really out there by the end of his set.  Jeno then twisted things
pretty good, and along the way, managed to play almost all of the
records that he owns that I really love.  Definitely a good time.  I'm
really glad that Rick (who is a very mellow/cool/nice guy) and the
rest of the posse continue to bring this excellent production to SJ.

(Safety tip/note: both Spun and Jeno like to turn up the mixer until
all the red lights are on.  for you DJs, this is ignorant and stupid
behavior, as this means that the mixer is putting out a lot of
distortion.  if you want it truly loud and also care about the quality
of sound (and the comfort of the people at the party), set your levels
so the mixer is only going into one red light occasionally, and then
the sound person will probably be happy to turn up the main gain on
the power amps.  much better all around.  never ceases to amaze me
that DJs think that they can get louder by cranking the mixer all the
way over, when really this just pisses off the sound people who
immediately turn everything way the fuck down so the stacks aren't
destroyed by THD.)

I'm going to be at the Blue Cube on Saturday... please excuse the
quasi-commercial nature of this info, but I'm clearing out all of my
rave tape inventory.  Prices will hold until everything is GONE... act
fast to avoid disappointment.  C2 (4 tape set), only 40 left, are now
$10.  Carlos tapes, only 20 left, now $5.  This is it, once these are
gone, they'll never be reprinted...

(FYI Liquid Air is now out of print and is no longer available.)

I'm really looking forward to the Blue Cube party and hope to see
everyone there!

Bob

Ya know,

There are not many things that can really irk me these days, but this
*person*, if I may call it that, is a rare exception.

First he talks to me about how elitist I am, then he posts some shit like
the above.  Wassup wit dat.  AND wasup wit YOU?  Why is it that you have
such a fucking bug up your self-riteous ass?  What is it with you, that
after railing against me, and others, about our apparent elitisism that you
see it completlely within your bounds to  be such a prick?  Why, for
instance, do you have such a grip against Wicked for its supposed elitism,
then say some elitist, self-serving rubbish about *your* party at *your*
place as if *you* were the end all to this entity (bka the scene)?

Man you need to check yourself.  Geoff was asking a very simple question,
and your *veiled* attempt at sarcasm, if I may call it that, was
unwarranted.  Personally, since I now know it is at your place,I will not
attend.  Could care less about you or any event remotely associated with
you.  You, and people *like* you, are the reason people stay away from
parties. And statements like the ones you have made, are one of the MANY
reasons for the complete possifcation of this scene (which existed before
blue ^3 parties, and will outlast them in some way shape and form).

The idea behind many of the things I have said (meet people, get to know
them, get info), is all part of *building* a community.  Getting to know
the promoter, dj, partiers, whatever is all a part of getting to know the
community.  It's not elitist, its called getting to know your neighbor and
eventually becoming friends.  You on the other hand, spout all this shit,
and I *mean* shit, about love togetherness, and then base it upon some
rigid laws *you* and *others* of your ilk have decided should be followed,
and then make no attempt to exend that philosphy above your blessed clique
(and beleive me, this list has just about as many cliques and as much
politix as the larger scene has).  In effect, *what* in the fuck have *you*
done?

Have you tried to extend what you call a party, to those who are unitiated,
and *not* so well connected (i.e. via computer).  I didn't see flyer one of
this event at the last Wicked (which provided a great opportunity for you
to *educate* those so ill informed).  Or is it that it is word of mouth?
(Hell, I ain't heard SHIT about this gig from the populus, so word must
*not* be getting out).  Or is it really just more of the same bullshit
philosophical masturbation about how *you and others* are so clued in, and
others not?  It's all about being that geek being laughed at, who now has
the last laugh?  It's all about *not* being PC  when it comes to diversity?
Get a clue newbie, get a clue.  You just gettin started while others have
already run this fucking race...

Look man, talk the talk, then walk the walk.  Anything less, you're doin
nuthin' but frontin'.  No future in it, believe that.  Next time you bag on
*insiders* think about how *inside* you're actin'.  Think about how
prejudice you're acting, think about how unforgiving and rigid you're
acting, and think about the image you present to those of us who reside in
BOTH scenes.  From my perspective, not a pretty site.  So I hope you, *and*
*your* posse have a good time.  *I* have decided to boycott your shit, and
any future event assocaited with you.  *I* have decided that you are nothin
more than a fronting, elitist newbie, who's trying to step, but don't know
*who* to step to.  *I* have decided that you are just like all other
fronters who talk a good game, but are hypocritical when it comes to
delivering or living up to a standard that you set (so arbitrarily too).
Weak...

Save your flames, put me in your killfile, could give a fuck.  We can talk
reasonably, as soon as you get your proverbial head outta your ass and stop
fronting.  Like I said, no future in it.

Others:  Please save your private e-mail about how wrong/right I am.  I
have taken the time to meet and speak with some of you, and you know who
you are.  If we have talked *personally* I do not mind hearing from you.
All others, who don't know *shit* about me (as much as I then would know
about you), save it.  Virtual community notwithstanding, unless we talk
face to face, neither of us know shit.  Analog Res has a serious bug up his
ass (probably as big as the one up mine, but I *know* I have a bug up my
ass.  Therein lies the difference), and his pontificatiing and over
religious attitude is sickening.  Fuck 'im and *any* other like him.
People like him form posses of knucleheads, so unforgiving, so full of
themselves (esp since they *think* they got a clue).  Not really interested
in people like him.


More damage:  Mr Fox, or should I say THE REV.->  Not interested in anyone,
especially a rev/preist trying to grow his flock so he can fleece 'em. I
trust him and *his* ilk as much as I trust the NSA/CIA/FBI/General Spooks
(I am African American so I can say the word Spook/Nigger/Colored since
that is *my* way of taking the word back, and thus diminishing it's power.
I would not trust such power to those who are *not* of the aformentioned
culture within our great
USofKKKSexistRacistNonDiversifiedWonderbreadKultura.).  C'mon, get REAL.  I
did not have to hear what he says, or what he's trying to do since it has
been done before (it's called being a missionary.  Wiped out whole
cultures/races, all in the name of growing the flock, spreading the word
and fleecing them *by any means necessary*).  If history is a good teacher
(2000 years of such teachings), and is any indication of the future, I
would hedge my bets on Pagans.  Hell, at least they make no bones about
what their deal is, quite the pragmatists too.  If this guys so friggin'
open, why in the *hell* does he wear a collar, or is even associated with a
specified religion. WHY is it that he wants come over here trying to spread
that word, expand that mission?  Muthafuka needs to go to the HVP (Hayes
Valley Projects) or POHill (Potrero Hill), or even North Beach (yuppie
overpaid money grubbers), or the Presidio (home of Diane "Old Bag"
Fienstein <- Yes, old bag is Sexist, but I never said I was not a sexist
dog ;)).Now *those* are some folx who need saving/growing/flocking/fleecing
IMO. As PE said, CANT TRUSS IT!!!  The scene don't need him or any other
collar to come here and *gorw* it  (reading about relgion and becoming an
"expert" is a far cry from living it.  He ain;t no Black Baptist, or a Jew,
so *what* does he know outside of his readings?  It's called LIVING IT,
WALKING IT, TALKING IT.  And I KNOW he has NOT done all THREE.  Summarily
disqualified....

I am quite done now.  Analog get a clue newbie, I consider you nothing more
than a vegetable TRYING to be meat (i.e. fronting).
Foxianswhowannagivethesuckaachance, *I* ain't with it.  Get in line, he has
his clippers, whose next to get fleeced.

Audi 5 & save your jive,
John S. Lee

> Ya know,
> 
> There are not many things that can really irk me these days, but this
> *person*, if I may call it that, is a rare exception.
> 
> First he talks to me about how elitist I am, then he posts some shit like
> the above.  Wassup wit dat.  AND wasup wit YOU?  Why is it that you have
> <more missing-the-joke stuff deleted>

Is it me, or isn't it apparent that he was trying to crack a _joke_?
   If he were serious about the fuck-you, then he wouldn't have offered
   directions via email.

The point of email directions is to reduce the number of casuals- "please
   only come if you really want to be here (specifically)" - it's not
   necessarily to be elitist.  While in theory, access to the info is all
   the same (assuming our hero isn't being selective about who he replies to),
   the fact is that posting a location/etc. will necessarily attract a
   larger, less intimate crowd.  That's fine for some kinds of events, but
   not for all.

now: peace.

like,
adam

ps. I'm going to be in the New York region (nyc + li) during June- can
    anyone recommend events/djs I should seek out in my journey?

uh, john, regardless of analog's attitude (or not), what you said was not
only uncalled for but stated at exceptionally verbose length.  i'm not
involved in this party because I'm back at home doing the TKOB shuffle,
so it doesn't affect me one way or the other, but he generously has made
his place available now a couple of times and the last Blue Cube Affair
was a rocketship by everyone's estimation.  

his place is small and if i were him i wouldn't want flyering or even
postering here on the net to bring the possibility of more folks than
the place can handle, and that is not an impossibility.  i wouldn't
have put it as indelicately as he did, but consider that aspect of it.

i've never met you but i've read and appreciated what you have written
here over the past year or more and all i can say is . . . you seem to be
in a situation where you *need* to go out and kick out the jams all night
at a good party!!  i mean, i *know* this feeling, on thursday as the
consequence of a dozen little difficulties i had the biggest flip-out
public tantrum i can recall in at least a year . . . so now that it's
done let's go on, and i sure hope i witness the handshake between you
and analog either next week at Launch Pad or at the Park on the 28th.

So there!  No frontin', just the way I see it.

I got to Blue Cube around midnight.  Lotsa of people hanging out talking
and lotsa of people dancing.  I finally was able to get some faces
attached to these e-mail addresses!  The people were very friendly and
receptive.  I was upset there was alcohol but no one ever got out of hand. 
I think I'm so used to people drinking to get wasted that I didn't see
people just drinking to have a good time.  I heard a little bit of Laura
and Lee An, (and Willy?).  I enjoyed the records they put on.  I would of
liked to see more black lights inside the dance area.  I stayed til 4:30
and got had a good time.  Got to meet some new faces.. and make some
people happy.

Thanks to everyone who made it out to Pt. Richmond for the free Freak Out!
party on Friday night. We had it jumpin with aprox 100-150 prople dancing
under the stars and the trees and leaves and other nocturnal creatures of the
night.
No thanks to the Richmond police dept  for busting it up at 4am and giving
Pat a ticket for tresspassing, unlawful assembly, and having a vehicle in the
park. 
Since we made about 1,200 invites and got several hundred calls on the voice
mail we were hoping for a bigger crowd but we heard that the cops had the
entrance to the tunnel blocked off.
After dealing with the police we moved it to the Berkely Marina where Pat
spun records until 9am when the crowd had dwindled to about 20 people.

We will be doing another party sometime in June and another on the fourth of
July so keep your ears and eyes open.

Hope to see you all at the next one!

-SeanC43@aol.com 

PS - Call the Freak Out! line (415) 485-6597

From sfraves-owner  Sun May 15 20:49:30 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA26747; Sun, 15 May 94 20:49:30 PDT
Received: from soda.berkeley.edu by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA26740; Sun, 15 May 94 20:49:24 PDT
Received: (laura@localhost) by soda.berkeley.edu (8.6.9/PHILMAIL-1.10) id UAA05429 for sfraves@techno.stanford.edu; Sun, 15 May 1994 20:49:41 -0700
Message-Id: <199405160349.UAA05429@soda.berkeley.edu>
From: laura@soda.berkeley.edu (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Sun, 15 May 1994 20:49:38 -0700
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: blue parties for cubed heads
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Every time there is an FMR and non-connected people post to 
SFRaves asking for directions they get chastized by people who 
have been around and/or who have direct connections with the Wicked 
posse.  You'd think people could follow directions that had been 
posted at least three times to the sfraves list, were listed in the 
sfraves calendar, and were printed in Martin O'Brien's "Choices" 
newsletter to find out how to get to the Blue Cube.

Somehow enough people found out to pack Steve's kitchen, hallway, 
under-stair area, garage, and chill room.  It's a good thing there 
wasn't more publicity or else there would have been too many people 
for the space to handle.  I don't know how many people were there.  
Many of them were from the Santa Cruz compute-hack-have-fun scene, 
and so were newbies in the raver sense and had a good time trying out 
the funky acid techno trance house beats and meeting and talking to people 
from a more sfraverish background.  I thought it was great that so many 
people trekked in from so far away to hang out and make a good time.

It was marvellous getting to hear Bryce spin.  He ALWAYS gives up his
slots to everyone else, and after hearing him finally take a turn
I am thinking that we should not let him give up his spots anymore!!
So if Bryce says to you "oh, go ahead, I don't care if I go on or not"
prod him a little bit!  Ethan and Lee were as trancey/acidy cool as 
always.  My friend Will, who's visiting from New York, was absolutely 
killer in the "clean up" spot.  I walked into the dance area and it was
a sweatbath . . . lots of brassiere and booty going on.  People were 
asking me who Lee and Will were, and why they never get on flyers in SF.
In Will's case it's because he's just visiting, and I guess in Lee's it's 
because he's so darn busy with finishing school.  I'm always happy when 
Lee comes out to play and hang with us, because I know he's making an 
extra effort.

I think extra effort goes a long way in parties.  The people I met
from Santa Cruz and Napa made an extra effort to come all the way in
to a party that wasn't "guaranteed" by having a known promoter or
DJ behind it.  People made an extra effort in general by following 
instructions to email for directions (sort of like with the "treasure
hunts" to find the FMR -- we've heard all the arguments defending the 
FMR by saying that in making it harder to find they ensure that they 
get mostly "true believers").  Will made an extra effort to schlepp his 
record-filled flight case out from NYC.  People who shared candy, 
cigarettes, lighters, beer, and conversation made an extra effort to 
be social.  You get my drift . . . the whole thing was rather inspiring 
in that it was all do-it-yourself/friends-doing-it-for-friends which gave 
things a close and intimate intensity.  

Unlike most of the rest of you all, I arrived in San Francisco 
too late to ever really be a part of any of the older, more established 
original rave families, so I love what's happening with the sfraves/sound
vision/metrovision/liquid air/launch pad conglomeration.  It's still an 
open system for me.  In these smaller intimate parties I meet and get
to know lots of people.  This has the comforting side effect that when
I do venture out to something larger and crazier like Come/Unity I
don't feel so lost -- there are a few people sprinkled through out the
crowd that I can touch base with.   Come hang with us!  There will 
be many renegades and a few larger parties all summer!  

Anyway, big hugs to everyone who came, to Steve for donating the use
of his house, to Bryce for the sound system and gear.  There will
be more of the same but different (different DJs, different location)
next weekend at the Launch Pad.  Dress in layers and save the phone line 
number next time you see it so you will know how to find directions. 
There are flyers at Ameba if you want a concrete reminder.  Info 
is also on the sfraves calendar which comes out on Thursdays.

Laura

Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: isn't it a MISUNDERSTANDING 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Sun, 15 May 94 20:11:23 PDT."
             <199405160311.UAA02685@netcom.com> 
Date: Sun, 15 May 94 23:45:07 -0700
X-Mts: smtp
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

John,

   You suck.  The scene- any scene- could do without this.  The dude's
   trying to be reasonable.  Your need to "speak the way you want to" is,
   actually, really really offensive.  Think about it: I don't even know
   you and I can't imagine you talking to people like this in person.
   You'd get punched in the mouth.  It's like you're picking fights.

   The rest of us already posted several independent and consistent
   accounts of why someone would want to give directions by email.  The
   thing to do at this point is say, "hey- difference of opinion" and let
   it go.

   I actually see your point, and it's reasonable: there's a fine line
   between emailing everyone and being selective about it.  Even if he
   doesn't, it still might feel like he is to the uninitiated, perhaps used
   to traditional, exclusionary "club" scenes.  I get that.

   But it's time to realize that email isn't the same thing as your diary-
   real people exist on the other end of the wire, and their feelings get
   hurt.  Those are fighting words; you should think twice before sending
   the verbal assault- I don't care if you're right or not: he didn't
   deserve the battering, and it's net.uncool of you to say such things,
   especially in a public forum.  If nothing else, it makes it unpleasant
   to receive mailing lists when flame wars rage.  You're not a newbie: you
   should know better.  There's no need for flames, especially in public.

   It's time to apologize: people fuck up over email all the time- I've
   been there many times myself.... it's easy to lose track.  But it's
   something you should really consider.  Reread the letters you sent, and
   imagine if you were the recipient.

Think about it,
adam


> >        hey j lee, my point was that i will mail EVERYONE directions.
> >        EVERYone is invited and its not one of your wicked "don't tell

From sfraves-owner  Sun May 15 23:46:33 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA29131; Sun, 15 May 94 23:46:33 PDT
Received: from netcom.com (netcom6.netcom.com) by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA29124; Sun, 15 May 94 23:46:26 PDT
Received: by netcom.com (8.6.8.1/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id XAA28673; Sun, 15 May 1994 23:46:51 -0700
Date: Sun, 15 May 1994 23:46:51 -0700 (PDT)
From: "JMRTNKO, the real McCoy!" <martinko@netcom.com>
Subject: 'possification'
To: as if waves <sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9405152231.A22289-0100000@netcom6>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


Hmm... sounds like this has become a dirty word on the list. Maybe I 
should have typed 'p*sse' instead. What I want to know is, what the big 
gripe with it? There are as many different tastes in parties as in music 
(I tend to dig that ez-listening freezer food aisle planetarium 
intermission groove myself). So what's wrong if I tend to gravitate to 
people closer to my own mindset? Doesn't mean I don't go out for parties 
of other flavor. Doesn't mean I slam people with other appetites. If you 
love fish, you don't hang out in a steakhouse (gee can you tell I just 
ate dinner?).

Putting on these events is a drain on time, energy and money. If I'm 
benefitting by going attending them, I like to make sure I can give 
something in return. Naturally, if enough people feel this way, it'll 
create a more close-knit group. Doesn't mean the door is closed on new 
folks. Doesn't mean one family is 'better' than another. There's much 
intermarriage between the families of the SF bay.

(now that I've recalled one of the gripes) Yeah, I guess it makes it hard 
on new events to grab a following, but many of us have been burned by the 
fly-by-night cash-rave cutlture of a few years ago, so there's a little 
leftover distrust (on my part at least) of forking over my cash and 
time and energy to anyone and everyone who decides to rent out a night at 
a club or cut a bolt on a warehouse door. I'm not in it just for the 
music or just to hear the best DJ that Walla Walla has ever seen. For me, 
the groove comes as much from the people as it does the music. So 
sometimes I'll pass on something I don't know when something I do know 
and have been looking forward to is going on. An unknown party may be 
good, but the promoters we already know and respect need just as much 
support.

(now that I remember another one) And yeah, a lot of the sfr/f+f stuf 
isn't heavily promoted. But I don't remember one instance where anyone 
was unwelcome. When you've already got a crowd maxing out your space and 
capabilities, why advertise? Just so you can get 300 people in a space 
only designed for 50? Just so the noise and other problems of the extra 
crowd gets the party shut down 5 hours earlier? Information this tendency 
to spread well beyond it's intended area (e.g. FMR) so I hardly think 
anyone is left out in the cold. If someone takes a few minutes to look 
(it's the *least* you can do) all you need to know is out there.

The Cacophony Society says "you may already be a member." So it goes with 
the SF families. All it takes is one minor speck of effort. Too much to 
ask? 

jmar.

I am outta here.

After one year on the list (has it been that long?)  I most certainly do
need a rest.  From this list, from the scene, from the people in it.

I have met some really nice folx in the virtual community that *IS*
SFRaves.  And for the most part, you guys/glas are a great group.  In all
honesty I do believe it.

I think that SFR will prove to be a force to be reckoned with in the
future, and I look forward to the *real* mutha's gettin out there and doin'
the do (some of you already are).

I have noticed that things are a changin' here on the list.  Just in terms
of 'tude.  I think that I may have contributed to it in many ways.  I don't
want to develop a whole group of enemies, I prefer freindship.  But to me
friendship means honesty.  Some  people prefer euphamisms...in any case
that ain't me.  Since there are still quite a few who have a problem with
me, I would just as well split.  I really don't think that I belong here as
much as others do.  I also do not think that I am ready to give up my way
of stating things just to make others happy.  I have been relatively quiet
over the past few months anyway, since the things I would like to talk
about would only stir up the pot, it's best to go.

I would really like to take some parting shots, but what would it prove,
other than I am the king of the slapshot, unrivaled in delivery...big deal.

Since it seems that I will never be into the "spirit" that is the list
(whatever that is), I should move on.

Peace,
John

For all newbies to this list: Hi!

the number from the jolly blond giant (Jeff).

Dianna -> Forgive them, they know not what they do ;).  Hey sistah!  Sultan
is fine, and he's kickin' it.  Talked to the pdog the other day, and asked
about you.  Heard you made a change, will talk to you soon.  Hope all is
well at the corporate!  Hey, how's sistah Maria?

SJ Posse ->  All you mutha's need is a club that stays open all night.  SF
would be shut down without you.  The South bay FUELS this scene in many
ways, and some SF posses love to diss 'em.  SF has quite a bit to learn
from SJ, like diversity, like family, like community.  SJ, and the people
in it, are all THAT!!!  My home from home.

Words:  I have always used fronting, dis, cool, punk, shit, ass, booty,
boongy, betty, triple B, triple D, audi, bcnu, wassup, wit, dat, fuck,
posse, bitch, shrtless male, hoofer, and a host of other things.  I do not
watch MTV (except to get really fucking stoned and watch beavis & butthead
for classic political satire).  My language is my own, didn't get it from
the streets, since I did not grow up on the streets.  I would suggest, for
those of you who do not understand how the fuck this black man can say
"Goddamn, wassup with dat shit!", and still program the Macintosh in C,
C++, Assembly, I would suggest the Invisible Man by Ralph Ellison, Native
Son by Richard Wright, The Autobiography of Malcolm X by Alex Haley,
Beloved by Toni Morrison, The Souls of Black Folk by WEB Dubois, and The
Art of War by Sun Tzu.  My shit is straight, my shit is real.  I don't need
TV to give me new words (by the time black speak is put on the air, it's
already run the gamut in the African American Community, get a clue).

Nature abhors a vaccum. Keep the door to your heart and mind open to those
who are different than you.  Diversity RULES!!!  Everything homogenous will
either be absorbed or destroyed.  Think about it.

Only punk chumps use these words to mask what they really feel:
Bad Neighboorhood, Rough Area,  Gangster-looking, ganster-anything, sketch,
underpriviledged, *us* and *them*.  Get real, and say what you really feel.
Many prefer it more honest, more open <- Direct quote from "Space
Seed-Star Trek Orignial Flavor".

I'm now done.

From sfraves-owner  Mon May 16 13:25:56 1994

	id NAA10195; Mon, 16 May 1994 13:26:15 -0700
Date: Mon, 16 May 1994 13:26:15 -0700
From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)
Message-Id: <199405162026.NAA10195@netcom.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Rave report - Vision, Blu Cube, Bay to Breakers
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Weekend Rave report
by John Draper

   Back again for yet another report on the SF Rave scene and also a report
on the Bay to Breakers foot rave across San Francisco.   For those not in
the know,  Bay to Breakers is a San Francisco tradition,  where more than
80,000 people participate in the craziest foot race,  dressed up in 
everything from Bevis and Butthead to StoneHenge,  and everything in between.

   First stop was the Blu Cube party in a small cramped home set in the back
of larger homes.    The dance area was a converted garage,  with a lot of
preparation done to keep the sound inclosed to prevent a noise problem.
This was the first time I took a girl friend of mine to a rave,   only
because I had arranged for her to get a ride home so I can continue my
raving throughout the late morning.

   Our own SFRavers provided the DJ'ing,  and Laura spun the most amazing
acid trance I've heard in a long time.   I thought I left the planet and
was soaring around the cosmos BIG TIME.    Ethan did his usual stuff,
introducing us to some of his new record acquisitions,  doing a technically
superb job.

   Unfortunately,  things had to shut down around 4 am or so,  which was rather
unexpected for me.    Dawn, the girls I was with took off back to Marin,  and
I was dropped off at the Trocadero to attend VISION.    By the time I got there
(About 4:45 am) there was a long line out in front,   but thanx to a friend
who saved me a place,  I was able to get in before they wouldn't let any more
people.   WOW!! it sure was pumpin in there,   as Tony was laying down some
pretty funkey tunes,  sorta mixing it up with some pretty aswsome trance.
I never heard this kind of mix before,   but I was on the dance floor almost
continiously,  other than to chill out.   This time,  the Troc had some fans
around the dance floor that really made a difference in my dance energy.
By that time,  I had almost forgotten that I wanted to run the 7.5 mile
Bay to Breakers race,   but early in the morning,  it started to rain
and I said "Oh S**t" what a bummer to be running in the rain.

   I continued grooving to the tunes,   going berserk from the awsome amount
of energy bouncing around all the way to the end (8 am).    By that time,
the Bay to Breakers race already started,  so I just left the Trocedero,
went up 4th St,  and I could see the huge throng of people boogie'ing up
Howard,  so I immediatley started running Bay to Breakers,  as I merged into
the throung of more than 80,000 people,  all going up Howard St.

   The race was totally insane,  and I felt great,  with lots of energy,
although I had been dancing ALL NIGHT,    I felt the change from dancing to
running to be less strenious than I thought.   Although I'm NOT a runner,
and have never even jogged a lot,   I took to a rather relaxed running style
and by the time I turned on 9th St,  heading towards Hays St,  I thought
this wasn't so bad after all.   Origionally,  I was expecting to just
run and walk the race,  resting whenever I can,  but that never happened.

   In the Bay to Breakers,  the route goes along Hays St,  up about 400 feet
elevation over about 8 blocks,  and is dreaded by the runners.    This hill
was about the 2 1/2 miles into the race,  with the 3rd mile just before the
top of the hill.    About halfway up the hill,   a lot of people were walking
at that point,   but I happen to be luckey enough to find a band of runners
moving along at my pace,  and literally got SUCKED up the hill,   passing
quite a few people that looked a lot stronger runners than I was.   Just
before the top of the hill,   it got so crowded that it was impossible to run
anymore without pushing people aside,  so I was skipping around parked cars
to get to the top without stopping.   There was *SO* many people....

   After I got to the top,   I speeded up my running,  and eventually turned
down Fell St towards Golden Gate Park,  where I was to rouse Aaron who lives
on Fell St.     He joined me there,  and we were running together for a while
untel Aaron (Who didn't start at the beginning) wanted to sprint the last 2 
miles.    In the meantime,  the miles were ticking away,  and when I got to
the last mile to run,  I opened it up,  pulled out the stops and at this
point,  I was passing everyone until I got to the finish.   Of course Aaron
was far ahead of me by then,   but we met at the finish line,  gave each other
a message,  and was partying a few hours at the Polo Fields.    Aaron volunteered
to get the car (I wasn't about to pay $5 to take a bus back).   It took him
15 minutes to run back to the car but 30 minutes to drive back due to the
heavy traffic.    Aaron is a big time runner,   so 5 minute mile is nothing
for him.

   This was my FIRST Bay to Breakers,  and for someone who never runs,   I
thought it was amazing that I could run 7 1/2 miles.   While in the Polo
fields,  I did my yoga,   and after that it felt like I never even ran the
race.   Anyway,  I made it back to Light-n-up,  and was dancing all day,   
wandering to the End Up and dacing there till about 5:30,  as if I had never 
even run the race.

   This morning I feel slightly stiff,   but not too sore,   so I'm chalking
it up as yet another awsome weekend experience for me.

   I hope that the others that went to VISION didn't get stuck in the traffic
nightmare,  trying to cross the race.   How many OTHERS participated in this
race?

More later,  as always...

Cap'n Crunch - The crazy raver...
