From: global1!nysernet.ORG!mochin on Mon, May 16, 1994 2:00 PM
Subject: Internet Metering (fwd)
To: Multiple recipients of list

The following message was sent to me from another (unaffiliated) list that I
subscribe to, and I thought that it was important for people on this list to be
aware of it as well.

Mark Foster (mfoster@tyrell.net)


> It has been a topic of wide discussion in my internet circles for some
> time: when would the powers that be start tollgating the internet. It may
> be sooner than most believe. I received this message today. The days of
> free internet usage seem to be numbered.
>
> Tom Alexander
>
> FWD>>ALERT:  Internet may be metered in the future.
> This should be of wide interest.
>
> --------------------------------------
> This message is of importance to all of us, since we all
> obviously use the internet to a great extent.  I received it today,
> and am forwarding it "for your information".  Thanks
>
> Subject: Metered Usage of the Internet: JSN
>
> Please forgive the mass mailing, but I feel this is a subject
> which is of great importance to anyone who benefits from the
> bountiful resources of the Internet.
>
> A very bad storm is brooding on the horizon.
>
> In the future, you might have to pay a charge for every E-mail
> message you send or receive, every Usenet article you read,
> every kilobyte of data you transfer with ftp, every hypertext
> link you follow with NCSA Mosaic or Gopher...
>
> Hopefully this frightens you as much as it does me.
> But it will happen, unless YOU do something about it.
>
> Please read the attached, fill out the requested info, and
> mail it back to mike@essential.org.  It also wouldn't hurt to
> forward a copy of this to everyone you know on the Internet.
>
> Thanks for your support.
>
> Craig Smith, <bcs@cs.tamu.edu> or <craig@stat.tamu.edu>
> Texas A&M University, Dept. of Computer Science
> 205 HRBB, 862-2084 (CPSC).   [PGP2 Public Key Available on Request]
> ---
>
> TAXPAYER ASSETS PROJECT - INFORMATION POLICY NOTE
> May 7, 1994
>
> -    Request for signatures for a letter to NSF opposing metered
>      pricing of Internet usage
>
> -    Please repost this request freely
>
> The letter will be sent to Steve Wolff, the Director of
> Networking and Communications for NSF.  The purpose of the letter
> is to express a number of user concerns about the future of
> Internet pricing.  NSF recently announced that is awarding five
> key contracts to telephone companies to operate four Internet
> "Network Access Points" (NAPs), and an NSF funded very high speed
> backbone (vBNS).  There have been a number of indications that
> the telephone companies operating the NAPs will seek permission
> from NSF to price NAPs services according to some measure of
> Internet usage.  The vBNS is expected to act as a testbed for new
> Internet pricing and accounting schemes.  The letter expresses
> the view that metered pricing of Internet usage should be
> avoided, and that NSF should ensure that the free flow of
> information through Internet listserves and file server sites is
> preserved and enhanced.
>
>   Jamie Love, Taxpayer Assets Project (love@essential.org; but
>      unable to answer mail until May 15).  Until then, direct
>      inquires to Michael Ward.
>
> If you are willing to sign the letter, send the following
>      information to Mike Ward of the Taxpayer Assets Project
>      (mike@essential.org, fax: 202/234-5176; voice: 202/387-8030;
>      P.O. Box 19367, Washington, DC 20036):
>
> Names:    ___________________________
> Title:    ___________________________   (Optional)
> Affiliation:   ____________________________________
> (for purposes of identification only)
> Address:       ______________________________________
> City; St, Zip  ________________________________
> Email Address: _____________________________________
> Voice:         __________________________________
> for verification)
>
>                             The letter follows:
>
> Steve Wolff
> Director
> Division of Networking and Communications
> National Science Foundation
> 1800 G Street
> Washington, DC  20550
>
> Dear Steve:
>
> It is our understanding that the National Science Foundation
> (NSF) and other federal agencies are developing a new
> architecture for the Internet that will utilize four new Network
> Access Points (NAPs), which have been described as the new
> "cloverleaves" for the Internet.  You have indicated that NSF is
> awarding contracts for four NAPs, which will be operated by
> telephone companies (Pac Bell, S.F.; Ameritech, Chicago; Sprint,
> NY; and MFS, Washington, DC).  We further understand that NSF has
> selected MCI to operate its new very high speed backbone (vBNS)
> facility.
>
> There is broad public interest in the outcome of the negotiations
> between NSF and the companies that will operate the NAPs and
> vBNS.  We are writing to ask that NSF consider the following
> objectives in its negotiations with these five firms:
>
>      PRICING.
>
> We are concerned about the future pricing systems for Internet
> access and usage.  Many users pay fixed rates for Internet
> connections, often based upon the bandwidth of the connection,
> and do not pay for network usage, such as the transfer of data
> using email, ftp, Gopher or Mosaic.  It has been widely reported
> on certain Internet discussion groups, such as com-priv, that the
> operators of the NAPs are contemplating a system of usage based
> pricing.
>
> We are very concerned about any movement toward usage based
> pricing on the Internet, and we are particularly concerned about
> the future of the Internet Listserves, which allow broad
> democratic discourse on a wide range of issues.  We believe that
> the continued existence and enhancement of the Internet
> discussion groups and distribution lists is so important that any
> pricing scheme for the NAPs that would endanger or restrict their
> use should be rejected by the NSF.
>
> It is important for NSF to recognize that the Internet is more
> than a network for scientific researchers or commercial
> transactions.  It represents the most important new effort to
> expand democracy into a wide range of human endeavors.  The open
> communication and the free flow of information have make
> government and private organizations more accountable, and
> allowed citizens to organize and debate the widest range of
> matters.  Federal policy should be directed at expanding public
> access to the Internet, and it should reject efforts to introduce
> pricing schemes for Internet usage that would mimic commercial
> telephone networks or expensive private network services such as
> MCI mail.
>
> To put this into perspective, NSF officials must consider how any
> pricing mechanisms will change the economics of hosting an
> Internet electronic mail discussion groups and distribution
> lists.  Many of these discussion groups and lists are very large,
> such as Humanist, GIS-L, CNI-Copyright, PACS-L, CPSR-Announce or
> Com-Priv.  It is not unusual for a popular Internet discussion
> group to have several thousand members, and send out more than
> 100,000 email messages per day.  These discussion groups and
> distribution lists are the backbones of democratic discourse on
> the Internet, and it is doubtful that they would survive if
> metered pricing of electronic mail is introduced on the Internet.
>
> Usage based pricing would also introduce a wide range of problems
> regarding the use of ftp, gopher and mosaic servers, since it
> conceivable that the persons who provide "free" information on
> servers would be asked to pay the costs of "sending" data to
> persons who request data.  This would vastly increase the costs
> of operating a server site, and would likely eliminate many
> sources of data now "published" for free.
>
> We are also concerned about the types of  accounting mechanisms
> which may be developed or deployed to facilitate usage based
> pricing schemes., which raise a number of concerns about personal
> privacy.  Few Internet users are anxious to see a new system of
> "surveillance" that will allow the government or private data
> vendors to monitor and track individual usage of Information
> obtained from Internet listserves or fileserves.
>
>      ANTI-COMPETITIVE PRACTICES
>
>      We are also concerned about the potential for anti-
> competitive behavior by the firms that operate the NAPs.  Since
> 1991 there have been a number of criticisms of ANS pricing
> practices, and concerns about issues such as price discrimination
> or preferential treatment are likely to become more important as
> the firms operating the NAPs become competitors of firms that
> must connect to the NAPs.  We are particularly concerned about
> the announcements by PAC-Bell and Ameritech that they will enter
> the retail market for Internet services, since both firms were
> selected by NSF to operate NAPs.  It is essential that the
> contracts signed by NSF include the strongest possible measures
> to insure that the operators of the NAPs do not unfairly
> discriminate against unaffiliated companies.
>
> Recommendations:
>
> As the Internet moves from the realm of the research community to
> a more vital part of the nation's information infrastructure, the
> NSF must ensure that its decisions reflect the needs and values
> of a much larger community.
>
> 1.   The NSF contracts with the NAPs operators will include
>      clauses that determine how the NAP services will be priced.
>      It is important that NSF disclose and receive comment on all
>      pricing proposals before they become final.  NSF should
>      create an online discussion list to facilitate public dialog
>      on the pricing proposals, and NSF should identify its
>      criteria for selecting a particular pricing mechanism,
>      addressing the issue of how the pricing system will impact
>      the Internet's role in facilitating democratic debate.
>
> 2.   NSF should create a consumer advisory board which would
>      include a broad cross section of consumer interests,
>      including independent network service providers (NSPs),
>      publishers of Internet discussion groups and distribution
>      lists, academic networks, librarians, citizen groups and
>      individual users.  This advisory board should review a
>      number of policy questions related to the operation of the
>      Internet, including questions such as the NAP pricing, NAP
>      operator disclosure of financial, technical and operational
>      data, systems of Internet accounting which are being tested
>      on the vBNS and other topics.
>
> 3.   NSF should solicit public comment, though an online
>      discussion group, of the types of safeguards against
>      anticompetitive behavior by the NAPs which should be
>      addressed in the NSF/NAPs contracts, and on issues such as
>      NAPs pricing and Internet accounting systems.
>
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> TAP-INFO is an Internet Distribution List provided by the Taxpayer
> Assets Project (TAP).  TAP was founded by Ralph Nader to monitor the
> management of government property, including information systems and
> data, government funded R&D, spectrum allocation and other government
> assets.  TAP-INFO reports on TAP activities relating to federal
> information policy.  tap-info is archived at ftp.cpsr.org;
> gopher.cpsr.org and wais.cpsr.org
>
> Subscription requests to tap-info to listserver@essential.org with
> the message:  subscribe tap-info your name
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> Taxpayer Assets Project; P.O. Box 19367, Washington, DC  20036
> v. 202/387-8030; f. 202/234-5176; internet:  tap@essential.org
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
>

From sfraves-owner  Mon May 16 15:31:49 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA16195; Mon, 16 May 94 15:31:49 PDT
Received: from soda.berkeley.edu by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA16187; Mon, 16 May 94 15:31:41 PDT
Received: (laura@localhost) by soda.berkeley.edu (8.6.9/PHILMAIL-1.10) id PAA00823 for sfraves@techno.stanford.edu; Mon, 16 May 1994 15:31:58 -0700
Message-Id: <199405162231.PAA00823@soda.berkeley.edu>
From: laura@soda.berkeley.edu (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Mon, 16 May 1994 15:31:55 -0700
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: blue cube redux
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Ovid said something to the effect that the Blue Cube was
more of a stand up and talk party than a rave, that there
wasn't enough dancing going on for a rave to break out.

Well, all I can say is what did you expect? :-)

The parameters of what to expect at a rave like Vision are 
well-known.  The parameters of what to expect at a party like 
the Blue Cube are also well known, as we did one of these back 
in January and it was widely reported on.  Blue Cube was never 
actually advertised as being a rave (whatever that is these days).
The word "party" was the operative word.

I think any situation where the dance floor is packed to capacity 
is a good thing :-)  Both Vision and Blue Cube were that night, so 
I'm sure a lot of people were happy.  In the long run isn't that 
all that matters, not how well we rebutted John Lee when he complained 
about a party he probably would not have showed up at ANYWAY based on 
past experience and knowledge of his usual party preferences?

If someone likes Wicked or Lighten-Up, then by all means go!  If 
someone feels like Spiral Jive, the NMR, SPAZ, or Liquid Air,
then go!  San Francisco is SPOILED for variety and choices when 
it comes to parties.  In some other parts of the US people are happy 
if there is ONE good party a month.  Parties are meant to be enjoyed.  
Enjoying a party is probably the BIGGEST contribution a party-goer can 
make to the party itself and to the scene in general.

I used to make fun of Susie for saying "party on" all the time.  But
you know, she's got a really good point.

Laura

From sfraves-owner  Mon May 16 16:47:18 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA17857; Mon, 16 May 94 16:47:18 PDT
Received: from crl.crl.com (crl.com) by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA17842; Mon, 16 May 94 16:47:00 PDT
Received: by crl.crl.com id AA16996
  (5.65c/IDA-1.5 for sfraves@techno.stanford.edu); Mon, 16 May 1994 16:45:43 -0700
From: Bryce Ryan <brycer@crl.com>
Message-Id: <199405162345.AA16996@crl.crl.com>
Subject: Blue^3
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Mon, 16 May 1994 16:45:42 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 3904      
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

i had a good time. i enjoyed having the opportunity to provide some of
the sound system, and the opportunity to spin dance music for people.
thanks for your patience with my screw ups, and for your encouragement.

i'm very sorry that some people were put off by the barriers erected to
keep the party at a manageable level.  these barriers were no higher than
many other parties that exist in the bay area. the information to list
people *was* presented several times, in several ways...personal invites,
on the calendar, in Martin's broadsheet, and in personal posts to the
list.  the organizers were respecting the wishes and needs of the person
who provided the space, since we all knew the limits of that space. the
last party in the space really exceeded those limits, and put people off
in a different way.  it seemed that we had a comfortable number of folks
come by, and stay, with enough room to move about without excessive
jostling or impediment.  there was a conscious decision *not* to create
flyers and *not* to have voice mail numbers because of space limitations.
flame me if you will, but i fully support having the right number of
people at parties...not too many, not too few.

as for some of the acrimony that has sprung up, i'm saddened by it, but
emotions will out.  i do hope that the folks involved will learn that
net.exchanges have real consequences to real people, and consider their
words carefully. i also hope that everyone comes to realize that a
net.repuation is a precious thing: a lifetime to build, a moment to 
destroy.

i think it's also interesting and informative that we've now seen the
other side of the "no FMR info" stand.  crisping people for asking for
information is somewhat of a problem.  all the devotees and
insiders who couldn't make it to the blue^3 despite their earnest
desires now have seen what it feels like to: a) get flamed, b) get
their noses rubbed in not being "with it", c) miss out on a great
party.  all the blue^3 devotees and insiders that caused mild flames
now get to see what it feels like to: a) get flamed, b) get their noses
rubbed in being "with it", c) be a part of something that others want
and don't have.  I hope it was a sobering experience for everyone. 

as for the talking/dancing/raving thread: i personally enjoy the social
aspects of these events, and i generally encourage people to talk at
them.  i'm not a big dancer at most events, for a variety of reasons
(some professional--i'm listening to the music intently, listening
to the sound, watching the DJ; some personal--sometimes the music doesn't
really move me; some historical--my body remembers many a bar and punk
event where there was no room to move even if i wanted to; and some
just plain practical--when i go off, i need *lots* of room, cause i'm
all over the room with flailing arms and legs, which can be quite
dangerous to others, and because one of my knees isn't quite up to
much high energy motion).

as for dancing/raving, i've been observing a change in the kind of parties/
events that i'm attracted to. i'm sorry that some people's expectations
weren't met...that's always unfortunate.  i also hope that those people
will let the organizers know what can help them have a good time.  more
importantly, i hope those people who are unhappy will bring a positive
contribution to the event and help turn it into an event that they are
happy at.  i am always surprised (and happily so) when some unexpected
and wonderful thing happens at these things.  i can't speak for other
promoters/organizers, but at the events that i'm participating in, i
try hard to encourage folks to do it for themselves.  not only to we
get to know someone a little bit better, we also get to get another
boost of energy--and we all need that.

thanks for letting me ramble on.  i hope to see you all soon!
-- 
Bryce Ryan ------- AMBIANCE ----------- brycer@crl.com-----

super-responsible about taking good care of the site.  Without my
saying anything, for example, my friend Paul went around picking up trash
at Bonny Doon before taking off for home.  And then there's my friend L.
who picks up cigarette butts wherever he finds them!  (and convinced me
to do it,too...)  Anyway, I'm sorry about the bad feeling that goes on
around the FMR.

From: anthrax@uclink.berkeley.edu (Ann Elizabeth Loraine)
Message-Id: <199405170127.SAA05287@uclink.berkeley.edu>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: sunday parties
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


I got to the Berkeley marina just as Buck was taking over on the 
turntables.  Due to the wind, they had set up behind a hill and weren't
having too many problems with records skipping, it seemed to me.  There
were maybe about 30-40 people there already enjoying the beautiful
weather and pleasant surroundings.  Buck was THERE; he played the crowd
and they played him in the way that happens when the dj really knows his
stuff.

Then Galen took over.  I noticed he played "This is Acid" as he got
warmed up...sort of like he did at the New Moon party on Tuesday.  Seemed
like maybe he uses this tune to get into the groove.  I believe this
party was the maiden voyage for his newly acquired sound system.  This
party's called "Galen's Sunset party," I think, and he's been doing it
for a while.  I hope it will be a regular thing-the site is a wonderful
place to spend a Sunday afternoon, especially after staying out all night
dancing.  

We left only a little while after Galen started...I was sorry to go, because
he was getting things going with his usual high energy dance music.  But
I wanted to make it out to Bernal Heights for Park, another outdoor party
where Kenneth Paul, Carlos, Bam Bam and Dan were going to spin.  The info
line for this is:  415-647-5795, by the way.  I think this is also a
semi-regular day-time party at another beautiful location.  

We got there about 7:30, but it had already ended.  Rats!  Does anyone
know how it went off?  I'd also like to read a review of Vision, if
anyone went to that instead of the Blue Cube party, which we had to miss
because we didn't have directions...(jus' kiddin!)

Sorry I missed you all Satuday!

anthrax

1)  Blue Cube was great!  fantastic to get together with this crowd, 
fantastic to get to hear WillE spin to a pumping crowd, and the thoughtless
generosity shown by Steve to allow us into his pad really made my weekend.
Even the cop who showed up around 3:30 because of noise complaints was
cool (sorry about that Steve - I have some ideas for reducing the amount of
noise at the next one).  Because both the SFR and the Scruz clans were
invited, it made for a nice cultural mingle.  And yes, it was also a good
place to talk - which I always appreciate, as it seems all the truely
life-changing conversations I have happen at parties :)  Good show, all.

2)  All I can say w/r/t JSL: John, we hardly knew ya.  I will miss your
presence, for at times you really did have good strong points to make in
the course of a heated conversation.  I've had my gripes with you before,
but I've also admired some of what you wrote too.  I'm just sorry you didn't
feel "in place" here on the list.  You're always welcome to come back.

3) This is a little bit of self-promotion, so indulge me (or hit 'd'
now).  I'll be flying to Geneva in a week, as a representative of
Wired, to go to the World Wide Web convention being held at CERN.  We
have been nominated for two awards in the "Best of the Web" contest
for http://www.wired.com/, and the awards will be presented in Geneva.
The voting for the awards is open to anyone with a web browser like
Mosaic or Lynx.  Go visit http://wings.buffalo.edu/contest - we're
under the "entertainment" and "document design" categories.  If you
think our site deserves it, vote for us!  Or vote for anyone else you
think is worthy, but you can only vote once remember.  Thanks for the
indulgement.

4) Finally, I'm forwarding this along to you all - if someone would like
to give him a synopsis of our region, feel free.  Slurp! isn't
Rolling Stone, don't worry. :)

	Brian

From: resonate@netcom.com (analog resonate)
Message-Id: <199405171013.DAA15618@netcom.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


	What the hell is a party anyway?

	Several people emailed me for "directions to the rave"
	to which I reponded "its not a rave" and then sent directions.

	A "rave" implies a one-off event that is a singularly culminating
	occurence.

	Nothing in life is singly occuring. Nothing in history is singly
	occuring.

	A party is where people come together and have a good time.

	I have a certain style for throwing my parties. 

	I like to provide a fairly durable space for people to act silly 
	and not break anything- 
	hence the chained fridge, sealed cabinets etc...

	I like to provide music for listening and/or dancing.
	I like to provide some munchies.
	And dialout terminals.

	One-off spectacles are always a let down since a) they are usually
	all the same and b) they really have an incorrect premise- that
	*this event* is a single unique phenomenon.

	To me life isn't a series of unique bursts. Life is a constant
	flow of good things. I picked this particular house to live in because
	its a low maintenance place to do functional things and have parties.

	I think it works.

	I'll be having more parties.
	

	For the few who think that every party needs to be some massive
	spectacle... well maybe you should spend more time at arena sports
	events.

I think this thing has gotten out of hand, personally.  Why don't you 
guys apologise to each other and establish at least some repoire--an 
agreement to be civil to each other?  I had this problem before.  It 
takes a lot of guts to be the first one to break the silence and admit at 
least part responsibility for the misunderstanding, but it is infinitely 
rewarding.  Having done this before, I have found that it not only makes 
life a lot easier on the others around (not so straining on them ) but you might actually 
find that you have some things in common.
Just my 2 cents
Good luck to both of you
T

From: pandora@hulk.sfsu.edu (Candice)

Subject: Hats off!!!
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU (sfraves)
Date: Tue, 17 May 1994 09:04:30 -40962758 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23alpha]
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 1421      
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU



I excpected this list to turn into one giant flame war.  I am so 
impressed and thankful that it didn't.  When I read jsl's post on
monday I was preparing to uns*bscribe for the week.  While I read
that post I noticed that I was cleanching my teeth and fists.  I was
both vicariously feeling jsl's anger and my own anger in response to
his.  I don't need to go through those types of emotions (particularly
this crazy week) so I felt it would be best to let go for a while.
But to my suprise this wasn't necessary.  I'm supposing that there 
were others out there that were just as upset as I was and how we
all managed to keep our fingers off of the "r" key is impressive.
Not to put down those people that did respond either, just as a flame
war would have been inexcusable letting that type of ranting go
completely unchecked would also have been inexcusable.

It was really nice to see that all of the talk of acceptance, tolerance,
love, and community has been more than catch phrases and lofty ideals.
I learned a lot through this whole incident and although it was 
difficult for me, I'm glad it worked out well (particularly on an 
intrapersonal level).

Please, please, please keep it up, and now more than ever before I'm  
looking forward to meeting more of you at the next sfr event.

Take care,
CC
-- 
Candice			pandora@hulk.sfsu.edu


    I'm nothing now, but I'm something compared to what I used to be.

To: resonate@netcom.com (analog resonate), sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Steve writes:

>	A "rave" implies a one-off event that is a singularly culminating
>	occurence.

I have seen this definition used may times, but I think it may no
longer be valid.  The "rave scene" has been around for three years
now in the US (at least), so the concept of "one-off" has basically been
rendered mathematically impossible ( :-) ) due to the sheer numbers
of parties that have been thrown in the name of rave.  In San
Francisco where there are a limited number of spaces (indoor and out)
that can support the usual large size of SF parties, spaces have to
be used and reused.  

>	For the few who think that every party needs to be some massive
>	spectacle... 

And the good news is that this group is few as you point out.  I see
growing support for things like Spiral Jive, MESS, the New Moon
parties, and Liquid Air/Sound Vision/Blue Cube/etc .  At the same time,
support for older, more established parties like Basics, Wicked, and
Come/Unity continues, so it's not like anyone is dividing or taking 
anything away from anyone else.  There's room for everyone and everything,
but it might not be the case that everyone is comfortable or happy with
everything.  

This is why there are choices, so people can do what best makes them happy 
or suits their particular mood.  If you don't like deep house, then why make 
yourself and the people around you unhappy by forcing yourself to go to a deep 
house party where you just can't get into the music or the dancing?  On the 
other hand, if you are in the mood for deep house or just want to find out 
what it's like, the opportunity is there.  Ditto for trip-hop, techno, acid, 
funky beats, tribal, breakbeat (when RAW or Demigod are working), and even 
hardcore (that's right, Bryce and I were talking about dusting off our Brooklyn
and Rotterdam records one of these days).  

SF is a veritable buffet of dance choices.  There is nothing wrong with 
having preferences, by the way, the only wrong is in telling people that they 
are less understanding of the scene for liking a certain style (and yes, I've 
heard that . . . the old "the true believers want to get down to soulful 
house" line . . . like give me a break.  In Toronto the "true believers" crave 
breakbeat, in Worcester Mass, it's acid trance.  But I digress.)

Just some random thoughts,

Laura

Well.

Amidst the recent deluge of venom I neglected to add my $.02 about the
party itself. So, without further delay:

Yet another fantastic party. Folks that had the committment to sweat it out
on the packed dancefloor made it really special. The energy was insane.
Best Vibe as such I've seen in a while. Throughout the night people were
yelling and screaming, really working the relationship with the djs, so of
course the music was great all night. Meme did the inimitable Richie Hawtin
more than justice and once again killed me with this amazing deep, and
soulful house track probing the intentionally vague and mournful sentiment:
I'm leaving alabama. Now I know why vocals and house go so well together.
House music is *emotional* music and nothing carries emotion better than
the human voice. Boy would I like to build a set around that kinda music...
So for all you collectors out there, Techno Daddy says: stick this one in
the archives ;-) 

I had a real good time on the decks. Sure is nice to play for friends :)
Acid is the shit  :)   :)

Laura thoroughly fried my brain proving once again that the dj often has no
idea of just how good they sound. Do it Laura. Played one of my favorite
tracks from the recent Juno Reactor 2x12: Acid Moon. Deep acid is the
double-shit. Joe Rice's tape (thanks Joe it's killer) features some great
acid of the extra deep variety as well. Can't wait to hear him do it live
June 18th...

Lee. What can I say? You could be huge. Consistently amazing. Now if he
could just keep track of his records ?-)

Will-E was awesome. Great music and loads of positive fucking energy. Too
bad I couldn't convince him to come back out for F&F (sniff).

Massive props to analog for once again opening his killer home to us. Any
parties only what we make it. If you don't like it, do something to make it
better.

Obvenom: Vibe is the energy that results from people BEING THEMSELVES in
community. Lets try and remember to give each other room to be ourselves in
*this* community. Use those smileys. Look for the best. 

take it easy
ethan

Received: from soda.berkeley.edu by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AB08553; Tue, 17 May 94 13:07:55 PDT
Received: (laura@localhost) by soda.berkeley.edu (8.6.9/PHILMAIL-1.10) id NAA02717 for sfraves@techno.stanford.edu; Tue, 17 May 1994 13:08:11 -0700
Message-Id: <199405172008.NAA02717@soda.berkeley.edu>
From: laura@soda.berkeley.edu (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Tue, 17 May 1994 13:08:08 -0700
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Brain Frying:  Why and How
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Ethan's comment that I throughly fried his brain has trigged me to write 
an essay.  You don't have to read it :-)

I started raving in Brooklyn during the height of hardcore.  Imagine
industrial mixed with punk but with so much weird space sounds added
that it was more science fictiony scary than REALLY scary.  That was
the sound and the feeling.

Of course, after 6 hours of this it got monotonous, like anything else
in the world.  I'd get tired, and practically fall asleep.  And then
something would wake me up.  Back then I had NO idea what the noise was,
but it sounded like a cross between dripping water, an electric guitar,
and fingernails scraping on a chalk board.  Sometimes the best way I
could describe it was as a highly resonating cat meow.  Whatever it was,
it would wake me from a sound sleep and send me screaming to the dance
floor.

Unbeknownst to me I had discovered acid.

After a while I started finding out about things like the TB-303 (one
lives in my house now, it's a sort of electronic pet of Brian's), the 
SH-101, the Roland Jupiter 6 (analogue death machine -- responsible 
for thick spacey vibrating quasi-industrial noises) and much much more.  
I was hooked.

If someone played me a record in a DJ store that had that buzzing dripping 
melting squawking burbling noise, I'd buy it.  Over time I got more 
discriminating, and stopped buying EVERY acid record that came out -- 
there are a LOT of them that are the same old 303/909/pipe-it-through-a-
distortion-pedal -- but there were also some incredible gems.  Hardfloor's 
"Acperience,"  Robert Armani's "Circus Bells," Kirilan's "D.R.U.G.," Richie 
Hawtin's "Substance Abuse," Equinox's "Surveyor-4," Underground Resistance's
"Sunshine and Fog."

Acid comes in all degrees of hardness, trancieness, and houseiness.  I
heard Leon mixing some slow acid over wailing divas when I was over at
Monica's last night, and in my opinion it gave it a new energy and drive.

I'm hooked on the energy and drive.  I guess I'm pretty hyperactive
(you all know I'm type-A).  To hear those bleepy analogue noises
percolating away like messages from outer space just lifts me up and
forces me to dance.  I get this insane smile, and when I'm really into
it I try to make silly 303 noises and sing along.

Adam X (Brooklyn DJ) really got me into the acid trance.  I'd hear him
spin at parties last spring and summer in New York and I would dance
in a complete trance of motion, staring into a strobe light and just
completely out of my mind because of the weird resonating panning dipping
swirling sound.  It was the best :-)  Tripping without any drugs, even.

It became my goal to give that to other people, too.  This is the why
of brain frying.

Somewhere along the line I've gotten it burned into my head exactly 
what I'm looking for when I record shop.  I was in Gaia Mantra with
Brian the other week and was working very quickly through a stack of
records.  Sometimes I'd play a track for about 5 seconds and then
reject it, and Brian would say "you didn't even hear it, how can you
tell it's not what you want?"  I just know what I'm after I guess.
I'm not after mellow rise and fall and achieveing some sort of
happy cruise along dance experience.  I want that insane onslaught
of energy, thought, and movement that I would get when Adam would 
spin.  I'm not vicious and would not drive the dancers from the floor
in exhaustion, I do watch what you all are doing, but I'd rather press
on with each track more bizzare than the last for a while and then
pull back when I read "I can't take much more" from the floor than do
anything else.  So that is the how of brain frying.

Thanks very much for listening.  Both to this letter and to the acid tracks.

Laura

P.S.  It's sort of been a tradition for me to post what I can remember
of my set after I've spun in SF.  This came out of a debate last fall about
how some DJs hide what they are spining and that this is sort of wrong.

Here you go:

	"Acid Moon" by Juno Reactor

	"Trancition (Mongolian 303 Mix)" on Aura Records

	some very long track on Cocci's Chewns that is not
		"Acid Air Raid."  I think it's "Solar Quest" but
		I'm not sure.

	the "Citric Acid" remix of "Afghan Acid," on EX records

	EX-23 (this is the catalog number), it's on EX records

	the first track on the B side of the new Hardfloor EP,
		the EP is "Funilogue" but that's not what the 
		track was

	"D.R.U.G." by Kirilian, on Tension Records

	"Sunshine and Fog" from Acid Rain II by Underground Resistance

	The first track on the A side of Acid Rain I by Underground
		Resistance

	"Plainsong" by Seefeel

	"White Sands" -- has a black label and is on EX records

	some stuff on Trans'pact Records from France

	"Drugs Work" from that old Tresor I compilation

That's all I can really remember now.

Whole Earth Electronics routinely carryies MDR-V6 headphones. They
recently had a sale where they were $60. If you can't find them there,
check with Uncle Ralphs in Berkeley. If you get really desperate, I
can pick up a pair for you at Turntables Unlimited in Sac, but they
have gouge prices.

If you're willing to spend some money, check out the nicer Sennheiser
headphones. The good ones are $200-$300, but oh man do they sound
good.

While I'm on the subject, I got my mixer, 1200s, and stanton 680s for
an obscenely low price at Uncle Ralphs. If anyone is thinking of
buying gear, go there and ask them what kind of deal they can make
you.

Sean

        "Brain Frying:  Why and How" (May 17,  1:08pm)
References: <199405172008.NAA02717@soda.berkeley.edu>
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.0.0 15dec93)
To: laura@soda.berkeley.edu (Laura La Gassa), sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: Brain Frying:  Why and How
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Mime-Version: 1.0
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Like Laura, I know pretty much what I'm after (although it's a very broad
spectrum, as I discover every time after I come back from a shopping
expedition!) . . . I miss a few good ones, I'm sure, but usually it only
takes a few seconds to determine whether a track is of interest, and then
I'll give it a longer test if so.  Some tracks just leap out at you, which
for example happened when I recently snagged copy of Fluke's 'Groovy Feeling'
which is a little dated but has that je-ne-sais-quoi which elevates the
truly memorable tracks.  Laura's looking for the 'energy, thought and
movement' and I've always described it as looking for the tracks that
'kick'.  That's *kick*, not pump, there is a diff.  Every DJ has a different
take on all this and that's what makes it so interesting.  While the
percentage of good tracks is always fairly low, as I've speculated before
the sheer number available is so great right now that it's possible to
construct remarkably diverse collections from the same pool of music 
circulating in the stores and other distribution channels of the moment.

Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT


Dear Adventurer,
          Here's some more info on the Peru trip from India
Supera who traveled to Peru and Bolivia to set up the trip
for us.  She will also accompany us in November as she knows
the territory and the local people very well.




INDIA SUPERA
FEATHERED PIPE FOUNDATION


Dear Friends,

Richard Edelman of the Rim Institute and I would like to
invite you to join Andrew Weil and ourselves on an
exciting journey to the Andes, the heart of Peru and
Bolivia, to celebrate the Total Solar Eclipse.  There is
a special significance to the eclipse here as the
Peruvian culture is rooted in a sun-centered creation
myth.  While most of us think only of the Incas when we
think of Peru, they were just the last of many great
civilizations spanning many thousands of years.  These
pre-Incan peoples thought of themselves as the Children
of the Sun.  The legend of the Sun says that the sun god
Inti sent his first two children to earth - Manco Capac
and his sister consort Mama Oello - to bring
illumination and light to the human race.  Their task
was to find the proper spot to place their gold staff
into the ground.  Cusco, where the staff entered the
earth easily, became known as the naval of the world
from which all life springs.  Manco Capac taught the men
to farm and Mama Oello taught the women to weave.
Archeologists know that weaving originated in Peru and
they think that agriculture occurs earliest in Peru.
This myth weaves strands of masculine and feminine,
light and dark, birth and death.  To be there for the
solar eclipse is like being awake in a dream.

We'll start from the peak experience of the Solar
Eclipse and rise higher. We'll climb to Macchu Picchu,
fly over the Nazca lines, skim across Lake Titicaca, and
cross the altiplano of Bolivia to La Paz, the highest
city in the world.  We'll experience the secrets of
these great civilizations as told to us today through
the ruins of the past as well as the arts, crafts and
music of people living there today. Join us to weave the
myth and majesty of Peru into our hearts.  No one ever
goes away disappointed from the Andes.

If you are ready for this adventure, please give us your
mailing address so that we can send you a registration form.
We hope that you'll join us.

Best regards,

(Signed)      India


SEND ADDRESS TO THE.RIM@ASU.EDU

SFR month continues with Launch Pad II, a couple MESS events, Test 2,
and tonight's Inspirations; all have organizers or DJs who are on
SFRaves.  Check 'em out and meet yr favorite net personalities!  Also
check the opening of Soul Purpose tonight, check the Wicked line
tomorrow, and keep 'em peeled for the full moon next week...

Jason, John Howard and Markie.

Anyone else see the Brand New Heavies last night.  I saw the early show, 
and was guardedly optimistic.  (How's that for an oxymoron?)  IMO, 
they're a very talented group of musicians, and I wish they'd jsut let 
themselves be that.  They seemd to be a little bit too concerned with 
"putting on a show."  All in all, a fun time...

Cheers,

Tony

/--------------------------------------------------------------\
|  Tony Grant          tgrant@netcom.com       s y n e r g y   |
|  415.280.8303                                 interactive    |
\--------------------------------------------------------------/

>From SCRUTON@delphi.com  Sun May 15 11:48:36 1994
Date: Sun, 15 May 1994 14:48:53 -0400 (EDT)
From: SCRUTON@delphi.com
Subject: european rave report (from my home email addr)
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU

Date: Sun, 15 May 1994 10:46:15 -0700
From: "James A. Squires" <jas@kaiwan.com>
Subject: Rave report from GDR
To: SCRUTON@delphi.com


----------------------L - i - N - E ----- N - o - i - Z ----------------------
File - $
From: uf341ea@sunmail.lrz-muenchen.de (Kajetan Hinner)


                           Mayday 6 "Rave Olympia"

                 Report of Eye of the Shadow....IRC: Shadow_I


     I live in munich and it's a long ride to reach Dortmund. I went by car
and left munich at 10.30 am. The nearer I came to Dortmund, the more passing
cars greeted with their horn or waved to me, when they saw the MAYDAY badge at
the rear window of my car. When I stopped to stretch my legs or to drink
something, there were always some other cars with ravers at the parking. It
was no problem to find the location, I arrived finally at 5.30 pm at the
parking and had to pay another 4 DM. With my camera I went to the main
entrance and took some pictures of the crowd waiting there. There were ravers
everywhere, some danced near there cars, where they had opened the trunk and
put their loudspeakers outside.
     So it was a good start. Weather was fine (sun, but not too hot), some lay
in the grass and slept a little bit. One pickup stood near the main entrance
with one raver singing live to trance music.
     Often ravers asked me if I'd sell tickets, but I had none over. I asked 
what they would pay, and one said he'd pay 250 DM, but nobody sells his for
that price, but he had an offer of 300.- My ticket I got for 70 DM, so I would
have made quite a good deal if I bought one more to sell it. But I never
thought they'd sell all 25.000 tickets in advance.
     There were signs which forbid cameras inside the hall, so I went back to
the car and left it there. When I came back, the doors still weren't open and
the first people began to shout and whistle. At half past 6 they began to let
the people in and after 40 minutes I too was inside. They checked us for 
weapons and drugs, as always.
     At first I bought Pizza (5DM, fair price) and a raver-shirt (100 DM, 
quite much), because I thought the wear would soon be sold out and I couldn't
lose that shirt but my money. Finally they'd actually had sold out those long
shirts, so I was right. Some T-shirts were left. You also could buy MayDay
posters, CDs, Video-Tapes of former MayDays, caps, even cups I think. Nearly
everything. Commercialisation is becoming overwhelming, not too good if you
ask me.
     Then I went in the main hall. It was full from the beginning on, but it 
was not TOO full, so that you'd get claustrophobia, like sometimes in munich,
where you really can't turn your body any more. In the front was the DJ's
desk, in the rear the Live-Act's desk, left and right loudspeaker walls. They
had a lot of strobos, lasers and beams, I didn't count them. The top of the
hall was closed, so it was fairly dark. The music was not too loud, I had
louder raves already; the hall was too big and too high, so the sound didn't
hurt. The quality was OK, I'd say it was one of the best sound systems I heard
so far. They had two video screens (one the mirrored of the other) with sport
scenes, i.e. there was the scene of a water diver, always repeated the jump
and the way through the air just before he hit the water, then again the jump,
etc. They had soccer scenes, dance scenes, and such, I think they were taken 
from the Olympic Games. Above all they had the MayDay logo, which sometimes
was lighted colourfully. The DJ's or Live-Act's name was displayed with a
Laser-Scroll, so you always knew who's at the decks. I had a timetable, but
lost it, so I have to recall everything out of memory.
     In the main hall they kept the time totally. If the timetable said Live
Act "Members of Mayday" is at time x, you can be sure it will start at x
o'clock. That's germany. :) The first DJ was Pierre Morgan, after him came
Cirillo. I think I heard a little bit of him, but don't like him so much. Then 
came Miss DJax. Her acid-set was OK, and the rave started to begin.
     Franky Jones I heard for the first time. I didn't know he's got so many
techno hits and anthems. His style is techno (melodic) and mellow (according
to psyched's reference samples... ;-) He really kicked. The crowd went crazy
and he was the first positive surprise for me, I didn't hear of him before and
he was SO good.
     I needed a break, and went up, drank something (Coke .4 litre 5 DM,
that's expensive and unfair, beer 4 DM 1/3 litre), water in WC for free... :)
and sat down to relax. From the top of the building you could see the light
show. It was cool, although some ravers told me it would have been better
last year. I can't compare it, but the laser level was cool. The beams
enlightend the ravin' crowd. Everyone was in a good mood, you had the feeling 
of having 24999 friends. :-)
     That time I felt that I had a hard day. 5 hours sleep (I was in the 
cinema the day before and came home at 4am), 600km car ride, 2 hours raving.
So I relaxed one hour or so, the DJs during that time I was not interested in.
     After relaxing I went to hall number two. There was Laurent Garnier. I
think everybody knows him and nothing more must be said about his techno/
mellow/trance (everything around 160 bpm) music and his DJ qualities. He's OK
and he was as good as I knew him from his munich appearances. We raved on and 
everything was fine.
     During the different DJs sometimes there was a Live-Act, always in the
Big Hall. Because I lost my timetable I do not know the sequence the Live-Acts
were, but I heard live
- Ultra Sonic
     I remember nothing, but it was OK
- Members of Mayday
     I'd say THE highlight of Mayday 6. They spinned their
Mayday anthems (of course everybody knew them) & some additional
tracks and because of the shouting hall you sometimes couldn't
hear the music! BTW, some had whistles too but only few. Westbam
sat on one loudspeaker and sometimes stood up and waved or
clapped his hands. There were around 20 ppl at the Live Act
podium and the whole hall raved off.
- Genlog
     same as Ultra Sonic
- Raver's Nature
     they kicked. I wonder why I remember so little, but I think
they showed us some hardcore techno.
- Acid Junkies
     trance, if I remember right. It was really good

     Then I went to the other hall to Pascal F.E.O.S. Some on the net told me
he'd be so good and I missed him as he was in munich. Those dudes are right!
He spins ass-kicking hard-trance and we danced our ass off. =:-( The 2nd hall
had 10 strobos (I counted them... hehe) and 4 balloons where they displayed
some video animations. Good sound, even better than in the main hall, and the
strobos kicked better because this hall wasn't so high. There were a lot of
people, but not TOO much, you had enough place to dance and the music was
really OK. To reach this hall you had to go through the chill-out area, camel
cigarettes ppl were there and offered you some for free, but actually they
wanted to sell there stuff of coz. Pascal is really a good DJ. When you think
"wow, it's so groovin'" he mixes in another track, even more better.
     I think Pascal spinned during Marusha's event in the Main Hall. She's
well known by me so I could skip her, as I went back to that hall (going to
the other hall took about 10 min) everybody danced to her "Rainbow" song, they
were all in a good mood.
     After I did a little break Westbam was in the Main Hall. This time he
wasn't so excellent. Of course he was good and flipped some of his favorite
songs, but there were also some experiments (unknown styles for him, even 
breakbeat one time; BTW: I heard no bb, except Carl Cox for some short time) 
and he couldn't create tension. One month ago I experienced him at a rave and
there he really kicked. But this time there was too much unknown music and new
style of him, not his techno/mellow, but more trance stuff.
     In the other hall I shortly heard LTJ Bukem. He spins some cool music,
very low frequencies, so that the hall vibrates and your back shakes "from
alone", the walls convulse and such. You heard the qualtiy of the sound system
by that... Very new and unknown for me, nothing to dance (many ppl left), but
cool. Some new kind of trance?
     I skipped Paul Estak on the one hand because I heard him often at former
raves and know he's good, on the other hand because my power drifted away.
It's very hard to keep track on his music and dancing and I want to live
longer... :). Same with Carl Cox, but I danced a little bit when he spinned.
He was good as usual.
     So I really thought to leave Mayday 6, but the music and feeling were
simply too good! And I'm a lucky boy, because the pre-last DJ of MAYDAY 6 was
DJ Tanith. I never heard him before, but I think: he was the best DJ that
night I heard. He has trance, deeptrance and hardtrance. It is excellent,
simply excellent. We all were low at power, but gave the last stomp to his
beats. He knows how to create tension and mixes perfectly. I danced like mad 
and fell into trance. I got second power. After Tanith's set I experienced 
Acid Junkies' Live Act (trance, OK) and then DJ Tom (or Woody, don't know) was
the final DJ. He had some popular techno songs, mostly trance (deeptrance). It
was nice, I liked it, but then I knew "that was it" and left the hall at about
9am in the morning.
     And then the bad part of the day began. My car lock was destroyed by some
unfriendly person (I heard 40 cars were theftet that night) and first I tried
to find another raver who could open the car without a key. Many tried to
help, but all failed and said it's impossible without proper tools. So after
three hours the damned car was opened by an ADAC (german automobile club) and
to avoid a bill, I became a member of that club (costs me 37 DM a year). :-/
Then I drove two ppl I met home to Koeln/Bonn and slept in the park of Bonn 
(ppl looking surprised about my clothes... :-) and then drove home. In total
I went 1400km with the car, 200 droven by a friend. But it was worth it.

     Enough said. To summarize Mayday6: All music was pretty new, I'd say from
the last four months. The scene seems to go into deeptrance, nearly everyone
played it, gabber DJs excluded. There were at least 25000 ravers, perhaps
more, around 35000. Ppl I met said that at 1am, as they arrived, many left the
hall, it was like come & go. And the hall was always full, so in total there
must be much more than 25000 visitors. The music was OK, the sound system too, 
the Line Up excellent (though Dark Raver missing... :-( ) but the visual
system could have been better, especially the strobos in the main hall. Not to
mension my request for free water (at raves in general). 5 DM for 0,4 litres
Coke is way to much. And finally: They really could afford protection of the
parking cars!

Rave on at Mayday7: Universe Rave

----
if you spread this text don't forget the (c) by its author, Eye
of the Shadow, E-Mail: uf341ea@sunmail.lrz-muenchen.de ; IRC:
Shadow_I ; Fax: +49 89 428419

>From eric@nit.AirTouch.COM  Mon May 16 22:21:34 1994
From: eric@nit.AirTouch.COM (Eric Pederson)
Subject: not rave related - job posting
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU (SF Ravers List)
Date: Mon, 16 May 1994 22:20:24 -0700 (PDT)

Note: commercialish article to follow!  Press 'd' now if you are offended!

We usually go through agencies for our contract software engineers, but
what better place than sfraves to announce a couple of job openings...

Description (2 positions - available immediately)
	- Full time, 40 hours per week.
	- Work though contract agency.  We will set you up with one
	  if you don't have one already.
	- C/Unix programmer.  Will design, develop and test code in C,
	  using Xview for GUI and ESQL/C for database access.  The ideal
	  candidate would also lead small project teams to obtain customer
	  specifications, divide work between team members and give
	  estimates on effort requirements, perform testing, etc. etc.

Requirements
	- Would prefer 3-5+ years of experience, professional especially.
	- Would prefer specific experience with Xview and embedded SQL
	  products, or Xlib/Motif or SQL experience.
	- Excellent communication skills, for a software type :-)  Must
	  be able to work in a team environment.
	- Must desire to expand horizons beyond pure coding.  We like
	  "highly motivated" types.  Would prefer "leadership" attitude
	  or experience.
	- Must be able to work in Walnut Creek.

Benefits
	- $35 to $50/hr, depending on experience.
	- Work in lovely Walnut Creek.
	- Full Internet access, including a full news feed and generous
	  sysadmins :-)
	- Lots of toys and tools.  Our "default" workstation is a 64Mb
	  Sparc 10 with 1Gb for your home directory...  We also use
	  Purify, Purelink, Quantify, CodeCenter and Atria ClearCase
	  for maximum slickness.
	- Casual dress code.  No, no shorts yet, but I'm working on it.
	- Raver friendly environment.

We will be looking at people from all different agencies and sources, so
you would be considered among many, but we know where the best and the
brightest are...  Email resumes to me, or email me a request for my
fax # if interested.
-- 
Eric Pederson                                        AirTouch Communications
eric@nit.airtouch.com                                          (don't laugh)
eric@nit.pactel.com                                             510-210-8890

From: SCRUTON@JOYCE.dnet.hac.com
Subject: eclipse info
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU

Return-path: <Pete@asu.edu>
Date: 17 May 1994 14:30:57 -0700 (MST)
From: Joy <Pete@asu.edu>
Subject: More Info on Weil Trip
To: Dave Scruton <scruton@joyce>
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT


Dear Adventurer,
          Here's some more info on the Peru trip from India
Supera who traveled to Peru and Bolivia to set up the trip
for us.  She will also accompany us in November as she knows
the territory and the local people very well.




INDIA SUPERA
FEATHERED PIPE FOUNDATION


Dear Friends,

Richard Edelman of the Rim Institute and I would like to
invite you to join Andrew Weil and ourselves on an
exciting journey to the Andes, the heart of Peru and
Bolivia, to celebrate the Total Solar Eclipse.  There is
a special significance to the eclipse here as the
Peruvian culture is rooted in a sun-centered creation
myth.  While most of us think only of the Incas when we
think of Peru, they were just the last of many great
civilizations spanning many thousands of years.  These
pre-Incan peoples thought of themselves as the Children
of the Sun.  The legend of the Sun says that the sun god
Inti sent his first two children to earth - Manco Capac
and his sister consort Mama Oello - to bring
illumination and light to the human race.  Their task
was to find the proper spot to place their gold staff
into the ground.  Cusco, where the staff entered the
earth easily, became known as the naval of the world
from which all life springs.  Manco Capac taught the men
to farm and Mama Oello taught the women to weave.
Archeologists know that weaving originated in Peru and
they think that agriculture occurs earliest in Peru.
This myth weaves strands of masculine and feminine,
light and dark, birth and death.  To be there for the
solar eclipse is like being awake in a dream.

We'll start from the peak experience of the Solar
Eclipse and rise higher. We'll climb to Macchu Picchu,
fly over the Nazca lines, skim across Lake Titicaca, and
cross the altiplano of Bolivia to La Paz, the highest
city in the world.  We'll experience the secrets of
these great civilizations as told to us today through
the ruins of the past as well as the arts, crafts and
music of people living there today. Join us to weave the
myth and majesty of Peru into our hearts.  No one ever
goes away disappointed from the Andes.

If you are ready for this adventure, please give us your
mailing address so that we can send you a registration form.
We hope that you'll join us.

Best regards,

(Signed)      India


SEND ADDRESS TO THE.RIM@ASU.EDU

Date: Wed, 18 May 94 14:10:12 PDT
From: winston@lurnix.COM (Mark Guthrie)
Message-Id: <9405182110.AA13189@cassy.lurnix.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Power

Are generators the only reasonable power solution for outdoors?  I know
you can use a car battery and inverter to run small stereos and appliances
so couldn't you use a bigger battery or a bank of small ones for outdoor
power?  Then, hooking up solar PV panels is just one more step for clean
no-gasoline power in the day time.  Doesn't Kotoja or some world/raggae
band in the area already do something like this?  It would be cool to get
off the gasonle-powered generators.  This would be quiter and probably
more reliable.  No moving parts to break or gas to run out of.

-Winston


From sfraves-owner  Thu May 19 18:16:32 1994

From: Bob Ramstad <rramstad@us.oracle.com>
To: winston@lurnix.COM, sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Power
Reply-To: boccibob%groovy@us.oracle.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


the amperage required is just too massive to run a sound system off of
batteries, or solar power.  on the other hand, there was a greenpeace
CD which had all acts recorded from a small portable studio which ran
off of batteries which were charged by solar cells.  the rig needed to
bake in the sun all day in order to run for a couple of hours... and
the power requirements for a small console and DAT deck is about
1/1000 what is necessary for a decent sound system.

(out of curiosity, ethan, what does SoundVision pull?  console + DAT
would probably snarf about 50W, assuming a small 8 track console.)

Bob

before posting, but here it goes.  My friends and I were going through the
MLOL (list of all music-related mailing lists) and we saw SFRaves.  We

getting Derek Chung's calendar, we decided we want to try one this weekend
(that is 5/20 or 5/21, preferrably 5/20).  Could some kind soul(s) out

all of us; we're looking forward to the experience.

sure.  whatever.  all i know is that the rave in a bag will run off of
two 12V 7AH batteries for 8 hours.  the batteries aren't huge, but
aren't small, and i don't consider it a "loud large sound system".

as you've noted, the mixer and turntables are really a minor issue.
they draw very little even if you used an inverter.  the bigger issue
is how many batteries / solar cells do you need to power three stereo
600 watts per channel amplifiers?

simple math gives the answer: lots.

my last post on this issue...  flame me in private, if you'd like,
Steve.

Mime-Version: 1.0

A fully charged car battery or two ought to be plenty to run a decent
sized sound system.  We've run our ham radio Field Day in Portland here
that way every year for the last decade.  We run through an inverter to
get AC and probably draw around 2 kW peak with a 25% power factor (i.e.,
about a 500 watt average).  We've sometimes used a generator to recharge
the batteries and then *turned the generator off* :)

phred w3xy/7

Good to have you! Lately, just about everything has been good.

If you're looking for a smaller friendly party, say 50-150 people, I'd
say your best bet is Launch Pad on Sat. It's outdoors, but the weather
forecast is good.

Alternatively, either of the events the MESS (Mother Earth Sound
System) crew is involved with this weekend should also have good music
and a nice friendly vibe.

If you want to twist your head right off your neck, Test 2 on Friday
ought to provide enough Acid and Techno-Trance to get you there.

And if you want a bigger more "Rave" like party packed with sweaty
people there may be a Wicked on Friday. Wickeds almost always go off.
Bring friends though, because the crowd may be a bit intimidating.

Myself, I'm thinking I may stop by MESS on Friday on my way in to the
city. Saturday, no doubt about it: Launch pad II! 

Sean

i went to what was supposed to be the 'first solar-powered' rock concert
  in peeples park back in 82 in berkeley.  wavy gravy was the host, and
    country joe and the fish were the main act.  they had 6 or 8 arrays
      of cells, each about the size of 2 ping-pong tables; and had been
       charging from sunrize to about noon.  the show lasted for almost
         four hours, and it was LOUD!  
 so supposedly, if you get yer wattages rite and enuf panels, ya can do it!

seeya!

Dave Scruton

Newbies:  before you go out, make sure you check to see if the
party has any "age requirements" if you are under 21.  Wicked,
for example, is held in locations that usually require you to be 21
to enter.  The MESS and Launch Pad parties, however, have no such
restrictions.  I'm only telling you this because it would really
suck to make your way to a party only to be turned away at the
door because you are under 21.  

Laura

Subject: Re: Power NONSENSE 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Thu, 19 May 94 18:53:08 PDT."
             <9405200153.AA07767@groovy.us.oracle.com> 
Date: Fri, 20 May 94 11:11:23 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


> they draw very little even if you used an inverter.  the bigger issue
> is how many batteries / solar cells do you need to power three stereo
> 600 watts per channel amplifiers?

i can't remember exactly what the ampere/hour ratings for car batteries
are, but i vaguely remember that it's in the 50-80 range.

12v * 80A/H == 960 watts/hr

A typical 600 watt class A/B amplifier will waste about 1/2 it's power
rating --> in other words, your 600 w playing maxed out will consume
about 900 watts (especially because it'll be closer to class B
operation when it's cranking out 600watts!). Modulo DC-AC inverter
inefficiencies, you can expect a single car battery to last an hour or
so. You might be better off skipping the inverter and using some of
those "cars that go boom" style amplifiers...

PS: I saw one of those solar powered traffic diversion lights sitting
around unattended late at night in the construction area on Guerrero St
in SF. The solar panels ontop of it were pretty large.... Not that I'm
advocating stealing city/state property or anything....

PPS: yes i to have heard the rollerdisco system in GG park. Very distorted,
and not much power. a rave requires big big power. 

PPPS: nuclear power, that's the way to go, it's clean and efficient :-) :-)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==           Niels Mayer -- netcom!mayer -- mayer@netcom.com               ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

	If a 12V battery is rated for 7AH (amp-hours), this means you can
	get 12*7 Watts for 1 hour or (12*7)*X Watts for 1/X hours.  I've
	read that a car battery puts out about 50 amps while you're 
	starting your car, this is 12V*50A = 600 watts.  But you can't 
	get 600 watts out or your car battery for long (re: starting 
	your car in the winter time...)

	jamescotthompson - CUBE ROOT DATA FATE WATT HOUR INFO GRID

Greetings, Ravers!

It appears that Launch Pad may well be the only "one off" this Saturday,
so we may have a large group of people attending.  It would be helpful
to us all if a few of you could volunteer a little bit of time to watch
the parking lot to ensure things are  going smoothly, etc.

Ethan and I could also use some help in unloading at the site.  As many
people as possible will make very short work of it.  We were imagining
getting the music going by 11, so if some of you could be at the site
around 10:30 to help us move equipment, we would *really* appreciate it.

If anyone has handtrucks/dollies that you could help us with, we would
also appreciate that.  One of ours broke, and is unusable.

Finally, Ethan's truck has broken, and is getting its engine replaced. As
a result, our usual low cost option of just a trailer has been upgraded
to a significantly more expensive requirement for a u-haul truck.  If any
of you attending this event could please donate some money to help defray
that cost (as well as the cost of a 5kW generator), it would really help
us out.  Any donations in excess of our expenses will be given to a
worthy rave-related cause (and not our pockets).

Thank you all, and I look forward to seeing you on the Launch Pad as we
Escape Velocity.
-- 
Bryce Ryan ------- AMBIANCE ----------- brycer@crl.com-----

Over the past umpteen years, i've heard lots of talk about
raves and rave culture being a social space that is somewhat
the opposite of standard bar/clubs in that the atmosphere
is less about picking up/being picked up

I'm kinda writing a paper on this, so what i would like to know is:
To what extent do you think this is true or not,
And how do you think the difference affects you?
(do you think it affects the way you dress? people you talk to? etc etc)

im not sure exactly what the point of the paper is going to be yet,
so anything and EVERYthing helps..
the stuff that seems really obvious
and the stuff that seems really trivial

my own experience is incredibly limited, 
so any ideas would be really helpful

also if you want to throw in reasons why you think you
are able to do this, or the reasons for the culture
being this way, that would also be really nice

thanks very much for your time/bandwidth :)

 ,
dana

Oh yeah.  And i dont really feel comfortable mailing this to
lists that i am not on, so if you are on a list other than
SFrave or Socal-raves, and think this might get response
and wouldnt be intrusive, please forward it on.

Thanks again.

From: JVLraves@aol.com

Message-Id: <9405212135.tn356345@aol.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Sat, 21 May 94 21:35:49 EDT
Subject: late post on flaming homos
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Hi all, it's time to post:

Remember the discussions about gay ravers a few weeks back?  I bet you
thought that topic was over.  I want to pose a question to help bring
together two topics i've been mulling over, in a humourous way.

I know what a flame war is, after reading sfraves for a month.  

I know many gays that 'flame' in a social kinda way.

What would you call a flaming homo who ignites/fuels a flame war on the net?

Trip 2 last night was cool!  They set up a sweet little ambient room.  I was
in that kind of a gentle mood.  It seems that that 'floor' not the dance
floor was where the more enlightened aspects of the eve. occured.  My younger
friend needs to relax and realize that bigger is not usually better wrt
raving.  (you know who you are.) Friday outings are always a bit challenging.
 
Ananda was a fiasco.  Can you guys get better organized next time.  Maybe
it's not your fault; could be friday carma.  Fridays never seem to *click*.
 Anybody aggree/know why?

 Anyway, I was talking w/ a really *exhuberent* young fella, (very
imaginative dancing guy!,) and the topic came around to my boyfriend, who
just won't rave w/ me.  He just hasn't figured out what hips are for.  This
guy told me that he lives in Santa Rosa, and his best friend, who happens to
be gay, just moved away.  He didn't take the opportunity to hug him good-bye.
 Can he give me a hug.  (Proxie, sort-of maybe?)  He said it would heal some
unspoken feelings he had for his friend, but being straight, or what-ever,
didn't coalecse  A hug - you bet.  Grrrhhh!  Now That Was Unity.  Little
things like that keep me outa da gay bars, and coming back to this family.  

Following this stream of thought, I noticed someone noticed the Gay element
at Wicked these days and posted it.  Cool.  I have to say i'm kinda proud to
be part of the gay posse at clan-o-Wicked.  My buddies tend to put on a bit
of a show.  I don't mind, and I don't THINK other mind.  The problem is when
I have to peel my buddies off of my body; no slither piles on the dance floor
please, i'm trying to groove, okay?

Keep the faith.
Jivala, the first two of each three.

On Sat, 21 May 1994 JVLraves@aol.com wrote:
> Maybe
> it's not your fault; could be friday carma.  Fridays never seem to *click*.
> Anybody aggree/know why?

I tend to like Fridays a lot more than Saturday only because of the 
logistics.  Maybe Fridays are bad because people still have some sort of 
load on their shoulders from work, school, or other sometimes stressful 
activity.

I like Fridays because it allows me a chance to exert myself more and 
have all of Saturday and Sunday to recover.  By Monday, I will feel 
physically and mentally prepared to go back to school.  (I'm done with 
finals, hurray!)  But going out Saturday doesn't give me enough time.  
I've really let go sometimes and I feel lethargic when Monday comes 
around to go to class.  I'll feel sluggish, slow, and apathetic until 
sometimes Tuesday.

Fridays are just better.

Lawdy, testwo was good! A tip of the topper to the SoundVision tag-team 
knob-tweakers, Alex, Jonah and all the others responsible for this one.

I went through absolute owl bus hell to get there, but it was quickly 
forgotten once I finally arrived. Once inside, you can't help but feel 
that something is going right. It really says something when the majority 
of the folks on the floor are dancing and stay dancing. Not to say that 
dancing is the only way to appreciate the music, but it just seemed that 
most of the crowd was really affected by what was going on.

Great space. Great folks. Great job. Don't miss testhree.

this list have asked for copies of it.  (I wouldn't call it rave music but
many people on this list like it...)

                    _________________________________

                      D E E P   F O R E S T   F A Q
                    _________________________________
                               version 1.0

"Somewhere, deep in the jungle, are living some little men and women.  They
are your past.  Maybe... maybe they are your future."
                                                -- Deep Forest


________________________________________________________________________
////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
________________________________________________________________________


This document would not have been possible without the help of a lot of
people on the Internet.  To some, this document may represent an extreme
example of some of the minutiae that gets compiled and transmitted over the
Internet.  Here we have this enormous FAQ and Discography for a group that
really only has one album out (which is rather amusing, actually).  But
fans of any particular group (or people interested in any subject) can
exchange information in cyberspace to each other's mutual benefit.  Now
*that* is putting power into the hands of the people, which is the goal of
personal computing. (can you tell I work in the computer industry? :-)

"OUT OF AFRICANS" by Leslie Sly has been a particularly helpful article,
from the April 1993 Sonic Magazine, and has been used without permission.
Also, "African Pygmy chants go Europop in 'Deep Forest'" by Paul Geitner of
the Associated Press has been excerpted as well, and is also used without
permission.

A special thanks to:
    Pete Ashdown
    Christian Barthold
    <\/>ike Brogdon
    David Campbell
    Ad Feelders
    Daniel M. Greenberg
    Joar Grimstvedt
    LAURENCE JANUS
    Erich W Leonhardt
    NEESH Manish
    william pabst
    Dan Nicholson
    Pima Pimenoph
    Jay Redd
    Gavin Stok
    Mathias Thallmayer
    David E A Wilson
    Eric Zanto
    and others as they send in info to be included!

                         SUMMARY OF WHAT'S INSIDE

II. Frequently Asked Questions

     3. Q: How did Deep Forest write their songs?
     4. Q: How did they make the album?
     5. Q: Is Deep Forest sensitive to the cultural heritage of the
           people that they have sampled in their music?
     6. Q: Will there be any more albums?
     7. Q: Will Deep Forest ever perform live?

           popular in the U.S.?
     9. Q: What is the background on the "Sweet Lullaby" video?
    10. Q: If I like Deep Forest, are there other groups that I might
           like?

    12. Q: What does the original Baka music that is sampled in Deep
           Forest sound like?
