    14. Q: How did they use the equipment on the album?
III. Discography
     1. Sample Credits
     2. Background on the Remixers

________________________________________________________________________

                       I .   L I N E R   N O T E S

DEEP FOREST - A Huge Green Brushstroke of Sound!

From a sticker on the cover: "A rare and unusual mix of ambient modern
music and the songs of the Pygmies of the Central African rain forest."

Deep Forest is based on an original idea by Michel Sanchez.
Arranged by Eric Mouquet and Michel Sanchez.
Keyboards and Programming by Eric Mouquet, Michel Sanchez and Cooky Cue
   on "Savana Dance".
Additional vocals:  Michel Villain
Produced by Dan Lacksman


From the liner notes on the Sweet Lullaby CD5:

"Deep Forest is not a band.  Deep Forest is not an artist.
Deep Forest is a concept ... a state of mind.
Deep Forest is music to dance to *and* to listen to.
Deep Forest joins together the hi-tech dance music of modern Europe with
the haunting voices of the rain forest Pygmies of Africa."


From the liner notes on the Deep Forest full-length CD:

"Imprinted with the ancestral wisdom of the African chants, the music of
Deep Forest immediately touches everyone's soul and instinct.  The forest
of all civilizations is a mysterious place where the yarn of tales and
legends is woven with images of men, women, children, animals and fairies.
Not only living creatures, but trees steeped in magical powers.  Universal
rites and customs have been profoundly marked by the influence of the
forest, a place of power and knowledge passed down from generation to
generation by the oral traditions of primitive societies.  The chants of
Deep Forest, Baka chants of Cameroon, of Burundi, of Senegal and of
Pygmies, transmit a part of this important oral tradition gathering all
peoples and joining all continents through the universal language of music.
Deep Forest is the respect of this tradition which humanity should cherish
as a treasure which marries world harmony, a harmony often compromised
today.  That's why the musical creation of Deep Forest has received the
support of UNESCO and of two musicologists, Hugo Zempe and Shima Aron, who
collected the original documents."


"The Producers and Musicians on this recording are donating part of their
profit to the Pygmy Fund."

    The Pygmy Fund
    Attn.:Jean-Pierre Hallet
    P.O.Box 277
    Malibu, CA 90265

________________________________________________________________________

       I I .   F R E Q U E N T L Y   A S K E D   Q U E S T I O N S

________________________________________________________________________

1.  Q: What does Deep Forest sound like?

A:  Deep Forest is Ambient Electronic Dance music which skillfully combines
centuries-old Baka pygmy chants from central Africa with Europop rhythms
and a synthesized dance beat.

________________________________________________________________________

2.  Q: How did the Deep Forest project start?

A:  "It was just for our pleasure in the beginning," Eric Mouquet, one of
two French musicians who helped create "Deep Forest," says of the project.
"We just put all the feeling that we wanted into this music, and after we
saw the success, we were very proud."

Mouquet says his partner, Michel Sanchez, found some tapes of Pygmy chant
recorded decades ago and played them after dinner one night.

"It was very quiet, very beautiful," Mouquet said in a telephone interview
from the studio in Brussels, Belgium, where "Deep Forest" was made.
Mouquet then came up with the idea of combining the sounds with their own
music.

They ended up cutting the tapes and mixing them with synthesized music,
drum beats and sound effects, all the while keeping as much of the
original melody and tempo as possible.

Then they took their demos to Lacksman and the songs were entirely
re-worked.  "It was the vocals and the emotion of the songs which attracted
me," he says.

They made a deal with Sony France, then sought to secure the rights to all
the vocals.  They eventually won the backing of UNESCO, which opened its
extensive library to them, and of two musicologists, Hugo Zempe and Shima
Aron, who collected the original documents.

Dan Lacksman comments,  "[Producing the album] has actually been quite a
long process (over a year to complete) and it's been one of the most
enjoyable jobs I've done because we had complete freedom to work on it
until we were happy with it.  We didn't have all the time pressures and
frustrations that you usually have in a recording session so we were able
to experiment.  We did lots of versions of the tracks to see what worked
best. We did four versions of Sweet Lullaby, for example, to try different
tempos. We did a fast version, but it lost its charm so we went back to the
current (slow) style.  While the album, in the end result, might sound
simple, we spent hours or even months on very small details."

-- excerpted from "African Pygmy chants go Europop in 'Deep Forest'" by
Paul Geitner of the Associated Press and "OUT OF AFRICANS" by Leslie Sly
from the April 1993 issue of Sonic Magazine.

________________________________________________________________________

3.  Q: How did Deep Forest write their songs?

A:  The songwriting process was unusual because they started with the
vocals and built the rhythms and textures around them.  First they sampled
all the vocals into an Akai S1000 in small sections, cut them up, and used
its time stretching facility to give them a rhythmic structure that would
work with time code.  Lacksman says he didn't know what the lyrics meant in
the first place and, by now, they may be quite meaningless because bits of
songs from different cultures were mixed together to achieve certain
textures and rhythms.

"This is not an ethnic album," he says in defence of his indiscrete
cut-and-pasting.  "But, we did absolutely want to respect the soul of the
songs and we hope that our music will inspire people who don't usually
listen to music from other cultures, to seek some out.  The funny thing is
a lot of African people have told us they really like the album.  Only
academics, purists and musicologists have been negative about it."

The voice samples have been use creatively - the usual cardinal sins of
sampling, like chipmonking and loop glitches, have been used to great
effect.  Sometimes, for example, a voice sample breaks briefly at the loop
point into a strange squarewave-type yodel.  But Lacksman says very little
was done to them in terms of artificial treatment.

There are no acoustic instruments on the album, some vocals were added.
"We wrote out all the lyrics phonetically for the (session) singers so they
could match with the sampled voices.  Then we did a lot of overdubs - 18
tracks bounced down to two, then 16 down to two and so on."

The sampled voices had been mapped out on a keyboard ant then played into
Cubase.  "The idea was to enhance the wonderful singing with the latest
technology and to really blend these old and new cultures."

Excerpted from "OUT OF AFRICANS" by Leslie Sly from the April 1993 issue of
Sonic Magazine.

________________________________________________________________________

4.  Q: How did they make the album?

A:  The making of Deep Forest's debut hit album happened in three stages.
Keyboard player Eric Mouquet got involved duing stage two, after fellow
keyboardist Michel Sanchez had laid the groundwork for some tracks by
putting synth ambience to the tribal tunes.  During a brief visit to
Australia, to promote the album and pick up a few didgeridoo samples for
their next project, Eric explained how he got involved and what happened
next.

"One day Michel played me the ambient version of Sweet Lullaby.  At that
stage it had no drums, just the vocals and synth pads.  I really liked it
because I thought he was trying to enhance the African voices, not just fit
them into his musical ideas."

Excerpted from "OUT OF AFRICANS" by Leslie Sly from the April 1993 issue of
Sonic Magazine.

________________________________________________________________________

5.  Q: Is Deep Forest sensitive to the cultural heritage of the people
       that they have sampled in their music?

Aware of the charges of cultural exploitation that have been leveled
against similar projects by such artists as Paul Simon and David Byrne,
the "Deep Forest" creators sought advice from experts on African music.

Mouquet says they took the finished album to Francis Bebey, an
internationally renowned journalist, author and musician from Cameroon,
whose 1975 book, "African Music: A People's Art," is considered an
important reference work.

"He said, 'Oh you're right to do something like that, because African
culture is not only for African people.  It's a good way to merge all kinds
of music with something new,'" Mouquet says.

[In order to really help the African people, Deep Forest] decided to give a
percentage of the "Deep Forest" royalties to The Pygmy Fund, based in
Malibu, Calif.  About $25,000 has been earmarked for the fund so far,
[according to] Golden.

The fund's founder, Jean-Pierre Hallet, was honored in Washington with a
Presidential End Hunger Award in 1987 for his work with the Efe Pygmies of
the Ituri Forest in Zaire.  He says he was dubious when first approached
about "Deep Forest."

"When I heard someone had taken their songs and cut them up and added a
disco beat, I said, 'Oh wow, that's terrible to do that to that beautiful
sound.'  Then I heard it," he says.  "It's almost magical music."

Hallet says he has yet to play the album for his Pygmy friends.  His last
trip to Zaire, in May, was cut short by renewed fighting in the country's
civil war.

"I cannot wait to go back and let them hear it,"  Hallet says.  "I'm sure
they will begin dancing -- automatically."

-- excerpted from "African Pygmy chants go Europop in 'Deep Forest'" by
Paul Geitner of the Associated Press.

________________________________________________________________________

6.  Q: Will there be any more albums?

A:  The band has a contract to do four more albums and Lacksman thinks
they'll work differently next time.  They'll build a new studio for a
start.  "We'll do a lot of demos but this time they'll be recorded on
digital 8-track, so we can use the elements from them in the final mix.  We
want to use sounds from a lot of other countries, too, especially India and
Australia."

Excerpted from "OUT OF AFRICANS" by Leslie Sly from the April 1993 issue of
Sonic Magazine.

________________________________________________________________________

7.  Q: Will Deep Forest ever perform live?

A:  While this project was studio-driven during the recording process, when
they go on stage they'll have three keyboard players, an African vocal
choir, a drummer, a bassist, percussionist and a troupe of dancers.
They'll use the sequencer only to run in some effects and to run the Roland
RSS with the timecode so they can recreate some of the spatial effects on
the album.  "It will be a very high-tech band," says Eric, "but it will be
a real band!  Some of the songs may be longer and the dance aspect may be
more prominent, but it will still be ambient.

"We don't know yet if we'll use a straight-forward stereo PA system or
whether we'll also have speakers at the back of the room to enhance the RSS
effects.  We've got to work this stuff out."

They will tour Europe and the US, and hit Australia by November 1994.

Excerpted from "OUT OF AFRICANS" by Leslie Sly from the April 1993 issue of
Sonic Magazine.

________________________________________________________________________

8.  Q: Why did it take so long after its initial release to become
       popular in the U.S.?

A:  First released in the United States in April 1992, "Deep Forest"
attracted little mainstream attention, although the single "Sweet Lullaby"
made it onto the modern rock and dance music charts during the summer of
1993.

Still, the album sold about 200,000 copies in the United States, mainly
through word-of-mouth and alternative radio air play, according to "Deep
Forest" publicist Ellen Zoe Golden.

In the fall of 1993, Sony decided to give it a second chance by signing
hotshot director Tarsem to shoot a new video for "Sweet Lullaby."

-- excerpted from "African Pygmy chants go Europop in 'Deep Forest'" by
Paul Geitner of the Associated Press.

________________________________________________________________________

9.  Q: What is the background on the "Sweet Lullaby" video?

A:  Tarsem (who was born in India and goes by one name) won a Grammy and an
MTV award in 1992 for directing R.E.M.'s "Losing My Religion" video.
Despite a deluge of offers, he has avoided the format since then,
concentrating instead on commercials for the likes of Levi's and Adidas.

"They had done a really bad video for it for Europe," Tarsem said in a
telephone interview from London.  "I saw the video and I heard the song
and I thought, 'What a great song -- what a crappy video.'"

Tarsem's version features a little girl (his 4-year-old niece) circling
the globe on a tricycle, searching for the perfect lullaby.  The haunting
melody of the Pygmy lullaby is combined with striking scenes shot in
Moscow's Red Square, at the Great Wall of China, in front of the Taj Mahal
and under the Brooklyn Bridge.

MTV latched on to the lush imagery in 1994, putting the video into heavy
rotation and fueling new interest in the album, which finally cracked
Billboard's top 100.

-- excerpted from "African Pygmy chants go Europop in 'Deep Forest'" by
Paul Geitner of the Associated Press.

________________________________________________________________________

10.  Q: If I like Deep Forest, are there other groups that I might
        like?

         - Enigma (generally more dark)
    - Dead Can Dance (generally more dark)
    - Will (this is more gothic and dark)
    - Mouth Music - Mo-Di (doesn't have a dance beat)
    - Jean-Michel Jarre - Zoolook

Mathias Thallmayer said, "[Deep Forest] is similar in style and feel to
Enigma.  (If you like Enigma, get Deep Forest. If you like Deep Forest, get
Enigma.)  I prefer Enigma, but Deep Forest is still very nice.  It is not
earth shattering but still worth-while."

Gavin Stok said, "Enigma is VERY different to Deep Forest - I am still to
understand why people say they are so similar... The only similarity is
that they work on the same principle - music layered on top of traditional
sounds.... Enigma is more gothic and traditional than Deep Forest which is
more upbeat and lacking in tradition."

Ad Feelders said, "If you like Deep Forest, I think you should definitely
listen to ZOOLOOK by Jean-Michel Jarre.  More creative use of sampled human
voices. I know the DF-guys have listened to it (especially the title
track!)"

________________________________________________________________________

11.  Q: Where do the chants come from?

A:  The chants chosen come from Pygmies and other ethnic groups in
Cameroon, Burundi and Senegal.

________________________________________________________________________

12.  Q: What does the original Baka music that is sampled in Deep
        Forest sound like?

A:  There are two companion releases produced by Martin Cradick of Outback.
(Released on Hannibal, a division of Rykodisc.)

1. HEART OF THE FOREST
   The Music Of The Baka Forest People Of Southeast Cameroon

This is actual field recordings of the Baka people, on-site in Cameroon.


2. BAKA BEYOND
   Spirit of the Forest

Mathias Thallmayer said, "This album was recorded approximately a year
after Cradick and his wife returned from living with a Baka family group
for six weeks.  "

Comments by Cradick from the liner notes: "Some of these tracks were
inspired by listening to and playing with the Baka.  Some are pieces that I
wrote in the forest with them which I have developed further since
returning to England.  Others are 'covers' of their songs based on
recordings made after giving them our guitar and jamming with them on
mandolin.  I have tried to recreate the spirit of these occasions rather
than copy the music exactly and have included their performances,
especially their percussion, where it helps in this aim."

Mathias Thallmayer comments about the album, "I guess you could say that
this one falls into the World Beat category.  (It is not Ambient Dance like
Deep Forest.)  The music is sprightly, upbeat, and very enjoyable.  The
music is primarily guitar, mandolin, violin, flutes and percussion."

________________________________________________________________________

13.  Q: What equipment does Deep Forest use?

A:  From Dan Lackman's recording and programming studios, Synsound, In
Brussels, are furnished with a massive array of old and state-of-the-art
gear.  These are a few of his favorite things...

RECORDING: DDA DCM 232desk with DDA automation, Mitsubishi X-880 32-track
with Apogee 944 filters; Otari MTR 90 24-track.  Both are fully
synchronized with U-matic video recorders for post production.  Monitors
are JBL, Dynaudio Acoustics PPM1, and Auratones

EFFECTS: Roland RSS, a range of Lexicon, Yamaha, Eventide and Roland units.

KEYBOARDS: Fairlight CMI Series III with Rev 9 software, 24-channel router,
three hard disk configurations (1.5 Gb in total).  Huge library of sounds
on 800Mb WORM optical disks. Fairlight Series II, New England Digital
Synclavier II (pre-Midi and pre-sampling).  Roland A50 & MKB1000 master
keyboards, Akai S1000 (6Mb), Yamaha SY99, TX816, TX807, DX7.  Roland D50,
MKS20, Super Jupiter, Sequential Circuits Prophet VS, Studio Electronics
Midimoog.

DRUM STUFF: Roland TR505, R8, TR808, TR707, CR78, Octapads, Linndrum V3.1,
Fairlight library, Alesis D4, SDSV Simmons with pads.

THE MUSEUM: EMS VCS3, Polymoog, Multimoog, Oberhelm OBX, Sennheiser VSM201
vocoder, Roland Jupiter 8, Moog IIIP modular with Midi via MPU 101
Interface.

SEQUENCERS: Atari/Cubase, Pro-24, Roland MC4, MSQ700, Linn 9000, Roland
model 104 (analogue sequencer), Fairlight Page R.

PROGRAMMING SUITE: Tascam 320 & 216 consoles, Tascam 80-8 eight-track.

Courtesy of "OUT OF AFRICANS" by Leslie Sly from the April 1993 issue of
Sonic Magazine.

________________________________________________________________________

14.  Q: How did they use the equipment on the album?

A:  Eric co-wrote most of the tracks and says this was a long process of
experimenting and fine tuning... "because we wanted to keep the same
feeling throughout the record."  The initial keyboard parts were mostly
written on a Korg Wavestation because "Michel knows that keyboard very well
and gets good sounds out of it."  However, the building of rich
multi-layered pads a lot of vector synthesis via the Prophet VS... "so that
the sounds were constantly moving and we sampled Mini Moog effects and a
lot of our sounds came from the Multi Moog.

"We never used the factory presets and most of the sounds on the records
are combinations.  The flutes, for example, are a combination of samples
and Roland pan flutes.  We used the internal effects on keyboards,
particularly on the JD800 because they're so important to the actual sound,
together with external effects and the RSS.

"We spent a long time on rhythmic sounds and we often used cheap toy-like
keyboards for the loops.  We spent hours adjusting the offsets of the loop
so we could run up to three at once to get a good feel.  Then I'd lay out
drum sets on the Wavestation and play in additional parts to get a live and
not too sequenced feel."

Courtesy of "OUT OF AFRICANS" by Leslie Sly from the April 1993 issue of
Sonic Magazine.

________________________________________________________________________


                     I I I.   D I S C O G R A P H Y

________________________________________________________________________

1. SAMPLE CREDITS

Deep Forest - Contains sample from "Marilli", recorded by Stephen Jay
   from the Elektra Nonesuch album "Ghana Ancient Ceremonies, Songs &
   Dance Music".  Courtesy Elektra Nonesuch Records by arrangement with
   Warner Special Products.

Sweet Lullaby - Contains a sample from "Sadeness", the sample being the
   drum break that starts the song, after the initial monk singing.

Hunting, Nightbird - Ethnic Sound Series Vol. 4 Polyphony of Deep Rain
   Forest track 1 and track 2 courtesy of JVC Musical Industries.

Forest Hymn - Ethnic Sound Series Vol. 4 Polyphony of Deep Rain Forest
   track 1 courtesy of JVC Musical Industries.
________________________________________________________________________

2. BACKGROUND ON THE REMIXERS

Tony Garcia works for/with MCT, which is a management company in
New York City.  Although it doesn't look like he has any of his own
projects out, he has done remixes for Sven Vath ("L'Esperanza - Raindance
Mix"), Depeche Mode ("Rush - Nitrate Mix" from the "Condemnation" single),
and many other groups. (NEESH)

Tony Garcia and Guido Osorio did the "V.R. Heroin Mix" and "Needle Park
Mix" on Billy Idol's "Heroin" single. (Dan Nicholson)

Jam El Mar and Marc Spoon are the group Jam and Spoon, from Germany.  In
addition to doing their own music, they also remix a lot of other group's
songs, including "Carly's Song" by Enigma, "Age of Love - Jam and Spoon
Remixes" by Age of Love, and work for Cosmic Baby among others.

DJ Digit and DJ Efx are San Francisco underground DJs who have recorded
their own music as well as remixed others' music.

and I'll make sure you get credited with helping out.

          A CALCULATED FORECAST OF ULTIMATE DOOM:
             Sickening Episodes of Widespread
               Devastation Accompanied by 
           Sensations of Pleasurable Excitement

Survival Research Laboratories' first full-scale San Francisco 
performance in five years will take place on Saturday, May 28th
1994.  Further information may be obtained by:

1.  Checking SRL.ORG from 0000-0600 PST by anonymous FTP.
2.  Calling SRL at (415) 641-8065 for recorded information.
3.  Calling (415) 241-1568 for site location _on the day
      of the show_.

Tickets will become available on May 24th at these San 
Francisco establishments:
	
	Naked Eye
	Leather Tongue
	Dark Carnival 

As this is an indoor performance, attendance will be limited
to 3,000 people.  A sellout is anticipated.


----- End Included Message -----

From sfraves-owner  Sun May 22 13:59:47 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA22546; Sun, 22 May 94 13:59:47 PDT
Received: from soda.berkeley.edu by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA22534; Sun, 22 May 94 13:59:37 PDT
Received: (laura@localhost) by soda.berkeley.edu (8.6.9/PHILMAIL-1.10) id NAA28409; Sun, 22 May 1994 13:59:53 -0700
Message-Id: <199405222059.NAA28409@soda.berkeley.edu>
From: laura@soda.berkeley.edu (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Sun, 22 May 1994 13:59:51 -0700
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: KEN.STUART@tigerteam.org (KEN STUART), sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: Breaks at raves
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Ken writes:
>On alt.rave, Joe (Raver909) recently claimed that raves in the U.S.
>rarely play any breaks/jungle/hardcore and that everything is "4 to the
>floor, 120 to 135 bpm", ie house.

First off, let me put in my two cents worth and say that I think Joe 
has been really reactionary and downright mean on alt.rave with his 
reactive bashing of all dance music forms that are not breakbeat.  

>From what I know from various experiences I've had around the US, 
breakbeat is not as dead as Joe likes to make it out to be.  It is 
happening in Houston.  One of the best DJs in the Southwest spins breakbeat.  
There's the Pittsburg/Toronto axis, there's got to be some somewhere in 
LA (as that is where R.A.W. is from), there's still some in Boston.  
People on alt.rave are always asking about such well-known breakbeat 
producers as the Prodigy (and from that starting point they can be directed 
to other less-well known breakbeat artists).

On the East Coast and in San Francisco house, progressive house, and 
tribal are currently showing a lot of popularity.  A year and a half ago 
on the East Coast hardcore and breakbeat were big.  In fall/winter of 1992 
all I'd ever hear in Boston was breakbeat, all I'd hear in Brooklyn was 
hardcore, and house was unheard of at East Coast raves.  Funny how when 
things change to something someone likes they say "it's about time" and "see 
I told you so" but when they change away from something someone likes they 
bitch and moan.  Human nature I guess :-)

But to answer your question:

>In your experience, is this true for S.F. Bay Area raves?

Until rather recently, it seemed it was hard to find any other form
of music other than the house/funk/trip-hop/disco vein, but over
the past six months I've seen a lot of new parties spring up that 
have been branching out into other forms of dance music. 

Breakbeat (in the UK hardcore sense), however, is rarely heard in San 
Francisco.  There is one DJ I know of in SF who plays breakbeat, and
that is Demigod -- the guy who was putting on the "Apocolypse" parties
at the Haze Theater last month.  He'd bring up R.A.W. from LA to 
spin breakbeat, too.  

Contrary to Joe Lesense's statements that breakbeat (or "jungle" as 
he calls it) brings out a livelier, friendlier, dancier, more diverse 
crowd, the people I saw at the Haze were pretty much just the average 
Haze bunch:  young (since there are so few places in town for under-21's 
to go out), nice enough yet insular (they'll smile and say hi if you talk 
to them, but didn't exactly give off open firendly vibes), and most just 
stood around and watched rather than really dancing.  The people responding 
to breakbeat at parties I've been to back East represented the usual 
cross-section of people who go to raves -- not any more or less wonderful or 
vibey.

After all, it's all just music -- a given genre of dance music isn't 
inherently bad or vibe-killing or extra-good-for-raving or anything like 
that.  It's what the individuals make of it.  Some people think that 
anything faster than 130 bpm is the spawn of the devil, yet I've seen many 
a happy party where people were bouncing along with huge smiles to that
"scourge" of the SF scene:  Brooklyn hardcore.  Some people think that a 
soulful house groove will make a party "right," but I've seen parties 
where someone will start playing deep house and people will leave the 
floor moaning in despair.  (For example, Garth's appearance at one of
the Essence parties in NYC was greeted by "what is this CRAP?" by some
and by frenzied dancing by others.)  I've been to parties where people 
leave the floor if the music is too hard, too dark, too happy, too 
discoey, too slow . . . It's all matter of taste and mood.

The best anyone can hope for is that a critical number of people will 
be happy with the music being played so that the party will continue 
onward in a lively and happy manner.  Claiming that one form of dance 
music is better for this than another amounts to declaring that personal 
taste and personal choice don't matter, and that the person making such 
claims knows the minds of hundreds of party goers better than they do 
themselves.

Laura

Y'alll missed Buck's set which was as good as Ethan's and real different,
which was great.  Will-E was lower energy; I missed Meme.  But what a
great night.  Those irrepressible FluidGroove-sters must have *paved*
the site: four lanes of fresh bouncy asphalt, going nowhere in particular.
I wonder a little bit, tho, with no other 'name' parties, why there wasn't
an even bigger turnoout.  Maybe folks thought it would be cold and didn't
want to go over there an find out.....  There were a few power glitches
but when I left at 5, there were maybe 50 - 60 people there.  With a nearlyy
full moon and a few lights for the dj setup and with various light toys that
people brought, it was suitably festive & primitive at the same time.  a
tad upscale from YSH,, in other words.   Great party.  I'm looking forward
to the one at Kommotion next month.

AstroBoy

	TestII was in a great artist loft space- the upstairs had lots of room
	to move around and great lighting.

	was also a great atmosphere.

Date: Sun, 22 May 94 21:16:35 PDT
From: DWATANAB@uci.edu (Dana Watanabe)

Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I was bored and had a few mintues to kill on my lunch break
so i decided to wander through our beloved campus bookstore.

Walking up to that wonderful section on computer books
(with the prominantly displayed and oh-so-colorful, Joy of X book)
and sitting there, also prominantly displayed, was this book
THE INTERNET WHITE PAGES
which i guess is a somewhat companion of the Internet Yellow Pages
made by some different people i believe

but anyhow...
in this wondrous book is a collection of email addresses
of everyone and their dog who has posted something somewhere
to somesuch public place... (actually i think it said
that they got some program to go through and snag
all the Usenet posters)

i dunno, it felt incredibly intrusive, but at the same time
kinda cool seeing my name there
although Greg Earle is much hipper, having two accounts listed
i looked for all my other accounts, but i guess i didnt post
during the right time frame or something

so anyways, if youre bored and want to go look up who the
person who sat behind you in geometry to see if they
have an email account, this seems like a nifty way to do it

everyone i tried to look for (whose account i didnt know)
i had no luck finding even though have of them HAVE email
but i guess they arent social enough or something

 ,
dana

"One more toke, and I'll see God."

What Is Rave ? ( Non-serious post follows ...)

Rave Is : A Sex Orgy! according to a cover expose story in a recent
          issue of Hustler. I think they went to a party with lots of
          simulated(?) sex acts.

"Rave" Is : A new "men's" magazine (lotsa picturs of nekkid gals).

"Rave" Is : A women's clothing store in the big shopping mall a few
            miles from me.

"Rave" Is : A shampoo.

 Anybody else know of a commercial use of the word "rave" that really
doesn't have anything to do with the original meanings of the word , or
dance parties?

	Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

> 	  candidate would also lead small project teams to obtain customer
> 	  specifications, divide work between team members and give

> What Is Rave ? ( Non-serious post follows ...)
>  Anybody else know of a commercial use of the word "rave" that really
> doesn't have anything to do with the original meanings of the word , or
> dance parties?

Namco refers to their "Galaxian 3" mega-huge laserdisc ride/arcade game
(much like Operation Starblade) as a "Rave War".  Since they advertise it
on all their other recent games, you can see "Rave War" stickers on Ridge
Racer, Suzuka 8 Hours 2, and other games...

Whatever.  My favorite Japanese arcade game title was the ship from a 
deservedly forgotten laser game called _Interstellar Fantasy_.  You were
the "Ferald Runcer".

// g

Subject: Launch Pad Review

I had a wonderful time at launch pad!  it was great to see so many of
you.  I also want to thank those of you who helped load and unload
the sound system: phil, will-e, lane, and sun.  there were others who
helped, too...forgive my memory lapse. big thanks to sean for the
lighting and lasers...that was way cool fun.  next time we'll know that
we *must* have a bigger generator to run the sound system, lights, and
more, and not have to watch the generator so closely.  i felt really
bad that the sound cut out at all...an important fact for the collective
memory is that sound vision plus extras requires at least a 5kW generator.
and major props to the DJs, the dancers, and to several very special 
people.  At one of the Liquid Airs, one of the people who reside near the
site told us about the location we used for Launch Pad....extra special
hugs and thanks to him for that information.  And, a special thanks to
two other residents who helped us drive the truck directly to the location
of the sound system when we were done.  that saved us all a lot of work.
A big hug and thanks to them.

i also want to thank those of you on the list who responded to my request 
for donations.  Ethan and I were able to pay cash for all the items that
we needed to rent in order to provide launch pad with the full on Sound
Vision system, generator, juice, munchies, and whatnot.  We had $24 left
over.  We've been thinking of reinvesting the money in the next launch
pad (or similar party), or donating it to a rave related cause.  If you
have a strong preference with what we should do with this money, please
let us know, and we will follow the desires of the consensus.

i'm really thankful for a great party, and i'm looking forward to 
participating In The Light.
-- 
Bryce Ryan ------- AMBIANCE ----------- brycer@crl.com-----

i can now think of three pieces of received (and named) wisdom from the list:

Resonate's Rule: "you know the sound is perfect when you don't wear earplugs"
Kawakami's Corollary: "You know it's a party when Captain Crunch dances"
Ramstad's Constant: "The first and last X minutes of a DJ's set will differ
                     from the body of their work"

pardon my paraphrases if i do not correctly reflect your original intentions.
any errors in quotation are purely mine. Any additions?
--

From: Luke Youngblood <LUKEY@wordperfect.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU, phred@well.sf.ca.us
Subject:  Re: phred @ ameba
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

	You know Donald?  He must be one of the most unknown DJs outside of
his area (Seattle), thats also one of the best DJs on the west coast.
I'm serious, we've brought him out to Salt Lake City twice now, and
he's completely blown us away every time.  Not to belittle or put
them down, but I seriously think he's better than Garth, Thomas, and
Carlos (some other big names we've brought out here).  He knows how
to build the energy with european techno (not too fast, he pitches it
down a lot), and once you think you're going to go crazy from the
amount of energy that he's built up on the dance floor, he releases
it all with a beautiful house track that makes the party _go off_! 
You people in SF don't know what you're missing.  Not very many DJs
that I know can do the insane 4 or 5 minute long house mixes that he
does and keep the beats perfectly in sync.  Not to mention the
cutting and scratching that he is a master at.  I seriously think he
blows away most of the Wicked DJs, and his price is probably a
quarter of what they charge.  Check him out if you get a chance.  Bye
for now.

Luke

>>> Fred Heutte <phred@well.sf.ca.us>  5/20/94, 06:08pm >>>
Ameba is near Haight & Cole, on the north side of Haight.  As you can
tell from the timestamp on this posting, I'm not spinning there now!
However, I hope to be there tomorrow afternoon.  Progressive/deep
house, mostly.  I didn't have much luck shopping at BPM today (though
it was fun hanging out there for "DJ treasure hunt" day -- new stuff
from the distributors generally shows up late in the week), but I did
find a copy of the Volume & Tension track that's a favorite of Donald
Glaude and which *I* really dig and will *definitely* play!

The way it works at Ameba is pretty informal so I don't know exactly
when
I'll be on deck, but it'll be either sooner or later :)

see you in the future 

phred

To: SFraves@techno.Stanford.EDU

Subject: Monterey meets Launch Pad!!
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Kudos to all you wonderful people who put on the Launch Pad.  To those of you
I talked to, and met for the first time; Ethan, Bryan, Sean, Lee, Lane, Sean,
Alyssa, Bob, GeoffW  Tamara, Cap'n Crunch, and Brian, was I really having
that much fun? I sure thought I did. I was so happy to be back on the road
with my rave buddy Forest, crawling around the streets of the industrial
wasteland, looking for the Launch Pad. What a spot!!!! A kind of twilight
zone,  blending the beauty of nature; the stars, the ocean, and the twinkling
lights of Sf, with the belching smoke of a mamoth power plant, "the vast
 blackened runway of the launch Pad, and assorted gargantuan industrial
factories. I felt safe, and among friends, and was dancing from the time
Will-E started spinning. What was that first record he played anyway? God it
was rich, textured, and beautiful! Ethan just kicked it! Straight-ahead dance
your dance off music; that could of  knock you back like a stiff drink of
tequila.  Thanks to Bryce too, you guys wer just great!!! I'm gonna work hard
this week and hope to see you all "In The Light."  Robertj---Monterey

From sfraves-owner  Mon May 23 13:50:15 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA00852; Mon, 23 May 94 13:50:15 PDT
Received: from uclink2.berkeley.edu by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)

Received: by uclink2.berkeley.edu (8.6.8/1.33(web))
	id NAA29160; Mon, 23 May 1994 13:50:31 -0700
Date: Mon, 23 May 1994 13:50:30 -0700 (PDT)
From: Starchild <rrose@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Spundae (Party Review)
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9405231324.A26111-0100000@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


This took place Sunday night, May 22, at 55 Natoma.  My friend and I got 
there around 1am.  Neither one of us had valid IDs and it was 21 & up, but we 
both got in with no problem (that's a good start to any evening).  :)  

It seemed like a good crowd for a weekly party, but then I haven't been 
to Spundae's before, or if I have it's been so long I've forgotten.  
Probably 2-300 people, which is a lot more than were at Lift on a 
Thursday, the last time I was at the space a couple weeks ago.

I'll start with the negatives:  Most of the people there seemed more into 
style than positivity.  (Although on the bright side, there was a lot of 
skin and mouth-watering bodies on display!)  I didn't encounter any 
stuffed animals, goofy outfits or toys, and there weren't a lot of smiles.  
A couple guys got into a minor scuffle/verbal exchange in the hallway.  There
wasn't really an ambient space, although there were two separate high-energy 
dance areas.  And they were charging $.50 for water at the bar, although 
we got around that by picking up discarded cups and bringing them back 
for "refills", which were free.

Now the positives:  Yippetty-yay!  I had fun!  I would like to thank 
Carlos, Henrik, and Markie Mark, who were the three DJs whose sets I 
enjoyed enough to make it a point to find out who was spinning.  I'm not 
a music techie, but Markie's entire set was *amazing* :)  One track he 
played that I'd heard before called "What Is House Music?" that I 
especially like, was either a mix I hadn't heard or a helluva job 
scratching, it sounded totally preprogrammed like part of the record, but 
it looked like he was doing it himself... wow.  I appreciated Mike of 
Communion, who showed me some of his cool artwork, and also had copies of 
Martin's excellent FEEL newsletter on hand (check out the Signs of Inner 
Peace symptoms).  Mostly Spundae's was hot, sweaty, and full of energy.  
Reminded me of Geoff's and JSL's review of that Wicked party in the 
bassment of 1015 Folsom.  By the time we left, my legs were rubber.  
Guess we had to get our sorry asses home before the beats stopped 
kicking... ;)  I also found some X for $20.  I haven't taken it yet, so 
of course it could be bunk, but my intuition sez no.  My advice is, it's 
still around, don't pay more than $20 a hit.  Also, a big hug & smile out 
to Kirk, the hippie-lookin' dude who gave us some good vibz & a hug 
apiece on his way out.

Th-th-th-that's all folks!  8)-

                           *** Starchild ***

Wow! What a party.

Many, many thanks to all of *you* who came out and helped generate the
thick, thick vibe, load the gear, dance, smile and help cover our costs.
Really, really appreciate it! 

Beautiful night: Clear skies, Oakland twinkling across the bay, steam from
the huge smoke stack surreal through the night, 3/4 moon slowly setting
behind the djs.....

Great music all night. Meme is really coming on strong; excellent,
excellent set. Really gonna miss Will-E and Phil: great guys, loads of
positive energy and Will-E is a hell of a dj :) I had loads of fun on the
decks despite a cranky generator; won't make that mistake again. Buck was
excellent as well, took him a little while to settle down but once he got
there he cranked. Probably see more of him in the future, he seemed to like
what we're about. Lee was killer as usual and his friend Gary gave us taste
of the LA sound which was an interesting change of pace too; real different
style than we're used to up here.

Nice to meet some of our more far flung sfr family, too  :)
Really one of the more positive expereinces I've had in a while.
Thanks again, couldn't have done it without you!

love always
ethan

Yes, Donald Glaude used to go by the DJ name 'Dominator' but in the last
year or so he's been just plain Donald which is fine by us.  He's the
best known 'underground' DJ in Seattle, and has played some elsewhere as
well.  To me, Donald is like the West Coast's answer to Derrick Carter,
as Luke mentioned he goes for the faster/harder "Detroit" techno sound
which still has that housey flavor to it (which is why Volume & Tension
is right up his alley, and yes I *did* play it yesterday at Ameba as my
final track in fact -- but it took my whole set to get the BPMs up to
that level :)

One of the better events I've been to recently was up in Seattle where
Donald had the clean-up position (4th in the order for you non-baseball
fans!) of an excellent Barry Weaver-Ernie Munson-Dub Tribe-Donald lineup.
You know how Carlos gets animated when he's spinning?  Donald is sort of
like that except he gets *pumped*, and he was pumped that morning!

Hi all, Phil and I are leaving Friday morning to go back to New York 
so the last party we hope to make is the FMR.  Anybody know when it is?

re: launch pad
Thanks to everyone for an amazing party.  You all have a wonderful scene
going here and I am very jealous and not looking forward to returning to 
the east coast.  Within the next few months you can be sure that we will
be thinking about moving here in the near future.  

It was great to meet a bunch of you finally.  What a party!  Wicked vibe,
space, sound system, everything was just right... except that I was way
tired.  Went to Test II the night before and stayed until the very end
helping pack the sound system away.  I haven't had this much fun since I
lived in England!  I'm certainly going to miss this community.  Special
big hugs to Bryce & Ethan for welcoming Phil and I, Tamara for coming all the 
way up from LA, and to everyone (especially Laura & Brian) for making us feel 
at home.  :)

Robertj--Monterey wrote:
> I felt safe, and among friends, and was dancing from the time
> Will-E started spinning. What was that first record he played anyway? 

I love opening with that track, a number of people kept asking me what that was.
It was "Sunrise on Epsilon" by Aurasphere (which I think is a pseudonym 
for Damon Wild or Bio-Dreams) on EX-25 (EXperimental records out of New York).
Every track on there is thick and beautiful.  This was a special anniversary 
double-pack that was pretty limited... I think only 500 were pressed.  This is 
a consistently good label to keep an eye on.

There are some great parties happening this weekend it seems and I'm a bit sad
that we're going to have to miss it.  We found a really cheap flight that only
flies once a week and we already have round trip tickets.  So you all have to 
have lots of fun for us!  

                      ___

(_/__/  /  (__ (__  ___/

not to "me too" but my sister used to frequent the record store Donald
worked at (in Tacoma) so i've listened to a couple of his tapes and
i've seen him spin a few times.  an excellent DJ.  probably one of the
best people at working a crowd i've ever seen --- and he seems very
aware of how the crowd is reacting.  many of the local DJs who get the
crowd off seem to do it without really looking at the crowd, they just
run through their stack 'o slabs 'o vinyl and either the crowd gets it
or not.  Donald adjusts what he is doing to how the crowd is reacting,
and can sense that energy flow that's so important.

if he was down here, he'd be a rave-household name.

for those Seattle scenesters, he went by DJ Dominator back in, oh,
around 1990...

Will-E mentioned Experimental and I also want to put in a positive note
for that label as well; I used their EX-27 release Shapechanger/Crystal
Dreams double pack yesterday @ameba; excellent stuff.  The track I played
was Analytic Groove; it says, "All tracks produced, written, arranged and
mixed by Cari Lekebusch.  Recorded in Sweden at Flow Motion Sound Studios,
Stockholm."  So there's some Swedish trance-techno for ya :)  One of the
things I find most intriguing about all this is the trans-national aspect
of recording now.  Detroit musicians go to the UK or Germany.  Swedes
get their stuff released in New York.  Ken Ishii from Japan gets his stuff
released from the UK.  Pete Namlook from Germany and Mixmaster Morris from
the UK collaborate.  A lot of this goes back to the UK-Jamaican reggae
connections that spawned the likes of the work that Adrian Sherwood has
produced for so many years at On-U, combining talent from all over.  
I think the Net may yet become a channel for further such collaborations.

phred

From: anthrax@uclink.berkeley.edu (Ann Elizabeth Loraine)
Message-Id: <199405232140.OAA19995@uclink.berkeley.edu>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Launchpad
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


Launchpad-

        We (Lain, Tim, Glen & me)  got to Launchpad around midnight or
so while Will E. from New York was spinning.  The evening
was PERFECT- no wind, not very cold, but certainly not too warm either. 
The terrain, of course, is about as much like a blast site as I've ever
seen..no green stuff hardly at all, just water, gravel and a huge
asphalt landing strip type place.  When we arrived, there were maybe 100
or so people there with lots of people dancing.

        Then someone got a large fire going, which always makes
outdoor raves feel more communal, more like an urban festival.
The darkness was very beautiful, with the close-to-it  full moon shining
overhead behind the dj.  For future reference:  you know those wooden
platforms you can find outside stores, and so on...I don't know what
they're called, but they make decent fire wood.  Does anyone know
whether those are re-used?  

        Ethan went on after Will E., and his set was EXACTLY the dance,
then trance music I wanted to hear, although it was a drag  the sound went
 down  a couple of times, mostly because (I guess..) the generator was too weak
to power the sound system AND the nifty laser Sean brought.  People
liked the laser and black lights, and also the glow-in-the dark 
string in front of the turntables..a couple of kids  were twirling it around and
dancing with it.   After Ethan, Buck went on, but I didn't hear much of
his set as I wanted to catch up with some old friends.  When we got
back, someone had turned on the BRIGHT BRIGHT lights in the parking lot
of a nearby warehouse, which was kind of bummer.  It was just too harsh,
I thought.  

        When the sun came up, people who had been kind of standing
around talking suddenly got energized and started to dance...it was neat
to see 20+ people spread out over the tarmac all dancing the
morning together.  Also, a few new people arrived who were itchin' to
boogey and you know how infectious that is!

        More about the spot itself:

There's a power plant nearby there...it's most prominent feature
is an ENORMOUS smoke-stack that contributed a continuous column of
vapors to the atmosphere all night long and into the day.  Does anyone
know what that stuff is?  (steam, maybe?) It was separated from
Launchpad by an inlet of water..the only way to get to the power plant
was to go along a narrow  path that crossed over the outlet for a
drainage pipe. But of course, there was a fence there:  a single unit of
six-foot-high chainlink fence to prevent anyone from getting on to the
land where the power plant was.  

        I noticed this as we came in: Not far up from the Launchpad
site, there was a man (?)  sitting next
to his tent staring into a fire.  I suppose he lived there because he
looked very much settled in for the night, almost cosy.  It occurred to
me that if I were going to get kicked out of my apartment for whatever
reason, I would try to live like him...i'd use my last dollars for a
tent and camping gear and try to find a peaceful place.  But things
weren't especially peaceful Saturday night!  Anyway, I hope he came over
to check things out.  Does anyone know if he did?

        All in all, a good party!

-anthrax

They are called "pallets" and I've posted here before that you can
pick them up for free at a post office warehouse in SF.  Unfortunately,
at this moment I can't recall exactly where that office was . . . I
remember how to get there:  Go East on Army to 3rd, turn right on 3rd, 
the 2nd Left should be where the post office is.  It's really just a big 
warehouse.  By the side door there was a big stack of these things with a 
sign on them that says something like "free wood." If anyone's got a 
pick up truck they should swing by there.

If anyone happened to save my original message from March?? with the 
exact street address and directions it would be cool if you mailed it
back to me.  Thanks.

Laura

doesn't imply that the music is necessarilly hip hoppy...but in this case
lots a backspins, hard beat motivated transitions as opposed to long mixes,
very progressive/ravey housy, lots of hooks, and vocal gadgets...I'd be
curious to hear Lee describe it as I'm sure he could do a better job than
I'm doing...

Subject: Rave report
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Weekend rave report
===================

It was yet another sleepless weekend for me.   I decided to take in the Friday
Dakota event at 1015 Folsom which turned out to be pretty good,  although things
ended a bit early for me (3:30am).

Dakota had almost all of the 1015 facilities opened,  including the new upstairs
outside area which they did up very nicely with gas umbrella heaters,  tables
and comfortable chairs.   It provided excellent chill-out opportunities so one
can cool down from dancing.   In the front room was mostly funkey acid jazz
(but I wouldn't really call it that).    Jeno was spinning in the basement,
which explained by everyone left the main room at about 2:30 am.   Even down
in the basement was much much cooler than the last Wicked event held there.

Upstairs in the bar area,  Craig Larson had a video phone hooked up to a rave
event in Texas,   but they had problems with the sound,   so all we got to 
see was the pictures (very jerkey,  and low resolution).   They couldn't get
the ATT phone's video to patch directly to the wide screen monitor.

In the main room,  the graphics was reallky great.   As well as some insane 
house music that kept me on the dance floor most of the time.

At about 4:30,  we head over to the Alley Cat (1190 Folsom),  to do more
dancing.    First time I spent time in there,  when there were a lot of people.
Really great crowd,   although much smaller than 1015 Folsom (Space is also
smaller).   Front area is a restaurant,  and a bar,  serving food,  and the
dancing is in the back room (Rather small) surrounded by mirrors.

The DJ clan was the SPAZ group,  really pumped out the tunes,  and kept up
the beat all night long.

Finally,  around 6:30 We head back to Mill valley and went hiking for most
of the beautiful day.    Couldn't manage to get any sleep,  but in the life
of a dedicated raver,   sleep is something I do when I want to dream or
something.



Launch pad II
-------------

Saturday evening,   I get on the net a while,   looking to find the location
for Launch Pad II,  an SFRaves event which I really try hard to attend.
It was advertized via private Email to be an outside event,   and we didn't
learn of its location until about 9:30.    We learned it was to be in one
of the usual outside locations which I'll decline to mention because so far,
it's a good bust-proof site,   but now made even better when we learned that
it was paved over with asphalt which made dancing a lot easier.   Another
advantage of ths site,  is that you cannot hear the music from the street
(or any other occupied spot).    Plenty of parking available also provided
the spread of cars in such a way as to not attract police attention.

A large yard with huge unoccupied buildings shielded us from outside observers,
so not even the fire could be noticed unless one were to fly directly over.

The tide was out,  so from the Bay side,   boats couldn't come any closer
than 1000 feet.

Not far away,  a fire was burning and provided an ideal chill space (or 
warm up space).   DJ's were the SFRaves crew,   Ethan, Tamara, Lee,  and
Buck plus a few others I didn't know from before.    Dispite the fact that
these aren' the "big name" DJ's,  I like them better because they experiment
more with the music and come up with some brilliant and varied sets,  not
just sticking to the usual 123 BPM stuff.

Dispite this being my 2nd sleepless night,   I had an amazing amount of energy
digging the really trancey set of tunes.   With the site location not being
in the prettiest place,  the smoke stack against the sky produced a rather
eerie visual stimulation,  enhanced by a tune that Lee started off with
the sound of race cars and airplanes zooming around,  had me looking for
"things coming out of the sky".   Lee pumped out some incredible spacey
acid trance I've heard in a long time.    The weather was very cool, clear
and perfect for dancing. 

The Sunrise (3rd one since I slept last),   was awsome...  as San Francisco
started to wake up on a Sunday morning.   Things eerily quiet at our site,
nobody around at 6:30 in the morning,  but few people remaining,  and fewer
people dancing.    Most huddled by the fire,   or crashed out on pads
layed down on the asphalt parking lot which was empty of most cars.

Ethan went on the turn tables at 7:00 am and played some of his newer
and stranger trancey stuff,  and switched off with one of his friends
as we we started picking up the trash and shutting down.

I eventually leave around 7:30,   and later on,  hung out at the End Up
or Light-n-up after-party for most of the afternoon.   Still not ready
or capable of sleeping yet.    Finally got back home around 4 or 5,  and
after a refreshing shower,   finally crashed....   Ahhh!  What a GREAT!
weekend...

--- over and out ---

CC

> I'd be interested to hear what you mean by the "LA sound" - if there is one,
> which if there is I guess I just didn't notice, it's nothing very different.
> But what did this guy play?

I thought it was definitely a British sound.  Hard progressive house I'd call
it.  Whenver I looked over I saw familiar British labels like Stress.
It started out kinda dark & hard but not too fast and then got a lot lighter
and happier.  It reminded me mostly of the more mainstream (by their standards
certainly not our standards  :) prog house that gets played in the bigger
clubs. I don't know how this relates to the LA scene since I've never been.

just my $.02

will

	When I first started spinning, my friends wanted to call me "DJ
Debbie."  It was funny because they tried to picture the reaction by
the crowd when they saw me spinning.  This is about what they
pictured happening:

Newbie: Who is that spinning right now?
Oldbie: That's DJ Debbie.
Newbie: DJ Debbie?  Are you sure?
Oldbie: Yeah, it is.
Newbie: But, he's not female.
Oldbie: No...
Newbie: Is he gay?
Oldbie: No...
Newbie: Then why does he call himself DJ Debbie?
Oldbie: I dunno, he just does, probably so people like you will get
their interest piqued and ask lots of questions about him...

It was pretty funny, maybe you just had to be there at the time...

>>> Bob Ramstad <rramstad@us.oracle.com>  5/23/94, 04:30pm >>>

male
DJ couldn't use a feminine name, or vice versa...

How-de-do,

i reference to Geoff's coment on wickeds being one of the last places
where there is a large visiable gay element: that is part of the reason
that i go to wickeds.  the group i go with tends to be very well mixed
up and when people are relaxed enough to enjoy themselves in whatever
way they feel things go off and great times are had.  Also IMHO a strong
gay mix in a party kills the pick-up scene, you actually might have to
get to know someone b4 crusing them, imagine that?!?

in a semi related story. The mayday wicked (beltan) i took a friend of a
very dear friend of mine for to the party.  She was suposed to take him
but needed to do other things that night.  this was his first party and
EXperiance of a wicked.  several hours into it he comes up to me with a
smile and a bewildered look: "a girl just asked me if i was gay straight
or bi?..............." wickeds are on of the few places where none of
that really matters so i told him "here it doesn't matter".  he bounced
away happy.

that is freedom

peace

CHE

could have read that post.  Of course nothing will probably come of it but I
do know that it is not impossiable. All clubs in San Fransisco have a very
hard time with the age thing (I hate the age thing too and I'm over) and
Spundae has had real problems with this as well as drugs.  I know it goes
with being a club... but Spundae is often visited by the police and have many
times arrested people in the parking lot while they were doing somthing in a
cor or whatever.  I know I have been searched before.  For some reason the
cops "like" Spundae.  All it would take is for one of the nice officers who
often check out the inside to notice yo lookin young and ask for your ID.

advertise.  Why do you need to broadcast?  Besides $20 is not a "good" price

To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU

Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I just wanted to add my thanks to the Launch Pad crew for a
really fine party.  Janie & I were still recuperating from a
4 day hiking trip so we couldn't stay much after Ethan's set,
but we had a great time.  The Djing was stellar (Meme, Will-E,
Ethan).  Will-E's set was a special treat, as I have never heard
him before - hope you visit us again :-) 

It was fun seeing lot's of SFRavers, as well as lot's of new,
young, unfamilar, friendly faces.  Many people were sharing
candy, toys, etc.  Lately, I've been getting a sense at many
parties that there has been an influx of fresh warm vibes into
the house/rave scene.  Even though the fad aspect of raving may
be on the wane, I'm beginning to see that we have a culture here 
that people want to perpeturate - a simple one of trust and the
sharing of good feelings towards one another.  If humanity is
ever going to spiritually evolve, this is how it might begin.

BTW, was I the only person who notice the crop circle patterns
in the gravel right next to the site?  Does anyone know the *real*
reason why that big slab of asphalt, the "Launch Pad" was put
there?  It would be pretty cool if the first encounter aliens
have with humans happens at one of our renegade raves.  I hope
the DJs have some special records set aside for such an occasion.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com

this is a forward as a favor to someone with 'puter problems.  offical

send mail to starchild not me thanx :) 

P.S. i brought a 10 lb bag of oranges to the last wicked. didn't it past
the door, although markie had mailed me with an okay.  The people who
own the space and therefore get the bar don't want anything that might
detract from the bar.  they have the ultimate say.  but on a lighter
note the door held the bag and it was quickly devoured by those of us
that stayed allnight.

P.P.S.: it is not that big a deal :).> 
> 
> On Wed, 4 May 1994 Che wrote, in part:
>  
> > also in a message to the people involved with wicked.  last time we
> > brought some fruit.  i would like to bring enough to give away to
> > people.  is there a problem here, i dont want to show up with a box of
> > oranges or the like to be unable to bring then in.  
> > 
> > thanks
> > looking forward to it
> > Cya
> > CHE
> 
> Che,
> 
>     I hear you loud and clear about the oranges.  My own feeling is that 
> these situations call for discrimination on the part of partygoers.  If 
> you go to a party and are told at the door that you cannot bring in 
> oranges, then tell them you will not be coming back, and you will tell 
> your friends, including the 250-300 or so people on sfraves about your 
> experience, urging them to boycott that event in the future as well.
>     Make sure the person(s) you tell this to are actually in a position 
> to make a decision on this issue (or if they are not, ask to speak to 
> someone who is, or get them to agree to pass on your comments.)  
>     I understand that if you go somewhere expecting to have a good time, 
> it may be difficult to just walk away over a seemingly small matter like 
> oranges, especially if you've come a long way or gone to much trouble to 
> attend, and there don't seem to be ready alternative parties to check 
> out.  I admit to not always holding a high moral standard myself in such 
> cases.  However, in all likelihood if promoters refuse something as 
> genuine and loving as an attempt to bring fresh fruit into their party 
> with the intent of giving it away, chances are it's not such a great 
> party anyway, and there will be further disappointments once you're 
> inside, such as bad vibe.
>     How do I reach the conclusion the vibe will probably be poor?  Well, 
> consider that at the average party, a good number of the attendees are 
> friends of the promoters.  I don't have statistics, but it only stands to 
> figure.  These are people that get in free, often (most parties have a 
> fairly large guest list), or are encouraged by the promoters to attend, 
> since they know them personally.  I know if I were promoting (which I 
> will be this July, hopefully), I would tell all the ravers I know about 
> it, and encourage them to come.  This being the case, what kind of friends 
> do you think someone who won't allow a person to bring in fresh fruit to 
> a rave is going to have?  Probably not terribly positive or friendly people.
>     On the other hand, if the no-fruit decision is made by the people 
> running the space where the rave is happening, rather than by the 
> promoters of the event, then the promoters are not necessarily to blame, 
> and the vibe may not be affected too much.  In this case, it is the *space* 
> which is deserving of a boycott, and you should tell the people running it 
> that you aren't coming back, that you will tell your friends about your bad
> experience, and so forth.
>     As a further note, if promoters of a party seem to *consistantly*
> choose spaces whose owners/operators have poor attitudes for their parties, 
> this is a good indication that the promoters' hearts are not in the right 
> place, or they would stop doing business with these people.> 
>     In my view, the following is a partial list of things which should be 
> considered unacceptable actions on the part of rave promoters or club 
> managers.  I'm sure many of you will think of things I left off.
> 
> (1)  Charging for water.  If there is free water available, such as from a 
> fountain, I consider this merely reprehensible and not unacceptable.  I am
> talking here about water that comes in cups from the bar.  I can see 
> selling bottled water, which costs money, but tap water is virtually free and
> plastic cups are a dime a dozen.  Even if the water for sale is Evian, 
> there should be free water available.  This is a safety issue -- people 
> have died from being overheated and dehydrated at raves.
> 
> (2)  Promoters who advertise that an event is free or discounted to those 
> who arrive before a certain time, or free to those who bring a canned 
> food donation or similar matter, and then fail to honor their word.  A 
> person I know showed up to a Wally World rave at the Haze Theater at 
> 930pm, waited in line outside until after 11pm, and then was told at the 
> door she would have to pay full price because it was after 11.  That's 
> b.s!!!  The main reason people are kept waiting outside, as far as I can 
> figure, is so the line will attract others who see it and figure 
> something good must be going on inside.  If people are kept outside 
> because the space/equipment/people aren't ready, this indicates poor 
> planning and they should start getting ready earlier next time.
> 
> (3)  Parties that cost too much.  I know this is subjective, but 
> basically if they're charging more than $10 at the door, there better be 
> a *&^(* good light show!  I don't mind paying $20 for a $20 party, but I 
> do mind paying $20 if I can't see how they spent the money.  In my book, 
> a $20 cover means a live act or acts, inflatable bouncy castles, virtual 
> reality, special guest speakers or panelists like Tim Leary, rides, 
> interactive computer or hi-tech stuff to play with, free fruit, candy, 
> drugs, that sort of thing.  Also, there's no reason promoters can't list 
> the cover charge on their flyers.  If they're not willing to tell you the 
> price in advance, chances are it's too much.
> 
> (4)  People who hire assholes for security.  Searching people for booze and
> weapons is an understandable, if unfortunate staple at large parties that 
> we basically have to live with.  The occasional jerk is also to be expected. 
> Systematic/endemic rudeness and bad vibes from security personnel however, we 
> do not.  Unpleasantness from security has decreased my enjoyment of too many
> raves.  
> 
> (5)  Promoters who don't pay people they've promised to pay.  Maybe it 
> hurts to hand Jeno or Carlos $200 when you lost money on a party, but if 
> that's what you agreed to, so be it.  Hire a less expensive DJ next time.
> Of course it's generally the less well known talent that gets stiffed, 
> but either way the principle is the same.
> 
> (6)  Refusing to let people bring personal possessions into a party which 
> do not pose a safety hazard or major disruption.  Oranges, water, candy, 
> literature/flyers, and many other things fall into this category.
> 
> (7)  Failing to deliver the goods.  Again, this is subjective, and covers a 
> lot of ground, but I can think of a couple clear cases.  One case would be a 
> party that promises to go all night, for example, when the organizers 
> know they only have a permit to go until 3am.  Another would be if a 
> paid-attendance party is busted early and there is no serious attempt 
> made to either reimburse people, move to a new location, or throw a 
> similar party later with those who paid for the first event getting in free.
> 
>      I really didn't enjoy writing this, because I hate focusing on 
> negativity in the scene, but hopefully some of you will find the message 
> useful.  In the end, the way we will get more better events is by 
> attending the good ones and not attending the poor ones.  This 
> concentrates our positive energy.  If our positive energy hadn't been so 
> diluted, the scene probably never would have gone downhill in the first 
> place.  Fortunately there is a lot of untapped positive energy and love 
> out there.  Our burden of love is to provide a focus.
> 
> May your days be filled with light,
>                                          *** Starchild ***
> 
> 
>

man, I love this thread . . . 

The best part of Wickeds is the Music.

The second best is being gay, being weird, and fitting right in.  Breeeeep!

The third thing is not being sized up by everyone person in turn, the long
stare, the body wash from hairdo to crotch size, and then a yes/no this brain
is receptive to you look.  I went to Pleasuredome sunday night.  The music
was great. The vibe was way better than expected.   But I was by myself, and
I felt ice in the air.  After finding the faith with you guys, I can't handle
that other attitude any longer.

Thanks for being my friends.

jivala

>From: mfogarty@netcom.com (Michael Fogarty)
Subject: SURVIVAL RESEARCH LABS: Announcement

          A CALCULATED FORECAST OF ULTIMATE DOOM:
             Sickening Episodes of Widespread
               Devastation Accompanied by 
           Sensations of Pleasurable Excitement

Survival Research Laboratories' first full-scale San Francisco 
performance in five years will take place on Saturday, May 28th
1994.  Further information may be obtained by:

1.  Checking SRL.ORG from 0000-0600 PST by anonymous FTP.
2.  Calling SRL at (415) 641-8065 for recorded information.
3.  Calling (415) 241-1568 for site location _on the day
      of the show_.

Tickets will become available on May 24th at these San 
Francisco establishments:
	
	Naked Eye
	Leather Tongue
	Dark Carnival 

As this is an indoor performance, attendance will be limited
to 3,000 people.  A sellout is anticipated.


>From SRL's FTP site: (JPG on CyberDen's anon ftp in the industrial pictures
area)


	SRL will be staging a major performance in San Francisco on May 28th.
The location is tremendous (see jpg image file showing site). We are accepting
donations of just about any kind of stuff in large quantities that could be
perceived as having any connection with the apocalypse, or more precisely, that
point of intersection where the survival instinct nuzzles up to the death wish
(this is the general theme of the show, watch this site for a convoluted
phrasing that will be more specific). We are especially interested in unusual
signage or large pre-assembled props. We also need a doomsday clock, preferably
digital, for the countdown.
	We are also open to any borrowing from individuals or companies with
access to high-energy physics devices, heavy equipment, military weapon
systems, process equipment, industrial robots, and any and all electronic,
mechanical, hydraulic, components. 
	Further, we are accepting volunteer assistance of skilled and
non-skilled types. Almost any kind or level of skill is applicable. No careless
psychotics please. E-mail to mark@SRL.ORG or call 415-641-8065. Thank you, and
remember, your kind assistance can help make this an apocalypse to remember.

	MAY: so-called after the Roman goddess MAIA.
	  This is the month of morris dancers and
	    Maypoles, a month to CELEBRATE life
	     and FREEDOM, especially dedicated
	      to DANCING away your wintery
	      worries. This is the month of
	      LIFE! If you were born in the
	       first part of May, you're a
	       TAUREAN which means you're
	      likely to be reliable, depend-
	        able and determined. This
	      year, May 22nd marks the divi-
	      sion between Taurus and GEMINI
	       those born under the sign of
	   the twins are cheeky, gifted people
	 like Geminian GEORGE BEST. This sign is
	 also associated with good communicators
	including MORRISEY and BOB DYLAN.

Lee Fogel writes:
 > It was fun seeing lot's of SFRavers, as well as lot's of new,
 > young, unfamilar, friendly faces.  Many people were sharing
 > candy, toys, etc.  Lately, I've been getting a sense at many
 > parties that there has been an influx of fresh warm vibes into
 > the house/rave scene.  Even though the fad aspect of raving may
 > be on the wane, I'm beginning to see that we have a culture here 
 > that people want to perpeturate - a simple one of trust and the
 > sharing of good feelings towards one another.  If humanity is
 > ever going to spiritually evolve, this is how it might begin.

Told ya so! I don't know how many times people have said "rave is
dead", but as long as people want to throw and attend underground
parties, it is being kept alive. There is a very healthy underground
scene going on in SF, and even I am surprised at how good it's gotten.
The quality and variety of the DJing is outstanding. And people are
coming together and donating their efforts to make free and
inexpensive parties happen. Wow!

And speaking of good feelings, I want to suggest stopping by Ameba
when they have something going on or just about anytime. Every time I
stop by there, I just get the best vibes. And I've never written
anything about it, but Allen and Mark and the rest should get some
recognition as going above and beyond to bring people together.

To all those people making it happen, thanks. I know it's worth it to
you, and I want you to know you're part of a really good thing.

:)

Sean

From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)

Subject: IN*THE*LIGHT - final announcement
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Tue, 24 May 94 16:42:23 PDT
Cc: sfraves-planners@techno.Stanford.EDU
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I want to thank everyone who has been helping me with preparations for
In The Light.  To many of you who have offered your assistance, I 
apologize for not getting back to some of you.  We have an equipment
loading crew in place, and I'm pretty much out of flyers, but there are
still a few things that people can do.

We will have an information table.  If anyone was any interesting
literature laying around, old USENET posts, drug info sheets, artwork,
poetry, anything positve or educational, please xerox and bring a stack.  
If there is anything that makes SFRavers unique, it is our access to
information.  It makes sense that we should foster communication at our
parties (especially ones that take place in the light and amongst the
public).  It would of course be great if someone could duplicate the
sfraves info sheet that we've handed out in the past, or even the sfraves
or alt.rave FAQ.

Whoever has it, please bring the SFR banner.

Stuff to share: fruit, drinks, candy, toys, bubbles, flowers, condoms...

Garbage bags: And any help picking up garbage will be greatly appreciated.

Duct Tape - (P-ter & M, do you guys have any left from last time?).

Water jugs or plant sprinkler: There's a water fountain from which  we'd
like to take water to sprinkle  over the dance area to cut down on dust.  
Can someone come early to do this?  

We'll also need some people to come early and move benches back from the 
stage to create a U-shaped dance area.

I'm still accepting donations to offset the costs for all this (about $600).
Although I'm not permitted to solicit at the event, feel free to give what
you can to myself, Janie or Bryce.  I'll be wearing an aqua baseball hat 
with a question mark on the back and can be seen at times hunched over
the DAT machine.   Please come and say "hello", or something equivalent.

The most important thing is that you bring your positive vibes,
dancing shoes, and friends.  Divert all energy from your shields and set 
your Luv Phasers to maximum.  If there is ever going to be a party that 
you'd want to bring your parents or dubious SO to, this is probably it.  

The generator is being delivered to the site at 11:30am.  So yes, we fully
intend to get the music started by noon.  There's plenty of seating, and
shade (and bathrooms, food vendors & museums) - so come early, hang out, 
mix it up, and have fun!
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com
____________________________________________________________________________

today's SFR South Bay Lunch ...

When: Wednesday  
Time: 12:15ish to 1:15 or so ... 
Where: Greer Park, Palo Alto

Directions:

* From 101 (South or North) take the Oregon Expressway Exit
  Northbound: Past San Antonio Road 
  Southbound: Past University Avenue 

* Left at the first signal - W. Bayshore
  (it's a frontage road that takes you south again)

* Follow this road approx. 1/4 mile (pass apartment complexes on right)
  
* You will see the park on your right hand side. Turn into the first 
  driveway on your right.

* We'll meet on the grassy knoll , behind the round baseball fence.
  Next to the restrooms and ball courts.

From: paul.geronca@support.com

     id A3172wk Wed, 25 May 94 09:42:11 -0700
Message-Id: <9405250942.A3172wk@support.com>
Organization: Los Angeles Valley College BBS (818)985-7150
X-Mailer: TBBS/PIMP v2.54
Date: Wed, 25 May 94 09:42:11 -0700
Subject: U HAVE NO PRIVACY
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


NSA can crack PGP

A lot of people think that PGP encryption is unbreakable and that the
NSA/FBI/CIA/MJ12 cannot read their mail. This is wrong, and it can be a deadly
mistake. In Idaho, a left-wing activist by the name of Craig Steingold was
arrested  _one day_ before he and others went to stage a protest at government
buildings; the police had a copy of a message sent by Steingold to another
activist, a message which had been encrypted with PGP and sent through E-mail.

Since version 2.1, PGP ("Pretty Good Privacy") has been rigged to
allow the NSA to easily break encoded messages. Early in 1992, the author,
Paul Zimmerman, was arrested by Government agents. He was told that he
would be set up for trafficking narcotics unless he complied. The Government
agency's demands were simple: He was to put a virtually undetectable
trapdoor, designed by the NSA, into all future releases of PGP, and to
tell no-one.

After reading this, you may think of using an earlier version of
PGP. However, any version found on an FTP site or bulletin board has been
doctored. Only use copies acquired before 1992, and do NOT use a recent
compiler to compile them. Virtually ALL popular compilers have been
modified to insert the trapdoor (consisting of a few trivial changes) into
any version of PGP prior to 2.1. Members of the boards of Novell, Microsoft,
Borland, AT&T and other companies were persuaded into giving the order for the
modification (each ot these companies' boards contains at least one Trilateral
Commission member or Bilderberg Committee attendant).

It took the agency more to modify GNU C, but eventually they did it.
The Free Software Foundation was threatened with "an IRS investigation",
in other words, with being forced out of business, unless they complied. The
result is that all versions of GCC on the FTP sites and all versions above
2.2.3, contain code to modify PGP and insert the trapdoor. Recompiling GCC
with itself will not help; the code is inserted by the compiler into
itself. Recompiling with another compiler may help, as long as the compiler
is older than from 1992.

Distribute and reproduce this information freely. Do not alter it.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------

Due to the double-blind, any mail replies to this message will be anonymized,
and an anonymous id will be allocated automatically. You have been warned.
Please report any problems, inappropriate use etc. to admin@anon.penet.fi.

From sfraves-owner  Wed May 25 11:09:28 1994

Date: Wed, 25 May 94 11:17:26 -0700
