Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I have passed this message onto some folks who can verify or debunk this
   drivel.  While it is possible that it is true, please be advised that
   this is almost certainly bullshit:
 - anyone who's ever met Richard Stallman (head of the FSF and the original
   author of gcc) would know better than to suggest that he could be
   coerced by anyone, much less the CIA or IRS.  The FSF makes far too
   little money to get into any serious trouble with the Feds.  It also has
   excellent accounting and management support.  Even if there was an error
   somewhere, the IRS would have a lot of fun retrieving that $52.16 in
   back taxes :-)

 - I have not received any confirmation of the Steingold story.  What
   probably happened is that he did something stupid, like used a computer
   that wasn't really secure.

 - the number of people who peruse the software packages in question in
   their work, research, maintenance, and porting efforts is astronomical.
   While possible, it seems unlikely that a hole would pass entirely
   undetected.

 - The story conatins factual errors.  For example, the author of PGP is
   PHIL Zimmermand, not "paul".  

At any rate, I'm awaiting official debunking, but I don't think people
   should worry: verified accounts have already reported several cases
   where PGP was unable to be broken in real law enforcement cases.
   (curious? go to the library and backscan the NYTimes and Wall St Journal
   for related material - I think the articles were published in the last
   month or two)

I'll post more info as I get it.

Enjoy,
-A.Sah'94                     ...Adam Sah...asah@cs.Berkeley.EDU...
                     "Grad school: it's not just an adventure; it's a job."

mistake. In Idaho, a left-wing activist by the name of Craig Steingold was

From sfraves-owner  Wed May 25 11:33:20 1994

Message-Id: <199405251833.LAA24999@soda.berkeley.edu>
From: laura@soda.berkeley.edu (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Wed, 25 May 1994 11:33:21 -0700
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: Irresponsible use of FMR site
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I have to say I was dismayed to learn it was "there" too.

Why?  Well, that site has been good to us and we've been good to it, having 
small parties (i.e. Liquid Air, Your Sisters' House) there every so often.  
Now, if history is any indication, there is a danger that we will lose the 
use of that site for throwing effective small parties.

Look at the trend:

FMR held at Palo Alto Wetlands -- Brian says there is now a ranger stationed 
	down there to make sure ravers never return.

Many parties, including many FMRS, held at Berkeley Marina -- cop cars now 
	sit there on full moon nights to prevent parties from being thrown.

FMR (and others) at Bonny Doon -- Santa Cruz police and local neighbors have 
	had enough so it's not safe to try a party there anymore.

Albany landfill -- location busted after 2nd FMR attempt there.

People who try to throw BIG RENEGADES are in a way doing the community a 
disservice?  Why?  Because it is just TOO DIFFICULT to consistenly hide 
parties the size of the FMRs and the free Basics, therefore the locations 
get busted and then watched so people who want to do smaller renegades with 
different musical focuses have fewer and fewer available spots in which to 
have their parties.

Sure, the FMR is supposed to be this big community gathering vibe fiesta, but 
it seems almost selfish to me that people throwing parties that big can come 
in, use a spot, and then get busted and ruin the spot for the rest of us.

Laura

Well, part of the reason he's not playing is that he has other 
commitments, but it really didn't matter to us that Donald wasn't 
playing.  We felt that we needed to open things up a bit, as Donald has 
played at practically every event here in Seattle.  This leaves room for 
John Howard (IMHO deserves to be heard up here more often), and 
up-and-coming folks such as Rod or Ryan... Things are definitely changing 
up here in Seattle....

At 11:17 AM 05/25/94 -0700, Adam Sah wrote:
>I have passed this message onto some folks who can verify or debunk this
>   drivel.  While it is possible that it is true, please be advised that
>   this is almost certainly bullshit:

Another factoid that bears looking at is the bit about the hacked compilers.
This actually happened a few years ago- a widely used compiler was self
modifying. and would insert code to propigate that way. It would be
possible
to do this for PGP, I suppose, but there are _way_ too many sources for all
compilers to do this to them all. Esp. with the GCC- it would be trivial to
find the hack in the source. My guess is the poster couldn't be bothered to
be more original.

Sean:
> This site is not remote enough and can't
> >withstand the people pressure of a FMR. The FMR people should know
> >this, and shouldn't have used the site.

Ethan:
> Yeah I really tend to agree. It *might* have been able to sustain weekly or
> bi-monthly gatherings in the low hundreds but there's no way the cops will
> tolerate thousands out there...I'm awaiting the reviews with no small
> amount of dread. 

The site wasn't revealed (to me anyway) until after 3am.  I was
asleep at the time, but stopped by on my way to work.  At 6:30am Garth
was finishing his set for maybe 200 -300 people - a bit larger than the
Launch Pad crowd.  The music was a bit louder too (not as clean as 
SoundVision though :) I was barely able to hear it from the street.  
It was a pretty well-behaved scene, but one that I would have to assume
would be noticed as the day progressed.  I left at the beginning of
Mark Farina's set, at around 7:30am.  I did not notice the presence of 
any alien lifeforms while I was there.

According to Geoff, the site location info was delayed to avoid a party
of thousands - so I don't think the FMR folks were being totally 
irresponsible.  Maybe they learned something from the Bonny Doon loss.

love/truth/energy

leg of eel

> From SFRaves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU Wed May 25 10:45 PDT 1994
> Date: Wed, 25 May 94 13:35:11 EDT
> From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
> To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
> Subject: Irresponsible use of FMR site
> 
> That site (we all know where it is) has seen way too much use lately.
> The people that found it can't even use it because now someone is
> doing something there every weekend. It's almost summer and we're
> going to start seeing schedule conflicts and promoters fighting over
> it. And now that the FMR has graced it, it's likely to crash and burn
> just like Bonny Doon. This site is not remote enough and can't
> withstand the people pressure of a FMR. The FMR people should know
> this, and shouldn't have used the site.
> 
> Oh well, maybe I'm wrong. Maybe I'm being naive and everyone will
> cooperate and the cops will look the other way.

Sean, chill out, the FMR used it, but guess what, the crowd that came
_really_ respected the site, there were maybe 300 at most, the cars
were parked neatly and there was a really good, strong, vibe, the best
I've seen in a long time.  Someone stole one of he "residents" fishing
pole but a collection was taken and given to him so that he could buy
another one.  There were plenty of garbage bags and lots of smiles and
dancing people, I'm sure it can be used again as long as people are
descrete.  The location wasn't announced until 3 a.m. to keep the crowd
size down.  The "owner" came arount 8:30 with two police officers in
tow, the "owner" was more of a dick then the police who just sort of
stood there and watched, the "owner" ws pretty pissed and wanted to
know who the equipment belonged to, he said he wanted it impounded,
when he said that Garth and I grabbed all the records and got them out
of there!  There was a stand-off for several minutes while diffeent
people talked to the guy, calmed him down and eventually he let us all
go with the equipment, a close call but well worth it.  There were
several SF high school kids who experienced their first full moon.
They don't get to go when it is way out of the city and this was a real
treat for them.  It was real surreal when the dawn came and we all all
dancing to some verry _deep_ house played by Mark Farina.  All in all a
good party.

> 
> FMR held at Palo Alto Wetlands -- Brian says there is now a ranger stationed 
> 	down there to make sure ravers never return.

This is an urban folk ledgend. I went by there yesterday and ther is no ranger
stationed.

> 
> Many parties, including many FMRS, held at Berkeley Marina -- cop cars now 
> 	sit there on full moon nights to prevent parties from being thrown.

Not just the FMR but _countless_ other parties were thrown there as well.

> 
> FMR (and others) at Bonny Doon -- Santa Cruz police and local neighbors have 
> 	had enough so it's not safe to try a party there anymore.

3000 people and 2000 cars were just too much for the county.  No one wants 
the FMRs to be big, the news of the location spreads like wild fire, 
WICKED released the info at 3.am. by 3;30 every one who stuck it out
knew.  Starting this late and being secretive wa the only way to keep the 
numbers and the people who don't give a fuck away, the result was a very nicely
sized FMR without incident.

> 
> Albany landfill -- location busted after 2nd FMR attempt there.

It was busted before the second attempt when another group tried to have
a party there, the FMR was the first party to be held there.

> 
> People who try to throw BIG RENEGADES are in a way doing the community a 
> disservice?  Why?  Because it is just TOO DIFFICULT to consistenly hide 
> parties the size of the FMRs and the free Basics, therefore the locations 
> get busted and then watched so people who want to do smaller renegades with 
> different musical focuses have fewer and fewer available spots in which to 
> have their parties.

Why is the FMR BIG, not the fault of the promoters, it is a free party, it
has the largest flyer in the solar system, and very popular DJs, it has become 
a tradition.  You can't have it both ways, complaining about it starting late
and being hard to find is silly, the easier it is to find the larger and more
out of control the party is,  I think this lesson was learned at BD but
note that Martin was the one who pushed the luck, (although I don't believe
that the FMR should have been held there that month).  This FMR was the perfect
size for the site, people respected each other and took care of each other,
even the police that did come were cool.


> 
> Sure, the FMR is supposed to be this big community gathering vibe fiesta, but 
> it seems almost selfish to me that people throwing parties that big can come 
> in, use a spot, and then get busted and ruin the spot for the rest of us.
> 
> Laura
> 
I'm tired of people dissing stuff they know nothing about.  I'm not defending
WICKED, when they fuck-up, I tell them so. but this time, they did good.

Maybe you should come and check out the party and then judge it instead of
dissing a party that you know nothing about becaue you weren't there.

That's another part of the equation in which I feel the FMR people
were irresponsible. That site cannot be used during daylight at all,
because it is private property and people (duh) go to work in the
morning and will see the commotion there. How smart do you have to be
to figure that out? Either the FMR people are really stupid, think
they are exceptionally lucky, or were just planning to run until they
got busted. I suspect it's the latter, but I hope not because it shows
a profound disrespect for the rest of the promoters in the scene.

To my knowledge, this is the first party there that has gotten busted.
Not only that, but a heated confrontation with the landowner to boot.
Good show. What are the chances of holding something there now? What
about the homeless people that live there?

It could have been avoided.

Sean

   to run around screaming things without substantiation of any kind.  I
   consider your post irresponsible: this is confusing the situation, at a

   kernighan?) trick of embedding the trapdoor propagator into the

   discount such stories, we need to positively discredit such hypotheses.

Subject: Re: Full Moon
To: payn@chaph.usc.edu (Koenig Feurio)
Date: Wed, 25 May 1994 14:22:22 -0700 (PDT)
Cc: socal-raves@ucsd.edu, sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU,
        brians@extol.sj.unisys.com (brian sassone)
In-Reply-To: <199405251714.KAA26850@phakt.usc.edu> from "Koenig Feurio" at May 25, 94 10:14:37 am
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 2403      
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I was supposedly going to be very industrious and write a paper that isn't due
until next week last night, but when Robert posted that he had room to 
drive anyone near the Santa Monica or Westwood out to the Full Moon, I took
that as my sign to go so I phond him up, hopped in with him and Andrew, and
took off for the 100 mile trek to the desert.

At 12:30 we arrived to a sound system that was basically set up but hadn't
yet gotten going.  The first DJ opened with a song that had a lush ambient
beginning that broke into a super funky beat. Super funky. That is when
I didn't regret the drive out.

Like Dana said, I don't think I have ever seen so much energy, and natural
energy at that. It really got me going, I danced super hard for about an
hour or so and then my knees started hurting but it was hard to stop.

The site was beautiful, but then again, I have never been to the desert
before and I was just in awe of it all.  The moon looked beautiful, 
especially around 3 or so when it started to get obscured by these dark
grey diaphenous clouds...there were vast expanses of flat land which 
prompted Robert to live out his latent drag racing fantasies and send us
careening out at 95 MPH which was great until we hit that bump and then he
decided to make a hairpin turn. *Sigh*

We tried to estimate how many were there but it was such a big area it was
hard to tell...perhaps 200 people?

we took off at 5:30, and I thought I would be back in time to hit my 9
o'clock class, but we didn't get in until 9:15(!) at which point bed 
seemed like a much nicer invitation.

I think this puts the San Francisco FMRs to shame...it's perhaps what the
SF FMRs once were...I don't usually speak of vibe but it was impossible not
to have fun with these people. It was great to know that these kind of parties
are happening down here, and it was their one year anniversary to boot.

(BTW, site is *very* special - would be great to do a joint list party 
perhaps...)


Tamara Palmer                                            Women Respond To Bass

HEY! everybody; a little update on what's up for EARTHSPACE.

It's definitely going to be On the Earth, Under the Stars, aka an 
_outdoor_ event.  We have _one and a half million_ square feet of 
grassy meadows to play in, about 50,000 watts of sound and hundreds and 
hundreds of pounds of _fresh_ wax.  We'll probably get started before 
sunset on Saturday and end about noon on Sunday.

Bring sweaters, pants, extra socks, a waterproof layer, blankets, toys, 
whatever.   We'll have bonfires, a lot of water, fruit, some food, 
hopefully coffee out there.   wooHOOO!!!  _Kicking_ it into a beautiful 
summer!!

	>>Greg

The method employed in this supposed expose is similar to that used by

From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Message-Id: <9405252321.AA15080@pilot.njin.net>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: Irresponsible use of FMR site
In-Reply-To: <9405252153.AA06046@gaia.internex.net>
References: <9405252153.AA06046@gaia.internex.net>
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Geoff White writes:
 > As I said, I didn't see you there so how do you know what happened.

There goes that "you" word. If you can't attack the argument, attack
the person.  I don't appreciate Geoff putting this slant on the
argument at all.  Geoff told us himself what happened, and he told us
enough to determine that the site was not used responsibly.

 > And besides you are taking a lot of things out of context. Launch
 > Pad doesn't own that space any more than any other promoter.  as to
 > wheather people will be able to use that space, that remains to be
 > seen.

Out of the context of what? Please explain that first sentence.

I wasn't even thinking of Launch Pad specifically. I was thinking
about some of the smaller events that were held there, and that may
not ever happen again there.

 > I'm sure the oqnr will mot station 24 hour guards and I'm sure
 > others will use it.  Just because one group gets busted doesn't
 > mean that the space can't be used by another group with success, if
 > you look back over the years you will see his to be true.

Sometimes it is true, and sometimes it isn't. No one "owns" renegade
spaces. No one is claiming so. But it should be each promoter's
responsibility to make sure it isn't ruined for other promoters that
wish to use the site. Promoters should also respect those that found
the site in the first place. If the FMR finds an unused site and wants
to ruin it, fine. If they want to use a site that 6 other promoters
have used and will probably still use, and they use it with the full
knowedge that they are high-profile and likely to be busted, and that
it will probably ruin it for the rest, that's downright selfish and
antisocial.

That site cannot support more than a couple hundred people. More than
that and the police start circling. I've seen it myself.

That site is private property. Anything done there during the week is
going to attract a lot of attention.

Doing any event there past dawn is insane.

I'm sorry, Geoff, but the FMR people blew it. They shouldn't have done
the event there. Now the owner is pissed and the police have a
heightened awareness of it. If such happened during a weekend event
with 200 people, I'd say it was bad luck. But this wasn't bad luck, it
was negligence.

The FMR is a good thing, but the logistics of it have become a
nightmare. It's too big for most sites, it runs way too late for most
sites, and it's used up most of the sites. Personally, I think they
ought to look at renting some private land somewhere where they can
hold it undisturbed. I think it's getting a bit out of hand, and
the promoters need to think about it's impact upon the community.

Sean

To: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey), sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Mime-Version: 1.0
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Sean, if you're charging Geoff with personalizing this discussion as a
member of the jury I have to vote, "Not Guilty."  I've been to quite
a few gatherings at that space and the history of it is more complicated
than some people (I will NOT say "you") may realize.  For one thing,
it's quite close to a police station as I recall, and I know that *they*
generally know what's going on.  Second, I am not entirely positive but
it appears to me that not all of the site is private land.  Third, while
the FMR folks may be faulted at times, they have quite a task to handle
in siting what has become a large and at times unruly event.  The one
thing I would definitely agree with is that it's not smart to run
something like this into working hours (which might be as early a 6 or 7
am for a site like that).  On the other hand, from all accounts the
situation with the owner was handled as well as one might expect under
the circumstances.  

I would guess, given what I know about the lengthy history of the use
of the site and those around it (somewhere between 50 and 100 parties
have been held there in the last few years), that the police will be
more vigilant for larger turnouts and potential problems, but are unlikely
to completely shut it down.  It's not a break-in site, there are few
dangers (== liability concerns) and no nearby residents.

Finally, while opinions may vary on all this, I hope we don't get at each
others' throats over it.  It just ain't worth it.

what more can i say, tamara pretty much covered it all...
was an unforgettable night, period.
it would be great to throw a joint sf-socal at this location this summer!

around 4:30 or so, joachim and i walked out into this flat, dark nothingness.
it was surreal, brilliant full moon above, mountains far off in the distance,
we had walked pretty far away from the crowd but the music was still there
and amazingly clear, it seemed to come from everywhere.  as joachim said last
night, some deep trancy ambient out there would have blown everybody's mind.

let's see what else...
1. don't forget to bring water next time
2. ear plugs == no annoying, energy-sapping ringing on the drive back
3. gotta learn to dance like dana :)
4. reserve a small plane next time to avoid the traffic!

ahem, as for...

   From: trance@netcom.com (Tamara Palmer)

   grey diaphenous clouds...there were vast expanses of flat land which 
   prompted Robert to live out his latent drag racing fantasies and send us
   careening out at 95 MPH which was great until we hit that bump and then he
   decided to make a hairpin turn. *Sigh*

*sigh* what can i say, that was stupid...

otherwise...  was great *finally* getting to go out and dance with fellow
socal-ravers!

hasta,

-robert

our resident cryptologist is also our resident urban folklorologist
and he also noted the following additional clue:
------- Forwarded Message

Oh, I forgot. The Craig Steingold is a reference to Craig
Shergold, (the poster child for alt.folklore.urban) the boy
who was dying of cancer and wanted the Guinness record
for the most postcards ever received. Unfortunately,
this was 15 years ago and he was cured but eh's still
getting cards, cause the story won't die.

------- End of Forwarded Message

Bryce,

>> Why do you ask ?
>> 
>i wanted to ask to see if you were an interested or disinterested party.
>it appears that you are an interested party.  

I have already told you that I am not affiliated with any organization.
This doesn't seem to be enough, now you change the question to whether I am
an interested party or not.  The answer is still No.  

I have no special interest in Basics or any other party or group. I am not
affiliated with any party or group. I go to any and all parties. I have
friends in all groups.  If a friend in Wicked asks me to keep an eye out for
a good site for FM's, I do it, this does not mean I am affiliated with
Wicked.  If a busy friend asks me to send out a message to our colleagues on
the net, I help out by doing it.  It doesn't make me affiliated to choices
or Basics.

>the information that you are providing has different value to me if
>it is factual or promotional in origin.

The information I provided was factual in nature.  Is the sfraves calendar
promotional in nature ? Last week the calendar contained a date for a party
which has since been changed.  I thought it would be nice to let people know
as early as possible about that change.  How silly of me.  

Early and complete information distribution is a good thing.  At least
people know what the age limit for Basics is, and where it's going to be
before they drive all the way into the city, y'know ?

If you or anyone else has problems with the dj lineup, contact the dj's.  I
repeat, I have no affialiation with them or any group.  I am trying to
inform people about a change in date, with information on the dj lineup as
of last night.  If there is a date clash, work out your dj problems with the
dj's from here on, not me.  

You obviously found my posting of use, because you now know there is a
possible dj lineup clash.  I reckon you all should be happy that at least
you found out that last night, not in 2 weeks time.  Of course you are
welcome to ignore the tainted information, since you judge it promotional in
nature. 

Jeez, talk about jumping on the messenger... Some positive forum this is !
Consider me unsubbed, I have more urgent things to worry about than arguing
about the purity of information I receive.  If you have any further comment,
mail me directly.  Be forewarned, I am not a spokesman for and am not
answerable to any organization.

Later,

Pk.

As everyone basically left, I had a chance to talk with the permit
officer.  He said a permit to have a party at 24th & Illinois would cost
about $1500.  But he said there was nothing dangerous going on and people
were having a good time.  He said he didn't give a shit really.  He just
wanted some person to come forward to come claim the equipment.  He was
very fair. 


From sfraves-owner  Thu May 26 12:06:14 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA29203; Thu, 26 May 94 12:06:14 PDT
Received: from soda.berkeley.edu by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA29194; Thu, 26 May 94 12:06:05 PDT
Received: (laura@localhost) by soda.berkeley.edu (8.6.9/PHILMAIL-1.10) id MAA27795; Thu, 26 May 1994 12:06:26 -0700
Message-Id: <199405261906.MAA27795@soda.berkeley.edu>
From: laura@soda.berkeley.edu (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Thu, 26 May 1994 12:06:24 -0700
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: Sun Kim <sunkim@mercury.sfsu.edu>, SFRaves <sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU>
Subject: Re: Irresponsible use of FMR site
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Sun Kim reports:

>As everyone basically left, I had a chance to talk with the permit
>officer.  He said a permit to have a party at 24th & Illinois would cost
>about $1500.  But he said there was nothing dangerous going on and people
>were having a good time.  He said he didn't give a shit really.  He just
>wanted some person to come forward to come claim the equipment.  He was
>very fair. 

Well, this is all very well and good but groups like Your Sisters'
House and Liquid Air don't HAVE $1500 to pay for sound permits.  Bryce
and Ethan have been steadily losing money throwing parties, but they
do it because they LOVE what gets accomplished.  The time could come,
though, when the money outflow would become too great and the free
renegades would have to stop.

The whole point of doing a renegade party is to get in and out without
being noticed and have a good time and to not upset anyone and to leave
the space better than it was found.

If we have to start shelling out $1500 to hold a free party then the
number of free parties will drop.  The number of opportunities to
hear new DJs and new music will drop.  The number of opportinities for
under 21's in San Francisco to be active in the rave community will drop.

Laura

i think i have some explaining to do.  firstly i did not read ethans post
regarding friends and family.  Ethan did however ask me a long time ago
what my plans were in june, im sure you all know the response, the 11th. 
since then certin circumstances have changed so i moved to the 18th.  all i
can really say is that i forgot about ethans party.  when i plan a party i
try to avoid the bigger promoters, this is not saying in any way smaller
parties are of less importance.  when i asked markie if he would play, he
said yes.  i then spoke to ethan to see if he would do my flyer, he
reminded me of friends and family and the line up.  it now looks like
markie is only going to play at basics, if i offended anybody i am sorry. 
i hope you all have a good time at friends and family.

me.

envision getting a lot of responses.  i do not want to offend anybody by
not responding.  sometimes i read the list sometimes i do not. I take on so
much in my life that somedays i have to remember to breathe. I hope i am
making myself clear, as this is a new form of communication for me.
this may be a paronoid dillusion?

From: Derek Chung <dhchung@us.oracle.com>
Subject: The Memorial Day SF Rave Guide!
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU (SFRaves)
Date: Thu, 26 May 94 14:31:26 PDT
Cc: sfraves-calendar@techno.Stanford.EDU (SFR Calendar)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL0]
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU



Everyone ought to come out on Saturday to In The Light - it'll be 
a great chance for you all to meet and dance without losing any
sleep :).  The bandshell is between the DeYoung and the Academy
of Sciences in Golden Gate Park.  See you all there!

Tonight, Your Sisters' House seems to have lost their location, so
you may want to check out Jeno, Garth & Spun at DNA.  On Friday,
the benefit has a great lineup of underrated DJs, and SFR's Tamara
is playing at SPAZ.  After In The Light, you can check out the
Funky Tekno Tribe/Come-Unity, a combination of two of the
good big parties.  And finally, if you get Monday off, try out
Spundae, with the largest DJ lineup I've seen in a while.

Misc stuff: I checked out Soul Purpose last week and it had a decent
crowd; Marques Wyatt was OK, decent music but wasn't really mixed.
Slide 5 played - they were good, and Mark Farina finished up.  
Together is still going strong.  I got there at 12:30 and it was 
sort of slow, but around 1:30-2 it was full and Dante and Aaron O
were working the basement.  The upstairs musik was good too, dunno
who the DJ was.

Subject: Wrecked for Life

Date: Thu, 26 May 94 14:43:03 PDT
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL0]
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


Here's a blurb for a film in the SF Lesbian and Gay 
Film Festival that's somewhat rave-related.  The
festival program is out in numerous locations in SF; I 
think I got mine in the Bay Guardian or something.


Wrecked For Life: The Trip and Magic Of Trocadero Transfer

Saturday June 11, 8:15pm, $7, Roxie theater.

Gay discos were all the rage in the late 70's
and early 80's, but a special kind of magic
permeated San Francisco's legendary Trocadero
Transfer.  John Goss's Wrecked For Life interviews
several habitues and employees from the Troc's
glory days.  There's a nostalgic tinge, and a 
sense of the club's enduring spirit -- one 
fellow carries his membership card in his
wallet to this day.  The interviewees regale the
camera with tales of sex and drugs.  They also
describe the tremendous feeling of community
the Trocadero engendered.  "In those days
the community wasn't so divided," waxes 
"Disco Connie" Norman.  Goss has rounded up an
engaging ensemble for this evocative soft-shoe
through a memorable moment in SF gay history.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 o derek chung  o  oracle graphics  o  dhchung@us.oracle.com  o 415.506.6195 o
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

At  5:51 PM 5/26/94 -0400, Sean Casey wrote:

>So Markie was going to play at F&F, but since Basics moved its date
>to the same night he cancelled F&F?
>
>Sean

1. Yes, Markie had confirmed for F&F. 

2. According to Martin Markie also confirmed for Basics. 

3. Markie is out of town and has been unavailable for comment. 

4. Martin indicated to me and Markie that he did not want Markie to
   double-book that night.

5. Following a barrage of rather heated email Martin changed his mind and
   indicated to me that he wouldn't mind if Markie played both parties.

6. During the heated email I found myself wondering why I/we even bother
   with the "big" djs given the propensity for situations like the above,
   and concluded that we were better off doing our own thing. We have no
   shortage of talent and more experience will only make us better. So I
   indicated to Martin that he could have Markie.

7. If when Markie gets back and reads all this he still has a burning desire
   to play F&F I will be happy to accomodate him. It is unfortunate that he
   has not been here to speak for himself during these discussions.

8. Tony will not be playing F&F. Spun will be playing F&F if Cool World
   doesn't mind (yeah right), I'll know tonite.

9. Those are the facts.

take it easy
ethan

Looking on the bright side of things, there is going to be
a HUGE selection of fun things to do on June 18.

You want a mega-party with lots of live acts, thousands of people,
and that old carnival-out-of-control feeling, there's Cool World.

You want a more traditional gathering of the bastions of the SF
scene, there's the Basics anniversary.

You want a small indoor party with an ambient chill room and the 
"usual suspects" from sfraves, there's Friends and Family.

There's even MORE, but I don't have the calendar in front of me
to look up all the possibilities.

Once again, San Francisco is an embarassement of riches :-)  I have
a feeling that Captian Crunch will be very busy that night. :-)

"More fun than one City should be allowed to have."

Laura

From: winston@lurnix.COM (Mark Guthrie)

To: brycer@crl.com, uunet!microguild.com!pkennedy@uunet.UU.NET
Subject: Re: On the value of an informed public
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Dudes, relax.  Can we say ESCALATION.  The way flame wars start is the
same exact way real wars start.

Let's not be so defensive.  I see people not having respect for differences
of opinoin.  I see people reading things in to other peoples posts.  I
see people getting even more worked up about a post or thread then they
might even have a right to actualy be.  I see people feeling that they
have to respond harshly because someone flamed them or responded harshly
to them and they have to "defend their pride".  Keep in mind that when
someone flames you the rest of us are thinking that you were innocent and
that that person acted like a jerk.  You can respond to them privately,
flaming them back usualy only makes the rest of us temporarily loose
an ammount of respect for you.  It doesn't prove that your witty or that
you "don't take shit".  I also see people nit-picking things that 
completely went by everyone else.  And, lastly, I see people having
disagreements or flames with one or a few people and then unsubing
because "the list" (of aprox. 300 seperate individuals, mind you) is
unfriendly or doesn't have good vibe.  I honestly feel sad when someone
unsubs in a huff because it's loosing a part of our group who can
contribute positivity.  As important as emotions are, it seems more
and more to me that the more we all acted like Spok, the less problems
we'd have.  "I believe you to be in error, logic dictates that some
poor choices were made regarding the use of the Launch Pad site as
follows...."  "Shut the hell up, you mother-fuckin-emotionless-pointed-
eared-freak".

-Winston

Hello ya'll!
This is my first post on the list so I like to start off by introducing
myself. My name is Mike a.k.a. E.B.E. I run a teeny weeny visuals company out
of SJ. I've been going to raves in SF, every now and then, for about 2 years
now. You may have seen me around, I sometimes wear a neon yellow contact
lens. I'll be at the park on Saturday. So please look for me and give me a
big hug. I'll probablly have a name tag on.
  Anyway, I don't know if the topic has been addressed, but around July 19
there will be an astrological event  of massive proportions. As a matter of
fact, it will be the biggest occurrence of its kind in the history of
humankind. I'm sure you've heard about it. Jupiter will be hit by a large
group of asteroids, causing an impact stronger than the force of all of
Earth's nuclear weapons combined. Not to mention it may very well turn the
sky red! This will undoubtedly cause a MAJOR FLUX OF ENERGY here on Earth! 
         My question is WHAT KIND OF FUCKIN' PARTIES ARE GOING TO GO OFF THAT
DAY?! 
  If anyone knows of any plans for one, please tell me about it. Thanks.
  See ya at the park!

    MIKE
             a.k.a.
                      E.B.E.

>From Phred:

>$1500 for a permit for 24 & Chillinois?  Compared to how much for Golden
>Gate Park, for example . . . 

$400 to use the band shell site, plus $35 for a sound permit.

*IF* this $1500 fee for 24th and Illinois REALLY is the correct figure, I 
agree it's ludicrous.  However, if it is someone's private land (this has 
never been made clear to me) then the owner can charge whatever he or she 
wants.

But anyway, if this $1500 is some number the SFPD came up with, then think 
on it:  maybe they purposely have set the price so high so as to discourage 
raving.  In 3 years they've seen a lot of parties come and go, and it's a 
known fact that someone on the SFPD has it out for ravers (I say someone 
because I can't recall the guys' name).  I mean, if all the ravers goodwill 
and smiles were counting for something, then why did a place like 1015 Folsom 
recently need a Federal restraining order to keep the SFPD off their back?  
I can easily imagine that any incident in town where cop-meets-raver is not 
going unreported, even if it's only going unofficially back to that one guy 
who makes a point of trying to close down parties.

Laura

From: Starchild <rrose@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Has The Scene Gone Downhill?
To: KEN STUART <KEN.STUART@tigerteam.org>
cc: sfraves.techno.Stanford.EDU@uclink2.berkeley.edu
In-Reply-To: <706FF2E2@tigerteam.org>

According to Mr. Computer, on Thu, 26 May 1994, KEN STUART wrote:

> 
> Starchild writes:
> >>  If our positive energy hadn't been so
> >> diluted, the scene probably never would have gone downhill in the first
> >> place.
> 
> Hello,
> 
> I'm curious as to when you think the scene was at its "height" and when
> it first started to go downhill?
> 
> respect,
> 
>     Ken

Dear Ken,
  
   I was afraid someone was going to call me on that little statement!  I 
probably shouldn't have included it, because I'm not absolutely sure 
myself that it's true, and I knew that it might arouse controversy and 
seem unduly negative.  Since I suspect others may want to hear my 
explanation as well, I'm posting my reply to the list.
   I will say that comparing the parties I go to now with the ones I went 
to around the beginning of 1992 when I started raving and during the 
summer of that year, the ones then seem better.  But it's an intuitive 
feeling on my part, and not one I can necessarily substantiate by 
pointing to irrefutable specifics.  Different people feel differently 
about what makes a good party, after all.
   It may be that simply that it was a new thing for me than, and the initial 
thrill wore off.  But I don't really believe that.  I've heard this on many 
occasions from others (that the scene has gone downhill), although, 
encouragingly, not so much recently as I heard it last year -- so it's not 
*just* me.  I'll list a few personal observations, which may or may not be 
accurate reflections of what's going on, since I haven't been going out more 
than a couple times a month for the most part:

(1) There are less people on Exstasy.
(2) The whistles seem to have disappeared. 
(3) I don't see as many goofy Dr. Seuss-style hats or weird, wacky 
outfits as I used to. 
(4) I don't see things like virtual reality and the moonbounce at as many 
parties as I used to. 
(5) I don't meet as many really excited people as I once did. 

All these things and others were/are important parts of the rave 
experience for me.  I don't remember dates well enough to try to estimate 
when I think the downward trend began, and I suspect it was more of a 
gradual thing than something that began at a given point anyway.

But as I hinted when I spoke of our positive energy being diluted, I think 
one cause may have been the rapid influx of new people to the scene.  I'm 
not one of those people who think raves should be kept underground for 
the privileged few, but I do think they grew too fast for their own 
good.  Instead of picking up the positive vibe that was there and 
learning to shed their inhibitions and open up to friendliness and love 
as a way of being at parties, the newcomers arrived in such numbers that 
the vibe was not effectively communicated to each new raver.  Of course 
this has a net effect, as it is harder to smile and be open and friendly, 
or have the courage to wear something really bizarre, if others aren't 
doing it too.

But whether or not these observations match your own, don't think I'm giving 
up on raves or let my opinion get you down!  This scene has changed my life, 
and I'm not going to give it up that easy.  I think/hope the best may still be 
yet to come, and this summer seems to be shaping up quite nicely.

So wear a smile this summer if nothing else!  :)

Rave On,
                               *** Starchild ***





From sfraves-owner  Fri May 27 07:10:23 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA20237; Fri, 27 May 94 07:10:23 PDT
Received: from nexsys.nexsys.net by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA20191; Fri, 27 May 94 07:07:41 PDT
Received: from localhost by nexsys.nexsys.net (8.6.5/SM-8.6.4)
	id HAA00253; Fri, 27 May 1994 07:05:30 -0700
Date: Fri, 27 May 1994 07:05:30 -0700
From: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White)
Message-Id: <199405271405.HAA00253@nexsys.nexsys.net>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: If you really love someone...
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

	Sisters and Brothers,

	It's 6 am and I just read Courtney Reimer's article in XLR8R
	titled "Think:There are no rules on the dance floor" in it he
	talks about how people in the Scene are spending more time,
	energy, emotion, etc.  "Dissing" each other as oppose to
	sending love and positive energy.  I realized that he was right
	on and that we all, including myself, need to really check
	ourselves.  Can some of you remember your first party?  It's
	hard for many of us isn't it?  Most of you can remember the
	party or parties that really turned you on to the Scene, I bet
	it had a lot to do with the UNCONDITIONAL LOVE and the Vibe that
	you received from everyone around you, regardless of how "new"
	you appeared.  Do you remember how you felt, and any
	epiphanies that you had on the dance-floor?  Remember dancing
	all night long in the moonlight till dawn and seeing a blazing
	Sun illuminate each and every one of you equally in the
	morning?  It's been a long time since Connection I.  Have we
	been reduced to a pack of snotty, bickering fools arguing over
	the rights to a "space" that in reality belongs to each and
	every one of us and none of us simultaneously?  It's so funny
	to me that we can bicker about the correct use/misuse of a site
	and simultaneously totally abuse the one "space" that each of
	us have, which is our body, which is a temple in itself.  We
	now as a community must come to grips with the naked questions
	of what do we do when someone in the group does something that
	you don't like.  You can diss them and complain to others, you
	can complain DIRECTLY to the perpetrators, (that might even get
	a result) or you can live the example that you preach.  I for
	one must apologize to Laura and Sean for matching their
	negativity with my own, I realize now that that is not the way
	to "defend" any "wonderful feeling" that I might have had at
	the last Full Moon, sorta like killing for Peace.  So Laura and
	Sean and Ethan I apologize for my harsh words, I realize that I
	need to do more dancing and less analyzing.  Maybe I'm spending
	way too much time in cyberspace, so to that end I'm going to
	unsub for a while and spend more time on the dance-floor.  I'll
	still be around and it won't be hard to find me, and many of
	you know how to reach me by phone or other ways.  Remember to
	love and take care of each-other, it's sooo important, it's
	what this planet needs more than anything right now, also try
	to extend it out past your boundaries, it's easy to love
	friends & family, it's harder to love the stranger or the Cop
	or "that other posse" but if we don't learn this quick, we, the
	Scene, the human race, won't be around too much longer.  Just
	as the light of the Sun and Moon falls on each and every one of
	us on the  planet, providing life and energy, so can Love
	emanate from the Core of each and every one of us and provide
	support and nurturing for everyone.

	if we lose Love, It's all lost.


	Peace,

	    G

Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Thanks for your post, geoff.  a very thoughtful one.  i would add that
in addition to the "don't dis" philosophy, that we need to move to a 
space where we a) respect each other, and b) consider the consequences
of what we undertake.  I see lots of respect in the scene, but, frankly,
i see all too little of the "consider the consequences".  it's all very
well to love each other, but if in loving each other, and doing it on
the dance floor, we thrash someone else or thrash our sites or thrash
the neighbors, the consequences are sorely felt by at least one individual
or one site or by the entire community.  if i, as a sound person, thrash
the dancer's ears, that hurts many people.  if i, as a raver, pollute
the air in a closed space with unwanted smoke, that hurts many people.
some consciousness about the consequences of each and every one of the
actions we undertake must be in our awareness.  otherwise, people's bodies,
minds, emotions, or spirits are injured.
-- 
Bryce Ryan ------- AMBIANCE ----------- brycer@crl.com-----

....FLASHBACK...October..1993...from.the.sfraves.archives...................
 
"Every now and then, when I think that the Scene is really bad, when I 
think that it is dead, it's over, fucked.  A party will come along that 
helps me remember why we are all here and connected.  This was the party 
that did that for me this summer..."

"The vibe was strong and I really got a good groove fix."
 
"...and *so* many sfravers in attendance!  i think many of us got our views 
of the scene pleasantly refreshed.  thank you so much."
 
"Sunday in the park was major FUN stuff.  BIG Thanks to everyone
who made it go off ...   I just love losing my head w/SFravers.  :)"
 
"Well gang, the park party was fantastic.  Great to see everyone.  I think 
we need to throw another one just to thank the crew that put up this first 
one! "
 
"Then we went to the GG Park rave. It was killer!  It was just a 
fantastic time from beginning to (Alas!) end."
 
"Ditto on the kudos, boyo! That was a great party!"
 
"The other reviews were right on. It was a good vibe all day with people
dancing and hanging out and just being family.  It's truly a privilege to 
have all of you around as you spread such a good vibe and so many good
feelings. That's what it's all about :)."
 
"I hope everyone who went to the GG Park rave had as much fun as I did. 
Good dj-ing, communal sharing of stuff to eat and drink, dancing  Praises 
and applause for all the people who made it happen.  Let's do it again."
..........................................................................
 
Out from the darkness and away from our terminals, the varied talents of
SFRavers will mix and merge to send a message to the Bay Area House scene 
and to the crazy city of San Francisco: 
 
Organized by technology and motivated by the love of music & dance, 
SFRaves will present on May 28th, the Saturday of Memorial Day Weekend:
 
                        IN THE LIGHT
 
A Celebration of Positive Intent, the Respect for Diversity, 
And the Ability to Transcend our Limits in Harmony with the World with a 
Ritual of Fun:
 
                ->Get Infected by Meme -> 
                ->Trance out with Laura ->
                ->Take an Acid House Bath with Markie->
 
              Audio by SoundVision - Three Turntables

    Noon to 6PM at the Bandshell in Golden Gate Park: 415.985.5244

Message-Id: <199405271709.KAA22207@netcom.com>
X-Sender: nrg@localhost
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Fri, 27 May 1994 10:12:29 -0800
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
From: nrg@netcom.com (ethan miller)
Subject: Like a Pheonix Rising
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I'm always amazed at life's ability to turn negatives into positives. 

It was, in general a fairly rocky week for me. As I'm sure many of you
noticed, the big boulders were rollin and I for one was feelin a bit
bruised.

However I'm sitting here Friday morning feelin pretty good. Communication
is never easy. Martin and I have been friends for while, but I feel as a
result of our recent interactions we both know each other a bit better now.
While in the short term that can often be tough, utlimately it can only be
a good thing. I for one have a much clearer vision (ha, ha) now of exactly
why it is that I do what I do. I'm also overjoyed to see him actually post
something to the list. It's always been a mystery to me that he could sit
by and read so much about his parties without jumping in and saying
something. I hope we see more of him. I'll say the same of Markie too, I
hope we see more of him.  

One thing that should be apparent from recent events is that we've got a
really lively scene here and as summer blooms full strength an unfortuante
(or fortunate) consequence wil be that we're going to see dramatically
increased demand placed on sites, and *potentially* increased competition
amongst would be party throwers for attendees/participants. Obviously the
best response to this is not to lay claim to and do battle for limited
space and other resources but rather to join together, pool our resources,
our flavors, our cultures. 

So it was with no small amount of joy that I yesterday encountered the
suggestion that it might be high time for YSH, Lauch Pad, Spiral Jive, SPAZ
etc. to start gettin together on parties. Really nice to have Maui from YSH
join us on the list and I also had the pleasure of meeting Dave from Spiral
Jive last night. So I'm really optimistic about some great things coming
together.

Yet another surprise greeted me last night too. I had kind of cynically
assumed that there was no way that Cool World would be interested in Spun
playing F&F the same night as their Cow Palace Ho down, but, they proved me
wrong. Sasson doesn't seem to feel threatened by what we're doing and Spun
is psyched to play with us. So Right Fucking On I say.

take it easy
ethan

MY negativity Geoff?

I do not accept your apology becuase it was couched in those terms.

I am not a negative person.  Realistic and pragmatic yes, but negative no.  
I fully believe that my cautions, warnings and complaints are valid and 
should be taken into consideration for the good of the renegade scene, and 
should not be wiped away.

All the happy love vibes and good feelings in the world will NOT change 
the fact that the rave scene must operate in a way that will 

	(1) be fair to the participants -- both party goers
		and party organizers

	(2) be fair to the environment

	(3) not cause undue confrontation with elements
		of non-rave society.

If you really loved someone you would not be so patronizing.  

Laura

Subject: more good old days
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


Starchild wrote about old rave experiences ...
These are my comments.

I think the whole "downhill" idea is mostly about 
people having a hard time recapturing very strong
first experiences.

The following observations caught my eye.

>(1) There are less people on Exstasy.
Write to your congress-person!

>(2) The whistles seem to have disappeared. 
Although intergalactic whistle communication is
entertaining it gives alot of people headaches.

>(3) I don't see as many goofy Dr. Seuss-style hats or weird, wacky 
>outfits as I used to. 

Well, I think the "Dr Suess" hats sorta killed off the wacky outfits.
The idea (to me at least) is to create and contribute to the common
experience.  Fabulous costumes are the greatest.  Outfits are a
personal contribution to the visuals of a party.

Of course, everyone has to be comfortable themselves and there
is no down side to not wearing a costume.  No one is going
to disapprove if you don't bring fruit.

>(4) I don't see things like virtual reality and the moonbounce at as many 
>parties as I used to. 

It's not what there used to be.  
It's what we're not thinking up now.
Make it new, fresh, and clean.

>(5) I don't meet as many really excited people as I once did. 
See item number one ;)

Dave

Laura wonders:
> Since I have been publically told today on this list that I am both
> full of negativity and patronizing, I am wondering if I would truly
> be a good representative for sfraves to spin at "In the Light" 
> tomorrow.  

Better than you may realize :-)

Laura,
I think it's important to realize that we're all capable of getting on each
other's nerves from time to time.  In fact, I would say that the bringing
together of diverse perspectives *requires* that this happens.  Ultimately,
none of us can be completely right because whatever words we post or speak
will always be interpreted in a variety of ways.  I'm not so sure about how 
useful this concept of "unconditional love" is.  What *is* useful is 
realizing that we can dislike one another (which is OK), and then find a 
space (i.e. rave) where we can love and accept each other *anyway*.  I think 
we can all agree that the petty bullshit that happens over the Internet is 
nothing compared to the intense feelings we get from dancing together to 
music that moves us.

And anyway, if we all got along so well and loved each other all the time, 
not only would life be boring, but raving wouldn't be as special as it is. 

> If enough people are against my participation, then I will gladly turn 
> over my time to someone who more fully exhibits the right kind of spirit. 

Your spirit will come through loud and clear via the killer set you
are going to spin for us tomorrow.  I can assure you that no one will be 
thinking about some stupid flames on sfraves when we're all freaking out to 
the music.  P.S. Despite weather reports to the contrary, it has been sunny
and warm all afternoon in the city.  See you all tomorrow!  d:-)
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com

hi! i am an astronomy grad student and i regret
to inform y'all that there will be no parties
going on while the comet chunks are hitting
jupiter, because i will be stuck in west virginia
at that time looking at the planet with a radio
telescope.

sadly, the impact will be very unspectacular. the
comet will hit the side of jupiter that we can't
see from earth. the earth's sky will not change
color at all, but frogs and cooked pigeons are
expected to fall from the sky in some areas. (^_^)

Laura--
 
*That* (your not being one of the sfr spinners
for in the light) was *certainly* not the meaning of
wahat I now realize was an ambiguous, laconic message f
from me! I merely wanted you and all of us to examine
that one statement that I selected from your public reply
to Geoff in the light of the little quote below.
 
I have been on sfr since near the beginning and ususally sit
back and watch the flow and flames of this marvelous gift of
the communications explosion we have in sfr/e-mail ingeneral.
Since it tends to be such a "hot" medium, sometimes our actions
and reactions are as quick as they would be in face-to-face
communication, but without the other physical instrumentalities
that are there in conversation.  Result: flame wars, hurt feelings,
instant misunderstandings as well as the opposite at times:
the incredible lightness of virtually being at-one with each other!
 
Ihaven't heard your djing since the side that I haveon that
delightful Liquid Air double cassette I bought awhile back.  Your
spinning at In the Light--and Geoff's dancing/trancing there will
be part of all of our healing and health!

World's second oldest and wisest raver,
Will

Subject: Good Ol' Days (tm)
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Fri, 27 May 1994 14:45:45 -0700 (PDT)
In-Reply-To: <9405272031.AA11945@bethe.ucdavis.edu> from "David Alves" at May 27, 94 01:31:39 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL21]
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 1743      
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


My first 'rave' experience was in Cleveland (!) at, I think, the first
big event held there, put on by a local Church of the SubGenius and
maybe some other folks.  It was in this really nasty old warehouse in
the Flats, and only a few people could get in at a time because you
had to go up to the fourth floor in this really creaky old freight
elevator that would only hold about eight people.  It spread out over
two floors -- the top had been semi-renovated and had a nice looking
bar and some decor, the floor below was still all concrete and brick.
All the right things were there -- fluorescent chalk and blacklights
for drawing all over, neat crash spaces with couches and brain
machines, tables of people selling SubG, RAW, and other marginal lit,
video monitors showing psychedelia -- but the vibe was a bit strange.
As my friend sagely observed, "Everyone was just standing around
waiting for the world to end."  I didn't get The Vibe (tm) until I moved
out here and found SFR.

I was putting little cheese stickers everywhere I went, myself and
others included -- "Mellow Cheddar" and "Creamy Jack" -- and had a
blast of a time meeting people, but there wasn't quite the critical
mass of smiles that lead to 'random acts of kindness and senseless
beauty'.  I hope/bet the Cleveland scene is going off now.

So...I'm not longing for 'the good ol' days'.  For me they've been
getting better.  I still get that apocalyptic feeling whenever I go
into a normal rock/industrial club -- the feeling that everyone would
rather be watching civilization collapse in flames and riots but no
one has the guts to push it over.

// g

PS: If we make it a contest to show who's more full of Peace, Love, and
The Vibe (tm), we've missed the point.

Greetings, ravers!

My apologies to all, and to individuals for jumping down anyone's throats
in the past week.  I've realized i've just been to quick with my responses,
and too eager to prove my point.  

That said, i shall happily go lurk for a while till i recover my sense of
humor.

However, i *will* be at In The Light.  If you'd like to hear me spin (shameless
self-promotion here ;) ), please come to the bandshell in the park and help
us set up at around 10:30.  The sooner we get things unloaded and running,
the more i get to play :).  And, in any case, I hope you can all come to
SFRave's premier event--i know i'll have lots of smiles and hugs for you
all.  We do bicker, but life in extended families is never an easy thing.
-- 
Bryce Ryan ------- AMBIANCE ----------- brycer@crl.com-----

if our intention is provide aid or support ( the  sfrave community) it should
be interpreted as a positive gesture.

Is it possible for a retail entity to love?

Probably not. But Robert,gary,matt,michelle, topher, tracy, mark and 
myself love you all and are proud to be associated with ya'll on this 
here internet thingamajiggy.  Some of us seem to be using this incredible 
technology to vent on eachother.  WE are all brothers and sisters.  Lets 
work together instead of against eachother--that's what it's all about. 
Love, unity, a beautiful vibe.

At ameba yesterday there was a very strong sketch element that made us 
here all pretty  uncomfortable.  We're going to have to start enforcing 
RULES (*$##@!!**) like no pages on the phones and stuff like that.
Our Manson Print is a reminder to us that we have some bad eggs amongst
us. They are hard to deal with. We Arent. Appreciate each of us who can
communicate.  Lets do this in a positive way and HELP EACHOTHER.

that post millenial boogie-woogie will rot your brain

Okay guys, 
	This is for those of you not going to Come-Unity, tonight, since I'm sure that party's going to be kickin'.  Unfortunately, some of you may be like me, and don't have cars.  So listen up, if you're near the Stanford area.

From SF:
	101 South
	University Ave. exit in Palo Alto
	Go towards Palo Alto, NOT East Palo Alto
	Follow U. Ave, until it becomes Palm Drive
	Rt. on East Campus Dr.
	Follow it around until you hit Santa Teresa St.
	turn Rt.
	Roble Hall will be on your right.
	It's the building covered with Ivy

From SJ:
	101 North
	University Ave. exit in Palo Alto
	Same as above

And btw, no more gripes from people at Stanford about this thing
Be discrete.
Remember, this is at a university, and the campus police here are real s.o.b.'s
Take care, and hope to see you there
It should last all night, and I assume less checking of Stanford IDs will be done as the night progresses

I'm glad that people had fun today.  A big hand goes out to Lee for
doing what needed to be done administrivially and financially to
get this party off the ground.  A big hand goes out to Bryce for
getting the sound system "just so."  (Bryce, pick a night this week 
and I'll come over and help you clean all the dust and grit out of 
your gear.)

Hands also go out to SFRavers I saw helping haul gear, set up,
move chairs, pick up trash, break down, and otherwise deal with
the before-and-after of a party.  Every little bit of effort and
labor made the task of cleaning up afterward bearable.

Will and Phil say they're glad they stayed the extra day and a half
(they're on a plane now, heading back to NYC :-( ).

Big hugs go to the bunch that drove up from LA:  Bryan, Tamara,
Chris, Greg, and Jennifer. 

See you all around . . . hopefully at least some of you at Friends
and Family on the 18th.  I'll even buy some new records :-) (but
not any softer or slower -- sorry whoever it was that asked of me
"is she ever going to play any house?", but the answer is "possibly
someday but probably not.") :-) :-) ;-) (I mean really, would you 
ask Markie "are you ever going to play any techno?"  No, I didn't 
think so.) :-) :-) ;-)

Laura

From: larryc@netcom.com (Larry Ching)

Subject: Re:  In The Light...
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU

In The Light:

 Let me lead off with a big THANK YOU ! to Lee Fogel for getting the
site reservations and everything else . Thanks too to Bryce for the
sound system , and anyone else for the technical setup. And , of course
, thanks to the DJs - Bryce again , Laura , and Markie.

General Impressions:

 Music started around 11:25. Most of the "crowd" were SFRavers , only
20 persons at this time. Crowd didn't start picking up until 3:15PM.
By 4:30PM we had a good sized crowd of about 150 - 200 dancers, kicking
up a lotta dust ( someone in the crowd was wearing a dust mask , and
was nice enough to give me one of his spare ones - I'll have to remember
to bring one for the next time! ). Markie was on from about 3:45PM ,
and spun until the park rangers shut it down at 6:18PM. Almost seven hours
of great dance music!

 I wish it had been more overcast - thanks a lot to the person who brought
the public bottle of sunblocker! 

 Given the political bent of the leaflets on the table , I wonder if folks
will think SFR is a group of partying Libertarians? ( I should've gotten
some Republican Party leaflets to put on the table - that would screw
people's heads up! ).

 As usual for a Golden Gate Park bandshell event , we got a lot of passer
by onlookers , and even some joiners, which is always encouraging to me.
Parking was a hassle, due to the amount of folks attending the park on this
holiday weekend , and a nearby museum exhibit was on display for its
last weekend ( Dead Sea scrolls ).

 No uniformed police presence until the end , when the rangers came over
to call time on us. Once they saw us dismantling the setup they left. 

 I saw so many SFRavers together that I haven't seen in a month or more -
almost like a class reunion! It was great and good to see you all again,
and hope to see you folks again for many more!
 
Leatherman:

 Arriving at about 12:15 was a guy dressed in a motely costume of leather
patches and metal plates - kind of a medieval/road warrior look. He was
pushing a shopping cart loaded with metal parts , shards of mirrors , and
other stuff. He had a big hat made of leather patches. His face was coated
with an olive green substance. During the day , he painted his face with
increasingly elaborate designs.

 He endeared himself to us (not) immediatley by shouting out that the
cops were going to be here in ten minutes to shut us down , "seriously!".
( No cops showed up ). He spent the rest of the afternoon declaiming his
views on us and life and the universe to anyone who would or wouldn't
listen to him. Kinda scary and annoying at first , then just mostly
annoying. He also did some "performance" stuff , and made a little altar on
the ground . Some of his rap seemed amusing enough to some folks - and he
finally found someone at the end of the afternoon to actually have a
conversation with. So , I guess the day ended well for him too. 

Which One Was Larry?:

 I was the guy in the grey pants and the yellow sun/blue moon tshirt. Also
had a goatee beard that's going to get shaved off by the end of this week
( upkeep is a hassle , and it tickles my wife's nose ...). You may have
noticed me neurotically trying to keep the left-hand hot air balloon under
control for most of the afternoon.

Security Mode:

 I notice that when I'm at an SFR related event , I can get into a kind of 
a watchful "security" mode. I try to watch out for things that don't look
right - for example , one of Mike's friends was trying to find the candy 
next to the stage-left speakers , and was looking in the milk crates that 
had the spare electrical stuff in it. I'm afraid that I started to politely
hassle him about what he was looking for. ( he did find the candy ).

 I also try to keep a lookout for fights or folks who look like they had
one hit over the line - although what I would do if a fight actually
broke out is uncertain to myself. I guess I feel this way because it's an
SFR event , and therefore in a way "my" event , and I should do what I can
to make sure that nothing screws up. ( sure does disrupt the "carefree"
part of my dancing , tho' ...).

Summary:

 It was GREAT ,I liked it , and if you weren't there , you shoulda been!


	Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com
extension cables.

To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU

URGH!@#@ After 1 1/2 hours of standing in the cold in a snaking line, we 
were told (by word of mouth) that many people had counterfeited tickets, the 
warehouse had filled up and the whole lot of us (who had legit $10 
tickets) would NOT be able to come in. A police car was sent to disperse us - One idiot 
started throwing bottles at the police car, the officer threatened to 
bring backups with clubs.

Most upsetting was the event went on without us (at a cool looking 
warehouse at Pier 70, near 3rd and 20th). While I sure everyone who didn't get in would like 
their money back, I think most of us would pay MORE money to see a 
make-up show (perhaps unlikely if machines get destroyed). I heard the 
last SRL show in San Francisco was 3 years ago.

I'm sure much wrath will be directed towards WIRED (a sponsor), because 
they are an easy target. The event is promoted in the current issue. In 
the future perhaps WIRED could help them design better tickets. The 
tickets we bought at Naked Eye were incrediblely inept. What looks like 
dot-matrix black output xeroxed on white card stock, UNNUMBERED, with an 
easily duplicated generic notary embossing.

Very disappointed I couldn't see what sounded like (from outside) 
an amazing show (lots of noisemaking sirens and explosions).

Jonathan

In the Light in Sight

        Gregg & I got to the park when Markie was spinning...we just
barely missed Laura's set, which bummed us out, because, believe it or
not...I HAVE NEVER HEARD HER SPIN!!... next time I'm gonna plan things
better!  

        As Alpha10 has already commented:  Markie was a dog.  He was
ruff.  (sorry...)

        Once he got going, there were probably over a hundred people
down in front and up behind him and on the bandshell, too, doing the
house boogey strut and wiggle.  Wow!  Was it my imagination?  Every time
he broke a new beat the crowd would stomp up a little extra dust.  

        My friend H. who arrived too late to hear the music told me:
Everyone looks so beautiful!  I mean, EVERYONE was RADIANT!  There were
lots of the people there that go to some of the same parties as me, but
you know, it's always so dark and it's hard to see people.  Was it the
weather that put people in such a fabulous mood? The day was perfect.
The sun (a much bigger flyer than that other thing, y'know) was shining
brightly but the air was light and cool; just the kind of day beloved SF alone
can produce.  In the Light was the perfect name...the name shaped the event,
it shaped the vibe, it cast some kind of magic spell on everyone there.
  
        *sigh*  I'm gonna remember those couple of hours a long time! 
It was good to meet you all (again) and say hi.  Maybe I'll see you at
Spundae tonite!  

-anthrax

Here's my set list from "In the Light."  Some of you may notice that 
I played a lot of pretty old records.  I have some long-standing 
favorites that I thought deserved to see the light of day in San 
FranDisco.  I endeavor not to bore you all, and so have since
retired several of these -- new sounds for Friends and Family!

"Gravitational Arch of 10" - Vapourspace [Plus 8, Canada]
"Surveyor-4" - Equinox [Vortex, USA]
"Nuclear Sun" - Nightvision (Damon Wild) [EXperimental, USA]
"Off-Axis Gravitational Fields" - Underground Resistance [UR, USA]
"Fantasies of the Mind" - Alici [See Saw, Belgium]
"Opus(Velvet)" - Beyond [ESP, Belgium]
"Tone Exploitation" - The Nighttripper [ESP, Belgium]
"Acid Moon" - Juno Reactor [NovaMute, UK]
"Trancition" - Choci and The Freedom of Sound [Aura, UK]
"Into the Nature" - Hardfloor [Harthouse, UK]
"Guijada" - Subliminal [Trans'pact, France]
"Harlequin" - Avalon [IND, USA]
"Confuss" - Hardfloor [Harthouse, Germany]
"Afghan Acid" - The Rising Sons [EXperimental, USA]
"Alice" - Sub-Stance [Now! Records, Germany]
"Second Earth" - Quark [Mucho Vinyl, UK]
"The Cutting Edge" - Dome Patrol [XL, UK]

I've seen some of this on CD, so if you liked it please support the 
musicians and bring it home.  Vapourspace has CDs out, as does Hardfloor 
(_TB Recsucitation_ on Moonshine/Harthouse).  I've seen "Tone Exploitation" 
on _The Best of Techno Volume Three_, and there is an ESP Records compilation 
out on Instinct I believe.  "Acid Moon" is on a full-length Juno Reactor 
CD called _Transmissions_.  "The Cutting Edge" is on volume two of a 
compilation from EXperimental Records.  I've seen these CDs at many
Bay Area stores, including Rasputnin's and Amoeba in Berkeley, and
Tower and Streetlight in San Francisco.

I know I sound like a commercial, but the fact is that the DJs often get 
a lot more credit than the artists do, and that's not right in my book.

Laura "I'd never put tape over my record labels, but please don't
ask to look through my crate while I'm in the middle of a set (yes,
it happened at the park yesterday)" La Gassa :-) :-)

From: deaks@netcom.com (Ernie Deakyne)
Message-Id: <199405300355.UAA02708@netcom14.netcom.com>
Subject: Trek up to tha Tekno Tribe!
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Sun, 29 May 1994 20:55:44 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

   I was quite bummed that I couldnt make it to In-The-Light this 
weekend.  The main reason was simple exhaustion (I went to Disneyland for 
Grad Night on Thursday.) 

   But by 6pm I was fully rejuvinated and ready for a good party.  I 
called the Funky Tekno/Come-Unity hotline and listened to Kevin preach 
about how great the party will be.  So I started calling friends and 
within two hours we were on our way up to Santa Cruz (from Monterey) to 
pick up some more friends.

   We arrived around 11pm and even though I brought about a dozen canned 
goods, we still had to pay $20. This was rather dissapointing since it 
was $10 before 10pm and I didn't think they would jack the price up that 
much.  But at least the security guys were REAL cool.  They didn't hassle 
us about anything, were polite and even chatted a bit.  I was truly 
amazed since most of the $15+ BIG parties I've been too have had total 
jerks for security.

   The inside was very nice and spacious and the sound was perfect.  The 
usual black light posters were in effect and they had a big tribal mask 
above the DJ which had lights coming out of its eyes.  The vibe was real 
good for a big event, people were friendly and I saw a lot of smiles.

   The chill space was nice, although I would of liked an ambient room 
but I guess the site didnt have room.  By the time we left the room was 
filled with a thick fog only matched by the fog we ran into on the way 
home.

   Unfortunatley, we couldn't survive the whole thing because we were all 
still burnt out from Disneyland. So we took off around 3:30 (which bummed 
me out cause I wanted to see Garth spin.. sigh..) the drive home was no 
problem, even though the CHP was out in FORCE! Crashed around 5:30 and 
allready began thinking about next weekend :)

NOTE: To all those people who sent me requests for one of my tapes, sorry 
I've been so slow, I've had finals and lots of other annoying work to do 
but I should have them all sent out by June 10th (thats when I leave for 
England). And when I get back from England, if you liked my first tape, 
I'll send you an all import tape :)... and speaking of..

 Does anyone know of ANY record pools in England??? Or Belgium??

  Peace out!

  "Hot and Crusty in minutes!" (Bread du Jour advertisement)

Subject: Re: Irresponsible use of FMR site

On May 25,  1:04pm, you proclaimed:
} > FMR held at Palo Alto Wetlands - Brian says there is now a ranger stationed
} > 	down there to make sure ravers never return.
} 
} This is an urban folk legend. I went by there yesterday and ther is no ranger
} stationed.

Not urban legend... according to other people who have tried to have
parties down there, cops do patrol the area regularly at night.  Also,
there is a "ranger's residence" that was being renovated when the FMR
took place down there, which may be completed and inhabited now.

} > Many parties, including many FMRS, held at Berkeley Marina -- cop cars now 
} > 	sit there on full moon nights to prevent parties from being thrown.
} 
} Not just the FMR but _countless_ other parties were thrown there as well.

True, but none drew as large a crowd as the FMRs, nor as regularly.

} > FMR (and others) at Bonny Doon - Santa Cruz police and local neighbors have
} > 	had enough so it's not safe to try a party there anymore.
} 
} 3000 people and 2000 cars were just too much for the county.  No one wants 
} the FMRs to be big, the news of the location spreads like wild fire, 
} WICKED released the info at 3.am. by 3;30 every one who stuck it out
} knew.  Starting this late and being secretive wa the only way to keep the 
} numbers and the people who don't give a fuck away, the result was a very nicely
} sized FMR without incident.

The point remaining that it got overused.  Additionally, Wicked should have
had the personal responsibility to realize that overpopularization of that
site would lead to not being able to use it anymore - it might be fine one
night, but it won't be usable again by anyone else.  

I wonder how they found unique sites before I was doing site-hunting for
them, because they haven't found any unique sites since....

Oh well, it's not like there's a lack of smallish spaces around the
bay area.  Lots of sites that when I went site hunting I dismissed as
not being large enough for 1500 people but that could probably hold 
a few hundred just fine.  Hmmm...

	Brian

Thanks to everyone on the list who helped make In The Light the raging
success and fun party that it was.  Although I ended up with a rash and
a nasty sun-burn on the back of my neck (i'm such a red neck ;) ), it was
fun to help lay the foundation for a party that so many people enjoyed.
It was nice to see so many familiar faces, and even nicer to see so many
new faces at the SFR event of the season.  Almost everything went smoothly,
a fact that we SFRavers can take great pride in.  Congratulations on a
party well done!

On a less nice note, because of all the dancers kicking up dust, ethan's
mixer, and his and my decks and the amp rack took a real beating from the
dust.  As a consequence, the sliders on the mixer and on the 1200's have
a really gritty feel.  His equipment is going to have to get serviced by
a qualified person to restore it to tip-top operating condition.  If we
could all help defray that cost, it would surely help him out, and help
keep the equipment we have used for so many parties in good shape for
the many parties we'd like to enjoy.  His email is nrg@netcom.com. 
thanks in advance for your generosity.
-- 
Bryce Ryan ------- AMBIANCE ----------- brycer@crl.com-----

Subject: My trip to geneva, and 8 forwards...
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


Hi all!  I'm back from Geneva now, and REALLY bummed that I missed In
The Light, but I am glad that it went off so well.  I followed and
contributed here and there to the other threads, and if anyone has sent
me mail yet hasn't heard back from me yet just be patient, I had about
1200 pieces of email to sort through despite having had occasional net
access from CERN. 

Anyways, my trip went great, better than I had thought it would be - 
there is a LOT of very cool stuff brewing on the horizon in the World
Wide Web that will make the interesting stuff we do today look like
the auto industry in the 1950's :)  I didn't get much of a chance to
check out "the scene" in Geneva, as I'm not convinced there is much of
any (I did see a DJ shop, but no fliers for local parties) though
there were quite a few young people with Sjobek shirts and the like...
I was considering shifting things around so I was in London Friday
and Saturday night but that didn't work out.  

And now for the weekly forwards.  They are arranged somewhat in 
editorial order...

        Brian

>From jsl@netcom.com  Mon May 30 07:55:54 1994
Date: Mon, 30 May 1994 07:56:31 -0700
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Subject: Into The Light

(Although I am no longer on the list, I thought that Lee deserved my public
props so, I am posting this, "blindly").

Thanks Lee for a good outdoor event!  The weather was great, the music was
good and there were alot of nice people there.  Nice One!

Lee's stress level rose a bit during the "Adventures of Markie" episode,
but other than that, he was a gracious host.  I saw him talking to many
people, making sure that things were in order, and that people were well
taken care of.  And by the mood of tyhe participants, he was doing an
excellent job.  The soundvision soundsystem was in its usual outstanding
form.  I got to talk to many who I had only seen as ascii, and that was a
treat as well.

Alot of people took the time out of busy weekend schedules to make the
party, and everyone was definitely in a mood to talk & dance a bit.  Once
again, good mood, good party.

Very Minor Gripe:
The are chosen had no grass, and was dusty.  I don't mind a dusty
warehouse, but I figure an outdoor event, if held, should have very little
dust.  Just vbecause you're outdoors does not stop soot from gathering in
your lungs (esp. when people start hoofing).  I would've preferred one of
the many meadows, surrounded by trees.  But this was only a minor problem
so....

Another Problem:
I have cited this before, and to me it is up to the promoters and his
closest pals to ensure this does not happen, but I found the crowd
racially/sexually homogenous.  There is really little excuse for it these
days.  Suffice it to say it was noticeable, and it should be corrected.


Nice One Lee, I look forward to your next event!,
John
