>From gilchris@indigo.ucdavis.edu  Mon May 23 00:26:45 1994
Date: Mon, 23 May 1994 00:01:49 -0700 (PDT)
From: "M. Lane Gilchrist" <gilchris@indigo.ucdavis.edu>
Subject: Escape velocity exceeded!
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU

Hayheyhay!
    It began on a dark and ominous nite as we crept undetected into the
wrecthedly beautiful bowels of stank industrial decay. Using our beat
detection sensors we picked up the faint emanation of energy. As we
directed our movement with our aural dowsing apparati it grew to a feeling
inside that we were in for a night of the SH*T!! Rounding the corner it 
seemed that a really crazy lookin' band of beings had laid down a asphalt
tarmac and we summoning something in for a landing, or no wait, maybe a
BLASTOFF! It was clear at that moment, with luv-phasers cocked and ready
that we were headed for a vibefest! OH the SOUNDS! What a beeeutiful nite
for a nifty little celebration to punctuate our little mundane existence. 
    I found myself continually drawn to the SOUNDVISION sweet spot of maximum
spectral overlap usually to be in the vicinity of a couple of guys (Bryce
& Ethan, of course!) that wavered between smiling big and doting over the
details of tuning the baddest mobile sound system I have ever had the
pleasure of hearing. I would continously find myself on the outskirts,
having a complete social BALL when BOOM - a track and DJ would begin their
emanation and I would then feel the most important thing for me to do at that
moment was to return and station my antennae for maximum absorption of the
mobile wall o' sound.
   As we arrived Will E was at the controls, as we started to get into da
groove it was damn nice to hear 4-5 tracks in his set that were fresh to my
ears and waaaay cool, the man has good form - especially how he brought things
down by gradually bringing the RPMS down to zero, strething out those
 bass notes w/ finger control, bringing us down for a safe landing down on
our LAUNCHPAD. But before that we heard some
grreat stuff from Ethan - it was really high NRG and really fun when he played
some fabulous track that we all seemed to know and love - during the break
in this song we knew that a viciously beautiful rhythymic crecendo was
inevitable and the dancers started to boil over with euphoria, howling like
primitive tribespeople. It was then that Ethan looked up at us and knew that
our minds were putty in his hands, giving us the beaming smile of approval and
knowing full well that the psychic vibe level of emanation was going to exceed
all known metering devices as the withering barage of the crecendo exploded
from the stacks, what a moment! I really don't think that any form of human
entertainment is as satisfying as what we are involved in in this scene,
WE ARE SOOO LUCKY! I'm giddy with the afterglow of this happenin'! :)
    This setting made for some killer socializin', it was great hanging out
with the various characters in attendence - Annthrax, Glen, Robert, Will E and
Phil from NYC (nice to hear about what's up on the right coast!), Sean
(and his cool collection of visuals), Neils, Jackie and Bob among others.
Mucho thanks to Bryce and Ethan for their superhuman equipment lugging and
general make things happen-ness. I hope you guys know that your efforts are
having a large positive energy amplification and reverberation effect!  
   
warmest personal regards,

Lane (and the rest of our Davis sub-posse :) )

>From robcamp@seas.gwu.edu  Sun May 29 12:38:52 1994
Subject: Puma and the rave community
To: dcraves@american.edu, ne-raves@umdd.umd.edu, sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Sun, 29 May 1994 15:37:37 -0400 (EDT)

This weekend's Financial Times reported Puma's quarterly earnings.
After poor performances in recent years, Puma is reporting a profit.
Part of this is due to restructuring.   However, it's 30 yr old CEO said
it's Puma Classics shoe first made in the 70's has been relaunched and
is selling especially well in the US.

It made me think about the economic power that the rave community has,
and maybe influence corportate policy.  We talk about giving back to the
community.  Puma has profited from the rave community, and I think it's
time they should give back.  It is my perception that Puma is the first
multinational company to profit from the rave community.

- Rob

>From SCRUTON@delphi.com  Wed May 25 23:00:30 1994
Date: Thu, 26 May 1994 00:02:21 -0400 (EDT)
From: SCRUTON@delphi.com
Subject: more nasty conspiracies from those pesky Bilderberg(erieans)...
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU

Subject: Forwarding: History of C++ & Smalltalk (casual reading)


Creators Admit UNIX, C Hoax
---------------------------

In an announcement that has stunned the computer industry, Ken Thompson,
Dennis Ritchie and Brian Kernighan admitted that the Unix operating system
and C programming language created by them is an elaborate prank kept
alive for over 20 years. Speaking at the recent UnixWorld Software Development
Forum, Thompson revealed the following:

"In 1969, AT&T had just terminated their work with the GE/Honeywell/AT&T
Multics project. Brian and I had started work with an early release of
Pascal from Professor Niklaus Wirth's ETH labs in Switzerland and we
were impressed with its elegant simplicity and power. Dennis had just finished
reading 'Bored of the Rings', a National Lampoon parody of the Tolkien's
'Lord of the Rings' trilogy. As a lark, we decided to do parodies of the
Multics environment and Pascal. Dennis and I were responsible for the
operating environment. We looked at Multics and designed the new OS to be
as complex and cryptic as possible to maximize casual users' frustration
levels, calling it Unix as a parody of Multics, as well as other more
risqu allusions.  We sold the terse command language to novitiates by
telling them that it saved them typing.

Then Dennis and Brian worked on a warped version of Pascal, called 'A'.
'A' looked a lot like Pascal, but elevated the notion of the direct
memory address (which Wirth had banished) to the central concept of the
language.  This was Dennis's contribution, and he in fact coined the term
"pointer" as an innocuous sounding name for a truly malevolent construct.
Brian must be credited with the idea of having absolutely no standard I/O
specification:  this ensured that at least 50% of the typical commercial
program would have to be re-coded when changing hardware platforms.
Brian was also responsible for pitching this lack of I/O as a feature: it
allowed us to describe the language as "truly portable".

When we found others were actually creating real programs with A, we
removed compulsory type-checking on function arguments. Later, we added a
notion we called "casting": this allowed the programmer to treat an
integer as though it were a 50kb user-defined structure.  When we found
that some programmer were simply not using pointers, we eliminated the
ability to pass structures to functions, enforcing their use in even the
simplest applications.  We sold this, and many other features, as
enhancements to the efficiency of the language. In this way, our prank
evolved into B, BCPL, and finally C.

We stopped when we got a clean compile on the following syntax:
for(;P("\n"),R-;P("|"))for(e=C;e-;P("_"+(*u++/8)%2))P("| "+(*u/4)%2);

At one time, we joked about selling this to the Soviets to set their
computer science progress back 20 or more years.

Unfortunately, AT&T and other US corporations actually began using Unix
and C.  We decided we'd better keep mum, assuming it was just a passing
phase.

In fact, it's taken US companies over 20 years to develop enough
expertise to generate useful applications using this 1960's technological
parody. We are impressed with the tenacity of the general Unix and C
programmer. In fact, Brian, Dennis and I have never ourselves attempted
to write a commercial application in this environment.

We feel really guilty about the chaos, confusion and truly awesome
programming projects that have resulted from our silly prank so long
ago."

Dennis Ritchie said:  "What really tore it (just when AIDA was catching
on), was that Bjarne Stroustrup caught onto our joke. He extended it to
further parody Smalltalk.  Like us, he was caught by surprise when nobody
laughed.  So he added multiple inheritance, virtual base classes, and
later ... templates.  All to no avail.  So we now have compilers that can
compile 100,000 lines per second, but need to process header files for 25
minutes before they get to the meat of "Hello, World".

Major Unix and C vendors and customers, including AT&T, Microsoft,
Hewlett-Packard, GTE, NCR, and DEC have refused comment at this time.

Borland International, a leading vendor of object-oriented tools,
including the popular Turbo Pascal and Borland C++, stated they had
suspected this for a couple of years.  In fact, the notoriously late
Quattro Pro for Windows was originally written in C++.  Philippe Kahn
said: "After two and a half years programming, and massive programmer
burn-outs, we re-coded the whole thing in Turbo Pascal in three months. 
 I think it's fair to say that Turbo Pascal saved our bacon".  Another Borland
spokesman said that they would continue to enhance their Pascal 
products and halt further efforts to develop C/C++.

Professor Wirth of the ETH institute and father of the Pascal, Modula 2
and Oberon structured languages, cryptically said "P.T. Barnum was
right." He had no further comments.

----------------------------------------------------------------------

>From cascone@well.sf.ca.us Mon May 23 00:44:22 1994

As I thought, a part of 24th & Illinois *is* a city park (I think it's
called Cold Water Harbor Park or something like that).  It is *not*
very big and isn't really marked, but there is this tiny little green
patch and the name on every Muni bus map in the city!

Date: Mon, 30 May 1994 15:37:56 -0700
From: Fred Heutte <phred@well.sf.ca.us>
Message-Id: <199405302237.PAA11599@well.sf.ca.us>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: In The Light &c.
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I realized I hadn't posted anything about Launch Pad so here's just another
in the series of thanks to Ethan and Bryce and the DJs, it was really a
good time in spite of being a little chilly.  I'm sorry I didn't get to
hear Lee as I always enjoy his work.  But I did have a chance to talk with
Buck who says he's spending a *lot* of time in the studio these days
(good news, as that means he can build on the potential he showed on the
'New Frontier' release last year).  In case you didn't notice, he was
using some of that stuff -- on reel-to-reel! -- mixed in with the usual
vinyl.  First time I've ever seen *that* done!  Randy notes that Buck
commented on how difficult it is to mix in with reels :)  (I guess it's
because of slight mechanical variations in tape speed.)

On Friday night I went to SPAZ and saw Tamara struggle valiantly with
balky turntables and win over a good crowd.  Some very nice energy there,
especially early on.  I like the SPAZ crowd and thought they were more
music-responsive than most I've seen lately.  The old bar at 60 Sixth
is in a pretty down-and-out part of town but it's a nice place.  Looks
like SPAZ is pretty well organized and gets my recommendation.

I helped a very little bit to get In The Light set up and then had the
most enjoyable time (except for our friend the Leatherman, who pushed
the concepts of Haight St. craziness to their limit, but not one inch
further).  But even he mellowed out :-)

Another fine set by Bryce, and I was glad to hear Laura again since for
some reason this was just the second since Sunshine at AU last year (ancient
history now!).  And Markie . . . well, Buck played Sasha's 'Talk To Me'
remix, and I've remarked on the Well about how it's 'the DJ's friend', but
Markie did an extended essay on the 'Talk To Me' riff that was just sublime.
I was also pleased to hear the 'Feeling Good (Dub)' mix which is a favorite
of mine right now (and the only thing I played both days at Ameba last
weekend), and something that had that 'Bird in the Bush' sound near the end,
but was something else.  Anyway, the details scarcely matter here; it was
an excellent set that built really nicely from the foundation Bryce and
Laura had laid.  I saw lots of people wandering around the grounds sort of
slide up toward the benches and take a seat and just sort of hang around
for a long time and watch this whole phenomenon.  The sun rose in the sky
(none of the rain tentatively forecast in Friday's papers, that's for sure),
we hung out under the trees or did the raver toyi toyi out in the sun,
and everyone sure seemed to be having a nice time.  A little dusty, but
oh well!  I had to slip away around 6 to catch my flight to Seattle, but
on the way out I saw one of the park police cars parked up on the driveway,
the guy was just sitting there with his shades on, sort of smiling
bemusedly :)

phred

Subject: IN*THE*LIGHT
Cc: sfraves-planners@techno.Stanford.EDU
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


Thanx to everyone who participated In The Light on Saturday.  So
many people came together for this in so many ways.  The fundamentals 
were certainly in place for this one; the site, weather, great DJing
and sound system.  But what I feel really set this party apart was 
the community spirit: the table full of food & stuff, the way so many 
people helped set up, cleanup and watch over things, the continuous 
outpouring of positive energy the whole day.  We left the bandshell area 
*much* cleaner than we found it.  Sorry about the dust; we did try watering 
the ground but the Sun insisted on having it's way.  I thought the turnout
was great; I estimate that we had more than 300 over the course of the day.  

One thought that struck me during the height of the party was just how 
"right" it all seemed - there was a real sense of harmony - the general 
public seemed to enjoy what we were doing and  it seemed so natural and 
(excuse the term) "normal" to be doing it, a celebration ritual whose only 
motive is to bring out and share in the goodness that connects us all to 
each other.  

Although In The Light was put on by our community for the community,
there are two very special people that I have to single out: Bryce - who
is a goddam saint in addition to being a damn fine DJ, and my wife Janie, 
the person who more than anything makes my life worth living and was with
me on this (as always) every step of the way. 

Love to all of you *** d:-]
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com
____________________________________________________________________________

hi! i am an astronomy grad student and i regret
to inform y'all that there will be no parties
going on while the comet chunks are hitting
jupiter, because i will be stuck in west virginia
at that time looking at the planet with a radio
telescope.
-----------------------------------------------------
No parties for you, that is.


sadly, the impact will be very unspectacular. the
comet will hit the side of jupiter that we can't
see from earth. the earth's sky will not change
color at all, but frogs and cooked pigeons are
expected to fall from the sky in some areas. (^_^)
-------------------------------------------------------

But the atmospherical turbulence might be kinda cool looking.

-Winston
